HEADLINE: Living Rent-Free, in Return for Restoration

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
FOR YEARS, Stephen Wecker wanted to own a historic home that he could operate as a country inn. He and his wife, Patti, traveled all over the country looking at places until he finally realized that they couldn't afford to both buy and maintain such a property.
Similarly, Agnes Bartlett had always planned to live out her retirement years in an 18th-century house. She and her husband, Lawrence, looked at several but couldn't find a suitable one for sale. 
 Both couples eventually realized their goals through Maryland's resident-curatorship program, under which they could live in state-owned houses -- paying no rent, mortgage or property taxes -- in return for restoring the property. The program requires potential residents to submit a detailed five-year plan to the state before moving in.
"This is no free lunch," said Ross M. Kimmel, the program's initiator and now supervisor of Cultural Resource Management for Maryland's Department of Natural Resources. "We have to approve their plan and we want to see regular progress reports."
Typically, curators spend about $100,000 over a period of years to restore a property, Mr. Kimmel said. They are required to sign an agreement with the state relinquishing all claims upon the property upon the termination of the curator relationship. Even appliances that may have been bought by the curator revert to the state.
But the program has appealed to people with skills -- or friends with skills -- who want to live in exceptional houses they would otherwise never be able to afford.
The Weckers and their four children, for example, now live in a 3,000-square-foot house in Howard County on a 16-acre property that also includes an 18th-century inn, a 2,000-square-foot house and two buildings thought to have been slave quarters. While the Weckers are restoring the larger house, Mr. Wecker's brother, Dan, is restoring the smaller one and all of them are restoring the inn and the slave quarters.
"Sometimes we look around and we can't believe we live here," Mrs. Wecker said. "Before this, we were going to buy a $250,000 house and split the upstairs with our in-laws."
The curatorship program is designed to make use of the state's considerable supply of historic properties. In the 1960's and '70's, Maryland used open-space funds to buy a vast amount of land. With over 330,000 acres, Maryland is now the state's largest landowner.
Along with the land came buildings, about 1,200 in all, a third of which have been deemed by the state's Maryland Historical Trust to have historic significance.
MOST of these buildings are not available for curatorships. They are either being used by the state or have fallen into the category of ruins. A small percentage of the historic structures, while too deteriorated to be useful to the state, are still of sufficient historic merit to warrant preservation. In 1980 it was estimated that $13 million would be needed to take care of them, he said, but nothing like that was available.
The solution came about through a bit of serendipity.
The Bartletts were in Baltimore County with a realtor one day looking for 18th-century houses when they spotted a two-story stone farmhouse built in 1770. Upon investigation, they found out that the house and surrounding farm were part of Gunpowder State Park.
"When we found out the state wouldn't sell it to us," Mr. Bartlett said, "we said, 'Let us restore it,' and they agreed."
That was in 1982. Now there are 20 such curatorships scattered throughout the state. From time to time the state holds an open house at a restorable home and the names of people who express interest in a curatorship go into a computerized file. When a property goes into the program, notices go out to those in the file.
It usually takes curators several years to get the houses into habitable condition. When the Bartletts first saw their dream house, the walls were warped, the roof leaked and termites had already damaged the structure.
"If we hadn't gotten hold of it when we did, it would be rubble by now," Mr. Bartlett said.
The Bartletts estimate they spent four years and around $200,000 restoring the house, about $50,000 more than their original estimate.
That's fairly typical, according to Mr. Kimmel, who said, "The curators always wind up laying out one quarter to one third more than they initially thought,"
Any restoration expenses can be written off as charitable deductions to the state. Nontheless, some people had to drop out of the program because they were losing too much money. One couple left after having spent about $8,000 because by then they realized that restoration would be beyond their capacity.
From the state's prespective, the program is pure profit.
"We've estimated that we already received about $1.5 million in free restoration work," Mr. Kimmel said. "And that's just out-of-pocket expenses. That doesn't include the labor."
At first glance, the program also sounds like a great deal for the curators. But out of every 100 people who inquire about it, Mr. Kimmel estimates, only two or three follow up.
"It takes special people," he said. "We've been lucky so far in finding just the right people for the job."
As an added incentive in drawing more curators to the program, the state offers a means by which they, too, can turn a profit. In special cases, the state will offer curators long-term commercial leases, allowing them to operate a business in some of the buildings.
THAT is what drew the Wecker brothers to the program. In addition to being resident curators in, and restoring, the two houses, they are restoring the slave quarters, turning them into a museum, and the 9,000-square-foot 1774 Elkridge Furnace Inn. For four years they have been replacing windows, installing a heating system and bringing the inn up to commercial code in the hope of opening it as a bed-and-breakfast by the fall.
As a result of all their hard work, the state agreed to sign a 40-year commercial lease with the Weckers, stipulating that once the business is in operation, they will pay the state 3 percent of their gross receipts. The lease calls for payment of $400 a month, but in return for all the work the Weckers have done -- and the Weckers say they have spent several hundred thousand dollars -- the state is requiring no rent until the year 2004.
(Several other curators, Mr. Kimmel said, have commercial ventures in buildings on their state property, but not in the houses in which they live.)
The Weckers are unique curators in that they do not have much upfront capital. Dan runs a catering business in the finished rooms of the inn to cover some of their out-of-pocket expenses. The rest comes from Stephen's full-time job in the printing business.
For much of the labor involved in the restoration, the brothers employ a barter-style economic arrangement. For instance, Dan recently catered a wedding in exchange for getting new windows installed in the inn. They also rely heavily on a network of community volunteers and congregants from their church group.
Patti Wecker said she would not recommmend their life style to the faint-of heart.
"You have to work 12-hour days and get up the next morning and do it again," she said.
She also worries about the long-term because as hard as they've worked, their business will disappear when it reverts to the state on the deaths of the curators.
Mrs. Wecker is hoping that once the business is operating profitably, she and her husband will be able to save enough money to buy another inn.
"Hopefully," she said, "we can start another business there. This way, at least, we'll have something to leave to our children."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawrence and Agnes Bartlett at 1770 restoration, Stephen and Patti Wecker and family at their project; both are in Maryland. (Photographs by Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Financial Hurdles on the Road to a Place for Escape

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo

 BODY:
PEOPLE who yearn to own a place for escape -- whether on weekends or vacation, in the country or at the beach -- also have to consider how to pay for it.
For many prospective buyers, interest rates, down payment requirements and credit standards are similar to those for a primary residence. for buyers who already have a mortgage, it may be difficult to meet the standard for the maximum amount of mortgage debt, relative to income, that is acceptable to the lender. 
 In a typical situation, a couple buying a $200,000 second home will have to put 25 percent, or $50,000, down, and pay 6 percent, or $12,000, in closing costs. A $150,000 mortgage, at 9 percent over 30 years, will require payments of $1,206.93 a month. Additional costs might be about $400 a month for taxes, insurance and utilities.
Though many buyers take out a second mortgage on their primary home in order to write the check for the down payment on a second home, no such shortcut exists for meeting their now double-mortgage debt-to-income ratio. Generally, lenders insist that buyers pay no more than 28 percent of their gross income in total mortgage payments.
"I don't know how they do it, the double mortgage is a double whammy," said Betty Tompkins, an artist who owns a loft in the SoHo section of Manhattan and a small home on eight acres north of the Poconos. "Some of these people are carrying $5,000 a month in housing costs. Then there is a car, tolls, gas, taxes. They add $10,000 a year to my expenses, and I have a zilcho mortgage."
Ms. Tompkins is one of the lucky ones. She bought her loft 18 years ago for $20,000. And instead of sinking her savings over that period into a larger New York residence, she bought a second home for $155,000. (She put 80 percent down.) "A lot of people in New York are renters and when they get $100,000 together, they buy something outside the city, especially if they are in a rent-controlled apartment," she said.
Many second-home owners also inherited their houses or bought them 10 or more years ago when prices were a fraction of even today's depressed levels. Others have saved long enough to be able to put a sizable amount of equity into the purchase.
And as for those two-home owners who are carrying two mortgages, they tend to have upper-end incomes or be free of child-rearing expenses or both.
For instance, three months ago, a single woman in her 40's, who asked to remain anonymous, paid $115,000 for a three-bedroom, fully furnished, saltbox house on a half-acre of wooded land in Shohola, Pa., in the Delaware Water Gap area. Her mortgage payments and taxes come to $800 a month; she made a 25 percent down payment.
SHE has a co-op loan that costs $1,000 a month to carry and pays $600 a month in maintenance for her 8-year-old unit, in the Kips Bay section of Manhattan. Her basic housing expenses are therefore $2,400 a month. Then there are utility bills, transportation costs and other items such as lawn mowing and the occasional repair bill. She expects one of $500 to $700 soon for a foundation repair. "Rain water is seeping in and creating a pool in the basement," she said.
How does she do it? She is a lawyer, earning between $90,000 and $100,000 a year. She has no children.
Perhaps that is also why her biggest caveat about buying a second home is not financial, notwithstanding advice to get mortgage pre-approval. "Watch out for bad roads in the winter," she said. "It was something I didn't even think about when I was house-hunting in the summer."

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Recitals, Opera Light and Grand, Plus Superman

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
NEXT weekend is shaping up as one of the busiest of the season, with more concert enticements than can be described. Among those of high promise though are two superstar recitals, light opera and a grand operatic doubleheader, more than half a dozen orchestral programs and Superman.
Flying in first is Superman since, at 8 P.M. on Wednesday, the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam is opening its 30th anniversary season with a revival of Charles Strouse and Lee Adams's "It's a Bird, It's a Plane, It's Superman." Kay McClelland, from the Broadway hit "City of Angels," plays Lois Lane, with Gary Jackson starring as the Man of Steel whose X-ray vision can no doubt see all the way through to the end of the run in early July. For dates, times and reservations, call the box office at 873-8668. 
 On Thursday evening at 8, Itzhak Perlman brings his warmth and violin virtuosity to the Stamford Palace, playing Schubert, Shostakovich, Suk and Dvorak with the pianist Samuel Sanders. Nor does Palace let the stage cool down for long: the master saxophonist Branford Marsalis arrives for a jazz concert Friday at that same hour (323-2131).
Also at 8 P.M. on Friday you'll find jazz at the Chester Meeting House, as the Robbie Collomore Concert presents the tenor saxophonist Bob Kindred, the bassist Todd Coolman and the pianist Bill Charlap, the threesome performing as the "Kindred Spirits" (526-5506).
The Troupers Light Opera Company has selected Gilbert and Sullivan's "Gondoliers" for its spring production, with five performances lighting up the Rippowam Center in Stamford: Friday and Saturday evenings this week and next, plus a 2:30 matinee on May 1 (637-5845).
Another Friday option is the return of Connecticut Concert Opera to the Centennial Theatre in Simsbury. These days of recession wouldn't seem to be the ideal time to launch a new company but, reports its president, John Wadhams, "our debut performances (last January) were outstanding, the only seats left were in the back of the third balcony, and people came streaming out to the lobby absolutely beaming." Performances are at 8:15 P.M. on Friday and next Sunday afternoon at 3, with a double bill of Mozart's "Re Pastore" and Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" featuring Peter Harvey, Yu Ping, Katherine Harris and other singers under the artistic direction of Toby Hall (236-0004).
Gunther Herbig leads the Yale Philharmonia in Schubert's "Great" C Major Symphony, No. 9, and with the graduate student Thomas Wiebe as soloist, Bloch's beautiful Cello Rhapsody "Schelomo"; the 8 P.M. Friday concert at Woolsey Hall also introduces a Yale conducting fellow, Arthur Post, who will take the podium for Haydn's "Surprise" Symphony (432-4158).
At that same hour, the New Haven Symphony previews its "Gershwin, By George" program at the Shelton High School before bringing it back home for an 8 P.M. Saturday outing at the New Haven Palace. Stanley de Rusha guests conducts on both occasions, the lineup including the Variations on "I Got Rhythm" and "Rhapsody in Blue," both with Elliot Finkel the solo pianist, a group of songs featuring the tenor Jerome Pruett, and such orchestral attractions as the Cuban Overture and the Lullaby for Strings (776-1444).
At Woolsey Hall, at 8 P.M. on Saturday, the Yale Symphony under James Ross plays Milhaud, Bartok and Prokofiev at its last concert of the school year (432-4150), while the season finales of the Ridgefield and Wallingford Symphonies occur at that same time, respectively, in the Ridgefield High School and the Paul Mellon Arts Center. Both of those concerts have a vocal component: in Ridgefield, the orchestra under Beatrice Brown welcomes the Connecticut Choral Society (and its director, Christopher Shay) for performances of Handel's Coronation Anthem "Zadok the Priest" and the Poulenc Gloria, the latter with the soprano Karen Van Posnak as soloist (438-3889). And the Wallingford concert begins as the actress Socorro Santiago narrates Poulenc's "Story of Babar" plus another delightful family piece, Benjamin Britten's "Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra," with the group's music director Philip Ventre conducting (284-5252). Each program then concludes with a popular orchestral favorite, Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony in Ridgefield, and in Wallingford the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto, with the orchestra's concertmaster, Nina Crothers, stepping to center stage as soloist.
The Greenwich Symphony is also giving one if its own players a chance in the spotlight: the multitalented Lowell Lacey, who plays in the viola section when he isn't otherwise occupied with whatever piano, celesta, harpsichord or organ parts appear in the symphonic repertoire. On this occasion, Mr. Lacey will be at the harpsichord for Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 5, the other major solos in the piece contributed by the group's concertmaster Dorothy Happel and its principal flutist Kim Haley. The group's music director, David Gilbert, has chosen Beethoven's "Consecration of the House" to begin the program; he'll end it with Nielsen's expansive Symphony No. 4, subtitled "The Inextinguishable." A program preview, with the associate conductor Patricia Handy, is scheduled at noon on Wednesday in Second Congregational Church; the 8:30 P.M. Saturday concert will be repeated at the High School the following afternoon at 4 (869-2664).
The seasonal farewell of the Stamford Symphony under Roger Nierenberg also provides a choice -- 8:30 P.M. Saturday or next Sunday afternoon at 3, both at the Palace Theater -- the program certainly covering a lot of stylistic ground, from Mozart's "Haffner" Symphony to Lukas Foss's "Salomon Rossi Suite," the latter itself a tribute across the centuries to the Italian violinist and composer who died around 1730. The featured Concerto is Rachmaninoff's Second, with the Philadelphia pianist Susan Starr as guest soloist (325-1407).
Finally, the Hartford Symphony may still be on strike but its Volunteer Association is going ahead with the orchestra's 18th annual Young Artists Competition. The finals, presented in concert form at the Watkinson School in West Hartford, begin at 3 next Sunday afternoon; no admission is charged (246-8742).

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Peekskill Single-Families;
A Hovnanian First in Westchester

 BODY:
Hovnanian Enterprises, of Red Bank, N.J., best known for its low-priced town houses and garden-style apartments for first-time buyers, will open its first community of detached one-family homes in Westchester County in June.
The company's president, Ara Hovnanian, said the development of the community, Forest View in Peekskill, N.Y., was spurred by consumer research and changing demographics. 
 "We are confident that these new home designs, located an hour's commute from Manhattan in the Westchester hills, will meet the needs of move-up buyers throughout the region who have waited until they could see the economy start to turn around," he said.
Modeled after several successful one-family-home projects in New Jersey, Forest View will consist of 169 three- and four-bedroom homes, ranging from about 1,900 to 2,500 square feet. The average outside dimension is 35 feet wide by 48 feet deep. Amenities include basements with ground-level entrances and oversize windows. Prices will be in the low $200,000's.
Mr. Hovnanian said most buyers are expected to come from the surrounding area and New York City. In a departure from its normal "preconstruction sale" practice, four model homes will be available for inspection.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Lost in Space;
Companies Finding That Getting Smaller Isn't Easy

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
THE Chemical Bank is working on a problem that would be the envy of most Manhattanites. It finds itself with too much, rather than too little, space.
Last December, it merged with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. And like hundreds of other companies that have consolidated or retrenched during the current recession, the 7.5 million square feet in 20 buildings that the two banks occupied in and around New York City offered far too much space for the combined entity. 
 It has therefore embarked upon a comprehensive analysis of its future space requirements to reduce overhead and redeploy departments for maximum efficiency.
"You get into a lot of issues when you do something like this," said Walter Wystkowski, its vice president of facilities planning management. "Which buildings should go. Which ones offer the best locations. How to minimize costs by making as many 'box' moves as possible."
Mr. Wystkowski defined a box move as one in which a department can be moved, in a block, into existing space without expensive renovations.
But these companies are not without help. As the recession persists, more of the major architectural and interior planning firms like Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, KPF Interior Architects and Fletcher Thompson -- firms that helped many of the same corporations expand in the 1980's -- now find themselves gaining skills in making them smaller.
Not surprisingly, they have found that cutting back tends to be painful. It forces companies to make unpopular decisions such as spending a sizable amount of upfront money at a time when profits may be flat or shrinking.
"There are contradictory pulls and pushes," said Peter S. Brooks, a principal with Austrian Roth & Partners, real estate consultants in New York City. Until the end of 1991 Mr. Brooks was a senior vice president at the Chemical Bank in charge of space requirements. "When you are expanding," he said, "the costs seem easier to swallow. In downsizing you find yourself resisting every expenditure."
Moreover, as the cutting back on space is usually carried out when the economy is weak it becomes harder to get out of existing leases or even find subtenants to cover the remaining term, said Randolph Gerner, president of KPF Interior Architects of Manhattan.
Thus a good program must also consider the cost savings that could be achieved by waiting until certain leases expire, especially if some new spaces will be needed for the consolidated enterprise; say, more floors in fewer buildings.
For even if subtenants can be found, it's rare for them to pay rent at the rate the corporation agreed upon when it first the signed the lease, Mr. Brooks said. What's worse, he added, the prime sites that can be re-rented most easily are often the ones the corporation is most anxious to keep.
The financial struggles may be further complicated, he said, because individual employees are likely to loose cherished perks like a private office with a window in the effort to cut costs.
"And many people measure their success in life by the size, shape and configuration of their offices," he noted.
BUT it can be done. Indeed many of the experts insist it's the ideal moment to be making fundamental changes that will benefit the company for years to come. "It's the best possible time to make a total re-evaluation," said John H. Winkler, the managing partner with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill of Manhattan, which is handling the consolidation for Chemical.
At Chemical, this re-evaluation is still in the earliest stages. Preliminary estimates call for a reduction in space of about 15 percent to 6.5 million square feet with a potential drop in employees from 45,000 to 38,800, some of whom have already left.
But those numbers could still change -- another difficulty that plagues the process. For planners must deal with fluctuating numbers at a time when nobody wants to be wasting money factoring in a "cushion." One solution offered by James A. Beaudin, vice president of Fletcher Thompson of Bridgeport, Conn., is to place those departments most likely to continue to contract next to the ones deemed most prone to expansion.
Certain spaces can usually be eliminated regardless, said Mr. Gerner of KPF. He maintains that square footage can often be lowered by 20 percent with only a 10 percent drop in employees. For instance, he notes that consolidation should immediately result in the need for fewer dining rooms, reception areas, conference rooms and even rest rooms.
It should become an opportunity, he said, to examine how much costly square footage is being wasted on filing needs. "We have made such strides in electronic storage," he said, "that many of those files could now be stored off-site," with the data available instead on disk.
Mr. Beaudin goes one step further. He favors what he calls "purge days" -- a designated day during the upheavals when dumpsters are brought to the site, employees turn up in their old clothes and everyone spends the day clearing out personal files. "You soon find out you don't need all those cabinets after all," he said.
OVERSIZED conference rooms tend to be another major space gobbler. Mr. Gerner maintained that too many large and lavish conference rooms were often added in the 1980's as something of a status symbol. Substantial space can be saved, he said, by creating smaller conference rooms. "Most of the time you're far more likely to need space for 10 rather than 25 people," he said.
Creating uniform corporate standards for office sizes and furnishings for each grade of employees (with rare exceptions) are even more important in contracting than during expansion, these experts say, as a sense of turf -- and thus seniority rights -- is at risk.
Though it may seem like excessive regimentation, they say morale is boosted when everyone at a certain level in a company knows in advance that equal treatment can be expected. Further, it helps the company save money because it enables the purchasing of a greater amount of office furniture in bulk.
Right now these planners note a trend toward smaller offices or even open-floor offices for middle managers as a key element in space cutting. And while it is never a welcome change it is the ideal time to break the news, these experts say, because those who remain may consider themselves fortunate to have kept their jobs. So they are less likely to complain.
Also helpful in contraction, they say, are updated designs that stress access to daylight for the maximum number of employees coupled with an emphasis on open-floor plans -- a feature that provides a greater illusion of space while consuming less square footage per person. This is in contrast to a decade ago when six-foot-high cubicles were all the rage, isolating too many people in what were essentially windowless boxes.

HEADLINE: Industry-Aid Bill Stirs Tax Battle

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
DEPENDING on where you sit, a bill that breezed through the State Senate on April 2 and the Assembly last week could cost residential taxpayers tens of millions of dollars, could save industrial taxpayers tens of millions of dollars -- or none of the above.
The sponsors of the bill, called the Business Retention Act, say it will keep business and industry from leaving the state by exempting equipment and machinery from local property taxes. They say the bill simply reiterates a previous law that has been diluted beyond recognition by a recent series of Tax Court decisions. 
 Gov. Jim Florio has said he is "generally supportive" of the bill but wants to examine some of the municipalities' concerns.
Opponents of the bill say it will produce a dramatic shift of the municipal tax burden from industry to residential and commercial taxpayers. In part, they say, this will happen because town assessors will lose the leverage, provided by the court decisions, that has enabled them to keep industrial taxpayers in line.
In a state hard hit by the recession, the debate comes as municipalities struggle to keep local property taxes affordable for residents, particularly those on fixed incomes, while state and local officials try to fan the fires of economic development and hold businesses -- and badly needed jobs -- in New Jersey.
"If we allow municipalities to tax equipment and personal property, we'll drive businesses right out of New Jersey," said State Senator Donald T. DiFrancesco, Republican of Westfield and sponsor of the bill. He said that the only community that had taken advantage of the court decisions was Bayonne, and that the bill would produce no major tax increase for homeowners in other towns.
But Jon R. Moran, a senior legislative analyst for the New Jersey State League of Municipalities in Trenton, said, "The bill is going to cause a shift in the tax burden from big business to the residential taxpayers." In a letter to legislators, the league said the cost to homeowners would be "tens of millions of dollars."
And some municipal officials fear that, once businesses are free of the threat of increased assessments, they will push for decreases.
"I'm sick over it," said James A. Sabetta, the Mayor of Paulsboro, in Gloucester County. "The taxpayers are going to be hit with a double whammy. We're going to be forced to spend 40 or 50 thousand dollars just to defend tax appeals." And, he added, the town might lose.
In New Jersey, municipal property taxes are calculated by applying the municipal tax rate to the assessed value of each piece of property. The assessment includes both the value of the land and the value of improvements on the land.
Residential property is typically assessed by using a "market value" approach; the assessment is simply the property's current market value. The market value of industrial and commercial properties, however, is more difficult to assess. The value of a piece of commercial property like an office building, for example, is often dependent upon the income that the property produces.
The market value of industrial property, on the other hand, depends more upon the use to which the property is put. A chemical plant, for instance, is worth more to a potential purchaser that manufactures chemicals than it is to one that manufactures automobiles.
For example, what makes a chemical plant different from an automobile manufacturing plant is not the building itself, but the equipment in it. Though such equipment is often considered personal property and therefore not subject to real-estate taxes, it is nevertheless a factor in determining the plant's value.
 
Ambiguity and Confusion
 That situation, experts say, has led to ambiguity and confusion when industrial property is assessed for taxing purposes.
Seth Davenport, a Montclair lawyer who specializes in property tax appeals, said the Legislature attempted to eliminate the confusion in 1986 by passing a law that exempted most equipment and machinery from local taxation. The regulations that resulted from that law allowed local assessors to tax only equipment that was "functionally essential" to the structure.
The State Tax Court, however, struck down that definition and said any equipment in a "special purpose facility" could be taxed at the local level. Determining what was a "special purpose facility" was left to the local tax assessor.
As a result, Mr. Davenport said, "if you built a widget factory, and machinery was necessary to make the widgets, then the machinery was taxable as real estate."
The Tax Court decision, he said, exposed nearly all machinery and equipment in industrial plants to municipal taxation -- a situation that could cost business and industry millions of dollars. And that, Mr. Davenport said, sent an ominous signal to businesses in the state -- a signal to which many businesses reacted.
 
100,000 Manufacturing Jobs Lost
 "In the last 28 months we've lost 100,000 manufacturing jobs," he said. "Eventually, New Jersey would become a rust belt."
Allowing municipalities to tax equipment and machinery might bolster the tax rolls in the short run, he said, but residents would suffer a substantial net loss after a few years. "When the plant that employs people in the town shuts down, where do those people go?" he said. "The residents lose their jobs and the town loses its ratables."
The Business Retention Act, Mr. Davenport said, will send a message to the business community that the state is serious about maintaining its industrial base and fostering economic development. And the effects of the law on municipalities, he said, should be minimal.
Joseph Politi, president of Market Value Appraisal Services, a Fair Lawn company that specializes in municipal assessments, agreed.
"It shouldn't have a major impact on most communities because most communities don't have those types of industrial properties," Mr. Politi said. And even the municipalities that do have such properties, he said, are not likely to be seriously affected because most assessors have not yet included equipment and machinery in their assessments.
 
'It's Not the Big Bugaboo'
 "It's not the big bugaboo that people are trying to make it out to be," Mr. Politi said.
But State Senator Raymond J. Zane, Democrat of Woodbury, said the bill would have a negative impact on nearly every municipality in the state.
"There's a spinoff effect," Mr. Zane said, referring to the fact that municipalities in a specific county share the cost of county government proportionately. If tax revenue in one municipality falls, then taxes in every other municipality in the same county must be increased to make up the difference.
Bayonne is the only community that has responded to the Tax Court rulings by including equipment and machinery in its assessment of industrial properties. Marvin J. Joss, the Bayonne tax assessor, said he was able to add about $80 million in industrial assessments to the tax rolls. Under the Business Retention Act, however, that $80 million will have to be taken off the assessment rolls, reducing the town's tax revenue by about $2.1 million.
That loss, Mr. Joss said, would have to be made up by the residential and commercial taxpayers. "It would translate into about $170 a year on the average house," he said.
 
League of Municipalities Blamed
 Senator DiFrancesco said the debate surrounding the Business Retention Act stemmed less from the bill itself than from the lobbying campaign led by the League of Municipalities.
"I've read their letters and they're deliberately misrepresenting the facts to their membership," Mr. DiFrancesco said. "On this issue, they're dead wrong."
Municipal officials, however, say that even if they have not actively assessed equipment and machinery, they have nevertheless capitalized on the ability to do so when industrial taxpayers have sought reductions in their assessments.
"It's used as a shield, not as a sword," said Lawrence Pollex, business administrator in Edison. Instead of going into a factory and assessing the equipment and machinery as real estate, he said, some municipal assessors instead used their right to do so as leverage to defend their assessments.
Mr. Davenport, the tax lawyer, said that even that practice was wrong and should be curtailed.
 
An 'Extortionistic Tool'
 "It's been used as an extortionistic tool to stop industry from getting a fair assessment on real estate," he said.
But some municipal officials say they need all the leverage they can get when they are up against big business in tax assessment appeals. And they fear that as soon as one business is successful in having its assessment substantially reduced, an avalanche of other appeals will follow.
Mr. Sabetta, the Mayor of Paulsboro, said the impact the bill could have on his community became immediately apparent when one of the borough's largest industries, the GATX Terminals Corporation, a Pennsylvania company, filed a tax appeal on March 31, this year's deadline.
GATX, Mr. Sabetta said, owns a terminal with a dock on the Delaware River that it bought two years ago for $9.7 million. The property is currently assessed at $8.4 million, more than a million less than the market value as established by GATX's own purchase price.
Now, Mr. Sabetta said, GATX has asked that the assessment be reduced by $7 million, to $1.4 million.
"They told us that the appeal was being filed in anticipation of changes in New Jersey law," Mr. Sabetta said, referring to the Business Retention Act. He said the tax assessor expected the law would cost the municipality $50 million to $60 million in lost ratables. That would result in residential property tax increases of about $250 on an average house.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
No More Tears, Raise a Cheer for the Banks

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Is this the golden era of American banking?
Those who are laughing at that question may not have pondered the latest profit reports from America's banks. They show profit margins heading ever upward, with a diminishing number of bad loans. 
 The latest wonderful news from the banks reflects a confluence of events. The rates they charge on what few loans they are making have not come down nearly as far as the rates they pay for deposits. And many are making an extra buck by buying longer-term Treasuries, on which rates are substantially higher than the rates the banks pay their depositors.
 Consider Wachovia, a healthy Southern regional bank. Its latest report shows that its interest income -- the money it gets from bonds and borrowers -- was down 14 percent in the first quarter from a year earlier. But its interest expense -- the amount it pays to depositors -- was down 30 percent. Over the same period, its outstanding loans were down 5 percent, but the amount of money it had invested in securities was up 16 percent.
Last week was the best week of '92 for the Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 111.13 points to a record 3,366.50, partly in response to the Fed's continued efforts to reduce interest rates. But only one major bank, Chemical, cut its prime lending rate. Most banks have little desire to make new loans, so why cut rates on existing loans?
The second part of the bank profit explosion is the rapid falloff in bad loans. There the picture is less clear. While most banks were reporting declines, there were bad reports from Security Pacific and Arizona's Valley National. Both banks are slated to be acquired, and each seems to be cleaning up its books in anticipation. Those decisions emphasize the discretion bankers have to decide whether to recognize bad loans or to defer making the decision, hoping something will turn up.
The strategies used to produce this year's profits may not work forever. When loan demand starts to rise, some banks may regret their decisions to cut savings rates so low that customers have fled to mutual funds, and may have to pay more for new deposits. Citicorp's move last week to cut credit card interest rates could spread and reduce profits. And the big risk, as always, is bad loans.
Still, while the bank regulators have more banks left to seize, it is possible to hope that those banks that manage to survive are entering an era of prosperity, in which competition is not very intense.
Eighteen months ago, investors suspected that every bank was hiding bad loans. Now they believe that the new reports show a genuine improvement that is likely to last. Since April 8, when stock prices bottomed just before the Fed pushed the Federal funds rate down for the most recent time, the Dow Jones industrial average has risen 5.8 percent. But Chase Manhattan, First Chicago and BankAmerica are just three of the many banks whose stock gained at least twice that amount.

At It Buys More Securities," tracks quaterly outstanding loans and investment securities at Wachovia, 1st qtr 1990-1st qtr 1992.

HEADLINE: Cuba, Long Forbidden, Wins Major Attention Abroad

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
A growing number of American companies, lured by the prospect of approaching change in Cuba as the island tries to ward off economic collapse, are following their foreign counterparts in showing interest in the island.
Located at the United States' doorstep, endowed with resources ranging from strategic metals to rich croplands and pristine beaches, and inhabited by an industrious, well-educated population, Cuba is seen by many corporate executives and academics as a country in need of almost wholesale economic reconstruction but also as a land of potentially bright opportunity. 
 American corporations are barred from the island by a 29-year-old embargo and are wary of the sensitivities of a large and politically active Cuban-American population that has expressed hostility to any easing of relations with the Communist regime. Thus they have been forced to remain largely on the sidelines as companies from France, Britain, Canada, Spain and elsewhere seized upon opportunities opened up by recent reforms in the island's policies governing private investment. Yet foreign subsidiaries of United States companies have started to take advantage of a little-heralded 1975 amendment to the American embargo that allows them to trade nonstrategic goods with Cuba.
Cut off from its traditional lifeline to the defunct Soviet Union, Cuba is scurrying to replace subsidized supplies of everything from industrial spare parts and oil to flour for making bread. It is feeding the effort by setting up attractive new investment regulations that permit the repatriation of profits, majority foreign ownership in some instances and control over management decisions like hiring and firing that were once the sacrosanct domain of the Government.
Cuba, locked into a sterile brand of central planning for the last three decades, barely tips the scales in the economic life of Latin America and the Caribbean. It is a Communist oddity in an increasingly free-market world. "If Cuba were to somehow sink tomorrow and disappear from the map, it would hardly make a ripple in the hemisphere's economy," a World Bank official said recently. "It would just not be felt."
But many companies have begun to prospect the island's markets, convinced that Cuba's bid to survive will ultimately lead it to convert to a capitalist economy, even if it is not acknowledged in name. If the Government should suddenly pull back on its reforms, many say, economic collapse will follow, eventually leading to the same result.
"There is growing anticipation among my clients, rightly or wrongly, that a political change in Cuba will happen sooner rather than later," said Sally Shelton, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Caribbean affairs in the Carter Administration who now works as a Washington-based consultant for several multinationals. "The feeling is that Cuba cannot remain unchanged forever, and quite apart from politics, Castro's need for hard currency will drive him to liberalize further and make foreign investment even more attractive."
While the debate is played out among Cuban policy makers over how quickly to pursue reforms and how to prevent the budding liberalization from ending the Communist Party's vise-like grip on almost every aspect of Cuban life, foreign companies are grabbing up rights to a growing variety of business ventures.
Recent investments run from the Spanish hotel company Grupo Sol's conquest of undeveloped tourism sites that are the envy of the Caribbean to a contract with Canada's Sherritt Gordon to rehabilitate some of the world's richest nickel mines. Sherritt Gordon failed to return repeated telephone calls about the size of its contract, but it is believed to be worth about $1.2 billion.
In a bid to relieve a crushing energy shortage that has brought back horse-drawn carriages and oxen-powered plows, the French oil company Total-Compagnie Francaise des Petroles was recently awarded a six-year contract to explore and develop offshore fields, which though still unproven, are widely believed to hold important reserves.
Shell, British Petroleum, the Swedish firm Taurus Petroleum and the Brazilian company Braspetro, drawn by the same prospect, have become active in Cuban oil exploration.
Although American companies remain excluded from Cuba by the embargo, the have been tantalized by thesight of foreign firms reaching potentially lucrative deals just 90 miles off South Florida's shores. Yet few of them, largely out of fear of confrontations with Cuban-American groups opposed to trade with the Government, are willing to speak openly about their involvement.
"I think a lot of them are really frightened about the legal complications of angering Washington," said Christopher Barton, assistant director of the Center for National Security Law at the University of Virginia.
"I don't think we should lift the embargo, but people who say they do are always getting death threats," said one business consultant on Latin America who refused to be named.
Foreign subsidiaries of United States companies are active in everything from fertilizer and elevator parts to raw sugar and tobacco. Their commerce more than doubled between 1988 and 1990, according to a recently published Johns Hopkins University study of Cuban-American trade relations. In 1990, the last year for which complete data are available, that trade reached $705 million.
The growing list of parent companies whose subsidiaries are involved now reads like a Who's Who of the American corporate world, including such names as Dow Chemical, Du Pont, Ford, General Electric, I.B.M. and Union Carbide. Treasury Department documents indicate that the vast majority of these subsidiaries are registered in Switzerland, with England a distant second. One company, Otis Elevator, is rehabilitating equipment in old buildings and installing new elevators through its Mexican subsidiary.
"Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the potential for U.S. trade has increased dramatically, and we have seen that in the subsidiary trade," said Donna Rich-Kaplowitz, an author of the Hopkins study. "We believe that we could see between $1.2 billion and $2 billion in trade the first year after the embargo is lifted and some analysts think that figure could rise to $6 billion fairly quickly."
One indication of the mounting American interest in Cuba is that an 84-page booklet called "Developing Business Strategies for Cuba," published by the New York-based publishing and consulting firm, Business International, "sold as well as any research document we have put out on Latin America, including much larger countries like Mexico," said Santiago Fittipaldi, the company's assistant editor for Latin America.
Subscriptions for the London-based bi-monthly newsletter, Cuba Business, have increased so handsomely in the United States in the last year that the publisher, Gareth Jenkins, plans to introduce an American monthly edition next month.
In June, another British publication, Euromoney, will hold a two-day conference on Cuba for American companies in Cancun, Mexico. The conference includes a one-day excursion to Havana, made legal despite Treasury Department restrictions on Americans spending money in an "enemy" country, because all expenses for the side trip will be paid by the Cuban Government.
For all of these signs of burgeoning corporate interest, however, experts in Cuban affairs say there is little chance that the United States embargo will be lifted. While allowing American subsidiaries to trade with Cuba, the United States quietly, but actively, discourages even foreign-owned companies from providing strategic goods to Cuba or resuscitating vital industries.
Last year, diplomatic pressure of this kind was widely believed to have scotched a pact by the Brazilian airline, Vasp, to acquire a major share in the Cuban carrier Cubana, which is badly in need of investments to replace its antiquated Soviet fleet. Executives at Vasp have declined to provide details of why the deal was suddenly canceled.
The Castro Government's harshest foes in this country are seeking to get the Bush Administration to take an even harder line on Cuba in a bill that is now before Congress.
Opponents of further tightening of the embargo, both here and abroad, see Cuba as a Communist dead end, a country in which economic realities are already working inexorably to bring about a dramatic transformation.
But until that transformation comes, many American companies say, there is little that they can do but watch.
"Like any big company in the United States, we are keeping an eye on the situation there," said George Jamison, a spokesman for General Electric. "As soon as things change, we will be taking a hard look at the opportunities there."
 
 
 
AN ANTI-CASTRO CONGRESSMAN NAMED TORRICELLI
 Even as international business involvement in Cuba grows, offering what some say is perhaps the island's only chance for peaceful change, President Fidel Castro's most determined foes are moving in this country to hasten the collapse of the 64-year-old dictator's Government.
In the forefront of these efforts lately has been an unlikely champion of a hard-line approach, Representative Robert Torricelli, a 40-year-old New Jersey Democrat who identifies himself politically as a liberal.
Representative Torricelli is the principal author of legislation that would penalize foreign-based subsidiaries of American corporations for trade with Cuba and at the same time seek to discourage American allies from doing business with the island by banning ships that dock in Cuban harbors from this country's ports for six months.
"It has been one of Washington's fondest hopes to separate Castro from $4 billion in Soviet assistance each year," Mr. Torricelli said. "Now that that is being accomplished, the assistance is being replaced with the profits of American corporations and that is intolerable."
President Bush, who has enjoyed support from conservative Cuban-American groups which strongly endorse the proposed legislation, has nonetheless vetoed past attempts to ban subsidiary trade. In doing so, he has cited concerns about the principle of free trade and potential impact on trading partners.
Administration officials have expressed concern that other elements of the Torricelli bill, which may reach a vote next month, also would unnecessarily damage relations with important trading partners. Other critics of the bill say it is a dangerous example of overkill. "Cuba is in a desperate state and change is just around the corner," said Merilyn K. Potter, head of the Latin America section of the London Chamber of Commerce, which organizes frequent visits to the island for British businesses. "There is no need for heinous laws that will only encourage violent disorder."
Representative Torricelli said that the first time he had heard of Cuba he was "hiding my head under a desk in the sixth grade during the missile crisis" of 1962. He called it unlikely that Cuba could change peacefully, and said it was "hopelessly naive to believe that any amount of commerce with Cuba would lead to reform by a leader who is as recalcitrant as Castro."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Back in 1960, Castro supporters took over an Esso refinery. (Associated Press)
 
Graph: "Trading With Cuba," tracks total trade (imports and exports) by foreign subsidiaries of U.S. companies, 1980-1990 (Source: Office of Foreign Asset Control, Department of the Treasury)

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The Competing Money Markets

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Until recently, when interest rates approached their lowest point in two decades, it was hard to go wrong in investing money that might be needed soon. Now, with rates in the basement, variations among investments can loom large, and savers who do not want to tie up their money for a long time have poured $39.3 billion this year into money market funds.
Money market mutual funds -- diversified portfolios of Treasury bills and short-term securities issued by banks and corporations -- are offered by mutual fund companies and brokerage firms. Bank money market deposit accounts, sold by banks or savings and loan associations, were authorized by Congress in 1982 to allow them to compete with money funds. 
 Bank money market deposit accounts can yield up to three percentage points less than money market funds because bankers make different investments than fund managers. In general, the spread between the two tends to grow when interest rates are rising and to shrink when rates are falling. Last week, bank money market deposit accounts yielded 3.61 percent, according to Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla., compared with 3.73 for money funds, according to IBC/ Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
With rates so close today, the main difference between the two types of investments is risk. Like all deposit accounts, bank money market deposit accounts are insured up to $100,000 by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The accounts held $537.4 billion at the end of last year, according to Veribanc Inc., a bank-rating firm in Wakefield, Mass.
Money market funds offer no insurance, but because their holdings are diversified and short term, losses would be minimal even if a commercial paper issuer defaulted on paper held by a fund. Compared with bank money accounts, "there's more risk in funds, but not enough to worry about," said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors.
Then there is service. Most money market mutual funds offer checking, though many have monthly limits of 15 or 20 checks. By law, bank money account holders are limited to three checks a month, although unlimited withdrawals are allowed.
Some people may confuse bank money market deposit accounts with bank-related money market mutual funds. Many banks are now selling funds, as demand for loans slackens and premiums for F.D.I.C. insurance escalate. Because of pressure on their profitability, "many major banks have decided to move out of traditional bank instruments, turning to management of money funds, and mutual funds in general," said Gail J. Liberman, the editor of Bank Rate Monitor.
Banks have been marketing their money funds aggressively, and their efforts are succeeding. While money flowed out of money market mutual funds over all for most of last year, the bank money funds had net inflows totaling $11.8 billion in 1991. Still, banks managed only about $40 billion of assets at the end of 1991, compared with $413.1 billion in money market mutual funds, Lipper Analytical Services reported.
The money funds themselves are similar. The main difference is where you buy them. For amounts up to $10,000 or so, "if you're happy with the services of your local bank, use it," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical. For larger amounts, small differences in yield can create significant differences in return, so "I'd look for which is a better investment in terms of return."
In terms of tax status, there are three distinct types of money market funds, and the critical measure is yield on an after-tax basis. Last week, all taxable money funds yielded 3.73 percent, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report. The yields on tax-free money funds were 2.83 percent, and money funds that invest solely in United States Treasury securities were paying 3.72 percent. But the tax-free funds may actually yield more after taxes are paid, depending on your tax bracket and place of residence.
Tax-free money funds invest in municipal debt, and their earnings are free from Federal income taxes. To find the after-tax yield, divide the actual yield by one minus your tax rate. For investors in the 28 percent bracket, the taxable equivalent yield for tax-free funds is 3.93 percent (2.83 divided by [1-.28]). For those in the 31 percent bracket, the tax-free fund yields 4.10 percent after tax.
Then there are municipal funds, which can invest in "private purpose" issues whose earnings are subject to the alternative minimum tax, a flat tax intended to insure that wealthy taxpayers pay their fair share. For people who are not subject to the A.M.T., the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, for example, which was yielding 3.75 percent last week, effectively paid 5.21 percent for those in the 28 percent bracket.
Funds that invest solely in Treasury securities are super safe and produce earnings free of state taxes. To figure the taxable equivalent yield for the state where you live, use the formula given earlier, substituting your state tax rate for the Federal rate.
For example, Treasury-only funds yielded 3.72 percent last week on average. For New Yorkers in the highest state bracket, that translates into a 4.03 percent yield after state taxes are paid. New Jersey residents earn 4.00 percent; Connecticut residents slightly less, at 3.90 percent. Californians would pocket a 4.18 percent yield.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Alcohol, Still the Drug of Choice

SERIES: Second of two articles on substance abuse.

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
For most employees, these are familiar office characters: fellow workers who stumble to their desks on Monday, haggard from a weekend of relaxing-by-partying. Or a colleague who disappears regularly for long lunches and returns looking dazed and smelling of alcohol.
Despite all the attention paid in recent years to the abuse of controlled substances like cocaine and marijuana, alcohol -- friendly, familiar, legal old alcohol -- remains the drug of choice for most Americans. For most Americans, it is not a problem. Hazelden, the rehabilitation and educational program in Center City, Minn., estimates that some 80 percent of the population either abstains or uses alcohol moderately. 
 But there is that other 20 percent, and apparently the drive to rid the workplace of controlled substances has had the side effect of increasing awareness of the role alcohol plays in such workplace problems as absenteeism, tardiness and lost productivity.
The number of employee assistance programs "has gone up tremendously in the last few years," said Rudy Yandrick, a spokesman for the Employee Assistance Program Association in Arlington, Va. And having help just a touch-tone away is apparently a positive trend. "People appear to be coming in at an earlier stage of crisis," said Jeff Monroy, an E.A.P. administrator at Corning Inc. in Corning, N.Y.
But even in the best of all possible worlds, with programs in place and sympathetic administrators trained to recognize the symptoms of abuse, colleagues, not supervisors, are often the first people at work to feel the impact of alcohol abuse. They are often asked -- explicitly or implicitly -- to absorb the workload of an impaired employee, fudge work results or actually lie.
What tack should a long-suffering co-worker take? "It clearly depends on the situation," said Jack Longie, a substance-abuse consultant at the Control Data Corporation in Minneapolis. "If a steelworker calls and says 'Hey, I'm working with a guy up in the girders who's impaired,' it's obvious." But most situations, especially in the white-collar workplace, aren't as clear cut.
"I would encourage the employee to learn about the illness before doing something," said Mr. Longie. He said he might elicit more information, then advise the caller to have an informal talk with the co-worker, depending on their relationship at work. For example, he said, "We do not normally encourage people to approach higher-ups. It is too risky. Call human resources or their manager."
Mr. Longie and other experts in substance abuse acknowledge that raising the issue is difficult. "You're afraid to say the wrong thing," Mr. Longie said. One bit of advice some experts offer is counterintuitive: Don't begin by talking about alcohol.
"Be careful of jumping to a conclusion about what's going on with people," said Caryn Oftedahl, a manager in Hazelden's community prevention and professional education division. "In some situations, alcohol may be the cause, other times it could be a child-care problem or something else."
She suggests focusing on the "behaviors of concern" -- lateness, deterioration of skills, preoccupied behavior -- rather than "diagnosing" a problem. "It is much more comfortable for people to say something like, 'Hey, you've been late for work for three days,' " she said. "You're a co-worker, not a chemical dependency counselor."

IT is crucial to let the co-worker know others are affected by his or her behavior and to avoid sounding accusatory or judgmental.
"Try to make 'I' statements," Ms. Oftedahl said. " 'This is how it is affecting me; I care about what's going on. I care about my job and the quality of my job.' " A complaint should be specific, she said: " 'This is what I see happening: You're coming in late or showing up drunk.' "
Co-workers' responses are unpredictable. "They could say, 'Thank you for sharing that,' get angry, or turn around and walk away," Ms. Oftedahl said. She suggests making a commitment to help, but deciding in advance how far to go. "It depends on how much you're willing to do and how much you care about the person," she said. If the person is unresponsive, the next step might be to alert a supervisor or the employee assistance program.
Colleagues squeamish about the possibility of hurting a fellow employee may take courage from one well-established pattern: The last place alcohol affects is the job. "The employee is already dealing with it in family and elsewhere," Mr. Longie said. "Knowing that, it's easier to decide to do what you have to do now. He could lose his life."
 
 
 
GETTING OUT THE MESSAGE
 Substance-abuse specialists sometimes are accused of being professional party poopers, unable -- or unwilling -- to distinguish between an alcoholic and a person who knows when to say when, but likes to push the envelope a little. Caryn Oftedahl, of Hazelden, the rehab center, says people tell her, " 'You're so dry you're a fire hazard.' " She laughs but says she doesn't try to approach alcohol as a wet or dry issue.
The idea is to have people think about it before indulging in such traditions as the post-work carouse. "Well, everybody goes out after work on Friday," she said. "But is that healthy? Should we question it? Prevention hits on those social norms."
Those social norms, what some call the "culture of tolerance" of alcohol, are changing. "It is clear to me in this culture," said Jeff Monroy of Corning Inc., "that it's not O.K. to go out at noon and drink your lunch." Company policy, worked out with employee input, sends a clear message. "We aren't saying don't drink," Mr. Monroy said, "We're saying it's not appropriate to come to work impaired."

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Weighing a New Operating System? Call a Timeout

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
WINDOWS. OS/2. Windows. OS/2. The promotional cannons are firing salvos over the newest versions of these two personal computer operating systems, and shell-shocked customers are asking, "Which side do I choose?"
The best answer may be both, or neither. 
 Billions of dollars are at stake for businesses trying to plan their information systems for the coming years. Those costs include purchases of hardware, and massive expenditures on software, training, maintenance, system integration and troubleshooting.
The Microsoft Corporation of Redmond, Wash., wants every personal computer to be operated through Windows, a graphical user interface that makes DOS computers easier to use. It introduced its latest version, Windows 3.1, on April 6. And Microsoft stocked the stores with so many copies that some rivals complained of a brief worldwide shortage of 3.5-inch diskettes.
If there were any extra diskettes around, they were probably gobbled up by the International Business Machines Corporation, which sent version 2.0 of its OS/2 operating system to the manufacturing plants at about the same time. I.B.M. wants every personal computer user to move to OS/2, a more powerful operating system than Windows or DOS that also makes computers easier to use. OS/2 version 2.0 should be reaching stores this week.
Both companies say they want to own America's business desktops. Suggestions that I.B.M. was resigned to playing a secondary role to Windows have brought a strenuous denial from Armonk, N.Y., where I.B.M. has its headquarters. Executives there vowed that OS/2 2.0 would be a "better Windows than Windows," eliminating the need for most people to buy Windows at all.
Next week, Windows 3.1 and OS/2 2.0 can be compared, side by side, feature by feature. For now, let's take up the question of whether the trouble and expense of moving to either one are worth it.
Both systems offer significant advantages over DOS, which is now 10 years old and was never meant to run on machines as powerful as today's desktops. But are the advantages significant enough to warrant the pain and cost of transition? Executives would be prudent to think things over, especially in these unsettled economic times.
The issue is simple enough for executives who already use Windows 3.0. The new version is simply better and there is minimal pain in upgrading. But trouble and expense aplenty await businesses that change from one operating system to another.
Most personal computers continue to hum along using DOS, producing useful output, and most of the machines could not move to Windows or OS/2 even if their owners wanted them to. Both new programs require more processing power, hard disk space and system memory than one would find in the typical office desktop computer today.
Of course, that will change as older machines die and are replaced by newer ones. But market researchers say the average configuration of a desktop PC these days is a 386SX microprocessor, with 2 megabytes of system memory, a color VGA monitor, and a 40-megabyte hard disk drive. Such a machine can be found next to the garden tractors and washing machines at a Sears store for about $1,500, regardless of how much a company paid a couple of years ago (probably about $3,000). Those machines barely able to run Windows effectively and cannot handle OS/2 at all.
To be sure, Microsoft recommends at least a 386SX microprocessor, 2 megabytes of extended system memory beyond the basic 640 kilobytes, a high-density diskette drive, 10 megabytes of open hard disk space, a color VGA graphics adapter and monitor, a mouse, and DOS 5.0. But many Windows users say 4 megabytes of system memory is a more realistic minimum.
OS/2 is even more demanding. Version 2.0 requires no less than 4 megabytes of system memory and 31 megabytes of open hard disk space, as well as a 386SX or higher processor. That's as it should be, since OS/2 is much more powerful, really a competitor for the NT operating system that Microsoft is promising later this year. Both OS/2 and NT are designed to run on so-called 32-bit microprocessors, like the Intel Corporation's 386 and 486 (and soon, 586) chips. Windows, in contrast, is designed to appeal to owners of older computers, even 16-bit 286 models.
OS/2's hard disk requirement can be pared to as "little" as 18 megabytes, by selectively installing OS/2 features -- OS/2 has a very nice checklist installation system. But the one-button installation process needs 31MB.
A production copy of OS/2 2.0 was tested in this office on a borrowed Compaq 486-33 with 8MB of system memory and a 40MB hard disk. (Granted, this is an odd configuration, sort of like a jet fighter with a 40-gallon fuel tank. If you need the power of a 486, you probably need a minimum of 100MB of storage.)
Even on this system, with its 8MB, OS/2 several times hit the ceiling as it tried to juggle several applications at once. In other words, the machine is brand new, and it is already time for an upgrade.
Adding memory chips is a relatively simple process, and by shopping diligently and doing one's own installation the cost can be kept to about $50 per megabyte. Adding a bigger hard disk is a bit trickier and will cost a few hundred dollars.
Or, one can simply buy new computers with maximum horsepower and features, a prospect that computer makers like I.B.M. must certainly relish.
Many businesses are adding high-powered personal computers but using them strategically as hubs for networks of PC's. This strategy is called client-server computing, in which desktop machines (clients) are linked to a brawnier hub machine (server). The server typically has a powerful processor and a large amount of information storage, which is shared by the clients. The desktop clients have their own processing power.
OS/2, being powerful and demanding, makes a great deal of sense for the server system. Windows, in turn, is better suited for the desktop client. Since OS/2 is compatible with Windows, some companies might consider OS/2 on the server and Windows on the client. That's why both systems might make sense for some companies.
For a company with more than a few PC's, the hardware costs for moving to Windows or OS/2 can be substantial; for corporations with hundreds or thousands of PC's, the cost is enormous. But the hardware costs are peanuts compared with the costs of software, labor, training, maintenance and support.
Any change of operating system requires a new investment in software, since the older programs will not take advantage of the new operating system features. In most cases, a simple software upgrade is required, which is less expensive than buying a new copy of the application. In other cases, as in moving to Windows from DOS, or to OS/2 from Windows or DOS, the user must buy new applications at a probable cost of several hundred dollars per copy.
Ouch.
Then too, new Windows users report that it takes weeks, even months, before they feel comfortable with the system and its commands. If an office has the luxury of a systems support staff, that staff can count on being busy with training classes and handholding for some time. Companies may experience a drop in productivity while their workers learn new ways to do their jobs. It is difficult to assess the costs of lost productivity, or added maintenance and support. But start with this: Is there enough flexibility in your own work day to absorb the hours, or days, it will take to learn new commands and applications?
Unless there is a compelling reason, sit back and enjoy the dueling ad campaigns , and wait a bit for the smoke to clear.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Stanford;
Students Elected To Seats on Council Hoping to Abolish It

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Taking anti-incumbency to an extreme, Stanford University students last week elected to their highest governing body, the four-member Council of Presidents, a slate of candidates who made only one campaign promise: to abolish the council.
The new council members, who call themselves the "I Prefer Not to Have a COP" slate, apparently benefited from a fake endorsement in The Stanford Daily, the campus newspaper. 
 The false endorsement, with the headline "COP? NOT," appeared in Monday's issue in place of an editorial endorsing another campus group, "Independents: A New Era."
The paper's editor in chief, Michael A. Laris, a senior from Pasadena, Calif., majoring in political science, said he wanted the culprits arrested. "It's not that The Daily can't take a joke, but I don't think people understand what kind of violation this is," Mr. Laris said. "A lot of people read The Daily really closely. This cuts into our credibility."
 
Call to the Printer
 Mr. Laris said he calls the printer, Fricke-Parks Press in Fremont, Calif., five nights a week to let the shift supervisor, Paul A. Fry, know when a courier has left with the issue.
Mr. Fry said that at about 5 A.M. Monday he received a call from someone identifying himself as Mike Laris. The caller told Mr. Fry he needed to change an editorial and asked him to hold the presses.
Mr. Fry said the printing company, which also prints The Daily Californian, the University of California at Berkeley's student newspaper, frequently fends off student pranksters. But he said the caller did a "reasonable enough job sounding like Mike." He stopped the press and waited for the changes.
When two young men arrived with the changes, Mr. Fry said, "We had our doubts for about a half a second.
"I happened to ask, 'Which one of you is Mike?' and they said he couldn't come, in such a way as to indicate that they resented the chore," he said.
"These two, they went to the method-acting school of political dirty tricks," he added.
The caller left Mr. Fry a phone number where he said he could be reached quickly. That number is the business phone of The Stanford Review, a politically conservative campus weekly. Detective Sgt. Richard C. Tipton of the Stanford police said The Review shares office space with several campus publications and the room is accessible to at least 100 students.
The Review's business manager, Christopher B. Grey, a sophomore psychology and economics major from La Jolla, Calif., denied that his staff had any part in the prank.
The perpetrators could be charged with false personage, which can be either a felony or a misdemeanor under California law, said Sergeant Tipton.
The four-member Council of Presidents serves in place of a traditional student body president. Each member receives a $4,000 annual stipend, an amount many students interviewed last week described as excessive.

HEADLINE: The Rich Get Richer;
And What to Do About It

 BODY:
On all sides, rich Americans are under attack. Shareholders want revenge for huge compensation packages paid to corporate executives. Congress wants to squeeze higher taxes out of millionaires. The Democrat Bill Clinton incites voters with his favorite statistic: The richest 1 percent of families got 60 percent of the increase in average family income between 1977 and 1989. 
 The actual figure, 70 percent, is even more startling. Historically, income gaps between the rich and poor have stayed fairly constant from one generation to the next. But in the 1980's, all that changed dramatically.
 
The Fact
 According to the Congressional Budget Office, the richest 20 percent of families took more than 100 percent of the growth in average family income. How could that be? The bottom 40 percent of the population actually lost ground. Even after correction or adjustment, the C.B.O. figures keep showing the same thing: In the last 15 years, the rich have gotten a lot richer.
How did so few capture so much? Some people, like Governor Clinton, blame Republican callousness in the Reagan-Bush years, or Congressional subservience to special interests. But those explanations don't explain this massive inequality. It spurted in the 1970's, when Jimmy Carter was President. Meanwhile, similar trends showed up in Europe and Canada.
Others blame foreign competition and the shift of production from manufacturing -- with lots of high-paying blue-collar jobs -- to service industries. But this argument is contradicted by data showing that most of the growing income inequality occurred within individual manufacturing and service industries, even those immune from foreign competition.
Yes, during the 1980's the stock market tripled and inflation-adjusted interest rates hit unprecedented levels, all favoring the rich. But it is wages and salaries that account for over three-quarters of family income -- and for most of the growing difference between rich and poor.
Between 1939 and 1975, the wage gap between high- and low-skilled workers barely changed. During the the 1980's, however, the gap doubled. At the start of the decade, college graduates with a few years of work experience were earning about 30 percent more than high school graduates; 10 years later, the gap was 60 percent.
 
The Reason
 Economists are increasingly persuaded that this rising inequality cannot be explained by anything as simple as greed, politics or foreigners. They look to something more deeply ingrained in modern industrialized economies -- call it technology for short.
The days when high school dropouts could earn high wages in manufacturing are gone. Modern economies more than ever require educated, skilled labor. That explanation ought to jolt people out of traditional remedies.
For one thing, tinkering with tax rates to favor the poor won't accomplish much. Studies show that even if Congress were prepared to jack up tax rates on the rich greatly while cutting taxes for the poor, the impact on income inequality would be trivial.
 
The Remedy
 But Government need not watch helplessly as income differences widen; it can act to narrow them. Consider the example of Canada. It experienced similar inequality trends in the 1980's. But Canada beefed up its anti-poverty programs and kept the poverty rate flat. In the U.S., it rose.
The modern industrial economy is calling out for skilled, educated workers. Government knows how to answer that call; and thus knows how to counter the widening income gap. The right way for Congress to respond is to promote the education of sophisticated workers.
That means massive new commitments to Head Start, to primary and secondary education, to training high school dropouts and welfare mothers, to more higher education of different kinds, to workplace training.
Like other Democrats, Bill Clinton is not bashful about bashing the rich. But his program nonetheless resonates because it turns on just such investments in people. One need not be a Clinton partisan to recognize that it is in every American's interest to create a new economic reality, one in which the rest of the population gets richer, too.
