PUB-DATE: April 19, 1992

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1217 words

HEADLINE: Playing It Safe;
The Paralysis of No-Pain Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In politics, 1992 seems to be the year of the ostrich. Most politicians are hiding their heads in the sand rather than addressing fundamental problems facing the country. And the few who raise the central issues do so at their peril.
Americans in the past have often put off action on difficult political problems. But what is different nowadays is that basic questions are not just going unresolved, they are hardly being discussed. 
 President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who is close to locking up the Democratic Presidential nomination, and even Ross Perot, the industrialist who is considering running for President as an independent, are ducking problems for which they cannot offer painless solutions. Congress is generally avoiding them too.
The one Presidential candidate who suggested that bitter medicine might be necessary, Paul E. Tsongas, fell by the wayside after the first month of primaries. Mr. Clinton savaged Mr. Tsongas in advertisements and speeches because the former Massachusetts Senator had advocated measures that would gradually raise the gasoline tax and reduce Social Security payments to the wealthiest. His stated goal was to restrain the vast consumption of fossil fuels and reduce the deficit.
 
Over Consuming
 Most politicians of both parties acknowledge that these are grave problems. Energy consumption per person in the United States is about double what it is in Europe and Japan. Almost half of the oil used in the United States is imported, up from just over one-quarter in 1985. Over-consumption is harming the environment, and the reliance on foreign oil is against the country's political, diplomatic and economic interests.
As for the budget deficit, at close to $400 billion this year, it is far and away the highest ever. The deficit will force the next generation to pay for today's profligacy.
But solutions to these problems would require some sacrifice from voters. Controlling energy usage would probably require that people change their driving habits and pay more for gasoline, which is now cheaper in the United States than bottled water.
Cutting the budget deficit would mean lower payments to the middle class or higher taxes, or both. About $700 billion, half the Federal budget, is now being spent on so-called entitlement programs that pay benefits to everyone who meets eligibility standards regardless of the total cost. Of this, only about one dollar in six goes to the poor. Most of the money is for Social Security, Medicare, farm supports and other payments that are awarded regardless of how well off the beneficiary is. But asking middle-class voters to relinquish some of their benefits seems to be out of the question.
Senator Warren B. Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican who has announced that he will not seek re-election because of his frustration over Congress's inability to confront the deficit, said such issues have lawmakers ducking, fearing opponents' exploitation.
"It has become increasingly easy," said Mr. Rudman in an interview, "to destroy a fine legislator with a series of very tightly drawn negative commercials."
Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House budget panel, said the problem of avoiding difficult subjects had worsened over the years. "Twenty years ago, the public expected discussion of the tough issues," he said. "But the Ronald Reagan legacy was not to tell people about what sacrifices have to be made but always to deliver good news and stick to a simple, 30-second message."
Few politicians today would dare utter John F. Kennedy's line about asking not what your country can do for you. Seven senators and more than 45 representatives have announced they will not run for re-election this year, and many cite disillusionment with a political system that accomplishes so little of value. To be sure, some who spoke this way, like Senator Tim Wirth, a 52-year-old Colorado Democrat, faced such tough races in November that they might well have lost. Others, like Representative Vin Weber, a 39-year-old Republican from Minnesota, were embarrassed by large numbers of overdrafts on their House bank account.
But some departing lawmakers are giving up safe seats, and the anguish in their voices is unmistakable. Senator Rudman, 61, is a case in point. "The system, the Government, this country, have become fundamentally flawed," he said. "Presidents and Congresses, Democrats and Republicans, have been unwilling to explain to the American people that there is no such thing as a free lunch. I do not want to be a part of this any longer."
This country has a knack for skirting big issues. The historian James MacGregor Burns has observed that the necessary steps against slavery that were apparent in the 1840's and 1850's were finally taken at a devastating price in the 1860's. The social welfare measures of the New Deal probably should have been adopted in the 1900's. Involvement with allies in collective security came after World War II instead of after World War I.
But slavery, social welfare and collective security were matters of political debate long before they were acted on. In the campaign four years ago, the rising number of savings and loan failures, now recognized as the worst financial disaster since the Great Depression, was all but ignored by Mr. Bush, his opponent, Michael S. Dukakis, and those running for Congress.
Even today, politicians refuse to face up to the matter. Congress left for its two-week spring break without appropriating essential additional money for the savings and loan rescue. Lawmakers will have to allocate the money eventually, but they seemed to feel that if they put it off, they will not have to explain it to their constituents during the recess. The delay could increase the ultimate cost of the bailout by $200 million.
To take another example, economists and political scientists almost without exception believe that the country allocates too great a share of resources to the old and too little to the young. About one child in five in the United States is growing up in poverty; it is about one in 10 for the elderly. But the Federal Government spends about 10 times as much for each person over 65 as it does for each person under 18. The Republican staff of the House Budget Committee has calculated that after inflation, Federal expenditures on children -- for education, health care and other programs -- fell by 4 percent from 1978 to 1987, as spending on the elderly, mostly for Social Security and Medicare, rose by 52 percent.
Much of the public money spent on children comes from state and local governments -- for public schools, for instance. But social policy experts say this does not make up for the disparity in Federal expenditures.
Politicians may agree that a change is needed. But nothing happens. Old people vote and children do not.
Presumably, the time will someday be ripe to deal with issues like the deficit, energy and the needs of children, but based on the election campaign so far, that time is not at hand. "Short of a crisis," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, "it's hard for people to look at immediate, certain pain and accept that for uncertain gains in the future."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Union Movement Loses Another Big One

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A prominent economist described the future of the labor movement this way: "American trade unionism is slowly being limited in influence by changes which destroy the basis on which it is erected.
"The changes, occupational and technological, which checked the advance of unionism in the last decade appear likely to continue in the same direction." 
 The assessment seems apt for labor today, a movement whipsawed by foreign competition, prolonged recession and emboldened companies like Caterpillar Inc., which last week ended a five-month strike on its own terms. But the remarks were made 60 years ago in a speech by George Barnett, the president of the American Economics Association. It was during the Great Depression, a conservative Republican Administration was in power, and the courts were antagonistic to unions.
 
Too Weak for All
 Fortunately for labor, Mr. Barnett turned out to be dead wrong. Or perhaps more accurately, he turned out to be way ahead of his time. For in the intervening years the labor movement peaked, and has now declined to the point where some experts think its weakness is a danger not only to itself but to the economy and the very industries that have triumphed over it. Three years after Barnett's 1932 speech, Congress passed the landmark Wagner Act, which gave the New Deal's benediction to union organizing drives. This spurred labor to historic victories, including the United Auto Workers' daring 1937 sitdown strike in Flint, Mich., which helped force mighty General Motors to recognize the then-puny union.
It was a time when unions were hailed as the friend of the working man, pushing for decent wages and Social Security. Membership soared from 3 million in 1932 to 10 million in 1942, and 16 million in 1952. After World War II, labor's bargaining power helped build the world's wealthiest working class, as factories churned to satisfy deferred consumerist dreams. The world has changed hugely since, especially for the labor movement. With 16.6 million members, unions have about as many members as four decades ago; if George Barnett's pessimistic prognosis were made today, it could be correct.
The labor movement is coming off what might have been its worst decade. In 1981 President Reagan broke the air-controllers union and helped create an environment in which union-busting became a common tactic for management. Some of the most powerful unions were squeezed by new forces including foreign competition and deregulation. Many unions had become a victim of their own success -- the fat wages they won made their industries easy prey for foreign competitors. As a result, employment in unionized industries plummeted.
Union membership has fallen by more than 3 million since 1980, and just 16 percent of American workers belong to unions. That is down from 23 percent in 1980 and almost 35 percent in the 1950's.
But just when it appeared that labor's fortunes had bottomed out, the Caterpillar strike erupted in Peoria, Ill., pitting the U.A.W. against the world's largest producer of earth-moving machinery. For five months, workers resisted Caterpillar's offer of a two-tier wage system and a less generous health plan, among other things. The strike's significance rose to a new level two weeks ago when Caterpillar said it would begin hiring permanent replacement workers. With unemployment high, that was a terrifying threat for the 12,000 strikers.
 
'Cat' with Attitude
 So on Tuesday the U.A.W. swallowed its pride and told the strikers to return to work under the terms offered by Caterpillar, while the union continues to negotiate. All in all, the strike was one of the biggest developments in labor since the air controllers walked out in 1981. Caterpillar, a symbol of industry, had quit cooperating with labor and favored a take-no-prisoners confrontation. "Cat was looking around and saying, 'There isn't a strong labor movement elsewhere in the country, so why do we have to put up with one?' " said Thomas Geoghegan, a Chicago-based labor lawyer.
Some labor experts argue that the weakening of labor is helping drag down the American economy. These analysts say labor's losses are helping turn America into a low-wage, low-skill economy. Strong unions, they say, create a durable relationship between employer and employee, in which the company treats its workers as long-term assets that need to be trained and cherished. When unions are weak, they argue, many companies treat workers as expendable commodities.
"In responding to the competitive challenges we face, we must ask, 'Do we respond by trying to become competitive with the Mexican economy and pay low wages or do we follow the route of Germany and Japan?' " said Harold Stack, a labor expert at Wayne State University in Detroit. "We seem to favor the low-wage, low-skill approach of Mexico, rather than the high-wage, high-skill approach of Germany and Japan."
Friends of labor argue that the atrophying of unions is one factor behind what they call the shrinking of the middle class. If unions were more powerful and could demand higher wages, they say, this would spur consumer demand and drive the economy forward.
But many conservative economists say that if unions win higher wages without increasing productivity, that will make for a poorer, not richer America. They say one reason so many steel and auto plants have been closed and so many jobs lost is that unions won hefty wage gains far outstripping productivity gains called for.
Some people are wondering whether the marginalization of labor portends a return to America's roots. In this view, the boom of labor for the four decades after 1935 may prove to be a brief parenthesis in the history of the land of hard-scrabble entrepreneurs."
In this view, the future holds only more trouble for unions. Many of he trends that have hurt unions -- the surge of foreign competition, the mushrooming of services, and the rise of small, agile firms like those in Silicon Valley -- are expected to continue. In addition, managements have become far more sophisticated in providing benefit packages so that workers conclude they can get what they need without unions. But many union officials are confident that labor will come back.
"We will see a more mature workforce that holds steady long term jobs." said Rudy Oswald, chief economist for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "These people will be looking more and more toward unions to achieve what they need at the workplace."

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK REGION;
Jersey Looks for Money To Restore the Shore

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
The storms that raked New Jersey's shores in October and January did more than damage sea walls, homes and businesses. They laid bare the state's lack of commitment to the protection of its greatest natural resource -- its oceanfront.
After the storms left more than $100 million in damage, local officials, businessmen and property owners discovered that New Jersey hadn't a penny earmarked for protecting the 127-mile shore. Over the years the Legislature has fought over who should pay for the sea walls, jetties and sand replacement, without resolution. The issue pits developers, shore business owners and homeowners against environmentalists, and shore legislators against those from other parts of the state. An important aspect of the debate is the impact on tourism, New Jersey's second largest industry, generating $15 billion in economic activity annually. 
 "We had been going from budget to budget, storm to storm without great effort," said Scott A. Weiner, the state's commissioner of Environmental Protection and Energy. "We now recognize what a fragile resource our beachfront is, and if we don't protect it, we are going to lose it."
In recent years New Jersey has seen a building boom along the coast, despite state attempts to contain it. The development has complicated efforts to control the ocean's impact on the coastline, something environmentalists argue will prove futile in the long term and increasingly expensive in the short term.
"What we're talking about is not shore protection but real-estate protection," said D. W. Bennett, executive director of the American Littoral Society, a national environmental group based in the state. "People think we have narrow beaches because of erosion, but the beaches are narrow because we've built too close to the ocean." Shorefront businesses and homeowners should contribute the lion's share to any shore protection fund, argue Mr. Bennett and other environmentalists, since they are the chief beneficiaries and, in many cases, deny the public access to the beaches in front of their properties.
Several years ago the state enacted a law requiring developers to obtain permission from the Environmental Protection Department before building along the coast in order to prevent overdevelopment and overloading sewage treatment systems. A loophole in the law, however, allowed projects with 24 units or less without state approval. As these projects began appearing side by side, especially in Sea Bright, Gov. Thomas K. Kean ordered a moratorium on further building. Later, When the Legislature failed to close the loophole, the courts dissolved the order.
The last state budget to include money for shore protection was adopted in 1988, and it appropriated a modest $12 million. That money is long gone, as are the proceeds of a $50 million bond issue approved by voters in 1983. Gov. Jim Florio found $3.2 million in a general emergency fund after the October storm to strengthen seawalls and bulkheads and repair dunes and beaches in nine areas, including Sea Bright and Spring Lake, that appear to be in the greatest danger of severe damage from subsequent storms.
The Army Corps of Engineers has finally begun pumping sand onto Monmouth County beaches as part of a project that Congress initially approved in the 1950's. The chief stumbling block, Federal officials have said, has been the state's reluctance to share the cost, about 35 percent of the more than $250 million that is expected to be spent over the next decade or so. The first phase of sand replacement off Sea Bright and Monmouth Beach is to cost $63.5 million, with the state's share $16.6 million and local governments' $5.5 million.
To maintain a 100-foot beach, the corps must build a 140-foot beach, since the engineers estimate that 40 feet of sand will erode every six years on average and require additional replenishment. A broader "feeder beach" will also be built up along the north side of the Manasquan inlet so tides pick up sand and deposit it along the beachfront. Some ideas for stable, recurring funding include adding five cents to the tolls at the exits on the Garden State Parkway near the shore and some combination of special assessments on shore homeowners and businesses and appropriations from general taxes.
In February Governor Florio convened a "shore summit" that brought many groups, including business owners, environmentalists, scientists, planners, fishermen, real estate brokers and elected officials, into the same room for the first time. Mr. Florio told the gathering: "We can't afford to stick our heads in the sand anymore, because pretty soon there won't be any sand." The conference produced a number of reports on beach access, water quality, land use planning, tourism and economic development, shore protection strategies and funding.
Efforts to get the public involved have started in the Legislature and through the efforts of the Jersey Shore Partnership, a new organization that includes officials from the four shore counties and representatives of 32 businesses and four colleges and universities. The partnership will hold a public hearing Wednesday in Toms River.
Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos, Republican of Middletown, has already asked for a $15 million appropriation for shore protection in the 1992-93 state budget and, despite predictions of a budget gap of more than $1 billion, he has won the support of Governor Florio and the Republican leadership of the appropriations committee.
"This a problem for all New Jerseyans, " Mr. Kyrillos said. "Protecting the shore is not just good sense because it supports our economy and provides recreation and pleasure; the shore is part of our culture."

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK REGION;
Dedicated Taxes: Good Policy or Bad Planning?

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Not so long ago, New York City officials promoted their plan for a property tax increase by arguing that the cost for a typical homeowner would equal the price of a movie and ice cream for four. These days, they skip the soft soap and just promise in writing to hire more police.
Facing voters tired of record tax increases and grappling with growing civic needs, New York's leaders, like others around the nation, have moved increasingly to earmark new taxes or fees for particular programs, on the theory that people will be more willing to pay if their money is dedicated to programs they want or need. 
 In the last year, the city has won higher taxes on property and personal income to expand the Police Department. Now ideas are afoot for new tolls or taxes on cars or gasoline to finance bridge repairs, and new fees on householders to bear the cost of garbage collection. The City Council leadership wants to reserve a portion of residential property taxes, which it has strived for years to keep low, to support education. One visitor to Mayor David N. Dinkins's open house at City Hall last summer even suggested a new $5 tax to pay for planting trees.
Governments have long set aside some general tax revenues for special requirements, like paying off bonds, or raised special taxes to pay for related general needs, like using gas taxes to finance highway maintenance. But now, experts say, they are more likely to siphon off broad taxing powers to pay for programs not intrinsically linked to the tax, like earmarking personal income tax receipts for police.
"As confidence in the public sector has diminished, while the desire of political figures to please particular constituencies has not, one way of doing something new is this concept of the dedicated revenue source from some external element in society for the benefit of some targeted program," said Dave Kehler of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey, a non-partisan consulting group in Princeton.
Not all such taxes are popular, of course, and imposing tolls on the free East River bridges is still viewed as such a sacrilege that only the bravest whisper the idea.
And so far, the proportion of dedicated taxes has remained relatively low in New York City, with only about 16 percent of the overall yield from two dozen local taxes earmarked for specific uses, and with most of that going to the traditional purpose: paying off long-term bonds. In California, nearly 40 percent of the state's entire budget is now dedicated to specific uses, through a combination of ballot propositions and legislation.
 
Funding the Basics
 But some worry that what seems like the easiest way to win taxes may become the only way. If the trend continues, there could well come a time when specific taxes or fees in New York would finance what were once considered the most basic municipal services -- police, sanitation, schools, street maintenance and water supply and sewers. That would leave general taxes supporting mostly social programs that many voters find less appealing and might balk at backing.
"Most services that government produces do not have the unique quality of being consumed only by the person who pays for them," said Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's Finance Commissioner. "Instead, they have the nature of what economists call a public good, like the notion that you benefit from having an educated citizenry whether your children are in public school or not. There are all kinds of things that only government can provide, and you need the most broadly based taxes to support them."
In fact, the move toward dedicated taxes and user fees has come partly because state and Federal laws and court decisions have already compelled the city to provide such specific levels of service for everything from prison inmates to homeless families that it must simply find a way to pay for them, whatever else it puts off. Sometimes, the cost is shared by the state or Federal government, so cutting such programs is not cost effective.
But precisely because New York's spending options are already so limited, some experts warn against limiting its revenue choices. "You want to give yourself some wiggle room," Ms. O'Cleireacain said. By the most conservative estimate, only about 40 percent of the city's $29 billion budget is under its direct control, after it pays the local share of welfare and Medicaid costs, pensions for retired workers and interest on bonds, and after it discounts state and Federal aid over which it has little control.
Moreover, while taxes or fees are often earmarked in the name of democracy, they are sometimes raised and spent by public authorities or appointed boards that are less susceptible to political pressure.
Wearing their policy hats, city officials bemoan dedicated taxes. But wearing their political hats, they support them, especially after anger at two years of local tax increases totaling more than $1.5 billion led Mr. Dinkins and the Council to promise a four-year freeze in property tax rates starting in July 1992.
"In a perfect budgeting world, dedicated taxes cause loads of problems, because they don't provide for the normal resource allocation decisions to be made on everything," said the Council's finance director, Marc V. Shaw, who has dreamed up several of them. "But the reality is that budgeting is not done in a perfect world."
Instead, Mr. Shaw said, politics plays a part and is supposed to, and just now politics dictates winning the confidence of the public by promises that taxes will be spent in certain ways. However, he argues that if taxes are won by pledging to spend them on certain goals, the public might be persuaded to free up the money for other purposes if it were convinced that officials had met the original goals effectively or if the goals needed to be changed. But Mr. Kehler said dedicated taxes "perniciously tend to freeze particular programs at particular levels, even if priorities may switch."
Mr. Dinkins himself is already facing that tension, locked into higher and higher spending for the police, even as reported crime has begun to decline. The worst case is a kind of government by auto-pilot.
"If you have very little control over your spending, and very little control over your revenue, then it doesn't matter who you elect," Ms. O'Cleireacain said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Some New York City taxes are earmarked to pay for police. At left, a new class of officers at graduation last year. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

Money With Labels

* All money estimated to be gained from the new city lottery game, $5 million, is reserved for criminal justice

More dedication
 With the city's programs and resources already stretched thin, plans to improve even the most basic government services frequently specify both how the money would be raised and exactly what it could be used for. HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Labor Party Tries To Imagine a Future

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Nearly 60 percent of the voters in Britain's general election 10 days ago did not choose Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Party, but still it won a 21-seat majority in the House of Commons, the Conservatives' fourth victory since 1979. If the opposition Labor Party couldn't win in the worst recession since the 1930's, many of its supporters are now asking, when could it ever win?
As the party began its painful reappraisal last week, its leader, Neil Kinnock, announced that he would resign to make way for a successor to be elected July 18. But the leadership question is not the most fundamental one. Neither is the issue of whether the British electoral system is fair to smaller parties like the opposition Liberal Democrats. The winner-take-all system gave them only the 20 seats in the House of Commons in the constituencies where they had come in first, 3 percent of the total, although nationwide they had won nearly 18 percent of the vote. The broader question is whether there is a future for the traditional left at all, in a society transformed more than anyone realized by a decade of Thatcherism. 
 It is only slight exaggeration to say that politics, like everything else in Britain, was largely a matter of class before Margaret Thatcher became Prime Minister in 1979. Conservatives and their supporters largely came from the privileged, propertied classes, and those who doffed their hats to them. Labor drew its support from the working, unionized classes that viewed themselves as adversaries of privilege, and of the privileged. You were born into one or the other, and for the most part you stayed where you were, your life long.
Thatcherism radically challenged these assumptions and speeded post-industrial economic change that reduced the role of heavy industry and labor unions in Britain's economy. It also challenged the notion that government was the most efficient means of looking after people left behind in the competition. Mrs. Thatcher's governments began selling public housing to those who lived in it, encouraging people who wanted to to use private doctors rather than the National Health Service, and privatizing publicly held industries by selling shares to the public.
Go for it, Thatcherism told the British; you have only yourselves to blame if you fail. It was strong medicine, but by the end of the 1970's, Britain had become the sick man of Europe, and it was ready to swallow. The British economy boomed in the late 1980's, but then Mrs. Thatcher went too far and forced through an unpopular "poll tax" for local government services, insisting that rich and poor pay the same amount in every community.
By 1990, a reaction had set in. Mrs. Thatcher was thrown out by her party, and her successor, John Major, began reducing the dosage. Labor had veered far left in the early 1980's, but Mr. Kinnock had brought it back, and this year he offered middle-of-the-road policies that looked, superficially, much like Mr. Major's kinder, gentler version of Thatcherism.
But there was a difference.
Labor would have used taxation to push the pendulum back the other way and effect a modest redistribution of national income from rich to poor. The definition of "rich" began at 21,000 -- $36,500 -- a year. For the 80 percent or so of people who made less, government would administer the benefits, through investment of new tax money in the health service, roads, railways and other public services.
As it turned out, only 34.2 percent of those who voted wanted to return to this traditional approach. According to one post-election survey by Gallup, only 44 percent of manual workers and their families voted Labor, perhaps because many are increasingly nonunionized and inclined to hope that they, too, can make 21,000 some day.
So, many believe that Labor's crisis will not be resolved merely by a change of leader, or a closer alignment with the Liberal Democrats, who aim not to put Labor in power but to put it out of business. Three men are running so far for the leadership.
John Smith, a 53-year-old Scottish lawyer and former Trade Minister, was groping last week for a better way for Labor to persuade the voters that compassion is not a zero-sum game. "We've got to persuade people who are prosperous, and who rightly want to remain so, that a poor standard of living for others is not necessary for them to enjoy a good standard," he said.
 
A New Agenda?
 Bryan Gould, a 53-year-old New Zealand native who is a former diplomat and television broadcaster, proposes what he calls a more radical agenda, one that would expand employee stock ownership plans and encourage greater economic growth as a better source of increased government income than higher taxes. A skeptic about the European Community, he would also devalue the pound against other European currencies so that Britain could lower interest rates -- the prime rate here is now about 10.5 percent -- that have dampened the economy since the late 1980's.
Ken Livingstone, a leftist Labor legislator who rejects Mr. Kinnock's brand of pragmatism, said last week that he would run for the leadership on a platform of devaluation, unilateral nuclear disarmament and big defense cuts.
Others on the left, particularly in the Charter 88 movement for constitutional reform, argue that Labor needs a whole new agenda. This would embrace causes like greater autonomy for Scotland, Wales and other British regions and communities that the Conservatives, for all their talk of individual freedom, have governed more tightly from London than ever before.
Britain is one of the most centralized states in Europe, they argue, with no written constitution or bill of rights to guarantee protection against the abuse of government power. A new politics focused on issues like citizens' rights, the environment and Britain's future role in Europe is needed, they say, and the left should provide it.
But the debate is only beginning, and the answers seem a long way off. Until they become clearer, the Conservatives look set to be the "natural party of government" for quite a while yet.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The U.S. Takes a Serious Look at Ukraine

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
While attention was focused last week on President Boris N. Yeltsin's agreement with conservative legislators in Moscow over Western terms for aid to Russia, an equally important development was quietly unfolding in Kiev. A high-level American team was laying the foundations of the first American foreign policy toward Ukraine. After months of dealing with Ukraine as an afterthought to relations with Russia, the Bush Administration has concluded that it must have a Ukraine policy, as unique and tailored as policies toward France, Poland or Germany.
The mission to Kiev, led by Under Secretary of Defense Paul D. Wolfowitz, was prompted by an acknowledgement by American officials that the way they had been handling Ukraine was not working. Washington had tended to deal with Ukraine primarily as an aspect of arms control problems between America and Russia. Establishment of diplomatic relations with Ukraine was made conditional on President Leonid M. Kravchuk's agreeing to transfer all of the nuclear weapons on his territory to Russia and maintaining a "responsible security policy" that would not aggravate relations with Moscow or anyone else.
 
An Interest in Stability
 To be sure, the United States has an overwhelming interest in focusing on Russia, since without stability and economic development there the whole Eurasian landmass would be shaky. Moreover, collecting all former Soviet nuclear weapons under the single control of Moscow makes some sense in security terms. Roman Szporluk, a professor of Ukrainian history at Harvard, said: "Empires like to deal with empires -- there is something neat about it. But to treat Ukraine as though it still belonged to the sphere of Russia was a mistake." 
Initially, Mr. Kravchuk, eager for ties with Washington, played along with all of its demands. But as the Ukrainians began to feel that Washington was not paying enough attention to them as an independent people, they began making noises about delaying the transfer of nuclear weapons back to Russia. Then, last month, American officials say, Ukraine began to tell them that Mr. Yeltsin and his reformists were eventually going to fail and be replaced by traditional hard-line types in Russia. Therefore, the Ukrainians questioned the wisdom of turning over weapons to their long-time Russian rivals and overlords. So half-way through the missile transfers, they slammed on the brakes.
"The Ukrainians started complaining that all there was to their relationship with us was whether they would agree to return their nukes to Russia," an American official said. "They said: 'What about Ukraine?' We decided that the only way we were going to get what we wanted on the big issues was by dealing with the Ukraine in terms of its own concerns."
In Kiev, the visiting Americans argued that Ukraine cannot operate an independent nuclear arsenal -- the keys and codes remain in Moscow -- and it would not give them real security anyway, if push ever came to shove with Russia. By holding onto these weapons, the Americans said, Ukraine would undermine the only relationship that could really bring security -- one with the West based on recognition of Ukraine as a democratic, peaceable member of Europe. American officials signaled that they would be ready to talk about limited military cooperation once Ukraine resumed its missile withdrawal -- which, on Thursday, it agreed to do.
This treatment of Ukraine may presage an even larger shift in American policy. Since last year's Soviet coup, the primary American agenda regarding the former Soviet Union seemed to focus on how the West could promote a stable transformation to free-market economies in the successor states, on the theory that without democracy and development these new governments will be neither stable nor legitimate. On that front, Washington could draw encouragement last week when Russia's conservative legislators abandoned an effort to force the resignation of Mr. Yeltsin's Government and proved unable to slow his economic reform program.
But Robert Legvold, a Columbia University expert on Russian affairs, argues that this focus overlooks the fact that with the disintegration of the Soviet Empire a whole new regional system of states has been created in Eurasia, with complex relationships and ancient animosities that make the do-si-do of Arab-Israeli politics seem simple by comparison.
"The disintegration of the Soviet Union has created a new neighborhood," said Mr. Legvold. "The problem with Western policy is that while it has begun to develop a more coherent approach to the transformation of societies inside the former Soviet Union, it has barely begun to develop a coherent policy for maintaining stability of this new neighborhood."
During the cold war, the main security threat from this neighborhood was the real or potential strength of the Soviet Union -- its ability to project nuclear power abroad. Today, the main threat is real or potential weakness -- the inability of the successor states of the Soviet empire to manage their feuds, and the threat posed for regional stability. What this requires, said Mr. Legvold, "is a post-Warsaw Pact security regime that insures this new neighborhood is characterized by cooperative institutions, not competitive alliances."
The Ukraine-Russia axis is the key. The national and ethnic tensions between Russia and Ukraine, two massively armed republics, could tear Eurasia apart. For one thing, 12 million of Ukraine's 52 million people are ethnic Russians, while several areas of Russia, as far east as Siberia, have majority Ukrainian populations. "Without overstating it," said one American official, "this is the place where the whole thing could come crashing down, and where we would have no choice but to get in the middle of it." The Russia-Ukraine dispute is not Nagorno-Karabakh, he added, referring to the enclave in dispute between Armenia and Azerbaijan. A Russia-Ukraine clash cannot be contained, he said, and therefore "there is a rather compelling case for pre-emptive diplomacy."

HEADLINE: PANAMA QUESTIONS U.S. BASE CLOSURE

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, April 15

 BODY:
With less than eight years to go until the United States is due to end nearly a century of military presence in Panama, many Panamanians are beginning to doubt the wisdom of letting the 10 remaining bases close and the troops depart.
In today's rapidly changing world, they say, they are no longer as nationalistic as they once were and the United States is no longer as colonialistic. That has removed the tensions that led to killings, angry demonstrations and flag burnings in the United States-occupied area bordering the Panama Canal in the 1950's and 60's. 
 Gen. George A. Joulwan, chief of the United States Southern Command, based here, and Bernard W. Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs both say that the United States is not seeking to stay.
 
Zero Troops
 "We intend to comply with the treaties, which means that we have a plan that takes us to zero by noon on Dec. 31, 1999," General Joulwan said in an interview. Plans for the transfer to Panama of the canal itself are proceeding on schedule, according to Panamanian and United States officials.
But a number of Panamanian politicians and officials said they believe something will be worked out to keep some United States presence here.
"In private, the State Department implies another thing from what it says publicly," said Leo Gonzalez, a member of the National Legislature who supports keeping the bases. "The State Department always says it's not going to do something until it decides to do it. A week before the invasion in 1989, it was saying the United States would never invade Panama."
The United States invaded in December 1989 after a period of increasing tensions that led the then Panamanian strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to declare that a "state of war" existed. General Noriega surrendered to United States troops and was taken to Florida, where he was convicted on charges of cocaine trafficking, racketeering and money laundering.
A senior United States official who did not want to be identified said there was "evidence of interest" by both Governments in retaining at least some bases.
 
U.S. Is Reluctant
 United States officials are reluctant to raise the issue. The 1977 Panama Canal treaties are specific in stating that the United States commits itself to turn over the canal and the adjacent land and properties before the year 2000 and that all troops will go.
The implementing legislation for the treaties does give the two Governments the right to re-examine the question of the bases, but a United States official said that would produce a "first-class political dogfight" in Panama, so Washington does not intend to take the initiative.
Much of the interest in keeping the bases appears linked to concern about the loss of jobs by 5,400 Panamanian civilians who now work on the bases and the economic benefits for Panama from the jobs and spending by United States troops. General Joulwan's staff said the benefits were conservatively estimated at $264 million; Mr. Gonzalez said he thought the actual value to the Panamanian economy was closer to $600 million.
As things now stand, both Governments are moving toward the complete turnover of the canal and the 500 square miles surrounding it, including 4,800 structures on the 10 bases and other installations, on or before the 1999 deadline.
 
Panama Commission Named
 A commission named by President Guillermo Endara and headed by a leading businessman, J. J. Vallarino Jr., is working on legislation to govern use and development of what are being called the "reverted properties."
Mr. Vallarino said he had calculated that "with a good plan, the area, after development, could be worth $25 billion in market terms." He said expressions of interest in buying or leasing property in the former Canal Zone had come from universities in Panama and the United States and from business groups in Asia.
Pentagon officials have drafted a plan providing for the phased withdrawal of United States troops and transfer of bases and other military installations to Panama between now and 1999.
General Joulwan, who has discussed the plan with President Endara, said it contemplates the withdrawal of about 4,000 of the 10,000 United States troops in Panama before the end of 1995 and "some major turnovers of property" at the same time.
Panamanian Government officials say that while President Endara seemed interested in re-opening the bases issue, he did not want to do it during his term, which ends in 1994.
A recent poll found that 77.5 percent of Panamanians surveyed wanted to renegotiate the matter of the bases. A majority indicated they would like to see Panama rent back some of the bases to the United States.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Racial Politics;
In South Carolina, a Tale of Campaign Trickery

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., April 15

 BODY:
Rod Shealy, a South Carolina Republican political consultant, will go on trial here on April 27 on campaign finance charges stemming from a bogus Congressional candidacy in 1990. Mr. Shealy recruited a black man facing felony charges to run for office with the intention of attracting a large white voter turnout.
The charge Mr. Shealy faces is a misdemeanor carrying penalties comparable to those for littering. But to many in the state, both Democrats and Republicans, the accusation speaks volumes about a style of South Carolina politics in which some people take peculiar pleasure in skulduggery and dirty tricks and shamelessly exploit racial differences and racism in the pursuit of victory. 
 Earl Black, a professor of political science at the University of South Carolina, said the case had a particularly discordant echo in the state that was home to Harry Dent, the political strategist who is considered one of the architects of Richard Nixon's 1968 Southern strategy of captializing on the anger of whites over civil rights advances by blacks.
One of Mr. Dent's protege's was Lee Atwater, the Republican campaigner who raised the hardball form of politics to new levels. Mr. Atwater, who died last year, was in charge of the George Bush campaign team whose research into Michael S. Dukakis's record discovered the case of Willie Horton, a black felon who committed violent crimes while on furlough from prison.
 
Shealy in Atwater Army
 Mr. Shealy said he considers himself "one of a whole army of people who learned a style of aggressive politics" from Mr. Atwater. He says it would be "blasphemy" to compare himself with Mr. Atwater, who became Republican national chairman after Mr. Bush was elected President. But in the views of some people, the 38-year-old Mr. Shealy has exceeded even Mr. Atwater's tactics.
Mr. Atwater simply put Willie Horton and any racist reaction he might provoke on television; Mr. Shealy put the technique into the voting booth.
It was not the first time that Mr. Shealy's name had come up in connection with political tricks or exploitation of racial divisions, said a number of people in both the Democratic and Republican parties.
State Senator Mike Rose, a Republican, said Mr. Shealy and a few other state party leaders were giving the party a bad name with racially divisive tactics and "pernicious political tricks" aimed not only at Democrats but also at Republicans like himself who opposed them.
 
Trying to Help His Sister
 The case against Mr. Shealy goes back to 1990, when he was trying to help his sister, State Senator Sherry Martschink of the Charleston area, in her campaign for the Republican nomination for Lieutenant Governor. That year a veteran black State Senator, Theo Mitchell, was making a strong bid for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
Late in the primary season, a first-term white Democratic State Senator from the Charleston area, Ernie Passalaigue, entered the gubernatorial primary race. Mr. Shealy theorized that this would lead many white voters who wanted to stop Mr. Mitchell to opt to vote in the Democratic primary rather than in the Republican race, as is permitted by state law. As a result, support for white Republican candidates, including his sister, would be siphoned off, Mr. Shealy feared.
 
'I Played Tit for Tat'

"They had their great white hope and he came from our low country area, where my sister was popular," Mr. Shealy said in an interview. "So I played tit for tat and orchestrated a black guy's candidacy in the Republican primary. I didn't care what black guy. It was all a ploy."
Mr. Shealy, with the help of former Representative Robert Kohn, recruited Benjamin J. Hunt, a 28-year-old unemployed Charleston man, to run against Representative Arthur Ravenel Jr., a Republican incumbent. This would have the effect of keeping white voters in the Republican primary in at least one of South Carolina's six Congressional districts.
According to Dick Harpootlian, the prosecutor in the case, Mr. Shealy paid $500 directly to Mr. Hunt and $2,414 in filing fees with money from an unreported $5,000 donation that he solicited from a major hazardous-waste hauler in the name of his sister's campaign. Technically, Mr. Shealy is charged with failing to report this contribution, since paying someone to run for office did not become a violation of state law until this year.
If he is convicted, he could face a maximum sentence of 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine. Under the law recently passed by the State Legislature, paying someone to run for office carries a one-year prison sentence.
Mr. Shealy distributed a campaign mailing that included a picture of Mr. Hunt beside a picture of Mr. Ravenel and text saying that while Mr. Hunt had conducted a quiet campaign, it was conceivable that he would have several thousand supporters quietly waiting in ambush.
Mr. Hunt has since been described as an alcoholic and drug dealer who at the time was under indictment for drug sales. He received about 2,000 votes, or 10 percent, in the primary in June 1990. He is now serving a five-year sentence in state prison.
But Mr. Shealy's sister, Senator Martschink, lost the primary for Lieutenant Governor to Henry McMaster, who then lost to the Democratic incumbent, Nick Theodore.
Mr. Kohn was later caught up in the widespread investigation of corruption among elected officials in the state and pleaded guilty to charges of accepting money in exchange for his support of legislation. He is awaiting sentencing.
 
Involvement No Surprise
 Mr. Shealy's involvement does not surprise State Senator Mitchell, who went on to win the 1990 Democratic primary but lose in the general election to Gov. Carroll Campbell, the incumbent. He recalls being approached by Mr. Shealy during the 1990 race with the suggestion that he and Senator Martschink engage in "staged bickering."
Mr. Shealy suggested that by championing a black point of view, Mr. Mitchell could enhance his standing with black voters while Mrs. Martschink could champion a white viewpoint and gain more favor with whites, Mr. Mitchell says.
"I rejected the idea and at the time I didn't even want to believe that he was suggesting that I deliberately polarize things racially," Mr. Mitchell said.
Nor did the charges against Mr. Shealy surprise students at the University of South Carolina who were familiar with his satiric "Gamecock Fever," a football season publication that carried slurs against black, Asian and Hispanic students and that featured a character called "Cockwheat," patterned after the Buckwheat character from old films.
Last fall, student leaders asked him to cease the racial and ethnic references. Manish Shrivastava, then the student body president at the university, said Mr. Shealy's response was to laugh at the complaints.
Other people, like State Senator Rose and State Representative Jimmy Bailey, suggest that Mr. Shealy has been involved in other dirty tricks and bogus candidacies.
Mr. Shealy acknowledged that he had "orchestrated other candidacies" in the state that were intended more as "distractions" than legitimate efforts, but he added that there was nothing illegal about it.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Pennsylvania;
After Time Off, Clinton Finds Campaign Trail a Little Smoother

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, April 18

 BODY:
Bill Clinton laughed. He waved a couple of bunches of broccoli, President Bush's most-hated vegetable. He walked with the Mayor. Then he flew from Philadelphia to Pittsburgh, put on a Pirates baseball jacket and blue jeans and did it all over again.
There is an art to walking down the street in a Presidential campaign. When it is done right, Mr. Clinton looks like a man of the people, offering snippets from his standard speech as he fields questions along the way. But sometimes the unexpected happens, as it did today when he was greeted by jeering supporters of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., who were waiting at the corner of 21st Street and Penn Avenue. 
 They yelled "Jerry! Jerry!" for several minutes, blocking prized camera angles with Brown campaign signs, before the Clinton partisans had the presence of mind to whip up a few cheers of "We Want Bill!"
Frank Greer, the Clinton campaign's media adviser, who was on hand to film commercials, rushed into the crowd at one point and earnestly advised one Brown supporter that such tactics did not work.
But if that was the worst problem the Arkansas Governor would encounter on an otherwise smooth week's return to the campaign trail, Mr. Clinton and his staff were relieved.
Although opinion polls continued to suggest that Mr. Clinton has a way to go before he wins voters' hearts as well as their minds, the Governor's advisers said that he scored points this week by challenging Mr. Bush on education and economic policy and that his last major Democratic opponent, Mr. Brown, has been largely drowned out.
"If their strategy is to crowd us out on the issues, it's a big mistake," Mr. Clinton's deputy campaign manager, George Stephanopoulos, said of the White House's decision to schedule major announcements on the same days that Mr. Clinton delivers major policy speeches. "Because every time he does that, he calls attention to what he hasn't done."
Mr. Clinton especially appeared to enjoy putting Mr. Bush on the defensive. After six days off the road that he spent nursing his strained vocal cords at home in Little Rock, Mr. Clinton seemed largely recovered from the battering he took in the weeks leading up to the New York primary.
He has also tried to minimize a potential conflict with Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, a Democrat who opposes abortion rights and has said he sees no reason to endorse Mr. Clinton when polls show that many Democrats wish there were other choices.
As Mr. Clinton strolled past shoppers at an outdoor market today before attending a baseball game between the Pirates and the Philadelphia Phillies, he said that his ability to win the Pennsylvania primary on April 28 should not be hurt by Mr. Casey's disaffection, just as he was unhurt by not having an endorsement by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York.
"I won in New York and Governor Cuomo didn't take a position during the New York primary," he said. "And I've won in many other states where the governors didn't."
"And my wife's family's from Scranton," he added. "That ought to count for something."
But everywhere he goes, Mr. Clinton is asked about the issue of his character and whether he can persuade voters to support him. Today the question came during an appearance on WPXI-TV, the NBC affiliate here. His response provided a look at what his aides have said will be the campaign's approach to defusing the issue in the long run.
"I think the American people, in looking at this character issue, ought to look at my record, my life and my commitment and ask themselves, who's told them that there's a character problem?" he said. "Not the governors who endorsed me, not the people that I grew up with, not the people who elected me Governor five times. Not the people who know me."

HEADLINE: Skipping Raises: A special report;
Blue-Collar Compromises in Pursuit of Job Security

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOOSTER, Ohio

 BODY:
On the edge of this prosperous rural town, rolling cornfields give way to neat ranch-style homes, well-groomed parks and unobtrusive, one-story factories. Here, Rubbermaid Inc., the town's biggest employer, boasts no layoffs since 1973.
Still, there is tension in Wooster as workers have traded raises for job security -- pressured to do so not only by Rubbermaid but by neighbors who fear the company might otherwise pull out. 
 The struggle here, experts say, represents some telling lessons about the manufacturing work place of the 1990's. Few corporations in America are as successful as Rubbermaid. Yet at Rubbermaid, and at many other American companies, gains from profits and more productive workers are not necessarily trickling down to the people on the factory floor.
"Spending the extra income that comes from productivity on higher wages is theoretically desirable, but not practical; it totally ignores competitiveness," said Stanley C. Gault, Rubbermaid's chairman from 1980 until last May, when he became chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in nearby Akron.
But while Mr. Gault says the payoff for worker productivity is job security, some of Rubbermaid's workers contend that job security is being used as a guise to cut income.
"They call us partners, but instead of sharing with us, as you would a partner, we are treated as indentured servants," said Michael Farmer, who earns $11.04 an hour packing plastic housewares as they come out of molding machines.
Nevertheless, a truce between the company and the United Rubber Workers union has evolved over seven years -- stemming from Rubbermaid's demonstrated readiness, despite its long history in Wooster, to forgo expansion here in favor of its 23 other lower cost, non-union factories from Cleburne, Tex., to Cortland, N.Y. Five already make the same housewares manufactured at the flagship factory here.
Indeed, Rubbermaid gradually shifted products once made here -- bathtub appliques and plastic-handled sponges, for example -- to its other plants. Finally in the mid-1980's, workers here agreed to wage and benefit concessions that halted the process and ended a shrinking of the work force. At one point, through attrition 250 jobs, or 15 percent of those at the Wooster plant, had been lost.
"We have acted as an explorer of the wage problem," said John Thompson, president of Rubber Workers Local 302, which represents the factory workers among Rubbermaid's 1,770 employees here. "We have said this is where we are now on costs, and this is where others are in the industry and at other Rubbermaid locations. And we have discussed with management how to close the cost gap between us and them."
In fact, the union not only gave ground on wages and health benefits; it also agreed to eliminate automatic cost-of-living increases, reduce overtime pay and relax rigid work schedules. The union also settled for a two-tier wage system that pays people hired since March 1987 substantially less than veteran workers.
In several ways, Rubbermaid has gained the sort of labor-cost breaks that Caterpillar Inc. has sought in recent months in its bitter dispute with the United Automobile Workers union. "The difference with Rubbermaid is that Caterpillar wants its concessions overnight, and that is jarring," said Wolfgang R. Schmitt, Rubbermaid's president. "We are doing it over time."
Even through recessions, Rubbermaid's output of housewares and other plastics products has kept climbing, along with sales and profits. By its own estimate, workers in Wooster today turn out nearly twice as many dustpans, for example, as they did in 1980.
Such productivity, if it were to spread across corporate America, should in theory bring larger paychecks, economists say, given that each worker produces more and more revenue. That would end the wage stagnation that has plagued America since the early 1970's. But instead of wage increases, Rubbermaid earmarks about one-third of its profits for dividends to shareholders, and nearly two-thirds for investment, mostly for new, more efficient machinery that the company considers critical to insure its survival.
Craig and Debora Droun, born and raised here, are both longtime workers at Rubbermaid, he as a machinist, she as a packer. Although they say they would never want to leave Wooster, they tell of the pressure on them to work harder and accept their lot, pressure that comes not only from their bosses but also from townspeople who fear the company might leave or even fail.
"We keep getting shoved down our throats how well Rubbermaid has done," said Mr. Droun, who earns $14 an hour as a highly skilled technician. "True, we are making good money for Wooster," where a typical three-bedroom home costs about $70,000. "But without raises, we have trouble making ends meet. People here who don't work for Rubbermaid, don't understand that. When we complain about our jobs, they say, 'Are you crazy?' "
 
The Company
Ties With Town Date to 1920
 A break with Wooster would not come easily for Rubbermaid, which was founded here in 1920, first as a balloon maker and then as a maker of dustpans, bathmats, dish racks, toys, office furniture and many other everyday products. One of the founding families is still a major shareholder, and one family member has a seat on the board. Rubbermaid's chairmen were Wooster natives or longtime residents, until the 58-year-old Walter W. Williams succeeded Mr. Gault last May. Until he joined the company in 1987, Mr. Williams had never laid eyes on Wooster, whose population is 22,000, but now he insists that he and his wife will live out their lives here.
"If Rubbermaid were ruthless, the only thing that would drive the company would be the search for towns with the lowest labor costs that are close to our markets," Mr. Williams said.
Clearly, Rubbermaid is not ruthless. Its headquarters here, and its flagship factory, employing 1,770, account for 7 percent of the jobs in the town. At a starting wage of $7.71 an hour and median pay of about $10.50 an hour, Rubbermaid's wages for both blue collar and white collar workers are top scale in small-town America -- helping to rank Wooster 24th in total personal income among rural towns and cities, according to Commerce Department data. It is better pay than Rubbermaid's 7,000 workers in other towns, who earn a median wage of less than $9 an hour.
Perhaps nothing reflects Rubbermaid's ties to Wooster -- and the privileged status of its workers in the eyes of their neighbors -- more than the company's pension plan. It evolved in the 1940's from the concerns of an earlier Rubbermaid chairman over the lack of retirement benefits for workers who were injured and forced to retire early. An amount equal to 15 percent of the total annual income of each Rubbermaid worker in Wooster is paid by the company into an individual pension account for each employee. For Rubbermaid workers outside Wooster, the company's pension contribution is only 5 percent.
The Drouns, who are in their late 30's, have accumulated between them more than $150,000 in this fashion, money which they cannot withdraw but can invest. "We have the money in an insurance fund that pays us 10 percent interest a year," said Mr. Droun, whose annual earnings combined with his wife's total less than $50,000 a year.
Such retirement savings, together with their wages, help explain why townspeople here are decidedly unsympathetic when Rubbermaid workers complain about their lot. When Richard Louttit, a former president of the United Rubber Workers local here, sent a letter to Wooster's Daily Record in November, denouncing the new Rubbermaid contract, the newspaper published it and then followed up with harshly critical replies from readers.
Mr. Louttit had written, "The 797 votes for this agreement (out of 1,063 blue-collar workers in Local 302) was more out of fear and intimidation than for acceptance." In reply, one reader wrote: "Have you any idea how many young men would cut off a finger to start a job at $7.71 an hour? Talk to someone who starts at $4.50 and reaches a high of $5.85 after four or five years."
Another wrote: "Rubbermaid is an asset to Wooster. It creates jobs, gives benefits and pays all kinds of taxes."
The company and its employees who live in Wooster pay 17.5 percent of the revenue collected from the town's income tax. As civic leaders, the company or its top executives have converted an elementary school into an arts center, donated the land for a new high school, built an office for United Way, a recital hall for the College of Wooster and a parsonage for the Methodist Church, among many other projects. Henry Copeland, the college president, said Rubbermaid or people associated with the company contributed 5 percent of all gifts received in the 1980's for new buildings and the endowment fund.
"If Rubbermaid were to leave, that would change the nature of the town; the quality of life would deteriorate, without a doubt," said James B. Pyers, director of finance for the municipal government. "As you drive around town, you don't hit potholes. If Rubbermaid were to leave, you would for a while."
 
The Union
Competition Among Factories
 With its concessions, the United Rubber Workers has in effect given in to an unusual proposition: the company's workers in Wooster have agreed to compete for production work -- and in the long run for their jobs -- against Rubbermaid's non-union employees at its 23 other plants.
Nowhere is that more evident than in the behavior of the workers themselves, among them Jan Douglas, a union shop steward who gathered her team of a dozen employees on a recent Tuesday to discuss various projects to increase efficiency.
Seated around a U-shaped table in a conference room at the Rubbermaid plant here, Ms. Douglas and her colleagues -- drawn from the non-union office staff as well as the shop floor -- told of a project they had promoted to equip maintenance technicians with electric carts, so they could get to repair jobs more quickly in the vast factory and minimize production shutdowns. The proposal to buy the carts was made by the workers and approved by management.
"We were not happy with the way things were going," said Ms. Douglas, who has 21 years at Rubbermaid. "The world was changing and Rubbermaid was growing and we were not the company's only factory. To keep work here, we have to be competitive with our brother and sister workers at Rubbermaid plants in other cities."
Essentially in this spirit, the labor agreement signed in 1985 specified no wage increases, but did include two one-time bonuses. To encourage management to once again expand operations at Wooster, ending the attrition, the union agreed in the 1987 contract to continue to freeze wages except for bonuses for existing workers while installing a lower wage scale for every new hire starting in early 1987.
That lower scale, which Mr. Williams describes as competitive with labor costs at other Rubbermaid locations, is $7.71 to $11 an hour, compared with $10 to nearly $14 today for workers hired earlier.
"We were paying above Wooster area wages, and the upper scale is still above wages in this area," said Mr. Schmitt, the company president. But at the lower wage scale, Rubbermaid has begun to hire again in Wooster -- adding about 150 new workers, some of them children of existing employees.
That Rubbermaid can pay these new hires at a lower wage scale is testimony, economists say, to a labor oversupply -- too many applicants in many parts of the country for jobs that pay $8 or $9 an hour. Given such pressures, the Rubber Workers have permitted overtime pay to decline at the Wooster plant, although the plant still operates seven days a week, three shifts a day.
The union has agreed to flexible schedules, without overtime pay, for workers hired since 1987. Even Mr. Droun, who is 39 with 14 years at Rubbermaid, voluntarily exchanged regular hours, with overtime, for irregular hours without extra pay, but an opportunity to advance. He now often works two consecutive 12-hour night shifts, from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. Then, after two days off, he switches to two consecutive 12-hour day shifts, from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M., at no extra pay.
"I spend my days off trying to adjust my sleeping hours," Mr. Droun said, "but that was my choice."
 
The Worker
A Machinist Tries To Move Up
 A small group of skilled workers, including Craig Droun, maintain and operate the factory's sophisticated, computerized machinery, and the company so far has restricted advancement to this group -- allowing them to increase their wages if they go through a rigorous training program to add new functions to their jobs, making them and the factory more productive.
Mr. Droun, for example, is to emerge from the program qualified to operate not only as a machinist but also as an electrician, computer operator and trouble shooter. He and seven others getting similar training will operate and maintain a recently installed 36-foot-high, German-made blow molder machine that uses blasts of air to mold nearly liquid plastic into large, three-ply plastic garbage cans.
The company agreed to install the blow-molder in Wooster rather than in another of its factories only if the union agreed to combine some jobs, as Mr. Droun is doing. "We have to run the blow molder all the time, or we can't justify the investment here," Mr. Schmitt said, "That's why we need people with multiple skills on duty all the time."
Mr. Droun's 12-hour days, at no extra pay, wasanother concession that the company required to install the blow molder here rather than at another plant. Why did he make such a choice? "I liked being a machinist, but I was stuck at $12 an hour," said Mr. Droun, whose pay has already risen to $14 an hour and by 1993 will be $15.43 an hour.
Still, machinists earn $16.50 an hour in Cleveland, about an hour's drive away, where they are apparently in demand, without all of Mr. Droun's extra training. Mr. Droun said that three of his colleagues at Rubbermaid had recently left the company to be machinists in Cleveland, at $16.50 an hour. Why didn't he go with them?
"I don't like to commute," Mr. Droun replied, while relaxing in the living room of his three-bedroom, ranch-style home on a plot large enough for his 9-year-old son Kevin to play soccer in the front yard.
Then, too, the Cleveland job might not last. Job security is clearly a draw for the Drouns, and Rubbermaid's record of not having laid off anyone since 1973, a record it maintains in part by using sub-contractors to produce Rubbermaid products and then, in slack periods, retrieving the work to keep regular employees busy.
"We don't want to leave," Mr. Droun said.

HEADLINE: SERBIAN GUERRILLAS POUNDING SARAJEVO IN DEFIANCE OF U.S.

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, April 18

 BODY:
Serbian guerrillas pounded central Sarajevo with mortar shells today as a high-ranking American official arrived with humanitarian aid for Bosnia and Herzegovina and support for its independence and territorial integrity.
Washington's confrontation with Serbia appeared to be heightening. The Serbian Foreign Ministry delivered a formal protest to the United States Embassy, calling American policy one-sided and anti-Serbian. 
 The Sarajevo television reported tonight that 7 people had been killed in fighting in the city in the last 24 hours and that 12 people had died in that period in clashes throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina. Security officials said it was possible that even more had died in the republic, where fighting surged this month just before the European Community and the United States recognized its independence from Yugoslavia.
 
A Symbol of U.S. Concern
 Serbs, who number about a third of the new republic's population, oppose independence and want to preserve links with Serbia, the biggest of the six republics that made up Yugoslavia. Serbian forces have sought to take territory in Bosnia and Herzegovina in the latest flareup of fighting in Yugoslavia, a nation that was welded together in 1918 from various peoples of different faiths.
The American official, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Ralph R. Johnson, arrived in Sarajevo today aboard the first of two Air Force C-141 cargo planes carrying a total of 40 tons of food, blankets and medical supplies, which he described as "a symbol of our concern for Bosnia." He was accompanied by Warren Zimmermann, the American Ambassador to Belgrade.
Security was tight at the snow-swept airport as the planes arrived. Five miles away, Serbian guerrillas fought militia forces loyal to Bosnia and Herzegovina near an arms factory and arsenal.
As Mr. Johnson stepped onto the runway, several Yugoslav Army infantrymen had their guns trained on his plane and the guerrilla-infested hills near the airport. But tensions eased as the operation unfolded.
Mr. Johnson held talks this afternoon with Bosnia and Herzegovina's President, Alija Izetbegovic, on establishing full diplomatic relations between Washington and Sarajevo. As they met in midafternoon, the Serbian shelling started.
 
No Comment on Sanctions
 The Sarajevo television, which is fairly reliable, reported that some of the mortar shells had been fired from a position within a mile of the presidency building where the two met. Serbian irregulars have held the position for some days.
Mr. Johnson, who is making the first stop of his trip here, refused to comment on whether the United States was preparing sanctions against Serbia for actively supporting the Serbian militias that have been taking over territory in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Hundreds of people have been killed and at least 200,000 driven from their homes in six weeks of fighting.
"I don't want to speculate on further actions," Mr. Johnson said. "In Belgrade, I have a chance to see the Serbians."
"Our concern is with the violence," he added. "We are not concerned only with one side."
The State Department warned this week that the United States would take steps to isolate Serbia politically and economically if it did not halt Serbian attacks on Bosnia and Herzegovina territory. The warnings by the United States and by European Community countries have so far failed to persuade Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, local Serb leaders in this republic and the Yugoslav Army commanders to stop the fighting.
Mr. Johnson and Mr. Zimmermann met later with the local Yugoslav Army commander, Gen. Milutin Kukanjac.
 
U.S. Policy Called Biased
 In his sharply worded protest to the American Embassy in Belgrade, the Serbian Foreign Minister, Vladislav Jovanovic, criticized what he called the "one-sided, biased and prejudiced policy the United States has recently been conducting in regard to the Yugoslav crisis."
Mr. Jovanovic condemned "the aggressiveness and ultimatum-like tone used by official United States representatives in their attacks on Serbia and the Serbian people in Bosnia and Herzegovina."
"Both the Serbian Government and the Serbian people feel very bitter about such an unprincipled policy," the protest said.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, a mountainous land that straddles the Roman Catholic west and Orthodox Christian and Islamic east, has long been a flashpoint for international incidents. In June 1914, a Serb nationalist assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in Sarajevo, touching off World War I.
Neither Bosnia nor Herzegovina has ever been an independent state.
Most of Bosnia and Herzegovina's 1.4 million Serbs oppose the republic's separation from Serbia by an international border. The 1.9 million Muslim Slavs and 750,000 Roman Catholic Croats oppose remaining a part of a Serb-dominated rump Yugoslavia, fearing repression by a Communist Government whose record on abuses of minorities has already been condemned by Western governments and international human-rights organizations as Europe's worst.
Mr. Izetbegovic, a Muslim Slav, today expressed confidence that his republic would soon fulfill all United States conditions for full diplomatic ties. "I gave Mr. Johnson oral assurances," he said after today's meeting.
Mr. Johnson said "the decision will be made in Washington," adding that he was confident that the United States response would be positive.
 
Fighting Reported Elsewhere
 Mr. Johnson is scheduled to travel to Croatia and Slovenia over the next few days for talks on establishing diplomatic relations with those former Yugoslav republics, which were recognized by the United States last week. He will later visit Macedonia, which Washington is expected to recognize in a matter of weeks, as well as Montenegro and Serbia.
In addition to the fighting in and near Sarajevo, heavy fighting was reported in the towns of Derventa and Srebrenica.
Much of today's fighting took place in a strip of land along Bosnia and Herzegovina's eastern and northern borders with Montenegro, Serbia and Croatia. The area is populated mostly by Muslim-Slavs and Croats but coveted by the Serbs because it links predominantly Serbian areas within this republic.
The American aid airlift has been greeted with more fanfare here than any American aid program since Tito's Yugoslavia benefited from United States humanitarian and military aid after it broke with the Soviet bloc in 1948.
The Serbian Government and Belgrade's Government-controlled press have hardly mentioned the airlift. Serbian officials tried to block the operation and demanded that the American planes fly first to a Belgrade airport to pass customs, American officials said.
In all, five planeloads of aid are scheduled to be delivered to Sarajevo by Sunday. The shipments are to include 90,000 ready-to-eat meals and 10,440 blankets from United States military reserves and 30,000 pounds of medical supplies belonging to the Dutch chapter of Doctors Without Frontiers, a French aid organization. The planes flew to Sarajevo from Pisa, Italy.
