SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1342 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
A Modest Perot Bandwagon Could Upset Big Apple Carts

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., April 18

 BODY:
Ross Perot's flirtation with an independent bid for the White House has thrown a sudden wild card into the race that both President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton regard as a danger. But neither side has yet figured out exactly how much damage the billionaire could do or precisely how to deal with him.
For now, the two campaigns have no real strategy beyond hoping that Mr. Perot will prove too thin-skinned for the pressure of public scrutiny and that his popularity will diminish without much effort from either of the opposing camps. 
 Mr. Perot threatens Mr. Bush's effort to overcome public doubts about his management skills and his attempts to escape the "throw the bums out" mood of the early primaries.
But Mr. Perot could also undermine Mr. Clinton's attempt to present himself as a credible alternative to Mr. Bush. If he withstands the inevitable dissection of his character and business dealings, Mr. Perot could end up helping Mr. Bush keep attention on questions about Mr. Clinton's trustworthiness.
 
Hoping History Repeats
 While strategists in both parties talk about how to counter a Perot drive, the campaigns are consumed with more immediate problems: Mr. Clinton with challenging Mr. Bush directly, and the President with pulling out of a nose dive and giving a meandering campaign some direction.
For now, they are contemplating the interloper warily, trying to avoid direct engagement and hoping that Mr. Perot will stay out. If he gets in, both sides hope for a repeat of history that shows independents, like George C. Wallace in 1968 and John B. Anderson in 1980, soar in the spring and crash in the fall.
"Our plan is to ignore him," a senior Bush strategist said as the President retreated to his family estate here for Easter weekend. "Our plan is to ignore everybody but ourselves, to focus on staying Presidential and laying out an agenda and not be distracted into exchanges with Clinton or Perot."
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's deputy campaign manager, said Mr. Perot is "not even on the ballot yet." He added, "Why would we want to start fighting another shadow?"
Mr. Clinton told reporters on Thursday that Mr. Perot "has high national name recognition, and you all haven't had the chance to put him though the meat grinder yet." He added that Mr. Perot was enjoying the politician's ideal of being "known by everybody and criticized by no one."
Mr. Clinton is right that Mr. Perot is untested, but he may overestimate his standing. A New York Times/CBS News poll of registered voters, conducted March 26-29, showed that twice as many had a favorable opinion of Mr. Perot, 16 percent, as had an unfavorable opinion. But 66 percent said they had not heard enough about him to form an opinion. The telephone survey of 1,638 adults had a sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Polls now show Mr. Perot drawing about equally from Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton. "If I was sitting in either camp, I would be very concerned," said Edward C. Rollins, a Republican strategist, "but I would be most concerned if I were sitting in the President's camp, because this is a guy who is going to spend $100 million arguing against the status quo."
Assuming that Mr. Perot does run, politicians in both parties expect Mr. Perot's standing -- between the 16 percent in the New York Times poll and about 25 percent in others -- to deflate as the race becomes more traditionally partisan. Mr. Wallace and Mr. Anderson started with about 25 percent each. Mr. Wallace finished with 13.5 percent of the vote, Mr. Anderson with less than 7 percent.
 
Tapping Into Resentment
 But Howard H. Baker Jr., the former Republican Senator from Tennessee and White House Chief of Staff, said: "We've had all sorts of third-party and equivalent candidates in the past. But we've never had one where you combine such a tide of anti-incumbency and a man who has got two to three billion dollars. Put those together, and nobody knows what will happen."
Mr. Perot's political message strikes to the rage of those middle-class voters who never shared in the prosperity of the 1980's and their disgust with Washington, just as Mr. Wallace galvanized blue-collar resentment of the civil rights movement and desegregation in both the North and South.
"You see these outcroppings of anger and frustration about every decade," said Lance Tarrance, the Republican poll-taker. "This time, it's about economic management. But it all has to do with perceived weaknesses."
In the November vote, Mr. Tarrance and others said, Mr. Perot could only hope to be the deciding factor by drawing enough voters from one candidate, or to deadlock the election and throw it to the House of Representatives to decide. In that eventuality, which seems unlikely now, Mr. Clinton would stand to benefit, since the House is controlled by a strong Democratic majority.
 
Looking Toward 1996?
 More broadly, Mr. Perot could force the two parties to amend their policies and tactics. "George Wallace set the agenda for the Republican Party nationally for the next 20 years," said Jack Bass, co-author of the "The Transformation of Southern Politics," published by Basic Books in 1976. "Many of their targets were first identified by George Wallace attacking the Southern liberal establishment."
Mr. Perot could also put himself in a position to make another bid for the Presidency in 1996, when the Republican nomination will be wide open.
Mr. Bush's problems with Mr. Perot were evident in the New York Times/CBS News poll. Among those who said they would vote for Mr. Perot in a three-way race, only 9 percent said they approved of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy, while 88 percent said they disapproved.
Mr. Perot has already started reminding voters of the way he amassed his billions and took on the General Motors Corporation by forcing his way onto its board of directors.
 
Both Will and Wallet
 "When one considers President Bush's line that we've got the will but we don't have the wallet, well, Perot represents someone with both the will and the wallet -- and the record as a problem-solver," said Kirk O'Donnell, a Democratic lobbyist.
The Bush camp's response forecasts how it might attack Mr. Perot. "Perot's got a lot of contradictions, liberal on some things, conservative on others," a senior Bush aide said. "He's not an anti-Government figure. He's a guy who made most of his money off the Government. He's a guy who's used the system and the old-boy network."
Mr. Perot, who supports legalized abortion and gun control, could interfere with Mr. Clinton's plan to draw voters who are unhappy with Mr. Bush on social issues. In Texas, he has long been active in education policy, a subject that Mr. Clinton is hoping to dominate, and he is a true non-politician.
Mr. O'Donnell said the challenge for Mr. Clinton is to "focus on becoming the candidate of change and not allow Perot to capture that mantle."
"Clinton must come forward as someone who has specific answers to the significant problems the nation faces," he said.
 
Challenge in the Rockies
 The Bush campaign sees Mr. Perot as a challenge in the Rockies, where Mr. Bush has never been very strong, as another complication in an already muddled California race, and as a problem in Texas, a state Mr. Bush cannot afford to lose.
"We would have to address Texas early," a top Bush aide said. "But he's repeated the need for a state income tax in the last year, and that's anathema down there. Pro-gun control is not going to take any votes from us."
The Bush campaign does not see Mr. Perot as a threat in the South, but he would complicate the race for Ronald Reagan's middle-class voters.
"Perot won't pull old dyed-in-the-wool Republicans, but he'll get a lot of peole who voted for Democrats way back and would never vote for Dukakis, but probably voted for Jimmy Carter the first time and then Reagan the second time," said Wayne Greenhaw, author of "Elephants in the Cottonfields," an influential work on Southern Republicans.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 12-17

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
An Uneasy Labor Peace Descends on Caterpillar 

"Because we want to rebuild good relations," said Gerald S. Flaherty, a group president at Caterpillar Inc., "we have invited back every striking hourly employee in good standing." But some of the 12,600-striking members of the United Automobile Workers, won't be staying for long. About 10 percent of them will be let go, the company said, through early retirement or attrition. "This is a successful company," said Bennett Harrison, a professor of political economy at Carnegie Mellon University. "It's not financially restructuring, its technically restructuring. It has invested enormously in automation." The U.A.W. wanted salaries of $40,000 for its top workers by 1994. Caterpillar drew the line at $39,000, saying that otherwise it could not compete internationally. But not everyone agrees. "Its competitors are all unionized -- Deere is unionized, Komatsu is unionized -- and there are no third-world, cheap-labor plants," Mr. Harrison said.

And Now, a Pepsi Uncola
 
When Pepsico Inc. introduced Crystal Pepsi last week, it posed a question to the $48 billion soft drink market even the philosophers would be hard pressed to answer: If you call it a cola, but remove the color, take out the caffeine, drop the sugar content and alter the name, will it still be accepted in the market? Pepsi hopes the new brand -- which was released in Dallas, Providence, R.I., and Colorado -- will do just that by snatching sales away from the fast-growing, clear-beverage market. Sales of colored beverages are, well, flat. But sales of clear beverages like mineral water, club soda and even Clearly Canadian, a sweet, clear wine, are growing smartly. "The brown goods are dying," said Jesse Meyers, publisher of Beverage Digest, a newsletter in Greenwich, Conn. "Crystal Pepsi is aimed directly at Clearly Canadian and its ilk," he said.
 
Boeing's Cathay Pacific Orders
 
Recession or not, the Boeing Company keeps racking up those orders. Last week it won an order from Cathay Pacific Airways, based in Hong Kong, for 11 new 777's to be delivered between 1996 and 1998. The sale was valued at $1.7 billion. Cathay also took options on 11 Boeing 777's to be delivered between 1997 and 2000. There was bad news for America's jet engine makers. Cathy will get its thrust from engines by Rolls-Royce.

Big Bucks for Millie's Boswell

Though Barbara Bush listed her occupation as "housewife" on the Bush family's tax return last week, she was the First Family's major breadwinner. President Bush's salary, which is set by Congress at a mere $200,000, paled next to Mrs. Bush's earnings. Royalties from "Millie's Book," which Mrs. Bush wrote from her dog's point of view, was a best seller. It earned $889,176 in royalties last year. By comparison, Mr. Bush's book, "Looking Forward," about government from his point of view, earned only $2,718. "The President is taking it very well," said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary. Mrs. Bush's royalties were donated to charity.

Chrysler's Electric Concept
 
The world's auto makers have been talking electric since the early 1920's, when Ferdinand Porsche, the great German automobile designer, raced down the road in a battery-powered car. Trouble was, none of these "concept" cars ever made it into production. Last week, Lee Iacocca, chairman of Chrysler, said his company would sell an all-electric van. "We have a good electric vehicle to sell now. This is not a show car," he said. The van, which will cost a pricey $120,000, will offset some of the pollution caused by Chrysler's gas-guzzling, 10-cylinder, 400-horsepower Viper, also on sale this year.
 
Last week, the Ford Motor Company said it would invest $3 billion in new plants and equipment. It also said it would buy half the Flint Rock, Mich., assembly plant which is owned by the Mazda Motor Corporation's. Ford holds a 25 percent stake in Mazda.
 
Is Big Blue Bouncing Back?
 
After agonizing in public for more than a year about its woes, the International Business Machines Corporation surprised many on Wall Street by reporting earnings of $595 million or $1.04 a share, in the first quarter. Big Blue lost $1.7 billion last year. Though analysts were upbeat, they cautioned it was too early to conclude that I.B.M.'s better performance was the result of a corporate restructuring announced in December. "It was a sigh of relief type of quarter," said Steven Milunovich, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. I.B.M. stock jumped 75 cents on the news, to $88.25 and ended the week at $88.625.

A Surge for CBS
 
Getting people to veg out viewing CBS hasn't been easy. For four years the former was dead last in the ratings. But last year the programming mavens at Black Rock, CBS' New York headquarters, spruced up their programming with oodles of sports, lots of news, several hot new series and 8,000 promotional spots. It worked. Viewers flipped to CBS and stayed glued to it throughout the season. Last week, when the A. C. Nielsen company tallied up the season's results, CBS jumped to first place with ratings of 13.8, up from 12.3 the year before. Each rating point represents 921,000 households.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Solid Gains in Housing
 
Falling interest rates stimulate the entire economy, but not all at once. It takes six to nine months, economists say, before the effects of rate cuts wend their way through the system. Those effects have now made it to the housing industry. The Commerce Department said Housing starts increased 6.4 percent in March, the fourth monthly increase in a row. "Unlike last year's false start, I think we are finally going to break out of the economic weakness we have been in since 1989," said David Berson, chief economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association.

Bit of a Stumble for Retail Sales
 
The nation's retailers, heady from two months of sharply rising sales, got a dose of reality last month. Retail sales slipped by 0.4 percent in March, the Commerce Department said last week. Though it was a stumble, most economists agreed it was no cause for alarm. "The recovery is not faltering," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at PNC Financial in Pittsburgh. "The retailers were just coming off two strong months."

Riding the Exports
 
Exports are one of the strongest sectors of the economy. They helped bring the trade deficit down to $3.38 billion last month, the Commerce Department said last week. That was the smallest deficit in nine years.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
U.S. Rice Still on the Boil
 
The rules were stiff, to say the least. American rice could be displayed at last week's Great American Food Show in Tokyo, the Japanese Government said, as long as it wasn't cooked, tasted or removed from the bags. But those restrictions were not enough to please Japan's politically potent farmers (voting rules heavily favor Japan's rural districts). Last week a group of farmers picketed the show demanding that American rice be kept out of Japan. "The U.S. says they displayed American rice for our education," said one protester. "But Japan has a 2,000-year history of rice-growing, while the U.S. has only done it for a few decades. We have nothing to learn from them."
 
Japan's Invincible Surplus
 
Rice imports or not, Japan's trade surplus with the rest of the world keeps growing -- even after decades of trade tiffs and negotiations. Last month, Tokyo had its largest monthly surplus ever. According to the Ministry of Finance, Japan exported $10.99 billion more than it imported in March, a 23 percent increase from the year before. One-third of that surplus was with the United States. The culprit now, economists say, is Japan's recession. Demand for imported goods has tumbled along with economic growth. "Imports kept declining due to weak domestic demand amid economic slowdown," said Hisashi Inoue, chief economist at the Nikko Research Center in Tokyo. "Japan's trade surplus is likely to stay at a high level this year." That means tensions will continue.

Gorbachev's Aid Data Redux
 
When advisers to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former President of the ex-Soviet Union, said $100 billion in economic aid was needed to turn things around, gasps could be heard in the world's capitals. Mr. Gorbechev backpedaled quickly, saying that number was just a ballpark estimate. But last week, the figure reappeared. Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said Russia and the republics would need $44 billion this year and $100 billion over the next four years from the World Bank, the I.M.F. and the world's richest governments. But where did he get that number? "It's the same figure Gorbachev used," said Vladimir Kvint, a Russian expert at Fordham University. "It was arrived at from a very bad study . . . and without any feasiblity study."

All Gaul, Divided in Two Parts
 
When it comes to the United States, the French are divided. They love hardcore Americana: McDonald's hamburgers are very big in Paris. But they also want France to stay French. Last week, when the Walt Disney Company opened Euro Disneyland outside of Paris, those two commitments collided. The park was filled even as French intellectuals derided it as a "cultural Chernobyl." Allan Finklekraut, a writer, said it was a "a terrifying giant's step toward world homogenization." With ticket prices at $40 for adults and $27 for children, with 100 million people a short drive away, that giant step may prove profitable. "If they bring their children to Disneyland, they'll have a good time," Michael D. Eisner, Disney's chairman said about the France-for-the-French critics.
 The article also referred incorrectly to another product, Clearly Canadian. It is a carbonated, sweetened water, not a wine.

HEADLINE: All About/Equipment Leasing;
Persuading People to Rent More Than Just Videos

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Equipment rental companies, whose crazy-quilt inventories often range from industrial air compressors to lawn mowers to fine china, have long dreamed of weaning consumers from their traditional preference for buying goods. But for years, the business was dominated by mom and pop outfits that failed to forcefully market themselves as an option for people who needed tools for repairs or silverware for parties.
In the last decade, though, the industry has consolidated and bigger companies with extensive operations are now aggressively preaching the gospel of renting, employing advertising campaigns and sales techniques adopted from retailers. 
 The shift in strategy has contributed to strong growth, with revenues for the industry -- which excludes rentals of housing, cars, billboards and office space -- increasing from $6 billion in 1982 to $20.8 billion in 1990, according to the American Rental Association, a trade group with 6,000 members.
"The whole idea of a rental transaction has become more familiar," said Chris Fletcher, editor of Rental Equipment Register, a monthly magazine that follows the industry. "The pride of ownership is not what it had been," he said.
The surge in the 1980's, received an added boost in 1986, when Congress abolished the investment tax credit as part of the Tax Reform Act. Investment tax credits permit businesses to subtract directly from their tax bills a percentage of the money they invest in plants and machinery. After the law went into effect, many companies concluded that instead of buying, they were better off renting from one of the 12,000 rental outlets in the United States.
 
Why Customers Rent
For the Convenience And Expertise
 Why rent instead of buy?
Many contractors have no alternative. They must rent heavy machinery because they do not have the capital to purchase it or they need it only occasionally. Some homeowners might also fall into this category.
But the choices may not be so stark for many customers, even after the costs are compared. That is why many equipment rental companies emphasize convenience and the extra services they provide: training to operate complicated machinery, delivery, long-term maintenance, fuel and computerized accounts to help executives manage operations.
As a result, most rental outlets set aside space for more than just equipment. At the Hertz Equipment Rental Corporation, a subsidiary of the car rental company that specializes in serving contractors, outlets have offices, fuel tanks, a 6,000- to 10,000-square-foot building for repairing equipment and enough open space to accommodate $3 million to $12 million in merchandise, as well as tractor-trailers for deliveries. Hertz has 84 equipment rental locations in such cities as Newark, Miami and San Diego.
The staff must be familiar with such popular items as backhoes (which rent for $195 to $275 a day), small air compressors ($70 a day) and dump trucks ($160 a day).
Equipment rental operations that specialize in smaller wares like power tools and party goods require less space, but they usually try to maintain a large inventory because they fear alienating customers if they are out of items.
Industry executives say this concern points to an important aspect of their business: many people are still unfamiliar with renting, so first impressions are important.
"That's really the key, making them know what's available," said Michael C. Kupperman, president of Acme Tool and Equipment Rental, which has two outlets, in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and in Staten Island. "A lot of people just don't know the scope of what's there."
 
Recession-Proof Myth
The Downturn Is Hurting This Time
 Many industry executives used to maintain that the rental business was immune to recessions. Based on past experience, they reasoned that though some customers might have less money to spend in a downturn, others would find that it was cheaper to rent than buy. And some homeowners might conclude that they save money by doing their own work with rented tools instead of hiring carpenters or other tradespeople.
But this recession has been different.
With housing starts and other construction down around the nation, many contractors have cut their rentals more sharply than expected.
Revenues at the Prime Equipment Company, which has 66 outlets catering to contractors and refiners in 10 Sunbelt states, declined 18 percent last year to $200 million, said Thomas E. Bennett, its president. At Hertz, revenues from equipment rentals dropped about 10 percent to $225 million, after growing an average of 22 percent a year from 1982 through 1990.
Smaller companies and independent businesses have suffered as well, particularly in the Northeast and Midwest, where the recession has been most severe. And lately, revenues in California have begun to sag.
"Clearly, our whole category of the small contractor has been hit pretty directly," said Dick Dandurand, president of Taylor Rental, a subsidiary of the Stanley Works Corporation that has more than 300 outlets.
Party goods -- like silverware, large coffee makers, tents and costumes -- have performed well despite the recession, leading many outlets to expand in this area while cutting back on other goods.
 
The Retail Mind-Set
Using Advertising To Find Converts
 That many consumers remain unfamiliar with renting was driven home by a Gallup Poll in 1990 that found that only 38 percent of respondents had ever rented equipment.
Neighborhood rental outlets have long relied almost solely on the Yellow Pages to market themselves. But many companies are now exploring other ways, including advertising on cable television and in local newspapers and direct mail solicitations. They are also computerizing their operations and using their data bases for marketing analysis and to insure repeat business.
"We can give them reports that tell them exactly what they are using," said Mr. Kaplan of Hertz. "They can assure themselves that the equipment they have is being 100 percent utilized."
The industry has discovered that many consumers first learned about renting from video rental stores. Many companies are trying to build on this awareness by educating the public that renting a wheelbarrow is just as easy as taking out a copy of "Fatal Attraction" for the night.
But even industry stalwarts believe they face a challenge.
"Culturally, the American public is still accustomed to retail," said James R. Irish, executive vice president of the American Rental Association. "Trying to get the public to think in terms of renting the correct piece of equipment to get the job done -- that's a concept that still needs to be seeded."
 
 
 
AVOIDING LIABILITY FOR ACCIDENTS
 Equipment rental companies delight in stocking a variety of goods. But lately, many are shying away from some items because of growing liability expenses.
Rental outlets across the country have been stung by lawsuits filed by people who were injured using rented equipment. Many companies are now so wary that they refuse to stock items that they consider particularly dangerous, like powder-activated nail guns, which use gun powder blanks to shoot nails into concrete, and acetylene blow torches.
American Rental Centers, which has seven outlets in Connecticut, no longer rents small boats and canoes because it is worried about accidents, said Dave Edwards, the company's operations director.
"Liability is always a major concern," said Michael C. Kupperman, president of Acme Tool and Equipment Rental, which has two outlets, in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and in Staten Island. "Insurance is a high cost for equipment and full instruction is mandatory for the customer."
The Hertz Equipment Rental Corporation, one of the nation's largest rental concerns, began a safety program two years ago that focuses on training construction workers in proper use of machinery. The program has "dramatically decreased" the number of accidents caused by Hertz's equipment, said Daniel I. Kaplan, its president.
Other companies are also focusing on ways to limit mishaps.
"You have to work hard to make sure you have excellent equipment and the maintenance is good," said William F. Berry, president of U.S. Rentals, which specializes in serving contractors. "Otherwise, the defense can be very, very expensive."

HEADLINE: Rafsanjani Sketches Vision of a Moderate, Modern Iran

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, April 17

 BODY:
Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani would like to be seen as a thoroughly modern mullah.
The Iranian President studies economic issues at least two hours a day, gets CNN in his office and speaks English perhaps even better than his Berkeley-educated brother. Although he holds the title of Hojatolislam -- one rank lower than Ayatollah -- he sprinkles his speeches and sermons with statistics, not quotations from the Koran. 
 Like George Bush, he likes to cut through his administration's bureaucracy by picking up the phone, calling his ambassadors abroad and fellow heads of state like Turgut Ozal of Turkey and Helmut Kohl of Germany at odd hours of the day and night.
 
The State Builder
 "His ideal is to bring Iran to the highest level of its economic, industrial and cultural potential," said Mohammed Hashemi, the President's younger brother, who runs the country's official radio and television. "He's in for the struggle."
If the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was the austere revolutionary determined to smash the old regime, Mr. Rafsanjani is the state builder, just as determined to create institutions that will restore the country to a position of power in the region.
Interviews with close associates before and after parliamentary elections on April 10 made clear that Mr. Rafsanjani's most pressing goal is to convince the world that he is a mature, reliable leader of a vital nation that is ripe for foreign investment and loans -- one bent on meeting the economic needs of its people, not political expansion.
But it would be wrong to characterize Mr. Rafsanjani as a Western-style leader ready to cast off his clerical robes at the earliest opportunity.
His Government is constrained by revolutionary purists who accuse it of betrayal. The regime has long been accused in the West of sponsoring terrorists, including the kidnappers of foreigners in Lebanon, although the intercession of Mr. Rafsanjani is credited with helping to free the remaining American hostages.
Since he became President, perhaps thousands of Iranians have been executed, including drug offenders, opposition guerrillas, Communists, Kurds, Bahais, even clerics. And his Government has refused to rescind the death sentence imposed in February 1989 by Ayatollah Khomeini against the writer Salman Rushdie for supposedly blaspheming Islam in his novel "The Satanic Verses."
The tension in the Rafsanjani Government between the impulses of extremism and moderation are perhaps best illustrated by the comments of the President himself.
In a sermon in December, Mr. Rafsanjani called for "prudence" in domestic and foreign policy, "so that we can have a presence and help people without being accused of engaging in terrorism, without anyone being able to call us fanatics."
Yet just this week, in an indication of the continuing political risks of being too closely aligned with the West, Mr. Rafsanjani said in his Friday sermon: "The West is drumming up confusion and pandemonium in their newspapers by saying that after these elections, the Government of Iran will become more and more Westernized. That is a lie."
Elected to a four-year term as President in 1989 with 95 percent of the vote, Mr. Rafsanjani appears to be headed toward another major electoral victory in parliamentary voting, in which he engineered the candidate-selection process to exclude some of his most troublesome opponents.
If the results of the first round of the elections last week are echoed in next month's runoff, he will enjoy a clear majority in the legislature, a development that will present him with a strong mandate to pursue his reforms and the most important challenge of his political career.
"So many changes have occurred so far, and more major things are yet to come," said Mohsen Adeli, the American-educated director of the Central Bank and a close ally of Mr. Rafsanjani. "Of course, it depends on how society can absorb it, and the more it can, the more we will introduce our policies."
A senior official in another ministry put it more bluntly.
"The country has become corrupt and the people are losing their spirit," the official said. "They have sacrificed for too long. Rafsanjani is the last chance."
To date the results of Mr. Rafsanjani's efforts have been inconclusive. Since the end of the Persian Gulf war, his country has re-established or improved relations with a number of European, Middle Eastern and Asian countries but has failed to attract much foreign investment or many foreign loans.
Mr. Rafsanjani, 57 years old, is an agile politician who speaks like the people, not like the religious aristocracy, and knows how to cajole, amuse, lecture, threaten and sway. He sometimes seems to feel confined in his clerical garb, pushing his turban back on his forehead and pulling up the sleeves of his robe as if they somehow constrain him. He has been known to burst into tears in mid-sermon, as he did when he spoke about Iraq's use of chemical weapons during the long border war.
Perhaps his most adroit maneuver came the day after a little-known Beirut newspaper in November 1986 broke the story of the illegal American arms sales to Iran, a revelation that was just as embarrassing for Teheran as it was for Washington.
Mr. Rafsanjani faced the nation at Friday prayers the next day, saying that the arms were needed for the war effort, but that the American envoys had been rebuffed. They had brought a cake in the shape of a key as a gesture of friendship, but Iranian security men "got hungry and ate the cake," he joked to the laughter of the crowd.
He did not tell the faithful that one of the channels with the Americans was via a close relative, by many accounts his nephew Ali Hashemi Bahramani.
 
Pistachio Business, Religious School
 Unlike Ayatollah Khomeini and his successor as Iran's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Mr. Rafsanjani comes from a religious family of merchant-farmers, not clerics. He cannot claim to be a direct descendant of the Prophet Mohammed, and therefore must wear a white, not a black, turban.
One of nine children, he grew up in the tiny village of Bahraman, about 40 miles from Rafsanjan in the southeastern desert. He was given the name Ali Akbar, after one of the first martyrs of Shiite Islam, and used the family name Hashemi. When Reza Shah, the father of the Shah deposed by Ayatollah Khomeini, tried to rationalize the country's family names by requiring the people to use the name of their towns, the name Rafsanjani was added.
It was there amid the cotton and wheat fields that he first developed an appreciation of capitalism, and even when he was preaching Islamic revolution, he depended on the farm's income and helped the family to acquire real estate. Although his mother still lives in the house of baked clay in a "simple way," according to his brother, the farm is now a vast pistachio enterprise managed by another brother, Ahmed, and the Rafsanjan Pistachio Producers' Cooperative has a number of branches overseas.
As a boy, Mr. Rafsanjani attended the local religious school and was a particularly active soccer player and wrestler. At age 14, he was sent to study Islamic jurisprudence in the holy city of Qom. As a student of Ayatollah Khomeini in the 1960's, he became steeped in the revolutionary view that it was the duty of the clergy to oppose Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and the heretical Western corruption that he represented.
Although the President's sense of humor contrasted sharply with the dour demeanor of his master, he entered politics as a militant follower of the Ayatollah's rebellion against the Shah's white revolution. And although clerics were exempt from military service, the authorities punished Mr. Rafsanjani's preaching by drafting him into the army. When he began preaching to his fellow conscripts, they dismissed him.
During the 1960's and 1970's, he was imprisoned several times for his political activities -- in 1964, for example, for his alleged involvement in the assassination of Prime Minister Hassan Ali Mansour. In 1967, he wrote a biography of Amir Kabir, the 19th-century reformist Prime Minister of the Qajar Dynasty, in which he praised his efforts to modernize Iran, a curious subject for a cleric.
"I was constantly in jail in those years," he said in an interview in 1980. "I was arrested more than 10 times. I was forbidden to write and preach. One winter night I was tortured from night until morning."
 
An Early Choice of Pragmatism
 During the revolution, he was a member of the ruling Revolutionary Council, a secret inner circle that made policy, and was one of the founders of the now-defunct Islamic Republican Party.
As speaker, he became so popular that chador-clad women would gather outside the five-story, white-marble Parliament building to chant, "We want Hashemi."
From the earliest days of the revolution, Mr. Rafsanjani has seemed to favor pragmatism over ideological oratory. In 1980, when Iranian leaders were demanding the return of the exiled Shah after the capture of American hostages at the United States Embassy in Teheran, Mr. Rafsanjani offered an interesting solution to one reporter.
"If the Shah dies, that would help," he said.
Shortly thereafter, the Shah died of complications caused by cancer.
As Ayatollah Khomeini's personal representative on the Supreme Defense Council, which made war policy during the Iran-Iraq war, and briefly as commander in chief of the armed forces, he is credited with helping to convince the revolutionary leader to end the eight-year war.
According to Ataollah Mohajerani, an aide to Mr. Rafsanjani, the clearest example of his pragmatic approach to policy was Iran's neutrality in the Persian Gulf war and its aftermath. Even when Iraq attacked rebels in the Iraqi city of Kerbala, one of the holiest centers of Shiite Islam, slaughtering residents and damaging the sacred shrines, Iran did not intervene, despite the revolutionary principle that Islam has no borders.
 
Enjoying Support of Spiritual Chief
 In recent months, Efat Marashi, Mr. Rafsanjani's wife and the mother of his five children, has begun to emerge as a public figure and a modern first lady. On the day of the election for Parliament, she voted along with him -- wearing jeans and a short-sleeved blouse under her black chador.
She has begun to host social events for foreign visitors, and in December accompanied her husband on official visits to Senegal and the Sudan.
Recently she stunned the wives of foreign ambassadors when she held a reception for them and turned up in Western dress, her hair stylishly coiffed. Her words of welcome and private conversations were translated into English.
"She looked just like any normal hostess, and was very refined, speaking about Belgian chocolates and things like that," said one ambassador's wife.
One of his biggest challenges will be to satisfy hard-liners like Ali Akbar Motashemi, the former Interior Minister and an enemy of Mr. Rafsanjani who in a news conference in early April referred to those favoring an "open-door policy and free-market system" as "rightists" who "either want to obliterate the revolutionary process or to make it fade away."
Mr. Rafsanjani is helped along by his close working relationship with Ayatollah Khamenei, who has frequently come to his rescue. Just before the parliamentary election, for example, the spiritual leader abandoned any sense of neutrality and told the people to support "their hardworking and popular President," a ringing endorsement that enraged Mr. Rafsanjani's hard-line opponents.
Mr. Rafsanjani has to steer a steady course between those in his entourage who want to press forward quickly with dramatic economic changes like unification of the exchange rate and Islamic purists who may turn to terrorism either at home or abroad if they feel they no longer have a stake in the system.
"A revolution in which people are not involved with not survive," he once said when talking about the need for satisfying the people.
Or as Ayatollah Ali Hussein Montazeri, the one-time heir apparent to Ayatollah Khomeini, put it before he was shunted aside, "If we don't tolerate listening to views opposed to our own, those opposing remarks will soon be turned into bullets."
 The article spoke of "tension in the Rafsanjani Government between the impulses of extremism and moderation"; the headline summarized Mr. Rafsanjani's stance inaccurately.
Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the director of the Iranian Central Bank in some editions. He is Mohammed Hussein Adeli.

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article last Sunday profiled Iran's President, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani. In late editions the headline said Mr. Rafsanjani had sketched a vision "of a moderate, modern Iran."
As the article noted, Mr. Rafsanjani appears to be trying to reach out to foreign investors and to show the world that he is a reliable leader. At the same time, he has said he does not seek to "Westernize" Iran, and he has continued harsh revolutionary policies and has refused to rescind the death sentence imposed against the writer Salman Rushdie for "blaspheming" Islam in his novel "The Satanic Verses."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Airfare Cuts Weaken the Industry. . . And Mislead the Flying Public

BYLINE: By DONALD L. PEVSNER; Donald L. Pevsner is an attorney and aviation consumer advocate in Miami.

 BODY:
THE old shell game isn't only used at carnivals. It is alive and well in the airline industry, and consumers are bearing the burden.
On April 13, led by American Airlines, most of the major domestic airlines implemented several important pricing reforms. But the new fares only look good when compared with the unbridled rapacity of what they have replaced. 
 After domestic airline pricing was deregulated on Jan. 1, 1985, the cost of unrestricted fares skyrocketed. Today, the unrestricted one-way New York-London fare costs $1,042, up 430 percent over its 1964 equivalent, but closely tracking inflation because international "on-demand" fares continue to be regulated by the Transportation Department. By comparison, the New York-Cleveland fare cost $302 until April 13, a 1,056 percent increase over its 1964 equivalent and a rate of increase nearly two-and-a-half times that of a typical international fare.
Congress' short-sighted and gullible deregulation of domestic airline pricing is to blame. Taking 38 percent off a fare that is two-and-a-half times too high to begin with, as occurred on April 13, is a classic version of the old shell game.
Ironically, most major airlines lost money last year despite these high unrestricted fares because their excessive level alienated the essential business traffic necessary to offset the bottom-of-the-barrel excursion fares offered to some leisure travelers. Also, millions of leisure travelers were turned off by onerous cancellation penalties, unreasonable advance purchase deadlines and other restrictions. It is a pity that these unimaginative major carriers did not follow the lead of Southwest Airlines. By charging dramatically less than all other majors in all fare categories, Southwest kept its planes full and made $27 million last year, while American lost $240 million.
Another example of the shell game is the airlines' use of nonrefundable tickets. Travelers used to be able to afford fully refundable tickets valid for travel on short notice and on any day of the week, with no onerous Saturday-night stay-over restrictions or advance-purchase deadlines.
But since 1986, most affordable domestic excursion tickets have been nonrefundable -- one of the more odious creations of Frank Lorenzo, former chairman of Continental and Eastern Airlines. When passengers decided that risking hundreds of dollars wasn't acceptable and stayed home instead of traveling, the oppressive airlines finally got the message. On April 13, excursion fares became exchangeable for a reasonable $25 fee if travelers' plans change. But draconian 100 percent cancellation penalties should never have been permitted in the first place, and were a direct result of Congress's abdication of its duty to protect the public. Belated, partial equity masquerading as a pro-consumer gift is one more version of the shell game.
What about the present level of excursion fares? In November, 1991, the New York-Miami seven-day advance-purchase, round-trip fare cost $340 on most major carriers. Then, the price increased to $559, and travelers stayed home in droves. On April 13, this fare "dropped" to $380. Anyone for the old shell game?
The actual systemwide airline cost of a round-trip New York-Miami seat (with a 65 percent load factor) is about 13.9 cents a mile, or $304. A generous 5 percent markup would create a total fare of $319. Even the new 21-day advance-purchase fare in this market is $320. This means that everyone except the 21-day-advance passenger is being gouged under the new "bargain" fares of American Airlines and its imitators.
American's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, initially proposed a new fare structure with only two fare categories: the new 38 percent off, unrestricted fare ($310 one-way, New York-Miami, or 28.4 cents per mile: more than twice American's cost), and the 21-day advance fare. Result: people who couldn't plan their trips 21 days in advance would be relegated to the high-priced seats or left behind. But this avaricious ploy did not fly, so a seven-day advance fare has been added. At 17.4 cents a mile New York-Miami, the price is still too high -- though temporary reductions in seven-day advance fares to Florida apply between April 23 and June 14 on Continental Airlines, TWA and USAir. But on-demand fares within Florida have doubled or tripled under the new fare scheme.
How can the nation finally extricate itself from the utter failure of deregulation, and protect itself against further predation when excess capacity shrinks and economic conditions improve? The only sure way is for Congress to promptly restore Section 404(a)(1) of the Federal Aviation Act of 1958 to the domestic arena, and for the Department of Transportation to compel the Act's mandate of "just and reasonable" fares on domestic routes, as it has never ceased to do on international routes. Tell your Congressman and Senator to do it now, or vote them out in November. In the meantime, watch out for the old shell game.

HEADLINE: For Sikhs, 15,000 Strong, Prosperity in A New Land

BYLINE: By JOYCE JONES

 BODY:
THE women will wear bright silk dresses, trimmed with gold. The men, their beards and mustaches carefully combed, will be in suits and turbans. They will park their cars in the comely suburb of Bridgewater and, 3,000 strong, enter the huge cream-colored building topped by domes.
Today in Bridgewater and at temples in Glen Rock and Deptford, as their neighbors celebrate Easter and Passover, the Sikhs will observe Vaisakhi, marking the day when Gobind Singh, the 10th and final prophet, established the discipline of Khalsa, through which the faithful can aspire to the ultimate state of purity. 
 As they worship, and during the meal that follows -- the langar, where legumes and yogurt will be served -- the Sikhs may look back over a remarkable decade. Their numbers in New Jersey have doubled, to more than 15,000. They have prospered as few immigrant groups before them. In spite of their differences in background and appearance from their neighbors, and in spite of the hostility many other Asian Indians have encountered in the state, the Sikhs have won a large measure of acceptance.
 
Many Forms of Acceptance
 That acceptance takes many forms. Some are official: last year, Gov. Jim Florio called upon the state to celebrate Nov. 21 as the birthday of Guru Nanak, the founder of the religion. Two months ago, the first Sikh was appointed to the Governor's Ethnic Advisory Commission; he is Arjit Mahal, a computer analyst.
But there are more meaningful signs of the Sikhs' achievement. The election of 18-year-old Kanwarpreet Saluja as president of his senior class at West Windsor-Plainsboro High School, for example. Or the absence of Sikhs from the public assistance rolls. Or the fact that a third of the gasoline stations on Route 22 are owned by Sikhs, according to Jerry Ferrara, executive director of the New Jersey Gasoline Retailers Association.
The Sikhs themselves tend to attribute their success to their adherence to the tenets of their religion, which requires that they work hard and support one another in times of need. But the religion also demands behavior that sets the Sikhs apart from their neighbors. Hair, as a God-given part of the body, is never to be cut or shaved, for example, and marriages are to be within the religion, often arranged by parents.
When Rajbikram Nayar enrolled in the New Providence school system in 1979, his long black hair was knotted in a bun at the top of his head. Fearing that the boy would be ridiculed, his father, Parabhsaran, and an uncle, Dr. Harbhajan Nayar, accompanied the youngster to school.
The principal assured them that all his pupils were "different" in one way or another and would "have a day" of being an outsider, Dr. Nayar recalled. Rajbikram Nayar is now a 21-year-old junior at Rutgers University, and he echoed the principal's views: his appearance has not held him back.
In fact, Mr. Saluja, the senior class president, thought his turban might have been an advantage. "The average person may see a Sikh once in their lifetime," he said. "When you do something good, he'll remember that."
 
Universal Brotherhood
 The Sikh religion dates to the 15th century when the founder, Guru Nanak, preached monotheism and universal brotherhood. The focus of the religion is the Guru Granth Sahib, the Holy Book, a compilation of the teachings of the 10 gurus.
In the cavernous room called the darbar, where members of the Bridgewater temple worship, the Holy Book rests on a small bed on a raised platform, the only objects in the room. Today, upon entering the temple, the members will remove their shoes, the women will cover their heads with scarfs and all will bow before the Holy Book.
Meanwhile, in another room, their children will be studying Sikh history and music and their native language. At the end of the worship service, the children will join their parents in the darbar to sing verses from the Holy Book.
It was Gobind Singh, the 10th guru, who in 1699 called upon his followers to wear turbans; he also required that they take military training to defend their land from invasion. Sikh soldiers have played a major role in the British and then Indian armed forces.
In modern India, militant Sikhs have fought for the independence of Punjab. Many of the Sikhs who have settled in New Jersey left India, they say, because of human rights violations in their native Punjab and the economic opportunities in the United States.
 
Insistent on Own Identity
 Unlike some other Asian Indian immigrant groups that are clustered in sections of Middlesex, Bergen and Hudson Counties, the Sikhs are scattered, and they are insistent on their own identity.
"People hear Asian Indian," said Mr. Mahal, the member of the Ethnic Advisory Commission, "and they clump us together. Our cultures in India are as diverse as those in the Soviet Union. Just as there are Ukrainians and Latvians, in India, Hindu, Muslim and Sikh cultures coexist."
He added, "Because we are successful, we don't regard ourselves as second-rate citizens, nor do we feel discriminated against."
The only exception, Mr. Mahal said, has been during periods like the war in the Persian Gulf, when some Americans "were provoked to believe that all turban wearers are the same."
Richard Gannon, the director of external affairs in the Governor's office, said of the state's Sikhs: "Economically, they are doing reasonably well to very well. In return, they have given back to the state with generous support to charitable organizations."
 
Jobs in a Variety of Fields
 The Sikhs hold a variety of jobs, but many are doctors, scientists and engineers with advanced degrees. Others work in construction and manufacturing, own restaurants or are owners or attendants at gasoline stations.
At the dozens of Sikh-owned stations, pricing policies differ. Sohan Singh Clottia, who owns a Shell station on Route 17 in Ridgewood, said it has been his policy to keep his prices one cent higher than those of his competitors, to reassure other operators that he is not trying to usurp their business.
On the other hand, Hardyal Singh Johal, who owns eight gas stations throughout the state, said: "I tell my competitors, 'I will undersell you.' I love competition. It is in the blood."
When the Johals first arrived in New Jersey, they had trouble finding an apartment. Working three jobs at once, Mr. Johal said, he was able to buy his first house within six months.
Why did he choose the gas station business? "Because when I started pumping gas, I had contact with the public," he said. "They could get to know me and see that the Sikhs were honest, disciplined, God-fearing people."
Mr. Ferrara of the Gasoline Retailers Association described the Sikhs as "fiercely independent and very hard working." Some negative reaction from competitors may result when a Sikh owner lowers the price of gas, Mr. Ferrara said, but they are generally regarded as good businessmen.
 
Marriages Often Arranged
 Sikhs by and large do not believe in marriage outside their religion, and that often leads to arranged marriages. Mr. Johal has a 25-year-old daughter, Navdeep, who has a master's degree in computer science from the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken. Without informing her, Mr. Johal placed an advertisement in Punjabi newspapers, inviting medical students to apply as prospective husbands.
Some 300 men answered the ad, and Mr. Johal and his wife traveled to India to review the list. A selection was made, their daughter went to meet her husband-to-be in Punjab, a long-distance correspondence began, and on April 6, wearing a bright red dress, she wed Bikramjit Singh Sandhu.
Though she was upset at first by her father's actions, she said before the wedding, she was now pleased.
Mr. Johal said that an arranged marriage had worked well for him and that the commitment had eventually led to love.
 
Students' View of Life
 Recently a group of students from the West Windsor-Plainsboro schools talked about growing up as Sikhs in America.
Jaskaran Grewal, 14, said there had been some difficult moments. "I'm on the basketball team," she said, "and at games we wear shorts and sleeveless shirts. My teacher helped, explaining to my teammates my religious feelings about shaving hair."
Sapreet Saluja, 16, emphasized the positive. "I think not cutting our hair has made us stronger," she said. "Our friends are mesmerized by it. They ask things like, 'Aren't you going to have trouble not stepping on it?' "
In keeping with the Sikh belief in sharing with others, the students travel to New York City once a month where, as members of a three-state youth group, they serve homemade sandwiches to the homeless.
The youths praised their religion's teachings. "It's amazing," Miss Saluja said, "that so many years ago, the gurus fostered equality among men and women. They preached against intoxication and smoking. Our diet has always been healthy. Today, many people are just beginning to believe these things for the first time."
 
 
 
A Matter Of Acceptance
 In 1955, when Dr. Harbhajan Nayar, vice president of the New Jersey Sikh Association, was 17 years old and about to leave India to study in the United States, he feared that he would not be accepted in a new land. His father sensed his concern.
Dr. Nayar recalled: "My father asked, 'Do people live in America?' I answered, 'Of course.' He replied, 'Well then, 70 percent of your worries are over.' I didn't know what that meant.
"He continued: 'People are children of God. They must eat and sleep; they have feelings and disappointments. Yes, there are differences, but don't let the differences overshadow the similarities. If you are in trouble, go to the nearest person for help. If he can't help, go to the second person. If that fails, I guarantee the third person will offer you assistance.' "

HEADLINE: Budget Vise Squeezing Teachers On Wages

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
TEACHERS in Fairfield narrowly agreed to a wage rollback if the town would pass the school budget they endorsed. But when the budget failed before the Finance Board, they withdrew their offer.
"We have been attacked in the newspapers, and the school board meetings have gotten pretty vicious," said Peggy M. Morris, president of the local teachers union, the 514-member Fairfield Education Association. "I would advise teachers in other towns not to even consider givebacks. It has caused tremendous hard feelings. It's been a very ugly period." 
 The Fairfield Finance Board did not intend to scuttle the agreement, said its chairman, Edward V. Crowley Jr. But he added that a cut of $300,000 in a budget of more than $16 million did not seem excessive.
 
Explosive Combination
 "It's very difficult to explain to people, when they're not getting raises, when they're being laid off, when they're losing their house to foreclosure, why one class of municipal employees is getting a 7.3 percent increase," Mr. Crowley said.
School budgets are being drawn up around the state, and at the same time 112 teacher contracts are up for renewal or newly negotiated. The combination has been explosive. Taxpayers are turning out for school board meetings, demanding that teachers' wages be rolled back. The teachers, meanwhile, are digging in their heels, and members of school and finance boards are often caught in the middle.
The Connecticut Association of Boards of Education recently released a study showing that contracts settled in February contained an average teacher salary increase of less than 3.5 percent, less than half of the average two years ago. Wages have been frozen for the 1992-93 school year in at least eight districts -- Eastford, East Lyme, Plymouth, Stonington, Union, Plainfield, Westbrook, and East Hartford.
At Joel Barlow Regional High School, which serves Redding and Easton, teachers recently agreed to accept a raise of 5.9 percent for next year, instead of the 7.9 percent they had negotiated. They will also take two unpaid days and pick up more of their health insurance costs. The concessions saved the district more than $140,000.
"The danger is not only to wages but to programs," said the president of the Joel Barlow Education Association, Randy R. Potter. "The bottom line is, we're in the worst economic situation we've ever been in. You have to balance progress for the profession against survival for the town."
The school business manager in Plymouth, Steven Kopcha, said an agreement to freeze wages allowed the school board to present a budget with no increase, for the first time in his 23 years. "The town really appreciates what the teachers have done," he said. But in other towns there is considerable resentment about the results of the state Educational Enhancement Act, which was supposed to attract better candidates to teaching by encouraging better training and higher salaries.
The chairman of the Board of Education in Bloomfield, Nicholas D. Caruso Jr., said that when the town agreed to finance higher teacher salaries, the decision was based on state promises that aid would increase every year. But the town has been told its state aid for next year will decrease by $2.1 million, almost 10 percent of its budget.
The board has cut 20 of its 58 classroom assistants and 8 teachers for next year, after losing 22 teachers this year, Mr. Caruso said. And because teacher retirement benefits are based on the three highest paid years, most of the older teachers have put off retirement until they have a few years under the new wage scales.
"We've just laid off all those bright, young, innovative teachers we've brought into the system under the Educational Enhancement Act," Mr. Caruso said.
Mr. Caruso said people should be upset at the state government for cutting aid, or at the Federal Government for piling on expensive educational mandates. "But people know there's no way of fighting the state or Federal Government," he said. "So people go where they can have influence. And people can vote down my budget."
The executive director of the school boards association, Terry P. Cassidy, said, "All districts are facing hideous problems this year." This is reflected by the large number of school board members who have decided to give up their posts. "As I talk with school board members, they tell me they're frustrated, and they don't want to continue," he said.
 
Nation's Highest Salaries
 Cliff Silvers, director of affiliate services for the Connecticut Education Association, the state's largest teachers union, with 30,000 members, said: "The pressure is out there. But most of our locals have taken the position that their contracts are in place, and they're not going to make any changes."
Six years ago, when the Educational Enhancement Act was signed into law, teachers in Connecticut were ranked 18th in the nation terms of pay; today they are ranked first.
The state's average teacher salary this year is $47,300, 8 percent higher than a year ago and $2,575 more than that of second-place Alaska, according to statistics released by the National Education Association. Connecticut's average is well above the national average of $32,977 and more than double that of South Dakota, lowest among the states, at $23,300.
"In 1986, when the Educational Enhancement Act went through the legislature, there was pretty general agreement that teachers' salaries had to be raised," said Ron Katz, senior research associate for the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council. "But we ended up with a much larger increase than anyone expected. It's time to slow down the rate of increase."
Mr. Katz and others blame much of the increase on binding arbitration, which allows teacher contracts to go before a panel of three members, one chosen by the school board, one selected by the teachers and a neutral appointee from the state. The two sides submit their last best offers to the arbiters, who are supposed to consider contract awards in neighboring towns in reaching a decision about which to approve.
Bridgeport went to binding arbitration with an offer of no salary increase, when the city's teachers were demanding 5 percent, Mr. Katz said. In a town that had declared bankruptcy, that was laying off employees in every department, the arbiters picked the teachers' package, he said.
 
A Political Issue
 "Binding arbitration has become a convenient mechanism to blame for any problems in the system," said Thomas P. Mondani, executive director of the Connecticut Education Association. He said teachers were scapegoats for the state's economic problems.
"If teachers' raises are cut, that isn't going to bring the Seawolf submarine back," Mr. Mondani said, referring to the loss of military programs that have devastated much of Connecticut.
"People who run for elective office don't run on the pledge that they're going to raise taxes, so they say, 'Teachers shouldn't get paid so much,' and the issue takes on a life of its own," Mr. Mondani said. "Teachers are unfairly singled out as a cause of the problem.
"Or what happens is the boards are saying, 'Well, we can pay you, but we won't have anything left for books,' drawing a connection that just isn't fair."
In the Redding-Easton school district, Mr. Potter said that perhaps the union agreed to concessions in part because no one tried to blame the other side for the problem.
"If you try to bring someone to the table with the shotgun approach, it's not going to work," he said.
 
Resentful Teachers
 Mr. Potter said Joel Barlow High School has won two national awards for excellence, including a Presidential citation, in part because townspeople have supported education so heavily. Now that the economy has taken a downturn, the teachers decided to help the towns, he said.
In towns where the giveback campaigns have failed, it could be a long year. In Fairfield Ms. Morris said the vote to reopen the teachers' contract was 153 to 146, and only after setting the condition that the town had to continue all programs and provide for no layoffs. When the Finance Board cut the proposed budget another $300,000, the offer was declared void.
"Teachers resent how they're being treated," Ms. Morris said. "We're being asked to subsidize the Board of Education budget out of our paychecks."
Though teachers in Connecticut are the highest paid in the country, Mr. Mondani pointed out that the state's per capita income is the highest, too. Teachers have the same cost of living as everyone else in the state, he said. Connecticut is also an urban state, he said, where schools face problems of drugs, crime, homelessness and other social problems.
"Basically, what people want is for teachers to be dedicated, which is another way of saying they should work for nothing," Mr. Mondani said. "That's not going to happen to teachers today, nor should it have ever happened. That's not to say teachers don't care for their students. But they have their own families to raise."

HEADLINE: Stockbrokers Are Catering To First-Time Investors

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
AS Wall Street rejoices over what has turned out to be a better-than-expected first quarter, so do stockbrokers in Westchester. Like their parent firms in Manhattan, branch offices in the county are enjoying what many are calling a boom.
To cash in on the good times and remain competitive with their city counterparts, local brokerage houses are offering a special dividend these days: face-to-face contact between the broker and the client -- what some describe as relationship-selling and others say is hand-holding in a time of economic uncertainty. 
 "The perception used to be that the best brokers were in Manhattan," said Marc E. Komorsky, a first vice president at the White Plains branch office of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "But a lot has happened on Wall Street since Black Monday, and clients feel they need a broker they can trust.
"What clients don't want anymore is to do business on the phone. The days are gone when a customer would call up and say, 'Buy me whatever.' It's a different psychology now."
 
A Record Number of New Accounts
 There are those who, having lost money in the October 1987 crash, say they will never be investors again. But there are also new groups of individuals cautiously approaching the stock market for the first time who want a better return on their money than a traditional savings account offers.
Brokerage firms in Westchester reported that new customer accounts were up almost 20 percent last year over 1990, and that trend appears to be continuing this year.
For those first-time investors -- among them Baby Boomers who have decided to forgo spending for savings and executives forced into early retirement as a result of companies' downsizing -- brokers said that a personalized selling works best.
"It may have been a record quarter on Wall Street," said Jill Gabigan, branch manager for Dean Witter in White Plains, "but for us at the branch, it was also a record number of new accounts."
That first-time investor "is a customer who needs some hand-holding," she said. "The process of investing is not a one-shot deal."
 
Brokers Make Hours More Flexible
 To meet the needs of the new clientele, investment brokers have adjusted their working hours, often meeting customers in the evenings. By living and working in the county, the brokers said, they could afford the luxury of a flexible schedule because they were not tied to a train schedule for the ride home from Wall Street to the suburbs.
"I chose to live out here because I didn't want to take all those hours off my life commuting," Mr. Komorsky said. "Now it's like going back to the days when I first started in the business. I'm working a lot of overtime again, meeting clients three and four nights a week.
"But in this economy, I have found that what works best is relationship-selling. And that means plenty of one-on-one contact at the client's convenience."
At the Windmill Group in Armonk, Frederick Adams, a broker, said that investment firms in the suburbs have "everything that brokers on Wall Street have except the high overhead."
"As a result," Mr. Adams said, "there is less pressure on us to push stocks on the customer. We can take the time to sit down and discuss what the trade-offs are."
Although there are a variety of factors at work, the drop in interest rates paid by banks to savings depositors appears to be the key force driving the heightened stock market activity in recent months, brokers said.
"Lower interest rates have historically been rocket fuel for stock and bond investments," said Peter W. Adolph, also a first vice president at Smith Barney.
In addition to lower interest rates -- which last week were as low as 3 percent on passbook savings, depending on account balances, and 3.45 to 5 percent on certificates of deposit, depending on the term chosen -- there are other factors, including a perception by the public that banks are faring poorly and the question of whether depositors' money is safe. Surprisingly, Mr. Adolph said, among those turning away from banks are the elderly. After the stock market crash of 1929, he said, many put their money in a savings account and swore they would never again invest in the market.
"But Mrs. Smith and Mrs. Jones are now saying, 'My can of Campbell's soup is costing more and the interest on my savings is down. I need an alternative,"' Mr. Adolph said.
At the other end of the spectrum, he said, are the 25- to 30-year-olds, who "would ordinarily be out buying Corvettes and boats" but have decided to save. "What the yuppies would have seen as disposable income to spend is being invested now. We've never seen that before."
Whereas the previous decade was characterized by flamboyant spending, the current one appears to be harking to a more conservative life style, to values centered on the home and family, brokers said.
Ms. Gabigan, describing trends at work, said: "The Baby Boomers are coming into their late 30's and early 40's now. They realize they have been spending money all these years and they don't have any savings for their children's college or for their own future."
 
Cautious Attitude Toward Investing
 But also, she said, the high number of relatively young retirees who have contributed to the record number of new accounts at Dean Witter's White Plains office may be a phenomenon restricted to the county.
"With Westchester being such a corporation-rich area, we are seeing many retirees who have been forced out by their companies, and these individuals have to do some long-range planning," she said. "Some of them are exercising their stock options and want to diversify. And all of them have to get the best return on their dollar now for the years ahead."
While there is considerable optimism that the economy will finally experience a decisive upturn and that the stock market will continue its healthy activity, the same conservatism that is prompting an interest in saving money for the future is resulting in a more cautious attitude toward investing across the board.
"It's not only the older people who are thinking conservatively," said Richard L. Reach, president of R.L.R. Capital Management in Pound Ridge. "Investors may be desirous of a better return on their money than the banks can offer, but they still want to avoid taking too much risk."
 
'Nobody Is Gambling'
 Mr. Reach, who manages money for corporations and individuals, added: "We are seeing the risk-averse, the defensive investor; and we are seeing those who are willing to take a little more risk for a better return.
"But nobody," he said, "is gambling their money. People are a lot more hesitant than they were a few years ago."
Mr. Adams, who was skeptical that the current stock market boom would last, said his small brokerage firm was advising eager investors to be "very, very cautious" because the market may have gone as far as it can go.
If a recovery is coming, he said, interest rates have probably hit bottom, and they could be going up again. And if interest rates go up, the stock market will go down, Mr. Adams said.
Mr. Adolph said that if history is any indication, Wall Street will continue to move ahead at a healthy pace because Presidential election years have traditionally been good for the stock market.
All the brokers agreed that much of the economic forecasting amounts to something more than looking into a crystal ball and something less than a precise science. Mr. Komorsky suggested that an old saying might serve others well: "Bulls make money and bears make money, but pigs get slaughtered."
"The best advice," he added, "is to stay away from hot money."

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Little House on the Prairie Goes to a Museum

BYLINE: By Witold Rybczynski; Witold Rybczynski, co-designer of the Grow Home, a small-house prototype, teaches architecture at McGill University.

 BODY:
The only existing prototype of Buckminster Fuller's Dymaxion House, which has served as a family residence in Wichita, Kan., since 1948, will be moved next month to the Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village, a national museum of American history and technology in Dearborn, Mich. The museum is planning to restore it to its original form at least by 1995, in time for the centenary of Fuller's birth. For the first time in almost 50 years, the public (and this critic) will be able to visit the house that might have revolutionized the American house-building industry.
The Dymaxion House looked like a flying saucer, but it was an affordable flying saucer, and the public loved it. Media coverage was intense. During the seven months after October 1945, when the first prototype was built, there were more than 37,000 unsolicited orders; the factory was prepared to produce 60,000 houses a year; Fortune magazine predicted that the "dwelling machine" would produce greater social consequences than the introduction of the automobile and estimated that as many as 250,000 houses might eventually be sold annually; and the publicly traded stock of Fuller Houses doubled in value. Buckminster Fuller, who had been, until then, best known as an unsuccessful automobile designer, seemed destined to enter history as the man who put America, if not on wheels, then into them. 
 It was not to be. Despite the widespread publicity, or perhaps because of it, conflicts arose among the financial backers of the project. Most wanted to move ahead and start production immediately. Fuller, then 50 years old, had endured two business failures, and, on the brink of success, he turned uncharacteristically cautious. He demanded more time for research and development, and resisted all the efforts of stockholders, friends and supporters to put the Dymaxion House on the market. In the end, the delays and wrangling proved fatal. Lacking the $10 million required to tool up for production, Fuller Houses collapsed.
Why put the Dymaxion House in a museum? The British architectural critic Martin Pawley has called it the "house of the century," and it was undoubtedly a remarkable technical accomplishment -- the most sophisticated prefab ever. The Dymaxion House, which is also known as the Wichita House and which Fuller called the Dymaxion Dwelling Machine, was certainly machinelike. The aeronautical impression was heightened by its streamlined shape and unpainted aluminum skin. The domed roof was capped by a huge rotating ventilator that looked like a tail fin -- it insured the natural circulation of air within the interior. The panoramic windows were made of curved sections of acrylic, riveted in place.
Inside, under the 18-foot-diameter dome, there was a large living area with a fireplace, a kitchen and two pie-shaped bedrooms, each with its own compact bathroom. The house had a centralized vacuum cleaner system, which was a novelty in 1945, and such space-saving features as revolving closets and electrically operated roller cupboards.
Panacea or sci-fi fantasy? Visitors to the restored Dymaxion House will be able to decide for themselves. What they will not see, but what made the house unique, was the method of its manufacture. The pieces of the house were made entirely in a factory and were engineered (mostly out of aluminum) to be extremely light -- they weighed about 6,000 pounds -- and were compact enough to be shipped disassembled in a single cylindrical container.
No part in this kit weighed more than 10 pounds, and the house could be erected in one day by six workers. Mass production had another dramatic advantage: the retail price of a finished house, in 1946, erected anywhere in the United States, was claimed to be $6,500, or about $46,000 today.
But it must be judged a failure, at least compared to Wallace Byam's Airstream trailer, for example, which dates from 1937 and remains in production today. Moreover, although the design of the Dymaxion House was unusual, it was not influential: neither its roof ventilator nor its rotating closets were ever replicated, and whereas Fuller guessed correctly that lightweight aircraft materials could be used in house construction, he didn't anticipate aluminum siding.
Unlike the 1934 Chrysler Airflow, a streamlined car that was ahead of its time and is said to have influenced Porsche's design of the Volkswagen, the Dymaxion House was not a harbinger. In the early 1950's, when factory-built houses finally became a reality, they took a very different shape -- not an elegant flying saucer but an ungainly shoebox on wheels: the mobile home.
Perhaps the chief lesson of the Dymaxion House is to be found elsewhere than in its unusual design. With the end of the cold war there is much talk of a "peace dividend," but it is far from clear exactly how military factories will be converted to the production of civilian goods; this question was precisely what impelled the development of the Dymaxion House.
In 1944, it was apparent to the labor movement that the boom in wartime industries, like the war itself, would not last forever. The president of the International Association of Machinists, which represented aircraft workers, invited Fuller, then employed at the Federal Board of Economic Warfare, to present his ideas on industrialized housing to the workers and management of the Beech Aircraft Corporation. As a result, Beech agreed to devote part of its Wichita plant and some of its workers to the development of a factory-built house.
Despite the popular image of individualistic American know-how, Fuller was no Lone Inventor; the Dymaxion House was the product of a collaboration between labor, industry and government. Labor, in this case, took the lead, and industry responded. The government had been the client for Fuller's earlier foray into industrialized housing -- the so-called Dymaxion Deployment Unit -- which had given him the experience necessary to undertake the more ambitious Dymaxion House. And it was the United States Army Air Corps that ordered the first -- and as it turned out the only -- two prototypes (the second was never assembled), thus providing the impetus necessary to get the singular project off the ground.
It is worth reflecting on the chemistry that produced the Dymaxion House, and on the way the industrial technology that had produced fighter planes was adapted to produce better and cheaper houses. It happened once, it could happen again.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Dymaxion House in 1946-The pieces, mostly of aluminum, were extremely light (they weighed about 6,000 pounds) and compact enough to be shipped in a cylinder (at left); the house could be assembled in a day by six workers. (Buckminster Fuller Institute)
