HEADLINE: 'Fiendish' Was Not Too Strong a Word

BYLINE: By Russell F. Weigley; Russell F. Weigley, the Distinguished University Professor at Temple University, is the author of "The Age of Battles: The Quest for Decisive Warfare From Breitenfeld to Waterloo."

 BODY:

SOLDIERS OF THE SUN
The Rise and Fall of the Imperial Japanese Army.
By Meirion Harries and Susie Harries.
Illustrated. 582 pp. New York:
Random House. $30. 
 As part of their repudiation of their warlike past, the Japanese rarely study the history of the Imperial Japanese Army. Among historians in Japan, the few who specialize in military history are even more isolated from other academic historians than are their Western counterparts. "Soldiers of the Sun" pleads for a reversal of such attitudes in both Japan and the United States. It argues that war and armed forces in general cannot be controlled unless they are studied and thus better understood. It also contends that the Imperial Army in particular was so closely bound to the Japanese people that it must be studied to understand Japan's future as well as its past.
Meirion Harries and Susie Harries, the authors of "Sheathing the Sword: The Demilitarization of Japan 1945-52," have lived in the Far East and have interviewed numerous veterans of the Imperial Army. Moreover, they have made good use of Japanese archives and histories, although the Japanese documentation that survived World War II is limited enough to require them to rely largely on the reports of Western observers.
The authors show sympathy for the Japanese, acknowledging, for example, that the extraordinary commitment of resources and energy to the army was a virtual necessity, from the inception of the Imperial Army in the 1870's and 1880's well into the 20th century, if Japan was to fend off Western imperialism. Nevertheless, while they are hardly Japan bashers, much of the history they narrate is so ugly that the reluctance of the Japanese to confront this part of their past becomes thoroughly understandable.
THE record of the Imperial Japanese Army is one of addiction to aggression, exacerbated by its habit of exceeding the instructions of the Government. From its first modern conflict with China in 1894-95 through the climactic Chinese war of 1937-45 and the Pacific Ocean war with the United States, the army increasingly gave itself over to atrocities that have cumulatively made its name as infamous as any in military history, including the German Army of 1939-45.
Sometimes with cruel haphazardness but often systematically and with strategic purpose, the Imperial Japanese Army tortured and slaughtered prisoners of war and the unlucky civilians in its path. It destroyed farms and factories either with deliberate intent to curb its enemies' economic growth or just for the hell of it. It entered the narcotics business on a massive scale, especially in China, with the goal of enervating an entire people. It practically enslaved Korean women (and also many Japanese women) to be its prostitutes.
The army's laboratories engaged in biological warfare experiments on human subjects that were altogether deserving of the melodramatic adjective "fiendish." Ultimately, with the China and Pacific wars irretrievably lost, it persisted in the struggle at the cost of vast, useless suffering for the Japanese people themselves -- in malnutrition, starvation and disease even apart from the Americans' bombing -- and many of the army's leaders wished to push the struggle even farther.
Mr. and Mrs. Harries attempt to tell us why. Their detailed narrative confirms their call to the Japanese that this segment of the past must be faced if Japan is ever to have a mutually intelligible discussion with other nations about its place in the world. Within the authors' argument, nevertheless, there is an apparent contradiction. This might have been better resolved if they had done somewhat more to set their Japanese study in the context of world military history.
They say that the Imperial Army was sufficiently an army of the people that the roots of its conduct must be sought among the Japanese at large. But they also emphasize that the army was so much a state within the political state that its condition verged on autonomy, a separation from the rest of the nation. To the extent that the second statement is true, then the crimes of the army were its own, and there is a certain justification in the current Japanese disposition to deny direct responsibility for its actions.
A partial resolution of this issue can be approached by suggesting that the institutional separateness of the Imperial Army as a state within a state did not have the same effect it had or would have had with a Western army. The Prussian and German Army from 1815 through World War II can serve as an example. That army enjoyed an autonomy comparable to the Japanese Army's, but with a greater gulf between the soldier on the one hand and the state and the people on the other. The reason was that in Prussia and Germany the political separation of the army was reinforced by an ethos of professionalism among the officers. In the Imperial Japanese Army, officership never developed into a full-fledged profession as it did in the West.
The officer corps of Western armies in general have been separated from the civilians around them by a professional value system that makes for civil-military tensions even in democracies such as the United States and Britain, where the army is not a state within a state. In Japan, by contrast, the value system of the officer corps was probably a modification -- and, as Mr. and Mrs. Harries aptly point out, in some ways a debasement -- of the code of the samurai.
Japanese officers were not so much professional soldiers as warriors. While the distinction may be subtle, it surely implies fewer restraints upon violence. And this warrior ethic was sufficiently shared by the Japanese nation to compensate to a considerable degree for the otherwise separate status of the army.
To suggest that a comparative view of other armies might well have enriched Mr. and Mrs. Harries's book is not to deny the impressive wealth of information and analysis in it. More than one book will be required to explore the subtleties of the relationship between imperial Japan and the Imperial Army. Meanwhile, "Soldiers of the Sun" offers the most readable introduction to the special qualities of the Imperial Japanese Army and to the sources of its especially appalling history.

HEADLINE: Plan by Dinkins Would Open All Libraries 5 Days a Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Finding a silver lining in a dismal budget, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday proposed a $23.4 million increase in spending for the city's crippled libraries over the next two years to restore five-day-a-week service at all 205 branches of the New York, Queens Borough and Brooklyn Public Libraries.
The libraries -- a safe haven after school for 100,000 children of working parents, a gathering place for older people and the cultural heart of many neighborhoods -- have been forced by Draconian budget cuts during the Dinkins administration to limit service at 141 branches to two, three or four days a week. 
 Described by Mr. Dinkins as one of his top priorities, the plan will be submitted to the City Council next Monday as part of the Mayor's $29.4 billion 1993 budget. Aides said it would be paid for with nickle-and-dime cuts in many municipal departments and not with another large whack of the budget ax.
 
Swift Approval Predicted
 The Mayor's proposal was immediately applauded by City Council officials, who predicted swift approval, and by officials of the independent but largely city-financed library systems, who said they hoped with the new money to restore weekday service at all branches by the summer of next year.
"Libraries are truly one of New York's precious jewels," the Mayor said in announcing a plan he clearly hoped would be popular with tens of thousands of New Yorkers. "Keeping them open at least five days a week is one way of making sure our city continues to shine."
The plan appeared to be a shrewd political move for a Mayor who faces re-election next year and who has been hurt virtually from the start of his administration by hard economic times and the constraints of stingy budgets.
Harvey Robins, the Mayor's director of operations who helped to develop plans for the city's expense budget, said the additional $23.4 million for libraries would be sought for the next two years -- $7.8 million for fiscal 1993, starting next July 1, and $15.6 million more for fiscal 1994, starting July 1, 1993.
The increases would raise city contributions to the three library systems to $128 million next year and to $135 million for 1994. That would, in effect restore the city money available to the 1990 level. Budget cuts in the first two years of the Dinkins administration had left the library systems with $120 million this year. The cuts led to reductions in staff and book acquisitions and in hours and days of service at branches.
The new money, according to the Mayor's plan, would be allocated among the three library systems according to their relative needs in restoring five-day service to all their branches. Each of the libraries would submit plans to a mayoral panel headed by Barbara J. Fife, the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development. The panel would consult with the City Council and the Borough Presidents in making the allocation decisions.
Marc Shaw, the City Council's finance director, praised the Mayor's proposal and predicted swift approval by the 51-member Council, which called two weeks ago for restoring $18 million in library funds to bring back five-day branch services next year and seven-day services by 1995. "It's going to get a very positive reaction from everybody," Mr. Shaw said.
Library officials also responded enthusiastically.
 
'Marvelous News'
 "It's great -- it's marvelous news," said Dr. Timothy S. Healy, president of the New York Public Library, which serves Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island with 82 branches and four major research centers. "Let us kiss the Mayor on both cheeks and go out and vote for him several times."
Dr. Healy said the libraries, in campaigning for a restoration of the five-day week, had stressed "the very serious fact that the branches of all three systems are part of the education of kids," about 100,000 of them the children of working parents who must allow their youngsters to go home alone after school when the branches are closed. "You come to any library after 3 o'clock on a school day and you'll find wall-to-wall kids," Dr. Healy said.
Mimi Koren, director of public relations for the Queens Borough Public Library, which has 62 branches and a major center, also applauded the proposal. "We're very happy to hear about the Mayor's plan to restore funds to the libraries," she said. "The libraries affect more New Yorkers than any city-funded service, and we're glad the Mayor has recognized New Yorkers' needs for libraries."
Larry Brandwein, director of the Brooklyn Public Library, which operates a central library and 59 branches, could not be reached for comment last night.
New York City's public libraries, organized in the late 19th century and expanded in the early 1900's with grants from Andrew Carnegie, have always been neighborhood centers and portholes to adult literacy, especially for immigrant populations, as well as extensions of household and school life for children.
Though they are independent, the library systems are largely financed by the city, with some money coming from philanthropic and public contributions and fund-raising efforts by the libraries. The New York Public Library gets about 40 percent of the city funds, with the rest split between Queens Borough and Brooklyn Public Libraries.
The libraries sustained heavy cuts in the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, and had not fully recovered when, in 1990 and 1991, the Dinkins administration was forced to impose new cuts.
While no branches were closed, as library officials had feared, 141 of the 205 branches in all three systems, or 69 percent, had to be cut back to less than five days of service a week. These cuts affected 77 of 82 branches in the New York system, 18 of 63 branches in Queens Borough and 46 of 60 branches in Brooklyn.
Currently, 17 branches (11 in Brooklyn and 6 in Queens) are open two days, 84 branches (37 in the New York system, 35 in Brooklyn and 12 in Queens) are open three days and 40 branches (all in the New York system) are open four days a week, according to city officials.
Mr. Robins, the operations director, said the Mayor had indicated in budget meetings months ago that restoring five-day library service would be a top priority, and to avoid major cuts elsewhere in the budget he asked department heads to look for small reductions in discretionary spending.
"For example," Mr. Robins said, "with the work force being reduced in earlier budget cuts, there was less need to purchase furniture and supplies in various city agencies. It amounted to taking dollars away from these areas and giving them to the libraries."

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Those Big Executive Salaries May Mask a Bigger Problem

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
It's nice work if you can get it. The $86 million paycheck that Coca-Cola's chairman, Roberto C. Goizueta, received last year is apparently the highest ever awarded for a year's labor. And with the market at a record high, dozens of other chief executives are expected to receive multimillion-dollar packages built around stock bonuses.
Is America's corporate leadership overpaid? In a defense that will no doubt be echoed by many of his peers, Mr. Goizueta suggested that his $83 million stock bonus was small change compared with the $50 billion increase in the market value of Coke shares during his decade-long tenure. 
 But such reasoning raises skepticism among those who think chief executives are no more than employees of the stockholders. Would Mr. Goizueta (pronounced go-SWET-a) have given less than his best if he had been paid one-tenth as much, asks Graef Crystal, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley and prominent analyst of executive pay.
Some experts on corporate governance think that seven-figure pay is not a real issue, but a symptom of deeper ills in the executive suite. The more important question, they say, is whether corporate directors hire the right people to run the company and dismiss them when someone better is available to fill their shoes.
 
The Cost of Poor Performance
 Jeremy Stein, a professor at the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said it should not have mattered to General Motors stockholders whether Roger B. Smith was paid $10 million more or $10 million less while he presided over G.M.'s long decline. What mattered a lot, in Mr. Stein's view, was the failure of G.M.'s board to replace Mr. Smith as the company tottered from humiliation to humiliation.
It is not surprising that most people see the executive pay issue in terms of fairness. The average pay of chief executives of large companies more than doubled in real terms in the 1980's, while profits rose just 19 percent and factory wages fell. That has led Congressional critics like Representative Martin O. Sabo, Democrat of Minnesota, to call for tax penalties on companies that allow executive pay to balloon out of proportion to blue-collar wages.
It is worth noting, too, that top American executives are more highly paid than their overseas counterparts. Professor Crystal has estimated that the chief executives of the biggest United States companies typically made $3.2 million in 1990, compared with $1.1 million in Britain; $800,000 in Germany and $525,000 in Japan. But foreign executives sometimes receive other generous rewards, like expensive club memberships in Japan.
But economists are inclined to put efficiency ahead of the equity of it all. At the heart of the problems facing the large modern corporation, many of them believe, is the paradox of "managerial capitalism." The true owners of a corporation, the shareholders, have no direct say in its operations. And when they dissapprove of managerial performance they have strong incentives to sell the stock rather than fight for internal changes.
Thus, if managers are to be persuaded to act in the interests of those they represent, said Prof. Kevin Murphy of the Harvard Business School, "it's crucial to use executive compensation to mimic the incentives of ownership." And there is no better way, he added, than to link pay to the ups and downs of share prices.
Mr. Goizueta's package apparently fits the description, at least on the up side of the equation. But Mr. Crystal asserts that relatively few corporate bosses can claim that their hefty salaries are in fact pay for a job well done.
 
Return to Stockholders
 Mr. Crystal compared executive compensation with the total return to stockholders for 450 large corporations and found that just 5 percent of the statistical variation in pay could be explained by variations in corporate performance. "The most common reference used by compensation committees must be a table of random numbers," he said.
Professor Stein worries, however, that huge paychecks are distracting from far more pressing issues of corporate governance. He says that directors generally do not replace bad managers until the executives have done enormous damage. And they rarely have the information or incentives to pick the best executives in the first place. In short, he concluded, "there is no market" for chief executives.
New research by John Kotter and James Heskett at the Harvard Business School indicates how harmful such foot-dragging may be. Their book, "Corporate Culture and Performance" (Free Press, 1992), focuses on 10 companies that succeeded in improving overall performance by making major changes in how the company functioned.
There was, of course, no single formula for success. The companies -- which included Bankers Trust, General Electric and Nissan -- did have something in common distinguishing the winners from corporations that tried and failed to change: All 10 brought in outsiders, managers who had not spent a career immersed in the corporate culture that they were pledged to change.
This finding suggests that the key to getting managers who really earn their millions is to increase the independence and professionalism of corporate boards. One way to do so is to increase both the number and authority of directors who are not employees of the corporation, and thus not under the thumb of the chief executive.
Such reforms in corporate governance were advocated by Ira Millstein, a New York lawyer who advises the outside directors at General Motors and reportedly engineered the demotion this month of the company's president, Lloyd B. Reuss, as well as the humbling of Mr. Smith's successor as chairman, Robert C. Stempel. Taken to its logical end, the Millstein model would put a wall between directors and managers. Managers would serve only as advisers to corporate boards, which would draw upon their own members for leadership.
But independence is an elusive concept. Outside board members may be tied to managers by friendship or compromised by financial dependence on present or prospective decisions by managers. A university president who is an outside director, for example, may look to the chief executive for donations or cooperation in laboratory research.
Even when directors see themselves as truly independent, notes Professor Kotter of Harvard, they may be so immersed in the culture of the executive suite that they are the last to recognize the symptoms of management failure. In this light, it is hardly comforting that 63 percent of the directors in a survey of 282 companies by Fortune magazine were chief executives.
Another path to holding executives to high standards of performance is to draw owners into the process. But most large stockholders are institutions: mutual funds, pension funds and insurance companies. Only a few of them -- notably the California Public Employees Retirement System -- have shown any inclination to put their mouths where their money is.
That situation is understandable and, by implication, difficult to change: it is no more in the interest of a fund with a broadly diversified portfolio of stocks to put time and energy into running individual companies than it is for Denmark to invest in its own nuclear deterrent.
In any case, Professor Kotter argues, it is far from clear that putting institutional owners on boards, or otherwise involving them in corporate direction, would improve corporate governance. There are enormous pressures on institutions, he notes, to beat the market during a quarter or a year. Thus, the thrust of their effort might well be to improve short-term corporate earnings -- a consequence that should probably not be welcomed.
There seems to be no magic bullet for fixing what ails America's corporate management or reining in managers who, some contend, have effectively captured control of companies they do not own. But these critics might still take modest comfort in the occasional nod toward self-discipline. As Mr. Goizueta pointed out to shareholders last week, Coke's board had the authority to award him a bonus twice as large.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The early reports of first-quarter earnings may support the contention of many executives that American businesses may be far healthier than the public believes. Many of the companies that have reported so far have shown results far exceeding what Wall Street analysts expected. [Page D1.]
Multimillion-dollar pay packages for executives have aroused a furor, but many experts think they may be beside the point. They say it is more important that corporate boards hire strong managers and fire weak ones when necessary. Economic Watch. [A1.] 
 Alan Greenspan takes great pains to be circumspect in his public utterances to prevent his remarks from setting off an unwanted market reaction. To this end, he says, he has learned to "mumble with great incoherence." [D1.]
President Bush and European Community leaders meet this week to try to break the deadlock in global trade talks. But even a modest breakthrough seems possible only if the White House orders negotiators to make concessions on farm subsidies. [D1.]
Kuwait is laying the groundwork to get a larger OPEC quota as it steadily rebuilds the oilfields destroyed by Iraq. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
Hollywood would seem to be the place for publicity to flourish, but the big studios are struggling with bloated, seriously flawed operations. Public Relations. [D1.]
Every year thousands of authors challenge the book industry and publish their own work. Over the years, many authors have found success on their own, although few to the extent of Craig Zirbel, whose book on the John F. Kennedy assassination has been on The New York Times best-seller list for eight weeks. [D11.]
Playboy magazine is staying faithful to its tradition, says its new executive editor. It remains a men's magazine but it is also concerned with issues, Kevin Buckley says. [D11.]
Chevy Chase was signed by 20th Century Fox for a late-night talk show, starting in the fall of 1993. The move is a big gamble by Lucie Salhany, the new head of television productions. [D11.]
Amid growing competition in women's fashion magazines, Hachette begins its most extensive and costly trade and consumer campaign yet, for Elle. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D12.]
Time Warner and Madonna will form a $60 million entertainment company to produce the singer's works. [C11.]
 
Companies
Few companies have tried as hard as Hughes to use their expertise in the weapons business to entirely new ends to find a place in the post-cold-war world. Long one of the nation's premier suppliers of sophisticated military electronics, Hughes is trying to remake itself as a technology company capable of moving nimbly into commercial markets. [D1.]
Arnold Hiatt, chairman of Stride Rite, is leaving his job to devote himself full time to the company's philanthropic foundation. Ervin Shanes is expected to be named his successor today. [D1.]
Hyundai Electronics is moving its operations to Silicon Valley in California. The leading South Korean maker of personal computers is trying to keep up with the industry's breakneck pace. [D3.]
Credit card purveyors are on the prowl for new features to set themselves apart amid furious competition. Citibank is planning to put photographs of customers on its cards; other inducements, like travel insurance, no longer impress customers. [D3.]
 
Today's Columns
Stock prices keep rising despite negative indicators. Now the bears have picked up support from the Leuthold Major Trend Index. Floyd Norris: Market Place.[D8.]
The steady slide in interest rates over the last three years has prompted a rising number of companies to redeem billions in outstanding debt issued when rates were much higher. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets [D9.]

HEADLINE: Surprising Increases In Earnings

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Early indications are that much of Corporate America managed to wring better-than-predicted profits out of meager overall economic growth in the first quarter.
The steady drumbeat of earnings reports at or over the high end of analysts' estimates -- from companies as diverse as I.B.M., Coca-Cola, Sears and Alcoa -- helped drive the Dow Jones average of 30 large-company stocks to record highs last week and lift stock prices in general. But economists say there may be important longer-term effects from the reports as well. 
 "Earnings have a huge impact on business confidence at the levels where spending and hiring decisions are made," said David Blitzer, chief economist for the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which analyzes corporate financial strength for the bond market. "Some new projects that were on hold because of concerns about funding are now likely to be put on the active pile."
 
Scaled-Back Expectations
 Analysts said the positive surprises were partly a reflection of how much Wall Street scaled back its expectations last year as the economy struggled to emerge from recession. But at least some of the gains seem to bear out the claims of executives who have been arguing for some time that much of American industry is far healthier than the public believes.
"I'm not surprised at the profits we are seeing, given the way people cut back employment and improved productivity to a greater degree than most people recognized during the recession," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
Economists agreed, but cautioned against reading too much into the figures. "It shows that business is fundamentally healthier than people thought six months ago, but I'm not sure what it tells us about the strength of our economy," said Lawrence Kudlow, economist for Bear, Stearns & Company. "A lot of the economically sensitive commodity prices seem to be slumping down again. That troubles me."
Analysts had been projecting a big jump in reported profits for many companies in the first quarter, even though it was clear that the economic recovery was slow and uneven to date. Such industries as airlines and railroads had been hit hard a year earlier when the Persian Gulf war sent fuel prices skyrocketing. Many other companies, including banks, brokerages and those with heavy debt loads, benefited from interest rates that were much lower this year than in the first quarter of 1991.
In addition, some companies had taken large one-time write-offs or spent heavily in the first quarter of 1991 to cover the costs of closing or selling unprofitable operations, increased severance pay for layoffs or inducements for employees to retire.
All these companies were bound to look much more profitable in comparison, with even a fragile economic recovery. But analysts had apparently been reluctant to count much on an extra boost from productivity gains.
"I think analysts understand, but they wanted to wait and see before building it into their estimates," said Carol B. Coles, president of Mitchell & Company, a market research firm in Weston, Mass.
Mitchell's analyses indicate that companies that have relied primarily on cutting employment to cut costs tend to enjoy only short-lived gains. But Mrs. Coles said the recession had unleashed a great deal of creative effort to improve productivity, by means other than simply eliminating employees, that should have a lasting effect.
The profits, along with such statistics as rising exports, point to a large improvement in the worldwide competitive position of most American industries, Mr. Jasinowski and other economists said. The United States actually has a substantial trade surplus, if autos and oil are stripped from the statistics.
 
Historic Standards
 But the operating profits, like the economic recovery, remain weak by historic standards. The International Business Machines Corporation, for example, earned $595 million, or $1.04 a share in the first quarter, up from $556 million, or 97 cents a share, leaving aside the negative effect of a one-time charge of $2.26 billion a year earlier for an accounting change on pension liabilities. This year's profits, however, are well below those of the last decade, when first-quarter earnings ranged from $1.30 to $1.97 a share.
A few companies, like Apple Computer, cited strong sales of new products as a reason they did better than expected. Many forestry companies had stronger sales than analysts expected. Coca-Cola was among those that did better than expected overseas. But many economists and analysts remain worried about how well new products from companies like I.B.M. and the Digital Equipment Corporation are selling, and about the general level of economic demand.
In addition, the small-business sector is still having an unusually tough time earning money. The quarterly survey of small businesses by the National Federation of Independent Business always shows more of them reporting earnings declines than gains in the first quarter, compared with the fourth quarter of the previous year. But this year's margin -- with 42 percent reporting declines and only 15 percent showing gains -- is larger than usual.
"It's not that they aren't well prepared," said William C. Dunkleberg, the Temple University Business School dean who oversees the survey. "There were just too many businesses created in the 1980's, particularly in retailing."
Unless there is a more robust recovery, the survival prospects for many of those businesses and the potential profitability of industry in general is still painfully limited.
 
'You Have to Sell More'
 "Restructuring only carries you so far, and sooner or later you have to sell more," said Raymond Worseck, director of economic research at A. G. Edwards Inc., a St. Louis securities firm. Mr. Worseck, who thinks the economy will weaken in the second half and grow only 2 percent for the year, said that nothing in the stronger-than-expected quarterly results had diluted his pessimism.
Mr. Worseck and those who have a similarly cautious outlook may find themselves on the defensive if the coming weeks bring more pleasant earnings surprises -- if, say, General Motors reports even a slim profit after six quarters of losses. But things would have to change far more than they have to create a truly optimistic outlook.
"Six percent growth in the first year of an economic recovery is the postwar average," Mr. Blitzer of Standard & Poor's noted. "These earnings are definitely a positive sign, but people predicting 5 percent are seen as the lunatic fringe and 4 percent is seen as high."

HEADLINE: As Work Begins on a Big New Mall, L.I. Officials Hope for an Economic Lift

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTBURY, L.I.

 BODY:
Construction of the largest shopping mall built on Long Island in two decades is to begin on a 69-acre site here next month, injecting new life into the region's construction industry.
The developer, Alan Fortunoff, president of five Fortunoff housewares and jewelry stores in the New York metropolitan region, said the ground-breaking was scheduled for the first week in May. 
 The $194-million Fortunoff Galleria project won the unanimous approval of the Hempstead Town Board this month, ending a four-year struggle in which Mr. Fortunoff worked with local civic groups to overcome bitter differences over zoning changes. The building site is in the heart of Nassau County, which many critics have argued is already overdeveloped with shopping malls and office buildings.
The deciding factor, however, was a sense among community and business leaders that the project could provide a lift to Long Island's recession-weakened economy.
"In this recessionary period we will now be able to create some jobs in the construction field," said Joseph N. Mondello, Hempstead Town presiding supervisor. "And when it's completed, it will result in permanent jobs for people."
 
Thousands of Jobs
 Mr. Fortunoff estimates that construction of the mall will provide 3,000 jobs, generating a $352 million economic spinoff among surrounding retailers and other regional service providers. The entire project is expected to be completed in 1995, and the Galleria will employ 3,540 permanent full-time workers with an estimated annual payroll of $97 million.
He said that "a considerable amount of road improvements" would be the first order of business at the site here on Old Country Road. It is adjacent to the now-closed 172-acre Roosevelt Raceway, which was also recently re-zoned by Hempstead for mixed-use development, including 555 housing units, a 10-screen movie theater, an office complex and hotel and conference center. Down the street is Roosevelt Field, one of the largest shopping malls in the New York metropolitan area.
The Galleria mall will be anchored by an existing Fortunoff store, which will be upgraded, and a new Price Club warehouse store. Mr. Fortunoff said he expected the Price Club building to be completed later this year. Adjoining it will be a cluster of retailers, not yet identified, that will probably include an apparel store, a sporting goods outlet, a general merchandise store and a restaurant.
The next phase of the project, the enclosed Galleria, is in its early planning stages, with financing being arranged, Mr. Fortunoff said.
 
'Value-Oriented Mall'
 Mr. Fortunoff first proposed the Galleria complex four years ago, but shelved it because of the growing recession and opposition from civic groups representing homeowners in surrounding communities.
At one point, the project was to include two upscale anchor stores, Neiman-Marcus and Nordstrom, with a three-level mall and tiered parking. But those plans were subsequently dropped and scaled back to create what Mr. Fortunoff described as a "value-oriented mall."
The 60,000 members of the Nassau-Suffolk Building Construction Trades Council -- half of whom are currently unemployed -- are eager to put their shovels into the ground.
"We're about to pick up our tools again," said David Richardson, secretary of the trade group. "For thousands of Nassau County construction trades people, it is nothing less than a lifeline."
Shelley Lotenberg, co-president of the Salisbury Civic Association, which initially opposed the mall, praised Mr. Fortunoff for his willingness to work with community leaders to settle differences.
"Perhaps the 90's will be the decade of compromise on the part of developers and the community," she said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
House Members Can Only Guess How Voters Will React to Bank Scandal

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
The House bank scandal is a live grenade rolling around the 1992 Congressional elections. It is sure to end careers, both lofty and undistinguished. But most thoughtful politicians are wary of guessing just how it will change the House, in either partisan or substantive terms.
House elections are rarely national events, swept along by the same issues from Maine to California. It did happen after Watergate, and it sometimes happens in recessions. 
 In 1990, Republicans had hoped that the ethics charges against Speaker Jim Wright that led to his ouster could be used to show that Democrats deserved defeat. But the Democrats gained seats. Local problems, local records and local personalities usually matter far more than national issues or scandals, and few politicians think the bank issue will prove an exception.
Democrats make that argument most energetically. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said Friday, "While undoubtedly no one is happy to see their representative bounced a check, they're much more concerned about issues that affect their lives directly, their jobs, their incomes, their health care coverage."
 
'Looking for Silver Bullets'
 Les Francis, executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said, "Republicans are always looking for silver bullets and a way to nationalize Congressional elections." He said that polls showing people would vote against representatives who wrote overdrafts were "virtually useless" because they omitted more important information about whether voters agreed with the incumbent on important issues or thought the lawmaker had served the district well.
Some Republicans argue that this issue is bigger than usual and that a national case can be made because the Democrats have ruled the House for 38 years. Newt Gingrich, the No. 2 House Republican, traveled the Southwest last week telling G.O.P. hopefuls "you will have a lot more ammunition" when the overdraft list was made public Thursday. And one Republican poll-taker who insisted he not be quoted by name because he thought his party was exploiting "a false issue," still argued that it had "burned itself into the public mind."
Another complication is a certain Republican ambivalence about going at the issue full-tilt. Some Republicans want to, but Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, said Friday: "I'd sure hope it was behind us. I really feel for my colleagues, most of whom I think are getting an extraordinarily bum rap for just a miserable operation" at the bank.
 
Republicans Could Gain
 But even if the more typical historical pattern holds and the bank issue turns out to be a district-by-district problem for incumbents, not a national force, it could still be the driving force behind major Republican gains. The simple fact is that more Democrats put themselves at risk, and not simply in proportion to their 62 percent majority in the House.
Polls have repeatedly shown that voters say they are more likely to oust someone if the lawmaker wrote a lot of checks, and not just a few, without the money to back them. Among the 17 incumbents listed by the Ethics Committee on April 1 as abusers, with an average of 513 overdrafts each, 14 were Democrats.
Among 30 others who wrote at least 100 overdrafts, 22 were Democrats. And among the 56 more who wrote 39 or more overdrafts, or at least one per month in the auditing period, 45 were Democrats.
But Republicans do not think they will gain from the scandal at anything like those ratios. They say their supporters are more likely to be shocked by such behavior than are some Democrats' constituents.
 
Seeing a Difference
 Mr. Michel, who said he had never written a check for more than than he had in a bank account, observed that in his Peoria area, one or two might be enough to finish a career. On the other hand, he said, in "the heart of big cities they won't give a darn."
Representative Norman F. Lent, Republican of Nassau County, was blunter. He told The Associated Press last week, "If you're from a Republican district, white, upper-middle-class people will not tolerate this from their elected officials."
Regardless of how well those two Republicans from small-town Illinois and the New York suburbs can judge the attitudes of urban constitutents of Democratic Congressmen, they probably know their own voters. Those judgments may be why six of the 22 Republicans with at least 39 overdrafts have retired. That equals the six Democrats who have announced that they will retire, but there were 81 with at least that number of overdrafts.
The impact of this issue may be felt most strongly in primaries, and that may diminish its partisan impact. When Representative Edward F. Feighan, Democrat of Ohio, dropped out of his state's primary as he was making the list of abusers, his district suddenly became safe for the Democrats again. Whoever wins the nomination in the heavily Democratic district will not have the check issue as a handicap. And if Tim Hagan, a Cuyahoga County commissioner, defeats Representative Mary Rose Oakar, who made the same list, in the June 2 Democratic primary, Republicans can give up on that Cleveland seat.
 
Time for Change
 The general election, after all, is nearly six months off. By fall, the economy and the combat of the Presidential election campaign may have drowned out the issue. And those six months offer ample time for incumbents, who still enjoy huge fund-raising advantages, to make their case.
Bob Squier, a Democratic television consultant, said the issue can be "a very handy lightning rod for vague, generalized anger" at a system that is not solving problems. But that does not mean it will overcome a record of doing things for a district, like Charles Hatcher's efforts in Georgia to get Federal subsidies for peanut producers or Thomas J. Downey's success in extending unemployment benefits and in keeping Grumman building airplanes on Long Island.
One complication is that for many lawmakers, redistricting has brought new voters who do not know them or what they have done. The bank scandal, said Ann F. Lewis, a Democratic consultant in Boston, is simply "the worst possible introduction."
The key to surviving a check problem, politicians on all sides agreed, was having a record of providing good reasons to be re-elected, apologizing forthrightly for writing overdrafts and hoping that the absurdities of the bank itself, such as rarely telling members that their checks were not covered or posting deposits late, could be made known without sounding like whiny excuses.
But without better than usual reasons for re-election, the bank issue can be a real threat to incumbents with lots of overdrafts, said Alan Secrest, a Democratic poll-taker who handles many House campaigns. He said the issue was no "silver bullet," but it still symbolized two basic cores of distrust toward Congress -- "a perceived lack of common sense and a lack of accountability."
Whether it hurts Republicans or Democrats more may matter less than how it changes the House. One retiring Republican worries that the issue may change the way representatives look at their jobs, and for the worse.
Representative Vin Weber, a respected Minnesota Republican with 125 overdrafts, said a week ago on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" that this year's challengers were "not pledging to do anything that addresses any of our nation's problems." He added, "We're going to have 150 new members here that are promising not to use a bank that's been closed for a year, and give their parking spot over to the homeless, and not work out in the House gym."
"How," he asked, "does that help us resolve the health care problem? How does it help us get a handle on the deficit? How does it restore the economy?"

GRAPHIC: Photos: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, left, the majority leader, said voters were more concerned "about issues that affect their lives directly," than the House bank scandal. "I'd sure hope it was behind us," said Representative Robert H. Michel, the minority leader. (The New York Times; Andrea Mohin)

HEADLINE: Discord Is Said to Stall Plan to Raise I.M.F. Loan Aid to Ex-Soviets

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund is considering a plan to help the former Soviet republics pay billions of dollars' worth of their trade bills, but cannot act because its member countries are divided on the idea, says a senior official at the lending institution.
The plan would be in addition to $25 billion to $30 billion worth of conventional I.M.F. loans over the next four years and would allow all of the institution's members, including the former Soviet republics when they join, to borrow extra money. 
 The senior official's remarks were the first indication that the I.M.F. might be coming up with a new and little-discussed method to help finance international aid to the former republics. Other I.M.F. officials said that the institution's economists had quietly begun work on the idea a year ago at Japan's request, and that they would finish their review before the I.M.F. and World Bank hold their annual meeting here in September.
The senior official discussed the plan on Friday with reporters on the condition that he not be identified. Poor countries and Japan support the idea, but a Bush Administration official said the United States opposed it.
Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the I.M.F., said on Wednesday that in addition to $24 billion in aid for Russia, Western nations should spend $20 billion this year to help the 14 other former republics pay for needed imports. But Mr. Camdessus provided few details of how to pay for them.
The senior I.M.F. official suggested that creating more special drawing rights, which allow the additional borrowing for member countries, might be part of the answer. "I believe that there is now a good case for it, and we will have it on our agenda before the next annual meeting," he said.
Special drawing rights are used almost exclusively by international lending institutions and central banks for transactions with one another, like the settlement of loans and trade bills. Like the European Community's ecu, the special drawing right is a composite of several currencies and fluctuates in value with them; one special drawing right is now worth $1.37.
 
System Benefits Rich Nations
 The International Monetary Fund can create new drawing rights whenever an overwhelming majority of member nations give permission. But under an amendment to the I.M.F.'s charter, new drawing rights are divided among member countries in proportion to their financial contributions to the fund. So rich nations get the most and poor nations get the least.
Whenever a country takes some of its special drawing rights out of the institution and uses them to pay a loan or bill, it owes money on the drawing rights until it replaces them. For this reason, creating more special drawing rights amounts to allowing I.M.F. countries to borrow more money.
Because the I.M.F. decided this week that the 15 republics would have a combined stake of only 4.76 percent in the institution, only this proportion of any new special drawing rights would be given to them. But an I.M.F. official who insisted on anonymity said some of the institution's wealthiest members had informally begun talks on ways to transfer some of their special drawing rights to the new republics.
 
No Figures Are Set
 Poor countries have been calling for the creation of 50 billion drawing rights over five years, which would be worth $68.5 billion. If such an amount were created, then the former Soviet republics would initially receive only $3.26 billion worth. The senior I.M.F. official provided no figures on how many drawing rights might be created, and other officials at the institution said that no amount had been set yet.
The official reason for United States opposition to the plan is a concern that creating money from nothing may be inflationary. The Treasury Department and large commercial banks in New York, however, profit handsomely from the current scarcity of special drawing rights and have no incentive to want the system changed. This is because central banks of third-world countries have to borrow large sums from commercial banks to maintain a large supply of Treasury bonds for loan payments and trade bills.
Because poor countries are viewed as risky borrowers, commercial banks charge them a higher interest rate than is paid on Treasury bonds. So poor countries lose the difference between the two interest rates, while commercial banks profit on the loans and the Treasury insures some extra demand for its bonds.
By contrast, poor countries pay roughly the Treasury bond rate when they borrow by taking special drawing rights out of the I.M.F., thereby saving on interest payments.

HEADLINE: With Budget in Hand, Albany Shifts Its Focus to Other Issues

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 19

 BODY:
For the first time in years, the Legislature will have time on its hands when it returns to Albany on Tuesday after a two-week recess. That may sound like a dangerous proposition to some, but it could make the next 10 weeks one of the most productive periods in the Legislature's recent history.
Before leaving town on April 2, lawmakers passed a budget that was virtually on schedule; the first time that has happened since 1984. Last year, the budget was not settled until July 4, the last day of the session. 
 "This is a tremendous advantage for us," said Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat. "Last year we were frustrated completely. We spent all our time negotiating the budget and everything else got shoved into the background."
This year, the lawmakers can turn their attention to bills that would change the state's election laws, change the way that health insurance rates are set, and even allow horse racing to be simulcast in homes on pay-per-view cable television.
Much of what the Legislature does will be shaped by the overriding influence of election-year politics. And, as always, many issues will become ensnared in disagreements between the Republican-controlled Senate and the Democratic-majority Assembly. But at least there will be a potential for action that has been missing in previous years.
Here are some of the prime issues facing the Legislature:
 
Election Law Changes
 The Legislature has already approved a redistricting plan for its own districts. But Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has hinted that he may veto the bill unless lawmakers pass a package of significant changes in New York's election laws.
The Governor has asked for changes that would make it easier for challengers to get on the ballot, would encourage voter registration and would establish a system of public campaign financing.
The Legislature is also considering a bill proposed by New York City's Campaign Finance Board that would place strict limits on the size of contributions received by candidates for major city offices.
The Assembly Democrats and Senate Republicans have declared an impasse over Congressional redistricting. A panel of Federal judges has given the Legislature until April 27 to break its deadlock. If it does not, the court is most likely to make the redistricting decisions on its own.
 
Insurance
 The Senate is to take up a bill, already approved by the Assembly, that would sharply change the way health insurance rates are set in New York. It would force commercial insurance companies to accept anyone who applies for insurance, regardless of risk. It also would require commercial insurers to set premiums for individual and small-group customers based on the average risk of a larger pool of customers.
The legislation has been opposed by Senate Republican leaders, who argue that it would give unfair advantages to the commercial insurers' ailing competitors -- the state's nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans. But Mr. Cuomo has warned that if the Senate does not approve the Assembly bill, the state would be forced to raise premiums for the 1.2 million customers of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in October, just before Election Day.
 
Transportation
 Almost everybody in the Capitol expects a colossal battle to unfold over how to spend nearly $750 million a year in petroleum taxes that now go into the state's general fund but will be dedicated to transportation projects in April 1993.
The battle will be fought on at least two fronts: how to divide the money between highways and mass transportation, and how to divide it regionally between New York City, its suburbs and upstate.
 
Clean Air
 The Senate has already approved legislation that would allow the state to delay the carrying out of tough new standards on reducing motor vehicle emissions. The bill's sponsors argue that the so-called California standards, which have been adopted by New York and would require cleaner cars to be sold in the state, would have a significant economic impact on automobile manufacturing and related industries. The same bill is being considered in the Assembly.
 
Environment
 With the voters' rejection of a $1.9 billion Environmental Bond Act two years ago, the Legislature has yet to create a permanent fund to finance recycling, water treatment, landfill closings and open-space preservation. Such projects could be financed in part by the $80 million a year from beverage taxes that were intended to pay interest on the failed bond act.
 
Adirondacks
 As the Adirondack Park enters its centennial year, the Legislature is expected to address finally a major package of proposals by Mr. Cuomo intended to protect the park's wilderness. The Governor's bill would tighten zoning restrictions in some lake-front and back-country areas while also expanding tax incentives for land preservation.
 
Bond Act
 The Legislature must give its approval to an $800 million job development bond act, proposed by Mr. Cuomo, for the proposal to be placed on November's general election ballot. Most of the bond act proceeds would be dedicated to infrastructure improvements like roads and sewage hookups that make areas more attractive to businesses. But legislators are likely to ask whether the state can afford more borrowing at a time when its debt burden has increased and its revenues are flat.
 
New York City Taxes
 Mayor David N. Dinkins has asked the Legislature to give him the authority to raise a number of New York City taxes. His proposals include an increase in the tax on income earned in the city by nonresidents, a 5-cent-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax, and a 1 percent tax on the value of cars registered in the city. He would also make permanent a surcharge on personal income taxes that is scheduled to expire next year.
 
TuitionHE>
Last week the City University of New York announced an unprecedented plan that would increase tuition by $600 a year for new students and by $350 a year for current students. If new students make it to their senior year, their last semester would be free.
But some lawmakers have argued that such a two-tier plan might be illegal. That could force the Legislature to either clarify the law so that City University could move ahead or take a formal step to kill the plan.
The State University of New York may try to pursue a first-ever plan to vary tuition among its 34 state-operated campuses. It cannot do so without legislative approval.
 
Cameras in the Courts
 The state's four-year experiment with cameras in the courtroom ended last year, and the Legislature has been unable to reach a compromise that would extend the program.
The main impediment last year was the insistence of Senate Republicans that witnesses in court cases be given the option of refusing to have their testimony filmed. This year, Senate leaders have said they may offer a compromise in which witnesses could choose to have their faces obscured.
 
Rental Cars
 New York's vicarious liability statute makes car owners legally responsible for damages caused by a driver, even if the car is rented. The Hertz Corporation recently used the law to justify its imposition of surcharges on renters from certain parts of New York City to cover higher liability costs in those areas. In response to the outcry provoked by Hertz's announcement, legislation has been introduced in the Senate to prohibit the surcharges while placing caps on vicarious liability.
 
Horse Racing
 The budget passed earlier this month includes $50 million from the sale of a 40-acre parking lot at Aqueduct race track by the New York Racing Authority to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
But the deal is contingent on a legislative agreement to allow the racing authority to simulcast horse races into homes via pay-per-view cable television. Bettors would be able to wager from their homes after establishing credit with the track.
The plan has been hung up over details of how the simulcasting system would work, including whether it would be controlled by the racing authority or by local off-track-betting corporations.
 
Item Pricing
 The state's 1976 item pricing law, which required all supermarkets to put individual price stickers on most items they sell, expired last June. While New York City and 10 counties have item pricing laws of their own, consumer groups point out that such laws are not uniform. They want the state law reinstated and made permanent.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Official Is Optimistic

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
A senior International Monetary Fund official brushed aside worries about a world recession and forecast faster global growth next year.
"Even if we see downward risk here and there, our expectation is for a global recovery," he said at a briefing ahead of the I.M.F.'s semiannual meeting here later this month. 
 The official, who requested anonymity, spoke to reporters on Friday but his remarks were embargoed until today. He forecast global growth next year of 3.25 percent after a meager 1.75 percent rise in 1992.
Some private economists are not so sanguine. They argue that Japan's stock market collapse, Germany's slumping growth and America's doubtful recovery have increased the odds of a global downturn.
"Given the financial fragilities around the world, we could easily be tipped into a world recession," said C. Fred Bergsten, a former United States official who is director of the Institute for International Economics, a research organization here.
That is a worry shared by the Bush Administration, which is afraid that weak growth overseas will sabotage the hesitant American recovery and hurt the President's chances for re-election.

HEADLINE: Credit Card Issuers Seeking New Ways to Keep Business

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
As competition heats up in the credit card business and big banks announce lower interest rates, bankers are still looking for new features -- like the customer's picture printed on the card -- to set themselves apart.
Citibank, the country's leading issuer of credit cards, plans to announce today an offer to print, without charge, a stamp-size photograph of the customer on the back of its credit cards. The bank says the pictures will help fight fraudulent use of the cards, which costs the industry about $1 billion a year. 
 On Thursday, Citibank announced that it was reducing interest rates for about nine million of its best card customers. The bank has more than 30 million credit cards.
 
Competitors Expected to Respond
 Banking analysts expect leading competitors, like Sears, Roebuck's Discover card, Chase Manhattan Bank, Bank of America, First National Bank of Chicago and American Telephone & Telegraph Company's Universal Card to respond with marketing ploys of their own.
As bankers and their marketing experts look for ways to keep their customers, they are recognizing that many are no longer impressed by offers like roadside auto service, travel insurance and protection against damage to goods purchased by credit card.
"The real movement now is the reduction in interest rates or elimination of annual fees," said Kurt T. Peters, editor of the Credit Card News, published in Chicago. "The bells-and-whistles enhancements put on cards in the late 1980's have run their course."
Mr. Peters said many issuers had reduced or dropped some extra services introduced in the 1980's. Citibank, for example, dropped free travel accident insurance coverage from most cards, Chase Manhattan reduced the amount of travel accident insurance it offers and Bank of America dropped a plan that insured items purchased with a card from loss or theft and doubled warranty coverage.
In contrast to the trend of the 1980's, when the banks concentrated on signing up new card customers, the current push is aimed at keeping the customers they already have.
David Robertson, president of the Nilson Report, a Santa Monica, Calif., newsletter covering the credit card industry, said, "The marketing war between the largest issuers is going to heat up, with lots of offers of lower prices and other benefits for customers who use their cards more frequently." Among the benefits he expects to see are offers of coupons or free merchandise for customers who use their cards often.
Many bankers have also learned that it is cheaper to offer services that reduce the number of customers who drop the bank -- now about 1 in 20 -- than it is to attract new accounts.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
The Fed's Master of Obfuscation

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
When it comes to Greenspan-speak, everybody is an expert. Stockbrokers translate his every utterance into buy and sell orders; bond dealers make their markets dance; the dollar wiggles, the mark jiggles.
Such confidence is somewhat strange, because the sole practitioner of Greenspan-speak, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, works extremely hard at being extremely circumspect about his intentions. 
 Take this example from a Congressional hearing last month, as senators were badgering him to cut interest rates to speed economic recovery:
"While I've indicated to you previously that we may well have, probably do have, enough monetary stimulus in the system to create that, I'm not sure that we will not need some insurance or to revisit this issue, and all I can say to you is that we're all looking at the same set of data, the same economy, the same sense of confidence which pervades it. We're all making our judgments with respect to how that is evolving with respect to economic activity and where the risks of various different actions are. And there will be differences inevitably."
In other words: recent cuts in interest rates just might be working to create a rebound. Or they might not.
Mr. Greenspan seems to reserve his most Delphic utterances for occasions on which he must discuss monetary policy and interest rates. Even on less market-sensitive subjects, however, it generally helps to have a practiced ear. For one thing, he often plays the king of understatement, as in an appearance last Friday before the Senate Banking Committee. He said then that he was "reluctant to advocate significant fiscal stimulus," when what he meant was that he strenuously opposed tax cuts or spending increases.
And, of course, the nature of Mr. Greenspan's subject matter often requires multiple readings to get his drift. Such was the case in his Friday testimony when he said, "The long-term capital inflow and current-account surplus in 1991 were offset by large private short-term capital outflows."
When Mr. Greenspan testifies, he attacks mountains of economic statistics like a slalom skier, weaving from positive to negative to positive to negative, twisting adroitly to a finish line marked with a banner reading "Uncertain."
One reason he takes such care to hedge is that monetary policy can be so easily hijacked by how traders interpret his remarks. Indeed, Mr. Greenspan denies neither his intent nor his choice of weapon.
"Since I've become a central banker, I've learned to mumble with great incoherence," he once told Congress.
In 1978, Congress began requiring Federal Reserve chairmen to testify regularly on monetary policy. These appearances have become exercises in hide and seek, where Fed chairmen reveal a few tidbits and play masters of obscurantism on most matters.
 
Freewheeling Predecessor
 Paul A. Volcker, Mr. Greenspan's predecessor, was also deliberately ambiguous when he testified before Congress. But the cigar-chomping Mr. Volcker was usually more freewheeling and occasionally more willing to signal his intentions.
David M. Jones, of Aubrey G. Lamston & Company, a New York securities dealer, a Fed watcher who has written tomes about such testimony, is full of praise for Mr. Greenspan. "I can't remember when there was such a master of obfuscation on analytical matters," he said.
But sometimes even masters stumble. On Jan. 29, stocks and bonds plunged after Mr. Greenspan made what he thought were some innocent remarks. "Monetary policy is clearly working to try to break the back of this credit crunch," he said. "Is it enough? I think so. Do I know that for sure? The answer is no."
The markets focused on the first half of his remarks and ignored the second half, pushing interest rates up and stock prices down on the belief that the Fed would no longer lower short-term rates. In subsequent testimony, Mr. Greenspan said that the market reaction surprised him, since he thought his suggestion that a recovery was in the offing should have buoyed the markets.
So six days later he made a slight change. "We expect that the amount of monetary ease in the pipeline is adequate to turn the economy onto the path of sustained recovery," he said. "We are, of course, continuing to evaluate whether some additional insurance in the way of further monetary ease would be appropriate."
After that remark, the markets ignored the first half of what he said and focused on the second half. And they soared.
Fed watchers say it is often hard to tell whether any given statement from the chairman is made murky because he wants to keep bond traders confused or because he himself is honestly confused about what signals the nation's economy is sending.
"If you read carefully what he says, I don't think you're misled," said Stephen Axilrod, a former staff director of monetary policy at the Fed who is now vice chairman of Nikko Securities in New York. "You're put in the same situation as he is."
But neither traders nor journalists are paid to be confused. When Mr. Greenspan goes to Capitol Hill, as soon as he says something that might -- or that some journalist thinks might -- indicate how the Fed will move, a half-dozen wire service reporters sprint out the door to phone in stories.
 
Detours and U-Turns
 Making matters more difficult for Mr. Greenspan and his listeners is the length of hearings. As they drag on from three to four or five hours, the syntax of his hypercomplex answers develops new detours and U-turns.
"His sentences are long and complicated, and you can watch on television as the senators listening to him get that my-eyes-glaze-over look," Mr. Jones said. "They try to hide it because they don't want to show that they've lost his train of thought."
Some economists say one reason Mr. Greenspan's jargon is so "on the one hand, on the other hand" is that he is afraid of making an incorrect forecast -- as he did last summer. Like most other economists then, he talked of a recovery gathering steam. But the pickup sputtered last fall when consumer confidence dived and consumer spending stalled.
Before becoming Fed chairman, Mr. Greenspan headed an economic forecasting firm, and even then he was cautious. Now he is quadruply so.
"This is an extremely difficult period to make economic projections," he told Congress on Feb. 25. "Hopefully we may be underestimating what's going on. But I think it is just as likely that we might be failing to even attain those levels that we are talking about."
Then, worrying that the signs of economic spring might suddenly be killed off by a sudden frost, he added, "I think it is crucially important that we not be misled by what is happening currently."
Many economists say the markets are dissecting Mr. Greenspan's language even more than that of his predecessors because with the huge budget deficit sending fiscal policy to the sidelines, monetary policy has become the policy maker's only weapon.
"The markets are worrying more about him, and he worries more about the markets," Mr. Jones said. "Sometimes it seems he is almost reacting to his own shadow."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Elle Clamors for Attention With a 'Naughty' Challenge

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
ELLE is responding to intensified competition in the women's fashion magazine field with a cheeky suggestion, "Go to Elle."
The theme appears in a series of print advertisements and posters that are part of the most extensive, and expensive, trade and consumer circulation promotion campaign to date for the Hachette Magazines monthly. The ads, which begin running today, appear as Elle's chief competitors, Vogue and Harper's Bazaar, are cranking up their own hoopla machinery. 
 Vogue, a Conde Nast publication, is commemorating its 100th anniversary with a special April issue. Harper's Bazaar, published by Hearst Magazines, is bringing in a new editor in chief as well as planning to mark its 125th anniversary later this year. At age 3, Mirabella, the fourth magazine in the crowded, contentious field, is too young for an anniversary party, but is celebrating winning a National Magazine Award last week for general excellence.
"We would raise our voice even if the noise were not out there," Gail S. Stone, Elle's vice president and publisher of almost five months, said in an interview last week at Hachette's office in midtown Manhattan. "We have a lot to say."
Among the points Ms. Stone is seeking to impress upon the advertising community about the French magazine's American edition are its circulation strength -- the rate base, the circulation guaranteed to advertisers, recently rose 6.1 percent, to 875,000 -- and its ability to attract advertisers in categories like automobiles, liquor and food.
David Pecker, president and chief operating officer at Hachette, said the $2 million to be spent on Elle in the next nine months was the most ever devoted to a single Hachette magazine campaign.
The 15 ads and posters are the creation of the mischievous minds at Lois U.S.A. The three-word theme typifies the agency's penchant for short, snappy, somewhat unsophisticated slogans for media clients: "Make time for Time" for Time magazine; "In your face" for ESPN, the sports cable television network, and "I want my MTV" for that music video cable network.
"You want people not only to remember it, but to have fun with it," said George Lois, the agency's chairman and chief executive in New York. "You can get away with 'Go to Elle' because it's a French, sassy, hip magazine. I don't think you could do anything that naughty for Mirabella or Vogue."
Ms. Stone agreed. "Most successful advertising is somewhat tongue-in-cheek," she said. "So when Lois came up with the idea, we thought it was right on target. We want everybody to 'go to Elle' with their advertising."
To achieve that goal, the campaign involves advertisers in an unusual manner. Companies that already buy ad pages in Elle, like the makers of Nike athletic footwear and Guess jeans, are lending Lois images from their own advertisements.
For instance, one Elle ad uses a photograph from a Guess ad, featuring a Marilyn Monroe look-alike; the headline reads, "Guess who went to Elle." Another reprints six Absolut vodka ads, created by TBWA Advertising in New York, with the headline "One more . . . for the Absolut Elle of it!"
Like the other fashion magazines, Elle's advertising sales have suffered during the recession. Last year, ad pages fell 23.3 percent from 1990, the second-largest decline in the category after a 26.3 percent plunge at Harper's Bazaar. And for the first six months of this year -- Elle's issues are closed through June -- ad pages dropped 14 percent from the comparable period in 1991, Ms. Stone said.
The print ads are scheduled to run in publications like Advertising Age, The Chicago Tribune, Inside Media, The New York Times, W and The Wall Street Journal. Beginning next month, the posters will appear on bus shelters and telephone kiosks and at airports and newsstands.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Lower Rates Prompt Refinancings

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
To the dismay of investors and the delight of corporate treasurers, the steady slide in interest rates over the last three years has prompted a rising number of companies to redeem billions in outstanding debt issued when rates were much higher.
Through April 15, 362 issues totaling more than $33 billion have already been called or will soon be called, according to Fitch Investors Service Inc., a bond rating concern. 
 "Corporate America is going to have a much better-looking balance sheet," said Nancy M. Drucker, a vice president of Fitch. "Individual investors, on the other hand, are seeing nest eggs that had been earning 9 percent or more going out the window."
Based on the number of bonds that are either callable or refundable this year, Ms. Drucker estimated that more than $70 billion in corporate debt could ultimately be called in 1992, assuming interest rates remain close to current levels.
 
Carbide and Du Pont Refinancing
 The Du Pont Company and the Union Carbide Corporation are the most recent additions to the expanding list of companies that intend to refinance high-cost debt.
Last week, Du Pont said that on June 14 it would redeem all $2.13 billion in face amount of zero-coupon bonds due in 2010. Also last week, Union Carbide said that on May 5 it would call all $350 million outstanding of 9 3/4 percent senior subordinated notes maturing in 1994.
Analysts say the trend is important because most of the torrents of new issues sold this year have been used to replace callable debt, not to raise new money.
"Despite the first-quarter deluge of corporate bond issues, corporations continue to pare total debt," Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, wrote in the firm's weekly "Comments on Credit" letter to clients.
The weakness of private credit demand when Government credit demand continues to expand at seemingly breakneck speed largely explains why market interest rates have declined as much as they have in the last two years.
And fears that huge Treasury borrowings will crowd out other issuers and drive up interest rates will not be realized as long as corporate credit demand remains weak, the analysts say.
"Private-sector debt growth is the lowest it has been since 1952, when records started to be kept," said Paul D. Mastroddi, an economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. "The voluntary cutback in private-sector borrowing has saved the day for the United States."
 
Trend Growing Since 1989
 Though the volume of corporate bond calls will likely hit record proportions this year, the deleveraging trend has been accelerating since 1989.
The dollar volume of corporate bonds called has risen from $30.5 billion in 1989 to $35.3 billion in 1990 and $50.1 billion last year, the Fitch data show. In addition, short-term debt issued by corporations decreased last year.
"We very well may be in a period when the use of debt becomes almost taboo," said Thomas J. Sowanick, senior fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
Although lower debt-service payments provided by refinancing at lower rates are the primary reason that companies choose to call outstanding bonds, interest rate levels are by no means the only consideration in making such a decision, corporate finance specialists said.
"The decision to refinance is very obvious if you want to refund a bond with a coupon of 13 percent or 14 percent," said Andrew Kalotay, president of Andrew Kalotay Associates, a New York consulting firm that specializes in debt management. "But it becomes a much tougher choice if you are looking at refinancing 9.50 percent issues with 8.50 percent paper."
A range of accounting considerations, from tax treatment to transaction costs, are among the factors corporate treasurers need to consider in such instances. In addition, Mr. Kalotay said companies needed to determine the value of the option the call represented before making a decision.
 
An Asset That Can Be Overlooked
 Exercising the call option under circumstances in which the difference between market rates and rates on an outstanding issue are fairly narrow eliminates any possibility of greater savings should interest rates move lower.
"In addition to looking at borrowing costs, you need to consider the value of the call options, which are assets," Mr. Kalotay said. "When you refund a bond, you are cashing that in."
The move to refinance and pare down high-cost debt has been generally applauded as a necessary palliative to the leverage excesses of the 1980's.
But if the economy is to grow at more than its current anemic pace, private credit demand will need to pick up. A turnaround is not imminent, analysts said.
"Corporate demands on the credit markets are very cyclical," Mr. Mastroddi said.
"Usually, a year or two after an expansion gets going they start tapping the markets for funds to expand capacity and the like."
At roughly 78 percent, capacity utilization in the manufacturing sector is currently quite low, Mr. Mastroddi said.
"There is no sense that a pickup in capital spending is going on," he said. "And I don't see it happening anytime soon."
