HEADLINE: Exhibition On Blacks And Jews Is Faulted

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE

 BODY:
Hundreds of compelling objects and images -- from a Jewish child's 1939 textbook with a Yiddish translation of a Langston Hughes poem to a photograph of black American soldiers standing among corpses after they liberated Buchenwald -- make up the exhibition "Bridges and Boundaries: African-Americans and American Jews" at the Jewish Museum's temporary galleries at the New-York Historical Society.
But the show, a collaboration between the Jewish Museum and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People that attempts to trace the complex relationship between blacks and Jews, has itself drawn criticism from several labor organizations, many of whose members are Jewish. 
 Before the exhibition opened last month, representatives of the United Federation of Teachers, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the Jewish Labor Committee contended that it inaccurately or unfairly portrayed aspects of their movements. They were upset by, among other things, the show's initial plans to use what they described as 30-year-old discredited charges by an official of the N.A.A.C.P., who said that black and Puerto Rican members of the garment workers' union were discriminated against "in terms of wages and other conditions of employment and in their status as members of the union."
The exhibition's organizers have removed the allegation that the I.L.G.W.U. found offensive, replacing it with a quote from a black rank-and-file union member who actually experienced discrimination during the 50's. But David Melman, an assistant to the president of the I.L.G.W.U., said his organization was not satisfied with the replacement quote, either. Its inference, he said, that the union made no attempt to train black women in the face of discrimination in the work place "was not true from what we could determine."
Jeannette DiLorenzo, the treasurer of the teachers' union, complained that her organization was not consulted by the show's organizers about the controversial school decentralization experiment in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section in Brooklyn in the 1960's. The teachers' union played a central role in that experiment, which Ms. DiLorenzo contends is inaccurately portrayed in the exhibition as one in which "black children and Jewish teachers were at the heart of the struggle that took place." The real issues, she said, involved contractual rights and due process.
Despite the complaints, the union representatives generally approved of the exhibition. Ms. DiLorenzo gave it an "A for effort," and Mr. Melman said its "positive side outweighs the negative side, both as it relates to the I.L.G.W.U. and in general."
"We always knew we were going to be dealing with controversial issues," said Ward Mintz, the Jewish Museum's assistant director for programs. "We relied on scholarship of many, many people, including major academic advisers in a variety of fields, so we do feel that all of our research is based on substantial scholarship and we are very serious about that."
 
'A Rich, Complex History'
 "Bridges and Boundaries," which took four years to assemble, comprises more than 350 works of art, artifacts, photographs, documents, film and television excerpts and press materials. Gretchen Sullivan Sorin, the show's guest curator, said an effort had been made to "include many different voices -- including people neither black nor Jewish and people both black and Jewish -- and talk about not just one community of African-Americans or one community of American Jews but multiple communities, to come up with a rich, complex history that includes the views of many."
Included among the exhibits are 1850 daguerreotypes of slaves stripped to the waist, a candlestick with a bullet hole from the Kishinev pogrom in Russia in 1903 and a children's book from 1831 that underscores ways in which notions of inferiority were planted: Africans were described as going "almost without clothes" while the English were "very wise and very rich."
There are also the 1964 F.B.I. "missing" poster for the slain civil rights workers James Chaney, Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner, and a letter Rae Frank wrote to her imprisoned son, Leo, a Jewish manager of a Georgia pencil factory, before whites abducted and lynched him in 1915 after his death sentence for murder had been commuted. Excerpts from feature films made between 1904 and 1958 trace the evolution of Hollywood's often stereotyped images of blacks and Jews.
The exhibition space is designed to evoke five historical "places" or settings where the paths of blacks and Jews have crossed in important ways in this century, as shared pains and battles against bigotry brought them together and tensions around the issues of class, race and economic disparity drove them apart.
The interaction of blacks and Jews in the I.L.G.W.U. and other unions is explored in a setting called "Joining and Organizing: Strength in Numbers." A scene called "Changing Identities: What's Ours Is Ours" uses the Ocean Hill-Brownsville struggle to illustrate how some blacks and Jews moved in opposite directions over such issues as community control, affirmative action and the black power movement.
Themes of freedom and liberation appear in the work of both African-American and American Jewish artists in the exhibition. Isac Friedlander, a Jewish artist, used "Exodus" as the title of his 1931 work symbolizing the freeing of the slaves. "Sanctuary," a 1946 linocut by Wilmer Angier Jennings, a black artist, represents either the underground railroad or the Holocaust.
Among those who worked closely with the Jewish Museum in assembling the exhibition was Mildred Roxborough, the director of development programs for the N.A.A.C.P., which was founded in 1909 by a multi-racial group and is the oldest of the nation's civil rights organizations. Now 64 years old, she was only 9 when she joined the civil rights group and started selling its magazine, The Crisis, after her parents organized a branch in Brownsville, Tenn., to fight for the right to vote. For her, the exhibition has practical relevance.
"We wanted this to help us learn about those who helped us in our struggle and those who hindered us," she said. "We think past experience can help us with future relationships."
The exhibition will be at the New-York Historical Society until July 19, after which it is to travel to San Francisco; Rochester; Baltimore; Wilberforce, Ohio; Los Angeles; Philadelphia, and Chicago.

HEADLINE: The Talk of Hollywood;
'Malcolm X' Is Setting An Industry Brushfire Months Before Release

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, April 19

 BODY:
Denzel Washington remarked the other day that his newest film, "Malcolm X," would not be the most controversial film of the year. "It's going to be the most controversial film of the decade," he said.
It's probably just Hollywood hyperbole, but the actor's comment underlines the anticipation here for the forthcoming Spike Lee film, which is stirring even more talk, if that's possible, than that other controversial Warner Brothers film, Oliver Stone's "J. F. K." And "Malcolm X," which is being edited, doesn't even open until Thanksgiving. 
 What got the "Malcolm X" controversy going and has kept it bubbling -- always good for business -- are issues involving money and personality coupled with the continuing fascination with and debate over the legacy of Malcolm X, the black nationalist leader who was slain 27 years ago. The movie, starring Mr. Washington, has been filmed in Harlem, upstate New York, Egypt and South Africa, among other places, and Mr. Lee, who has never been shy about his own endeavors, has described it as "an epic picture on the scale of the great films that David Lean did." The reference was to "Lawrence of Arabia" and "Dr. Zhivago."
The problem with epics, though, is they are expensive and run far longer than two hours, hardly what movie executives are seeking in the current recessionary mood.
Initially budgeted at $28 million, which is not elaborately expensive, the movie's costs have climbed to $33 million. This prompted the Completion Bond Company, which insures investors against films going over budget, to take financial control of the movie and inform Mr. Lee that his film was to be no longer than 2 hours and 15 minutes. Mr. Lee recently showed Warner Brothers executives a four-hour version and said that if Oliver Stone could create a more than three-hour movie about John F. Kennedy, then he should have equal time for Malcolm X. Studios generally abhor great length in films because it reduces the number of times a day the film can be shown at theaters.
But the producer of "Malcolm X," Marvin Worth, who has made such movies as "Lennie" and "The Rose," made it plain that he wanted a three-hour film if that was what Mr. Lee wanted. "I showed a four-hour cut to Warner's and the bond company and no one even went to the bathroom," he said. "They loved it." Mr. Lee is in New York editing the movie.
The film is largely based on a screenplay written more than 20 years ago by James Baldwin and Arnold Perl, who are both dead. Mr. Worth said that Malcolm X's widow, Betty Shabazz, served as a consultant on the movie, which traces Malcolm's life from his early days of petty crime to his prison conversion to the Nation of Islam and his rise to become a leader who preached black pride and self-reliance.
The film has already provoked a dispute among blacks -- and this may very well grow. Mr. Lee has tangled with the poet Amiri Baraka, who has said that the movie, which he has not seen, will be a distortion of Malcolm X's life "to make middle-class Negroes sleep easier." He has also deplored several of Mr. Lee's previous movies, including "Do the Right Thing" and "She's Gotta Have It," for their depiction of blacks, and said the film maker "is part of a retrograde movement in this country."
Despite reports that lawyers, agents and producers are still hassling over the movie, Warner Brothers officials and Mr. Worth insist that everything is normal, for the moment. "There's no fighting, no trouble in River City," said Mr. Worth, sighing.
 
An Age-Old Problem

Del Reisman declines to say how old he is.
As president of the Writers Guild of America, West, which represents Hollywood's 8,000 movie and television writers, Mr. Reisman indicates that his decision to keep his age private is a matter of professional survival for a writer in a town where 40 is old, over 40 is very old. And it's also a statement about his role with the Writers Guild.
"I'm acting in behalf of hundreds and hundreds of writers in not mentioning my age," he said in his office on Beverly Boulevard. "I would like to make a point that age is irrelevant. I'm gray haired. I'm not a kid. I began writing for television in the 1950's. But at a certain age in this town -- let's face it -- you're in trouble."
Mr. Reisman has made a successful career writing for numerous television series. He began in the 1950's as story editor for the live show "Playhouse 90" and has written for such shows as "The Untouchables," "Rawhide," "Peyton Place" and "Streets of San Francisco."
He said that since he took over the Writers Guild six months ago, the age problem for writers had turned into a nightmare. The sluggish economy, the diminishing number of studio development deals, the rising number of under-30 television executives who want to hire their own friends and classmates for shows aimed at the 20-something crowd, the town's youth culture, have left many older writers reeling. "A lot of older writers are having serious problems," he said. "Especially on television."
Mr. Reisman said it was common now for older writers like himself (he served in Europe in World War II) to list their credits for producers or executives, but discard the last page or two that may begin in the 1950's. "It's not wise to list your credits going back," he said. "It's a way of telling the executive, 'Boy, am I old.' A lot of writers simply won't refer to past credits."
Older writers pitching stories often take younger writers with them. "It takes the edge off the fact of their age," he said.
Mr. Reisman said: "I have a sense of great failure and frustration. I thought I could make a dent in this problem. A little dent. And I haven't been able to. And I'm very upset about this kind of ladies' and gentlemen's agreement that's so pervasive among executives. It's not a plot. It's an ingrained attitude. We can no longer approach the industry on the basis of compassion. We can't say you're hurting nice people. That doesn't work. We can only say that you're overlooking some real talent."

HEADLINE: How Health Insurers Get Away With Fraud;
For National Reform

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report that Federal court rulings have given employers that act as their own insurers wide leeway to cut medical insurance benefits (front page, March 29). You thus create the impression that we can cure the ills of our health care system if we replace the Federal law that regulates employer-provided health plans with state-by-state regulation of health care benefits. Nothing could be further from reality.
Health-care coverage is a national issue, and reform of our health care system requires national solutions. If we abandon Federal laws like the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, also called Erisa, for a patchwork of state-by-state regulation, employers will be forced to spend scarce dollars complying with a dizzying array of state mandates and on expensive litigation that too often reflects the influence of special interests. Employers will have to cut back on the breadth of -- or even altogether drop -- their health-care coverage. Needless to say, state mandates and financial incentives to sue will chill any inclination to provide coverage by those employers who do not now do so. 
 The most glaring weakness of our health-care system is not Erisa's pre-emption of state laws. At the heart of the growing crisis is the system's failure to contain the extraordinary escalating cost of health care, soon to exceed 13 percent of gross national product. Neither employers nor Federal and state governments can afford to cover every infirmity and every medical procedure, let alone the type of custodial nursing care you cite anecdotally.
The nation's largest employers, represented by my committee, has adopted a policy statement on health care system reform, which asserts that comprehensive health-care coverage for employees will be in jeopardy unless we address the cost and quality concerns that must be the focus of national reform.
We need national reform that provides for cost containment, accountability and affordability. Promises to increase access without such reform are at best empty and at worst a cruel fraud.
 
MARK J. UGORETZ
President, Erisa Industry Committee
Washington, April 2, 1992

HEADLINE: Let's Look at These 12 Years of Misrule

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The barrenness, paucity, cynicism and indifference of the Republican Administration were clearly exposed on the same day, March 30, by two opposing forces in the Republican Party, namely the anonymous Republican author of "Our Do-Nothing Government" (Op-Ed) and Representative Newt Gingrich ("The Slow-Motion Suicide of the World's Once Greatest City," letter).
The Op-Ed writer describes a Republican Administration bereft of concrete ideas and programs for solving the enormous problems it spawned through 12 years of bungling and ineptitude. 
 Mr. Gingrich illustrates a well-known tactic of attacking whatever or whoever may seem fashionable to attack to divert attention from those problems and the lack of concrete programs to alleviate them. He could better serve the American public by facing the homelessness, poverty, hunger, violence, voodoo economics, flip-flop foreign policies, inadequate health care, high infant mortality rate, AIDS and dependence on foreign oil that have exploded during the last 12 years of Republican rule.
It is no less than obscene that more Americans are killed by handguns in one day than in Japan in one year; that American taxpayers will pay $500 billion to bail out the savings and loan scandal; that one of every five children in America lives below the poverty level; that two million Americans at the top earn as much income as 100 million Americans at the bottom; that the Republican leaders think so little of American citizens they dare not articulate the sacrifices that sooner or later must be made to solve the problems.
Mr. Gingrich should focus on some of the serious problems that concern the majority of Americans, instead of bashing New York City. I would just remind him: Do not be concerned with the speck in your neighbor's eye until you have removed the log from your own.
 
HAROLD E. DE BONA
Manchester, Vt., April 1, 1992

HEADLINE: Killing City's Dreams;
East Orange Sorrows Over 6 Deaths

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 19

 BODY:
In the last week East Orange, a community long troubled by urban ills, has found itself defined, at least temporarily, by the conclusion that six women were murdered and their bodies discarded here beneath train trestles, along highway embankments or in abandoned buildings.
But if America's experience with mass murder is any guide, the geography of these killings was purely coincidental, not an indictment of a place or its people. "It could have happened anywhere" was a familiar refrain here last week. 
 And while two arrests in the case have helped to allay some fears, there remains a sense of sorrow that it did, indeed, happen here, in a city already weary with its struggle to sustain or attract a black middle class since the migration of whites to newer suburbs more than 25 years ago.
Once a true suburb of New York and Newark, East Orange now seems neither urban nor suburban, but instead a string of densely populated neighborhoods whose inhabitants have little in common with the well-to-do ruling class that built it.
With East Orange weighed down by a high crime rate, high property taxes and low property values, being middle class here may be more a state of mind than a statistical fact. By all standard measures, said George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of urban planning at Rutgers, East Orange represents the failure of black suburbanization.
"This is where we should have really focused all our energies, because no one really knew what to do with our central cities," he said. But with the black migration from Newark in the 1960's and 1970's, he said, a large economic vacuum left by retreating whites went unfilled, and the city's class structure was undermined.
Yet the suburban dream of property, comfort and safety lives on along many streets in this city of 73,000, where block after block of spacious turn-of-the-century homes still provide comfort, if not grandeur.
The dream is evident on Crawford Street, a residential block that would be typical, except that one of the murder victims lived there.
 
Was on Her Way Home
 It was at No. 70, a two-story white frame house near the corner of Rhode Island Avenue, that Elizabeth Clenor, 30 years old, the widowed mother of two young children, lived with her mother, Theresa James. Mrs. James has described her daughter as a hard worker who had held a series of jobs, as a food shop manager, cashier, even forklift operator. On Feb. 17, she telephoned to say she was on her way home, but she never arrived. Last Monday, the authorities announced that hers was one of three bodies found by the police on April 10.
The news was stunning, but the residents of Crawford Street, by most of their accounts, did not break stride. Their lives are bounded by work, home, children and school, and there is little time for anything else.
"I didn't know them, but I knew them by sight," said Clifton Miller, who lives across the street from No. 70 and who leaves the house at 4:30 A.M. on weekdays to drive a truck for a private hauler. "They were quiet. The whole street is very quiet."
In its two-block stretch from Tremont Avenue on the Newark border, Crawford Street has about 40 one- or two-family houses. And while few are trimmed with prosperity, most exude a sense of responsibility.
 
Knowing Few Neighbors
 Almost all are occupied by their owners, and few have changed hands in recent years. A pedestrian is a rare sight after 9 A.M. or before late afternoon.
Neighbors say they tend to know only those who live across the street, or upstairs, or next door. Few say they actually knew Ms. Clenor, who lived near one corner.
Thelma and Delmore Washington have owned half of a two-family house on Crawford Street for 20 years. They both recently retired, he as a ship's engineer in the merchant marine and she as a saleswoman at the Livingston Mall. Both of their sons went to college and now live in Union County. But for the Washingtons, East Orange is home.
"No reason to move," Mrs. Washington said.
That was not the case 20 years ago, when their sons were young and they moved into a new subdivision in another New Jersey town.
 
'There Were Some Incidents'
 "Our son was the first black in his school in 97 years," Mr. Washington said. "There were some incidents." They moved here and put their sons in a New Jersey prep school.
"What happened was very sad," Mrs. Washington said of the killings. "It could have happened any place, but it's sad."
Their neighbors are Billie and Harry Wilson and their 8-year-old son, Jon-Nicholas. When the Wilsons bought their 70-year-old house six years ago, the interior wood trim was in great shape, and they reinstalled a pair of French doors -- "in the attic since '45," Mrs. Wilson said.
The Wilsons moved from Jamaica, Queens, she said, because "there was more real estate for the dollar here." Mrs. Wilson, a former secretary at CBS in Manhattan, takes temporary jobs now, and her husband, an illustrator and editor of manuals for a shipbuilder, was laid off recently."
Crime is not a factor. "I don't even think about it," she said. "The neighbors next door have a Doberman and the lights outside are on all night."
"The block has improved since we got here," she said, pointing to a bright white house across the street. "It seems like everybody put new siding on."
But upward mobility in East Orange cannot be assured. With the recession losses felt more keenly here and little industry to bank on, its potential as an emerging zone for the black middle class has not been realized as it was for whites decades ago.
"East Orange entered the 20th century a city of well-appointed homes and prospering businesses, one of the state's wealthiest communities," according to a history published to commemorate its centennial in 1964.
Upper Central Avenue became a suburban Fifth Avenue, with branches of New York merchandising giants like Best & Company, B. Altman and Black, Starr & Gorham. Later, dozens of insurance companies moved here. Today, the low-rise storefronts are occupied mainly with small variety and food stores that replaced the more prosperous chains and large anchor stores.
Two monumental roadbuilding projects proved decisive, but not helpful. The Garden State Parkway and Route 280 sliced the city in quadrants with an effect that recalls the damage of the Cross Bronx Expressway in the Bronx. The parkway, the state's great north-south coastal highway, replaced a more modest lane called Oraton Parkway, tearing up the parklike median that stretched through the city like a carpet.
Route 280, an east-west cut from Newark to the western part of Essex County, should have proved a catalyst for businesses along its length, but did not. Four of the murder victims were found on and around the embankments and underpasses of these roads and nearby train tracks.
What these capital improvements began, the 1967 Newark riots finished, with a migration to East Orange, its nearest suburb.
"In the larger context, the white middle class moved into the true middle class, i.e. stored wealth, with the capacity to support their kids, their housing, or by going into business," Dr. Sternlieb said. "And they did it through real estate."
But an East Orange house that sells for $85,000 could bring three times that or more in Millburn, just six miles away, he said.
"If you move through most of New Jersey suburbia, and if you just sat on your property and you were fortunate, you could get 10 times your money," he said. "It was the super Christmas club. But East Orange failed. That is its terrible final tragedy."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 21, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A map yesterday with an article about East Orange, N.J., misidentified two major highways. South of Perth Amboy, the New Jersey Turnpike runs into the western part of the state and the Garden State Parkway runs along the shore.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL: THE PLAYOFF PICTURE
Knicks Seek Second Wind and Nets Hope They're Not Blown Away;
Fitch's Squad Hits Its Stride

BYLINE: By AL HARVIN

 BODY:
After Derrick Coleman and Chris Morris both refused to obey Coach Bill Fitch and go back into games last week, the conventional wisdom was that the Nets were a team in the process of self-destructing.
On Saturday night, however, New Jersey showed it is a team that defies conventional wisdom: The Nets defeated the Orlando Magic, 127-111, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena to advance to the National Basketball Association playoffs for the first time since 1986. 
 Coleman had 31 points, hitting 12 of 17 shots from the field. Morris scored 22, including 16 in the third quarter, when the Nets put the game away, finishing at 40-42 and nailing down sixth place in the Eastern Conference and a first-round playoff matchup with the Cavaliers, beginning Thursday in Richfield, Ohio.
"I congratulated the guys, said they worked hard and said they proved they deserved to be here," Fitch said after the game.
The 57-year-old Fitch, who is in his 21st season as an N.B.A. coach, refuses to compare this Nets team to his teams in Cleveland, Boston and Houston, but he has helped in a task of franchise rejuvenation in New Jersey just as he did in those cities.
In 1976, he won the league's coach-of-the-year award in Cleveland, and in 1980, he won it a second time with the Celtics. He should probably get at least a nomination for a third such award, considering how the Nets, who started the regular season at 2-11, finished. Despite the lingering bad feelings, New Jersey won 9 of its last 12 games and had a 21-14 record after the All-Star Game.
Fitch has been playing down his team's squabbling. "I don't believe in fining because it's like so much Monopoly money to these guys anyway," he has said. "By the time you fine and suspend and get the players coming in with their collars on straight and saying yes sir and no sir, you look up and you're 10 games out of the playoffs. So what good does it do?"
This little experiment in group dynamics has apparently worked for the time being, but the Nets will resume practice today, on the Fairleigh Dickinson campus in Teaneck, with some large questions looming about their future:
What's the significance of the Nets' having finally made the playoffs again?
True, it has been only two years since they finished with the worst record in the league, after Fitch took over for Willis Reed, who moved upstairs to the general manager's office. But the coach could still find himself unemployed later this year if the team does not at least make a respectable showing against the Cavaliers. The teams split their four games during the regular season, with each winning its home games.
By making the playoffs, the Nets won't have a first-round pick in this year's draft. But that shouldn't be a problem. Morris was the fourth player chosen over all in 1988; Mookie Blaylock was 12th in 1989; Coleman was first in 1990, and Kenny Anderson second in 1991. And Reed has a couple of second-round picks to use.
"This team is so young already, I don't think I'd want to have any rookies on it for the next four, five years," Reed, the club's senior vice president of basketball operations, said recently.
He is also adept at acquiring talent in other ways, witness Sam Bowie, Drazen Petrovic, Terry Mills and Chris Dudley, who were acquired in trades, and Rafael Addison, who was lured from Europe.
What are the keys to the Nets' doing well against Cleveland?
First, of course, New Jersey must find some semblance of team harmony.
Second, the Nets reserves must continue to play as well as they have been. Coleman, the league's rookie of the year last season, missed 17 games this season with various ailments, but Mills filled in ably at strong forward.
Dudley started 21 games in relief of Sam Bowie, and is averaging more rebounds than the starting center, 9 to 8.1, and more blocks, 2.1 to 1.67, although Bowie leads him in scoring, 15.0 to 5.6, and assists, 2.6 to 0.7.
The Nets proved they can win on the road this season, finishing with 15 road victories, the most since 1984-85.
They must use their youth to their advantage.
"We're not supposed to be here, so we'll go in feeling very loose," Bowie said. "I think it will be an exciting series and we won't embarrass the state of New Jersey. We're a confident group going in."
How far can they go?
It's going to be awfully tough to get past Cleveland (56-25), a team with a first-rate center in Brad Daugherty and one of the league's best floor leaders in Mark Price. But advancing is not really the point for the Nets this time around.
"The main goal was to get this franchise a winner, get it back where it had some respect, where something was expected of it besides losing, and now they've got that," said Fitch. "Now each guy has got an obligation to be here this time next year and the year after that because they're young players.
"I've said all along that winning is a lot harder to live up to than losing."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bill Fitch (pg. C1); Derrick Coleman, an enigma to his coach but talented enough to dominate a game by himself, gives the Nets a shot against Cleveland. (pg. C3) (Photographs by Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Battered Men Sounding Equal-Rights Battle Cry

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
After 15 years of publicity about the plight of battered women, battered men are beginning to demand equal time. Increasingly, men who say they have been victims of domestic violence are challenging the dogma that all violent spouses are male and are lobbying for changes in counseling, shelters and, above all, public perceptions dealing with domestic abuse.
 "We are just beginning to say, 'Hey, men, if you are being slapped, kicked or punched, that's illegal and you don't have to take it anymore,' " said George Gilliland Sr. of St. Paul, founder of the Domestic Rights Coalition, an advocacy group that plans to open the first shelter for battered men later this year. "We want equality. Let the cell doors slam shut behind women just as they do on men." 
The statistical underpinnings of this emerging branch of the men's rights movement come from several studies with surprising findings: that wives assault their husbands as often as husbands assault their wives.
 But the idea that battered men can be equated with battered women is disputed even by the author of the 1985 study most often quoted for that proposition. Because men are bigger and stronger, says the author, Murray Straus of the University of New Hampshire's Family Research Laboratory, their assaults are far more likely to cause serious injury.
 "From a policy standpoint, the emphasis should be on battered women, because women suffer by far the most injuries," he said in an interview. "But I am an absolutist against violence, and I think it's important to recognize that women are just as likely to use violence as men. If you're looking at assaults, not at who gets injured, it's one to one, women and men."
 For many feminists, those findings, and their use by men's-rights advocates, raise troubling questions about where the quest for equality crosses the line into misogyny, and when the swing of the social pendulum becomes an all-out backlash against feminism.
 "It's such a twisting of things to ignore the reality that women live in fear of men and men do not live in fear of women," said Ellen Pence, a founder of the Domestic Abuse Intervention Project in Duluth, Minn. "Domestic violence against men is just not a social problem."
 Men who are victims of domestic violence, however, say they suffer a special stigma. They complain bitterly of the injustice of a system that would punish them harshly for hitting back, but gives them no help in stopping their wives' assaults, and often treats the whole situation as comic.
 Mr. Straus's study surveyed 6,000 married and cohabiting couples, asking each spouse how often they or their partner used particular tactics, violent or nonviolent, to resolve conflicts.
 Women in the study were slightly more likely than men to have slapped, kicked, bitten or punched, hit or tried to hit with something or threatened with a gun or knife. Men were slightly more likely than women to have beaten up their spouses or choked them. Both sexes were equally likely to have used a knife or a gun on their partner. The overall finding that women were as assaultive as men matched that of a similar study Mr. Straus conducted 10 years earlier.
 
'A License for Hitting'
"I was originally very surprised at the numbers on women assaulting men but I shouldn't have been, given the cultural messages that it's O.K. to slap the cad if he gets fresh, or chase him with a frying pan." Mr. Straus said. "In this society, family relationships seem to be a license for hitting, whether it's women assaulting men, men assaulting women or parents assaulting their children."
 Many advocates for battered women say that despite Mr. Straus's reputation as an early researcher on battered wives, his findings are an outrageous skewing of the truth. It is misleading to speak of men and women as equally assaultive, they say, when it is almost always the women who live with broken bones, repeated visits to the emergency room and a constant fear for their lives.
 "Women abused by male partners tend to sustain multiple injuries to multiple sites of the body, an injury pattern not seen in men assaulted by female partners," said Dr. Angela Browne of the University of Massachusetts Medical School. The Straus findings also fail to measure whether the women's violence is in response to prior aggression or threats by the partner. Dr. Browne and Ms. Pence say that the results are misleading because they fail to reflect the reality of a male-dominated society.
 
Men Assail the System
 Men who have lived with violence, however, complain that though men may dominate, women are wrongly seen as the only victims. Mr. Gilliland likes to tell how he was arrested and charged with domestic assault although he says he never retaliated against the former wife who yelled at him, pushed him and threw hot coffee at him.
 "We were having a family argument in 1988, and she said something about calling the cops and getting me thrown out," he said. "I said, 'All right, I'll call the cops.' She ran out and screamed, 'Take me to a battered women's shelter,' and they took me to jail. The system is 100 percent stacked against men."
 Even the most ardent advocates for battered women acknowledge that women can be assaultive. Indeed, one of the 13 therapy groups in Ms. Pence's intervention program is for assaultive women. But, Ms. Pence said, in a decade of domestic-violence work she encountered only one man truly battered by his wife and more than a thousand such women.
 
Man Trapped and Hurt
 "There was one man with a hearing aid, who thought his wife was very beautiful and above him, and she used to come up behind him and whack him on both ears," she said. "He felt trapped and he was getting hurt, and it was exactly like talking to a battered woman. His life was not in danger, but it was dominated by physical and emotional abuse, which didn't stop until he left her."
 A major difference between battered wives and battered husbands, she said, is that when men leave the relationship, the violence almost always stops, while when women leave, the violence often escalates, forcing the woman to seek court protective orders, go to a shelter, or flee.
 "When the woman leaves is usually the most dangerous time, which is why we need battered-women's shelters," said Ms. Pence, who is currently studying in Canada.
 About a third of all female murder victims in the United Sates are killed by their husbands or boyfriends, according to Federal Bureau of Investigation Uniform Crime Reports, compared with about 5 percent of male murder victims who are killed by their wives or girlfriends. And while estimates vary, experts agree that many male murder victims are killed by women acting in self-defense.
 The majority of domestic assaults, by husbands or wives, cause no injury, much less the murderous brutality marking high-profile cases like that of Hedda Nussbaum in New York, or Francine Hughes, the woman whose story was told in the television movie "The Burning Bed." While such stories have raised public consciousness of battered wives, the idea that men can be victims of domestic violence is still alien to many people.
 "I did a talk show a couple weeks ago, where a woman called up and said she had chased her husband around with a clawhammer and the audience laughed," Mr. Gilliland said. "A lot of people think it's hilarious, and ask why the guy doesn't turn around and hit her, but most men have brought up to think that above all, you don't hit a woman."
 As a result, many men whose wives have assaulted them say they are mocked, or ignored, if they report their experiences. And in most parts of the country, men have no access to the counseling and support networks established for battered women.
 "I went to a pay phone and called the police after years of abuse, when my wife locked her arms around my neck from behind and knocked me to the floor," said James Blanchard, a 48-year old Connecticut man who later divorced his wife. "The police officer met me at the phone and argued against my filing charges. But he came back to the house with me, and when he confronted my wife and she admitted it, he referred us to counseling."
 
Turned Away by Agency
 Mr. Blanchard made an appointment at the recommended private agency, which also runs a shelter for battered women. But the agency refused him shelter because he was a man. He then filed a complaint with the Connecticut Human Rights Commissioner, which was settled in 1985 with an agreement that both the private agency and the state agency that helps finance it would end their discriminatory practices.
 "There are still very, very few resources for battered men," said Mr. Blanchard, who now counsels other men. "I'm near bankruptcy now, and like most men who are victims of domestic violence, I've found it very hard to get myself back together. I try to talk to young men, and tell them that not all the women out there are parasites."
 Counselors at shelters for homeless men say many battered husbands end up there.
 "At any given time, 2 or 3 of the 20 men at our shelter are referred here because they are victims of domestic violence," said Mark Price, a counselor at the Arlington, Va., shelter for homeless men. "It's usually men who are unemployed and have a problem with low self-esteem. This is not as rare as people seem to think."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 20, 1992, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 20 described efforts by men's rights groups to change the perception that domestic violence affects only women. It included quotations from George Gilliland Sr. of St. Paul, founder of the Domestic Rights Coalition, an advocacy group that he said planned to open a shelter for battered men.
Since the article appeared, additional information about Mr. Gilliland has emerged, including that a court ordered him to stay away from one of his ex-wives, because of his threats of violence, and that his two other ex-wives also sought court protection from him. Moreover, experts in domestic violence say his group actually defends men accused of battering women rather than men who have been battered.
Any account of Mr. Gilliland's position on domestic violence should have included these facts and allegations about him and his organization.

HEADLINE: States See Connecticut Business as Ripe for Picking

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 20

 BODY:
Murray A. Gerber, whose small plastics company is hardly known outside Middletown, Conn., was stunned to get a personal invitation to lunch earlier this month with the former governor of Virginia, Gerald L. Baliles.
Mr. Baliles made a personal pitch about the virtues of Virginia as a possible new home for Mr. Gerber's 60-employee company, Prototype and Plastic Mold, and Mr. Gerber said that when he left the restaurant he was "impressed as hell." 
 "He was a wonderful salesman," Mr. Gerber said.
Kansas has offered free trips to business owners in Connecticut thinking about the Great Plains. Maryland provides a cash bonus for every new employee. Other states have developed data bases that show when Connecticut business leases expire so they can make a polite telephone call precisely six months before.
If all is fair in love and war, then add the interstate competition for business to the list. Business leaders and economic development officials say that although poaching on other state's businesses is an old and honored game, the effort has taken on new sophistication and aggressiveness in the last few years.
And Connecticut has become a target. With well-publicized turmoil in the state budget, rising taxes and the adoption of an income tax last year, other states seem to have more or less declared open season here.
"Problems with taxes, problems with the Governor -- there's a feeling of instability," said Ted M. Levine, president of Development Counselors International, a private economic development company in New York. "And where there's trouble, the vultures sweep in."
Mr. Levine and other experts said that while companies in New York and New Jersey have long been among the prized trophies of relocation hunters, Connecticut's reputation as a low-tax state with a pro-business Yankee tradition kept many poachers at the border until the last few years.
 
'Fight of Our Lives'
 "We're in the fight of our lives," said Connecticut's Commissioner of Economic Development, Joseph McGee, whose assignment is to retain manufacturing, which Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has identified as the state's bedrock economic base.
Until recently, Connecticut was regarded more as predator than prey, beckoning to New York City-based companies especially, with appeals to their bottom line and to the happiness of their workers, who would pay no state income tax. But the wage tax, combined with a decade of soaring home prices and property taxes, have made the state less competitive and less appealing, many business people say.
Connecticut has lost almost 25 percent of its manufacturing jobs since 1985, according to the New England Economic Project, an economic research group. Cutbacks in military spending -- a major contributor to the economy -- promise to compounded those losses in the 1990's.
There are no statistics about how many companies have left the state, but there is a sense of what types of companies are being wooed: mid-sized manufacturers, especially high-tech suppliers, with skilled workers -- the very kinds of companies that are typically lacking in lower-wage states that can offer the best relocation deals.
Business organizations and state officials say that image and momentum are greater enemies than the recession. In the network of who's who and who's going where, each move causes ripples. Mr. Gerber, for example, said he looked at Virginia specifically because the Stanley Works, the toolmaker that is one of the oldest and most revered names in Connecticut industry, chose that state in 1990 to build a new consumer hardware manufacturing plant. He wants to see Atlanta because United Parcel Service of America, Inc. moved its headquarters there from Greenwich.
"There's a pretty broad recognition across the nation that Connecticut had become difficult," said Richard H. Ayers, chairman and chief executive officer of the Stanley Works, which was founded in Connecticut 149 years ago, but now has all but 2,100 of its 18,000 employees elsewhere. "I don't think there's a day goes by that I don't receive something from a state outside Connecticut," Mr. Ayers said.
And some of the arguments are hard to resist.
At the American Cyanamid Company, which has 30 chemical plants around the nation, workers' compensation costs are 10 times higher in Connecticut than in any of the other states where the company has plants, a fact competing states seldom grow tired of repeating, said Bob Leitzman, manager of the company's Wallingford resins and plastics factory. Many executives said they had been promised a minimum 10 percent increase in profits because of lower wages, lower taxes, or other incentives, especially in the South.
But Connecticut's efforts to fight back have propelled it on an odyssey of its own, as state officials try to shore up the business environment, and at the same time decide what the environment should be. Mr. Weicker, who pushed through a personal income tax law last year in part, he said, to relieve tax pressures on business, has focused his efforts on retaining high-tech, especially aerospace-related manufacturers.
 
Marketing the State
 And next month the state will start a national marketing campaign -- its first ever -- to fight the talk that Connecticut is a bad place to be in business.
But business leaders say the effort has been spotty and sometimes erratic. Two weeks ago, for instance, Mr. Weicker and other state leaders held a news conference in an empty warehouse in Avon to announce that one 85-employee company that makes aircraft fuel connectors had been given several millions of dollars in grants and loans to stay in the state.
Mr. Gerber, on the other hand, who also has aviation clients, has had one brief conversation, last summer, with someone at the Department of Economic Development who never called back.
"What we have now is an attempt to fight fires -- there doesn't seem to me to be an overall economic plan," said Edward J. Deak, the chairman of the economics department at Fairfield University. "I don't think there's any attempt to say, 'are these the kinds of companies we want to retain, is this the best place to spend the funds and effort,' " he said.
Mr. McGee said his agency has a four-step screening process to identify which companies to try to retain, and he says that while a full industrial policy will eventually emerge, there is no time to spare. Rockbestos, a wire and cable maker, has been helped in recent weeks, as have two gun companies, Colt's Manufacturing and U.S. Repeating Arms.
Through various publicly controlled agencies, the state can issue and guarantee loans, make direct stock investments, issue grants and help negotiate local property-tax breaks and reduced utility costs.
The state Legislature is also considering bills to provide additional tax breaks and speed up the processing of permits by the Department of Environmental Protection.
For companies that are caught in such a flux, the winds are strong indeed. Mr. Ayers at Stanley Works said he believed that if current trends continue, he could envision a time, perhaps by the middle of this decade, when expanding a business here could make economic sense.
Mr. Gerber at Prototype and Plastic Mold said the decision to think about moving has brought forth emotions he had not expected. He founded his company 24 years ago in a corn crib in Haddam.
And state officials fairly jump with glee when word filters back about someone who left and did not like it so much.
The chairman of United Parcel Service, Kent C. Nelson, recently complained, for example, about the quality of schools in Georgia, the company's new home state, and state officials here immediately began a low-level whispering campaign.
Mr. Nelson told an audience of Atlanta's civic and business leaders that the company and its employees had benefited from lower costs, but he added that Atlanta is not paradise. "Had our relocation decision rested on education quality alone," he said, "it's safe to say we would not be here today."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record;
Arkansas Water Pollution Looms as a Campaign Issue

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EUREKA SPRINGS, Ark.

 BODY:
Four years after George Bush took a famous boat ride through Boston's polluted harbor and took control of the environmental debate in his Presidential quest, environmental specialists in the Administration say Mr. Bush's re-election campaign is now deciding whether to make a similar campaign stop here in northwest Arkansas.
Across this splendid region of hump-backed hills, hardwood forests and emerald pastures an angry struggle has erupted over wastes from hundreds of millions of farm animals. 
 The waste is draining from the land and polluting the White River and its tributaries, a network of streams nationally acclaimed for trout fishing and canoeing, and critics blame Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democrat likely to run against Mr. Bush, for being slow to react.
Mr. Clinton's top environmental aides vigorously defend him, saying that in his 12 years as this state's chief executive he has balanced two important concerns, economic growth and environmental protection.
But both Mr. Clinton's critics and supporters say the deterioration of the White River region has made him vulnerable to political attack.
"Clinton's guys in Little Rock say they have the situation under control," said Skip Halterman, a 47-year-old guide who has fished in the White River basin of northwestern Arkansas all his life. "It's not true. Not a one of them has walked these streams, floated these rivers or seen the pollution up close. What they're doing is all a show to keep what's happening to our water from becoming Bill Clinton's Boston Harbor."
Officials of President Bush's campaign organization are considering a campaign stop in this area to highlight Mr. Clinton's environmental record, or sending a television production crew to the region to film a political advertisement, say top environmental policy specialists in the White House, the Office of Management and Budget and the Interior Department.
In some ways, the deterioration of the White River is a new problem for Governor Clinton. As a candidate for President, he is being judged by different standards than he has been while Governor. During his first term, from 1978 to 1980, only a dozen or so advocates were prominently expressing concern about the state's environment.
 
An Interest in Jobs
 There was more concern about the economy in this, one of the nation's poorest states. Many people argue that the most pressing issue should be economic development, and a certain amount of environmental cost is the price of propserity, and aggressive environmental regulations raise costs and could make the state less attractive for industrial investments.
In the interest of jobs, Mr. Clinton encouraged the development of a formidable animal agriculture industry, and it is now the nation's eighth largest. Much of the industry, which produces 1 billion animals a year, is in the state's northwestern region, where they produce as much organic waste each year as New York and Los Angeles. Most of that winds up being spread on the land as fertilizer.
His aides say that when he learned that scientists were linking declining water quality to the industry's wastes, he formed a task force to solve the problem.
But Mr. Halterman and other critics point out that the 28-member panel is dominated by representatives of the poultry, hog and cattle industries. Several panelists, including some state officials, agreed that the group's agenda was heavily influenced by representatives of the poultry industry, the Farm Bureau and cattlemen's association.
Mr. Clinton's critics also noted that he formed the task force only after John Tyson, vice-chairman of operations for Tyson Foods formed a similar panel to develop practices that would minimize pollution from chicken farms.
 
Tourist Industry in Jeopardy
 The condition of the White River is now changing the views of many Arkansas residents. The river is known to fishermen nationwide for its trophy-size trout. And its problems strike at the heart of what many people think is special about living here. As Bill Bowen, Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, put it recently: "The eternal paradox of Arkansas is that all of us want a modern economy, a VCR, a big pickup -- and we still want to be able drive no more than a mile to be in the woods and go fishing."
The White River's problems seem to be jeopardizing the second half of that equation. Each of the last two summers, dead German brown trout and rainbow trout washed up by the dozens in the tailwaters below the dam that forms Bull Shoals Lake, suffocated by a lack of oxygen in the water. Potentially dangerous concentrations of fecal bacteria have made more than 400 miles of streams unfit for swimming.
Canoeists and fishermen no longer flock here as they once did. Hotel and motel owners say the region's $300 million a year tourism industry is in jeopardy.
Almost everybody interviewed for this article said that while Mr. Clinton has been in office, 1978-80, then 1982 until now, the water quality in the White River and its countless tributaries has grown worse. The only exceptions were his top aides and executives of poultry and hog companies, led by Tyson Foods, based in Springdale.
 
Wide Extent of Pollution
 The debate over whether it is fair to blame Mr. Clinton is likely to continue through the Presidential campaign. What is not debatable is the extent of the pollution.
This resort town once had pure mineral springs and streams so clear that the gravel gleamed like polished amethyst and jade. Today, not a single spring is safe to drink.
After light rains, animal wastes wash off the land, and springs in neighboring Boone County become more contaminated with fecal bacteria than New York Harbor, a study by the United States Geological Survey, a unit of the Interior Department, found.
Nearly every scientist who has studied the contamination says manure is being too heavily applied as a fertilizer and soil conditioner to cropland and pastures. Nitrogen and phosphorous not used up by the crops drains into streams and ground water.
But in a region where most homes have shallow wells, and fresh water is the lifeblood of an economy based on cattle, hogs and chickens, many residents have a more pointed explanation for the contamination. They say that the deteriorating water quality is a result of political choices, especially Governor Clinton's reluctance to challenge Arkansas's rich and powerful poultry industry.
"In his first term, Bill Clinton took on Georgia-Pacific," to stop clear-cutting of timber in the state by the the huge paper and wood products company, but was unsuccessful, said James Lingle, an environmental lawyer in Rogers who has known and supported the Governor for 20 years. "It was a big factor in why he lost after one term," Mr. Lingle said. "You can fight that big industrial windmill like the paper companies and the chicken processors, or you can be Governor of this state. When he was re-elected in 1982, Bill Clinton decided he wanted to be Governor."
In 1990, after nearly a decade as the state's chief executive, Mr. Clinton formed the task force on animal waste. Its mission was to develop voluntary programs to persuade poultry and cattle farmers to store and spread manure more carefully. It was also to rewrite an old rule regulating the storage and use of liquid wastes from dairies, hog farms and egg-laying houses.
The task force's work has raised a furor in this region. Environmentalists say its proposals are almost identical to minimal rules that are already in place and will do little to clean the water. But farmers fear rising costs and bristle at more Government interference in their business.
Both groups, as well as people involved in tourism say that formation of the task force was a political gesture, and point out that it did not occur until Mr. Clinton decided to run for President.
 
'A Big Political Game'
 "What I'm worried about is that we farmers are pawns now in a big political game," said Jerry Hunton, a 41-year-old dairy and poultry farmer from Prairie Grove who is a Democratic first-term State Representative who says he supports Mr. Clinton.
Clinton's top environmental aides are working hard to counter the impression that the task force was motivated by political considerations. "We didn't know as much about this kind of pollution as we do now," said Kenneth L. Smith, Mr. Clinton's special assistant for natural and cultural resources. "As soon as this was brought to his attention, Governor Clinton acted as forcefully as state and Federal law would allow him to."
Pollution experts say Mr. Clinton had ample warning but has been consistently slow to react. In 1983, the development of a sinkhole in a creek near a water treatment plant in Green Forest allowed a million gallons a day of partially treated chicken wastes from the plant to drain into the underground water supply used by Green Forest residents. Seventeen months later, Mr. Clinton declared 60 square miles of Green Forest an "imminent health threat emergency."
In 1989, residents of Clifty confronted Tyson and the Clinton administration again after the Department of Pollution Control and Ecology allowed the company to spread chicken wastes from two plants in Rogers across mountain pastures there. The state also issued a permit for Tyson to build a 471,600-gallon chicken waste lagoon within 200 feet of a stream.
Wastes flowed off the hillsides, killing all the fish in two ponds built by John Obenshain, a cattle rancher in the community. Bacteria also contaminated his well, and the wells of several more families in the area, according to tests by the state Health Department.
"I was one of those guys who used to think that what happens on the other side of the fence is no concern to me and what happens on my side is no concern to them," said Mr. Obenshain. "But when it's coming over the fence and under the fence, I decided to do something about it."
Tyson voluntarily closed the lagoon in 1990 and pulled out of the community after the dispute became one of the region's top television news stories. John Tyson, the 38-year-old grandson of the founder of the $4 billion-a-year company, the nation's largest poultry producer and processor, said his company no longer uses lagoons to store plant wastes and will end the practice of spreading waste on land next month.
"We're all responsible for northwestern Arkansas," Mr. Tyson said. "We've got to get out of finger pointing and get down to what really needs to be done here. I live here. Our employees live here. It's a beautiful area, and we mean to keep it that way."
In little more than a generation northwest Arkansas has grown from a land of chicken-scratch farmers raising a few cattle, hens and hogs into one of the country's centers of industrialized animal agriculture. But the region's 350 million chickens and turkeys, 400,000 cattle and 500,000 hogs produce huge amounts of organic waste.
Amid the concern about pollution, farmers look at all the waste, particularly the 300,000 tons of "litter" cleaned out of chicken houses, and see grass, miles of green grass for grazing. The litter, spread across the land, turned ruined ground into fertile soil. Washington and Benton counties west of here are now productive cattle-raising areas after being fertilized.
"When I came here in the 1940's, this land was nothing but dry sand with gullies so deep you could hide a tractor in them," said Floyd Hunton, Jerry Hunton's father who established the family's farm in Prairie Grove. "Chicken litter made this country."

HEADLINE: Syria Trying to Breach Air Embargo on Libya

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, April 20

 BODY:
Syria, uneasy over the United Nations embargo against Libya, has produced the first crack in widespread adherence to the sanctions by the Arab world.
Syrian officials, who have offered public support to Libya, tried unsuccessfully to get neighboring countries to give airspace clearance for a Syrian Arab Airlines jet that was scheduled to fly from Damascus to Tripoli today. 
 And the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, who has been touring Persian Gulf countries, is apparently trying to induce his neighbors to re-examine the embargo, Western diplomats said.
"The Syrians are worried, that if the Libyan sanctions are successful, they will be vulnerable," a diplomat said.
The embargo was put into effect on April 15 after the Libyans refused to turn over two suspects wanted in the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, in which 270 people died. It bans all air traffic in and out of Libya, calls for a reduction in Libyan diplomatic staff abroad and bans arms sales to Libya.
But Syria, which is on the State Department's list of countries that sponsor terrorism, fears that it may be next if the United Nations decides to sanction another state for terrorist activities, diplomats contend.
President Assad has held talks in Saudi Arabia with King Fahd and the Emir of Kuwait. He is scheduled to go on to Abu Dhabi and the three other Gulf Cooperation Council states, Bahrain, Qatar and Oman.
A high-ranking Syrian official, Tawfiq Salihah, in a visit to Libya over the weekend, announced Syria's support for the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
The public statement of support "raised the morale" of the Libyan people, Colonel Qaddafi said.
At the debate at the Security Council this month, the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, objected to the discussion, arguing that the Council did not have "the authority to discuss disputes of this kind." The state-controlled Syrian press has blasted the sanctions as "unjust" and called for "solidarity" with Libya.
In the Arab world only Iraq, under a much more severe United Nations embargo that also includes a ban on commercial flights, and the Sudan, with an Islamic fundamentalist Government at odds with the West, have said they would defy the sanctions.
But the Syrians did not openly defy the embargo until the announcement over the weekend that they would request permission for their scheduled commercial flight to travel to Libya. A spokesman for Syrian Arab Airlines said it would continue to try to obtain permission for flights to Libya. Civil aviation authorities in Cyprus and Greece refused to allow the Caravelle aircraft to enter their airspace on route to Libya.
[The Chicago Convention of 1945, which set international aviation rules that are still in effect, defines a country's airspace as ending only three miles from its shores. So a Syrian plane could fly over water to Libya without crossing any country's airspace and risking a legal interception by military aircraft, said Richard P. Magurno, an aviation lawyer at Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith in New York.
[But all of the air over the Mediterranean Sea has been divided up among the coastal countries' air traffic control regions. So a flight from Syria to Libya would need permission from some combination of air traffic controllers in Cyprus, Egypt, Greece, Lebanon or Turkey, depending on the route chosen, said an airline industry official in the United States who insisted on anonymity.]
The Syrian defiance has signaled an open break with the Unites States. The relations between the two nations, distant and often hostile in the 1980's, reached their zenith during and just after the Persian Gulf war, when Syria sent troops to Saudi Arabia as part of the allied coalition forces. After the war, the Syrians assisted in gaining the release of the Western hostages from Lebanon, and Syrians took part in the Middle East peace process. The Syrians even expelled the terrorist known as Carlos, who is reported by Western diplomats to have taken refuge in Baghdad.

HEADLINE: Welfare Eligibility Checks Drag as Applicants Surge

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
New York City has been so swamped with people seeking welfare benefits in the last year that it has fallen way behind on checking to see that those already on the rolls are still poor enough to qualify for help.
The delays in checking eligibility mean the city may have paid out as much as $5 million more than it should have in welfare benefits, state social-services officials say. 
 To prod the city to ease the problem, the state is withholding $870,000 from the city until the city's Human Resources Administration reviews 35,000 overdue welfare cases. Typically, about 5 percent of those families would be removed from the rolls after the mandatory review of cases.
City caseworkers are required to interview each welfare recipient in person every six months. The workers ask recipients if they have found work, have married or had a child turn 18 years old -- all changes that could cut the size of their welfare benefit or eliminate it entirely.
But it has been at least a year since the city interviewed people in 35,000 of the 475,000 households on welfare rolls. The recertification process is meant to curb welfare costs and make sure only those who need the help get it. The problem was reported in The Daily News on Sunday.
"It's been a problem from time to time, but it's never been this big a problem," said Terrance McGrath, a spokesman for the State Social Services Department. "This is directly related to the recession."
The city submitted a plan addressing the problem last month. But the state and the city are still haggling over specifics. Neither side would comment on the city's proposals.
State, city and union officials all agree on the cause of the problem: the number of caseworkers has not risen fast enough to keep up with the staggering rise in the number of people applying for welfare.
From 1991 to this year, the number of households on welfare has risen a staggering 33 percent. In the preceding four years combined, the number rose only 11 percent. But the city has not been able to hire enough caseworkers to keep up with the deluge of people seeking help, officials say.
The city's first priority has been to make sure those who apply for help get it within 30 days as required, said Sheila Jack, a spokeswoman for the Human Resources Administration. But as the city reassigned workers to handle the surge in applications, it fell behind in checking the eligibility of the people already on the rolls.
Bob Myers, the union representative of the welfare workers, said that workers are supposed to carry a load of 160 cases under their contract with the city but that caseloads have risen to 220 or 230. "People are burned out and wiped out," he said. "It doesn't make sense for the city to do a patchwork solution, hoping the economy will suddenly become great and people won't be on public assistance."
The city and the union, Local 1549 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, are now in arbitration. The union says the city needs to hire at least 800 more workers to bring the caseloads down to the size specified in the contract. It currently has about 4,900 workers, Mr. Myers said.
Ms. Jack said she could not comment on staff levels with the arbitration continuing. But city budget officials said the city had hired about 350 workers so far and planned to hire an additional 188 by the end of the year.
