HEADLINE: As China Looks at World Order, It Detects New Struggles Emerging

SERIES: After the Cold War -- Third article of a series: Chinese Views

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 20

 BODY:
As the band strikes up for a new international order in the 1990's, one major power broods on the side of the ballroom, equally alarmed at the Western tune and at the prospect of being left out of the dance.
As China broods, it pumps more money into the military -- a 50 percent increase since 1989 -- and sells what it describes as civilian nuclear technology to Algeria and Iran. The message seems to be that while China has lost strategic importance with the collapse of the Soviet Union, Beijing still has a dizzying capacity to disrupt the post-cold-war party. 
 Much the same is true of the other remaining Communist country in northern Asia, North Korea. Economically near collapse, its President 80 years old, North Korea also has plenty of ways to disrupt the world, including what Western officials call its emphasis on developing nuclear weapons.
Any Western-oriented plan for a new international order could face major challenges from this Communist rear guard because China has nuclear warheads, three million troops and significant territorial disputes with its neighbors and because North Korea may be able to make nuclear arms in a few months or years. Both countries may collide regularly with international efforts to promote human rights, to curtail the spread of missiles and nuclear technology, and simply to preserve the peace.
 
Fears About the West
 "One cold war has ended -- two more cold wars have begun," warns a Chinese central Government document whose nervous tone underscores Beijing's insecurities in the post-cold-war era. The two new cold wars appear to be first, the struggle between capitalism and the remaining Communist countries, and second, growing frictions within the Western alliance.
The analysis was intended for internal use only, to guide the coverage of foreign events in the Chinese press, and consequently it offers a window into the leadership's private concerns about China's role in the new world order. The document warns that Western forces are infiltrating neighboring Mongolia and Indochina, that the United States is using human rights "as an excuse to pressure our country," and that the collapse of Communism abroad has added to China's burden.
"After the end of the cold war between the United States and the Soviet Union, the confrontation and struggle between the two systems and two ideologies is still fierce," the document adds. "The collapse of the Soviet Union is a severe blow to international socialism, and it puts those countries that are sticking with socialism and other third-world countries on the front line against the threat of imperialism."
 
The Soviet Collapse
Possible Bellwether For the Chinese
 The suicide of the Soviet Union (as officials here see it) has encouraged many Chinese dissidents, who echo Mao's dictum in the 1950's that "the Soviet Union's today is China's tomorrow." The Soviet disintegration has also cost China some strategic leverage with both Washington and Moscow, for the China card was most valuable in an era of superpower rivalry. Washington today seems to find little use for the China card in a game of solitaire.
Yet, the end of Soviet might was in some ways also a relief for China, which had experienced not only a cold war with Moscow but also a border battle in 1969.
"The recent events in Moscow can benefit us," insisted an elderly Chinese who occupies a senior post in the foreign affairs hierarchy. "The Soviet Union was a menace to us, a threat, and now it's gone."
Moreover, the economic troubles in the Soviet Union have had a cautionary effect on many ordinary Chinese, reminding them that overthrowing the established order may lead not to prosperity and efficiency but rather to shortages and upheavals. And in a country that in the last 100 years has faced repeated convulsions, no word provokes more shivers than luan -- chaos.
"What happens in the Soviet Union will be of crucial importance in China," another senior Government offical recently said. "If chaos continues and prices rise, then that will help the Chinese Government because the last thing people here want is chaos. But if there is a quick turnaround in Russia, and production increases and living standards rise, then people here will say they want to make the leap as well."
 
The Military
Spending Increases As Tensions Ease
 One of the puzzles of China in the 1990's is why it is pouring money into the military even though its most important military threat collapsed with the Soviet Army. The risk of military conflict with other neighbors, particularly India and Vietnam, has also diminished sharply in recent years as Beijing has normalized diplomatic relations with those countries.
Yet China is not only increasing military spending generally, but in particular it also is seeking to project power beyond its shores. It is trying to do this by acquiring air-refueling capability for its fighter aircraft, by building up a blue-water navy, and eventually by building an aircraft carrier.
All this is raising concerns in Taiwan about whether it is the target of the rising military spending. China regards Taiwan as a renegade province and reserves the right to use force to resolve what it considers to be its own "internal affair." A confrontation in the Taiwan Strait could well happen if Taiwan's opposition movement gets its way and declares independence from China.
"If Taiwan declares independence, we'll have to attack them," said a Chinese official with ties to senior generals.
 
Taiwan Crisis Not Ruled Out
 In part this may be bluff, and military experts say a conventional assault by the People's Liberation Army on Taiwan would be difficult and not necessarily successful. But while most scholars and diplomats seem to believe that a military crisis in the Taiwan Strait is unlikely in the 1990's, few rule it out.
Huan Guocang, a scholar at Columbia University who grew up in China, cited two additional security risks in the post-cold-war era.
The first is in Xinjiang, the semi-desert region of northwest China. Xinjiang is inhabited by Muslims of Turkic origin who are ethnically related to the people of Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Kazakhstan across the old Soviet border. Two years ago the Chinese authorities in Xinjiang confronted an armed rebellion, and there are reports of continuing discontent in the bazaars.
"They're getting guns smuggled in over the mountains from Pakistan and Afghanistan, and that's very worrying," said a Chinese official well informed on security issues.
 
The South China Sea
 The second security risk cited by Mr. Huan is the territorial dispute in the South China Sea. China claims a huge region of islands and ocean, extending more than 1,000 miles south of Hong Kong and embracing virtually everything between Vietnam, Malaysia and the Philippines.
The zone includes the Spratly Islands, beautiful, palm-lined islets that are essentially uninhabited, set in an area thought to contain oil, natural gas and phosphorus deposits.
Some or all of the islands are claimed by nations in the region, and clashes could quickly follow a major oil find. In 1988, China and Vietnam fought a minor battle over the islands.
China alarmed Southeast Asia this year when it approved a new law asserting its sovereignty over the South China Sea.
 
Strategy
Exploiting Discord And Gaining Power
 The internal Government document supports the view that China is increasing its readiness not because it wants to take on its neighbors, but because it feels threatened itself.
"Facing this international turbulence, our policy is to coolly survey the situation, bide our time, increase our guard, and absolutely not stick our head up," the document declares. "We're going to exploit the divisions among Western countries, strengthen ourselves, and focus our efforts on the Asia-Pacific region and the nations along our border."
Chinese officials note that the military budget, while rising, is tiny by international standards: just $6.8 billion this year. But true military spending is far higher than that official figure, which does not include funds raised by arms sales or the income from hundreds of army-owned factories.
With a bit of sleight of hand, the generals also exclude capital expenditures, which fall under a separate budget category.
Perhaps the structural problem facing China today is that it was so weak beginning in the early 1800's that it could not defend its interests, and as a consequence it lost significant chunks of territory. Now for the first time, it is gaining economic and military clout, largely because it enjoys one of the most buoyant economies in the world. With that strength, it seems increasingly interested in resolving long-time disputes in its own favor.
So while China has no interest in conquering India, for example, it might some day feel that it needs to "retake" a large swath of Indian land in the Himalayas that it says is historically China's. That was how the Chinese-Indian border war of 1962 broke out.
While it is not Government policy, some Chinese would also like to recover the independent country of Mongolia, which China was forced to give up earlier in this century, as well as strips of territory taken by Russia in the last century.
 
On Japan
Lingering Hatred Clouds Relations
 The nationalist pressures are greatest in shaping policy toward Japan. Chinese grow up hearing and reading about the brutal Japanese occupation of China beginning in the 1930's. About 10 million Chinese may have died because of the Japanese occupation, which lasted until the defeat of Japan by allied forces in 1945.
"There's considerable hatred for Japan, and we have to be careful not to inflame it," the elderly senior official said.
Whenever the Chinese leaders improve relations with Tokyo, they risk being criticized as unpatriotic by Chinese students. In 1985, thousands of Chinese students demonstrated against the profusion of Japanese imports, and in 1990 there were calls for demonstrations against the Beijing leadership because it was accused of failing to defend the Diaoyu Islands, also claimed by Japan, which remain a potential flashpoint between the two countries.
 
Wartime Reparations
 The clearest sign that the Chinese Government feels pressured to take a stronger position against Japan came just in the last few months. A small group of Chinese scholars and officials, acting without Government approval, began to issue calls for Japan to pay China compensation for damage and injuries in the 1930's and 40's.
China's leaders and Japan's agreed in 1972 to resolve all claims, and Chinese officals had previously acknowledged this. But now the leadership seems afraid of squelching the reparations movement. When Jiang Zemin, the Communist Party leader, was asked this month about reparations, he responded with virtually an outstretched hand.
"As for the left-over issues concerning the war of aggression," he said, "we have always maintained that all of the issues should be settled fairly and reasonably through mutual consultations in the light of the principles of seeking truth from facts and adopting a serious attitude."
 
Diplomacy
Shedding Status As Pariah in West
 For all of China's diplomatic difficulties in the 1990's, most diplomats and scholars say the Government has made great strides in improving its position lately.
Just a couple of years ago, for example, China seemed to face an intractable challenge in its handling of foreign relations: Li Peng's hands. No Western leader wanted to shake them.
Prime Minister Li had been a central figure in the 1989 crackdown, in which the army crushed the Tiananmen democracy movement and shot to death hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators. While the third world paid little attention, the West was outraged and some diplomats suggested then that if China wanted to resume high-level exchanges with the industrialized world, it would be obliged to ease Mr. Li from power.
But the Government proved more patient than its critics, and these days Mr. Li is no longer grounded.
His triumphal 11-day visit in January and February to Italy, Switzerland, Spain, Portugal and the United Nations in New York, where he met with President Bush, suggests that China has largely reintegrated itself into the international community.
 
On the United States
Conflicting Views About Washington
 The only major trading partner of China that is not improving relations significantly with Beijing is the United States. Indeed, there could be a significant further deterioration in ties with Beijing if a Democratic president is elected this fall and refuses to extend China's access to low trade tariffs known as most-favored-nation status.
China's leaders apparently are as vexed by the United States as the other way around. Most Chinese express deep admiration for America, but the leadership seems to feel that it has been betrayed by American support for anti-Communist dissidents in China. The central document conveys that ambivalence about America, as it passes on instructions on presenting news from America to Chinese audiences.
"We want to ease tensions with the United States and break down the sentiment in America for sanctions," the document states. "We should take prudent and active measures, and properly report issues in Sino-American relations, so that bilateral relations develop in a way that will help us. Propaganda news stories must be careful and tactical, paying attention to results. As for American interference in our internal affairs, violations of our sovereignty, and slanderous rumor-mongering, we can reveal this in ways that accord with the circumstances and with our diplomatic aims.
"We should study and write about the problems that the United States is having now, since being victorious in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union," the document adds. "We should point out that since becoming the sole superpower, the United States has been grasping wildly for new hegemonism and power politics, and also that it's strength is in relative decline and that there are limits to what it can do. The American domestic problems are severe, and can be the topic of exposes, but we must be accurate."
 
Forgoing Ideology
 Paradoxically, China now says it is abandoning ideology in foreign policy, just as Americans are becoming more idealistic -- or, from Beijing's point of view, ideological -- about relations with China, particularly in American criticism of China on human rights.
"In your country, some people are very ideological, especially your congressmen," a senior Foreign Ministry official said in an interview. "But what determines relations between states is not ideology but common interests."
Reflecting that new position, China recognized Israel in January -- after assuring the Palestine Liberation Organization representative in Beijing that this would never happen. Beijing also seems to be moving toward recognizing South Africa.
In an effort to appear accommodating and non-ideological, China says it is willing to discuss human rights issues in general -- although not its own human rights problems in particular. And last year, under pressure from the West, China said it would abide by the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and, with conditions, the Missile Technology Control Regime. Most diplomats do not entirely trust China to curtail arms sales and nuclear proliferation, but they believe the moves are still significant.
"You have to give it some credit," said a Western diplomat in Beijing. "On human rights and arms control, it was backed into the corner and it finally acted rationally. It seems to be coming slowly in our direction."

HEADLINE: Dinkins's New Budget Approach: Looking Toward Re-election

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
After two years of budget proposals that tried to be fiscally correct even if they were politically unpalatable, Mayor David N. Dinkins is now trying hard to find enough good news to shape a budget that will make him more popular as his re-election campaign approaches.
In the last week, the Mayor has moved to restore library service five days a week at all branches, to rescind planned cuts in spending for capital construction, to propose new tax credits for businesses that donate to cultural institutions and even to spend more money to fix a smelly sewage plant in Harlem. 
 Just yesterday, he announced plans to create a new network of public clinics intended to provide basic health care for poor New Yorkers. Today he is to announce that a new police academy, planned for the South Bronx but put on hold last year, is now back on the drawing boards.
How he can do all that and whether it makes sense for the budget is hard to say, because word of the goodies has been doled out in dribs and drabs. The full range of the Mayor's choices will not be clear until he presents his proposed $29.4 billion budget next week, and it will still have plenty of bad news. But the city hopes that savings from two years of slow, grinding cuts might actually produce a healthy surplus in the fiscal year that ends June 30, money that can help pay for some of the projects.
 
Light Some Candles
 Regardless, most of the Mayor's ideas will not cost much, most will be put into effect over several years in the hope that the economy and tax revenues will rebound enough to support them and some, like the clinics, might end up saving money in the long run by improved efficiency.
The financing will come from sources as different as water and sewer bonds, which are backed by special water fees and not affected by cuts in the operating budget, and rejiggered state and Federal aid.
But the real answer is that, politically, the Mayor simply cannot afford not to try. "We're not going to curse the darkness," Mr. Dinkins said yesterday, announcing the new health centers. "We're going to light some blasted candles."
For months, it seemed City Hall and its critics did little but curse, but now the Mayor is looking ahead. He pledged to break ground on all 20 new centers by September 1993, and when a reporter noted that there would be another important event that month, Mr. Dinkins smiled slightly and asked, "Oh, what's that?"
"That" is the Democratic mayoral primary, something that is bound to drive many of the Mayor's decisions these days, as he strives to cut the losses of two years and rally his political coalition before it is too late. Yet actions now prompted by political exigencies also highlight failures of his administration's past budgeting.
The restored library hours are a case in point, reflecting the Mayor's sensitivity to a service popular in rich and poor neighborhoods alike.
Mr. Dinkins cut library service last year, as part of a scorched-earth budget strategy that threatened to close the Central Park Zoo and darken streetlights to prompt an air of crisis that would win concessions from municipal labor unions. But that effort foundered, and the City Council had no sooner adopted the budget than the Mayor moved to restore some of the most unpalatable cuts.
 
Money in Nooks and Crannies
 Now, by promising to find money in nooks and crannies to restore some of the library cuts, he is all but acknowledging that he may never have had to make them in the first place.
Yesterday, Mr. Dinkins refused to compare last year's approach and this year's, saying circumstances were different. But he did say, "The more you do it, the better you get."
Or as his chief political aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, put it: "You can do some things with meager resources, if you look and plan carefully, and it's taken us a while to get an understanding of how to do that, and we're now doing it."
Paradoxically, it could be argued that the Mayor actually has somewhat less flexibility this year than last. Now, he has pledged a four-year freeze in property tax rates, while last year he won $700 million in higher taxes. And there is little prospect now of money-saving concessions from the city's unions.
On the other hand, the Mayor has reaped savings from a reduction of about 13,000 in the city's work force since November 1990 and plans more cuts, mostly through attrition. He has also pledged to freeze wages, except in exchange for improved productivity.
"I think our productivity programs and our belt-tightening has worked," said Budget Director Philip R. Michael. "You no longer have the experience of the bottom falling out as far as taxes are concerned. So while we don't like the size of our revenues, they are not slipping. That has given the Mayor some flexibility to do program restorations."
By law the city's budget must be balanced, and mayoral aides insist it will be. They numbers-crunchers talk of controls and safeguards, but also, frankly, of hope.
"We do have a level of confidence," Mr. Michael said. "We can't say where the economy is going for sure, but we do feel we have our systems in place and they're working, so we can take a little step back."

HEADLINE: Private Owner to Sell L.I. and Queens Water Utility

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 20

 BODY:
Facing a groundswell of customer protests over rates, the corporate parent of the largest water company in Queens and Nassau County said today that it would sell the utility and withdraw from the water business.
The company, JWP Inc., based in Purchase, N.Y., said the sale was part of a corporate restructuring because of reduced earnings. It said it would seek buyers for the Jamaica Water Supply Company, which serves 118,000 homes in Queens and western Nassau, and also for the Sea Cliff Water Company, a small utility with 4,200 customers in northern Nassau. 
 JWP, a diversified concern with holdings in electronics, mechanical equipment and computers, said the sale was intended to let the company focus on its "core businesses," and not to avert controversy over its water service. The two utilities account for only 2 percent of its revenues, the company said.
But its announcement was welcomed as a victory in Nassau, where hundreds of people have organized to protest the Jamaica Water Company's rates, which for years have been two to three times higher than those charged by neighboring municipal water companies.
 
Public or Private?
 "They saw writing on the wall," said William Corbett, a spokesman for the Waterbill Watchdogs, a group formed in September in the Nassau village of Floral Park to protest the utility's prices and to advocate a public takeover of the company.
Whether JPW's decision to sell will lead to public acquisition of the utilities remained an open question. But officials in Nassau said the company's announcement was welcome, even if the water companies are acquired by another private concern.
"It has to be regarded as good news," said John J. Ciotti, a lawyer in Mineola and chairman of the Western Nassau Water Authority, a panel formed by the towns of Hempstead and North Hempstead to study the viability of taking over Jamaica Water by eminent domain, or of acquiring it through a negotiated sale.
"If the buyer is another private company whose business is providing water, and not a conglomerate, it is bound to be more responsive to the public," he said. But he added that his panel would "certainly consider" approaching JWP with a bid of its own for Jamaica Water.
 
Higher Rates
 New York City has been trying to acquire Jamaica Water's operations in Queens through eminent domain for three years. A State Supreme Court judge in Queens, Edwin Kassoff, is to determine the fair market value of the company later this year, enabling the takeover to proceed.
"I don't think JWP's announcement changes anything," said Leo Connelly, assistant counsel for the city's Department of Environmental Protection.
Jamaica Water, which has been providing water service since 1887, is New York State's second-largest water utility, behind the New York City Municipal Water System, and by far its largest private water provider.
Several studies have shown that its rates, which are subject to approval by the state's Public Service Commission, are far higher than those of municipal utilities, with many families in Nassau paying Jamaica Water $900 a year or more for service.
JWP has defended its water rates on the grounds that it must pay taxes on land and equipment, costs which are passed along to customers. Municipal utilities are tax-exempt, and therefore can charge less.
Some officials said it was not clear whether a public takeover would make economic sense, because tax revenues would be lost. "Everybody wants lower water rates, but if we have to eliminate too much in tax revenues to get them we are not doing anyone a favor," Mr. Ciotti said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Bush and Clinton Face A Long, Familiar Road

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
The two parties are sliding into a general election campaign with all the reassuring rituals of modern Presidential politics.
President Bush is back out on the hustings, talking about his commitment to change and a reinvigorated domestic agenda, just as he did in 1988. (A tacit admission that this message, somehow, did not get conveyed during four years of running the Government.) Gov. Bill Clinton is trying to make the transition from little-known Democratic Governor to potential President, just as Michael S. Dukakis tried in the spring of 1988. Other Democrats are busily engaged in another party tradition: carping about their probable nominee. 
 The conventional wisdom of the press and pundit class has formed and re-formed a half-dozen times already, and is currently in something of a fugue state. Mr. Clinton has gone from inevitable to impossible to inevitable but doomed, and may now be entering a kind of exhausted limbo in the minds of the pundits. Mr. Bush went from the Unstoppable Hero of the Persian Gulf to the Hapless Tribune of a Recessionary Status Quo in a matter of months, then suddenly looked formidable again in comparison to Mr. Clinton.
The real buzz inside the Beltway these days is over Ross Perot; nothing thrills the Washington insiders like dire warnings of the anger Out There, like British aristocrats regaled with chilling tales from the far-flung outposts of the empire.
For all that, the shape of a Bush-Clinton race is emerging. Mr. Bush is blithely campaigning as a President devoted to domestic policy, talking about issues like education that are critical to the all-important suburban swing voter. Americans can expect a constant drumbeat of Presidential concern between now and the Republican convention in August, at which point Bush strategists hope to have a fully retrofitted candidate for the fall campaign.
There will be a burst of foreign-policy events in June and July, including the visit of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and an economic summit in Munich, Germany, that will undoubtedly be used to remind voters that Mr. Bush, commander in chief, is running against Mr. Clinton, Governor of the smallish state of Arkansas. But by and large, Mr. Bush will be focused on the bread-and-butter worries of the home front, which is, after all, where the votes are. (One domestic issue he would probably prefer not to highlight is abortion, where his opposition could alienate many of the swing voters he needs.
Democrats are already trying to challenge Mr. Bush's commitment to a serious domestic agenda. In 1988, when the polls also showed many Americans yearning for a more aggressive effort to solve problems here at home, Mr. Bush systematically undermined the Democrats by promising to be the Education President, the Environment President, and so on. The Democrats assert he paid lip service only and vow they will not let him get away with it again.
"They're going to try to run 1988 all over again," said James Carville, Mr. Clinton's strategist. "They're going to be relentless in their attacks on us and try to co-opt issues like education and the environment with some very modest, squishy proposals."
Mr. Bush's critics will almost certainly ask where he was hiding these domestic policy passions for the past four years. This is where Congress comes in. Charles Black, a senior advisor to the Bush campaign, says the President can document how Democrats on Capitol Hill blocked his plans for domestic reform.
The Clinton campaign is reveling in a debate about issues larger than whether the Governor did or did not inhale. Context is everything in politics, and Mr. Clinton's context is no longer a brutish, tabloid-driven primary fight in the streets of New York. He still has to deal with former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, notably this week in Pennsylvania, which holds its primary next Tuesday. Mr. Brown was in the streets of Philadelphia today, railing about corrupt politicians and very much alive. Still, many of the headlines in recent days featured a give and take between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush on issues like education and job training, and this cheered many Democrats.
Mr. Clinton's allies hope that this "Presidential" dialogue begins to repair their candidate's image, which came out of the primaries in very grim shape, with polls showing widespread doubts about his honesty and integrity.
In the midst of all this, Mr. Clinton was probably not helped by the willingness of many in his party, on Capitol Hill and elsewhere, to ventilate their own reservations, underscoring the sense that the Democrats have become something of a dysfunctional family in recent years. One Democratic strategist moaned in an interview about the fretting on Capitol Hill with a rhetorical plea: "Would you people go home and take a Valium?"
The superdelegate endorsements keep trickling in. Some of Mr. Clinton's allies say this was not a great year, anyway, for mass endorsements by politicians. What counts, they say, is that Mr. Clinton is still lurching forward, toward the nomination and the fall campaign.

HEADLINE: Ads Warn G.O.P. on Cutting Homestead Rebate Program

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 20

 BODY:
New Jersey Democrats today announced a $150,000 broadcast and direct-mail campaign to warn Republicans away from cutting the homestead rebate program, which returns as much as $500 to homeowners and renters.
A script of a radio commercial to be broadcast on stations serving the New Jersey market beginning Tuesday features ominous music and the warning, "They're after your money, and they know where you live." 
 There is then the sound of a window breaking and a burglar alarm going off, with the words, "There's a gang out there plotting to take up to $500 out of your pocket. The Trenton Republicans. They run the New Jersey Legislature, and they're plotting to cut your homestead rebate."
The ads sharpen the battle lines in the Legislature's fight over the rebate program, which cost $710 million in the current fiscal year and is pegged at $685 million in the next budget. The Democrats are picturing themselves as the champions of ordinary people trying to make ends meet, particularly elderly people, while the Republicans portray themselves as defenders of a fiscal responsibility in the form of a balanced state budget.
The Republican majority in the Legislature needs to find $608 million in spending cuts to make up for a one-cent reduction in the sales tax it approved last month to fulfill a campaign promise.
Before the election the Republicans hinted broadly that they would cut even more. One Republican leader, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, suggested that all of the $2.8 billion in tax increases enacted by the Democrats in 1990 be rolled back. But the Republicans settled for about a quarter of the total rollback when it became apparent that bigger cuts would be impossible without drastic reductions in state jobs and services.
But even the relatively modest rollback amid a recession has put the Republicans on the spot to come up with ways to trim $608 million from the $15.7 billion budget proposed for the fiscal year that starts in June.
The homestead rebates appear to be a prime target. Mr. Haytaian, who became the Speaker of the Assembly after the Republicans won control in November, has said that "everything is on the table, including the rebates," and Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, the Republicans' leading fiscal expert and chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee, called the rebate program "a vote-buying scheme" that has "gotten out of control."
At a news conference today about the ad campaign, the state Democratic chairman, Raymond J. Lesniak, said that any plan to cut the rebate program to make up for a tax cut "is a flimflam, it's a bait-and-switch, it's a shell game."
A brochure that Mr. Lesniak said would be mailed to 500,000 voters in swing districts now represented by Republicans also hints of legislative banditry, featuring a photograph of three masked men in business suits standing in front of the gold dome of the State Capitol.
As Mr. Lesniak announced the effort to get citizens to write or call their legislators, he was joined by representatives of the New Jersey chapter of the American Association of Retired Persons, the New Jersey United Senior Alliance and the New Jersey Council of Senior Citizens.
Councilman Hank Miller of Monroe Township, which has a high percentage of elderly people, warned, "If they ever want to see gray power at work, the Republicans should try to take away the Homestead Rebate."
In an interview, Assemblyman Bob Franks of New Providence, the State Republican chairman who created the successful campaign to take over the Legislature by capitalizing on voter anger over the 1990 Democratic tax increase, called the Democratic media campaign "simply pandering at its best, which we have learned to rely on the Democrats in New Jersey to specialize in."
Although he did not say that the Republicans plan to cut the rebate program, he said, "We have a significant fiscal problem in New Jersey today and someone has to provide leadership in order to put our fiscal house back in order."

HEADLINE: Profits Up at Nationsbank, Chase and Dime

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Nationsbank, now the country's fourth-largest banking company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits increased 95 percent, while earnings at Chase Manhattan rose 20.5 percent. At the Dime Savings Bank, profits were five times as high as their very depressed level a year ago.
Like most other banking companies, Nationsbank, Chase and Dime said their first-quarter results benefited from a wider spread between the interest rates they paid for deposits and the rates they collected on loans and increased collections of fees from consumers. All three were badly hurt by losses on real estate loans the last few years, but Nationsbank seems to be recovering more quickly than Chase or the Dime. 
 While the scope of Nationsbank's operations are not as grandiose as its name, the company has outgrown its home in North Carolina to become one of the nation's biggest banking companies. The result of the merger last year of the NCNB Corporation, of Charlotte, and the C & S/Sovran Corporation of Atlanta, it is now the leading bank in Texas, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and Virginia, a part of the country where the economy has not been as weak as the Northeast.
Chase, the nation's largest bank a few decades ago and now the sixth biggest, is building its consumer business and expanding into Connecticut, but it remains only about half as profitable as many regional banking companies, after adjusting for size.
The return to profitability at the Dime Savings, which lost $237.4 million last year, comes at a time when regulators are pushing the bank to develop a plan to raise more capital and strengthen its financial condition.
Following are the results of the three banking companies:
 
Nationsbank
 Nationsbank's profit of $310 million, or $1.28 a share, was up from $159 million, or 70 cents a share, a year ago. In addition to a $204 million profit from securities it holds as an investment, Nationsbank benefited from its first quarterly decline in non-performing assets in two years. Non-performing assets are badly delinquent or troubled loans not expected to be repaid in full, and real estate acquired through foreclosure.
As problems with bad loans abated, Nationsbank wrote off as a loss $214 million in loans, down from $220 million a year ago, and it added $265 million to its reserve for loan losses, down from $333 million a year ago.
Although loans at Nationsbank fell slightly in the first quarter, Rusty Page, a company spokesman, said customer inquiries and demand for loans have increased slightly the last few months. As loans increase, the company hopes its profits will gain as it can finance new loans with money previously invested in government securities. On consumer loans, which Nationsbank wants to increase to 50 percent of its total from 39 percent now, interest rates of 11 percent would be far higher than the 6 percent earned on securities.
"They are one of the few major banks to use their investment portfolio just like the textbook says," Thomas Hanley a banking analyst at First Boston Corporation, said. "When the economy and loan demand was weak, they accumulated investments, and as interest rates fell they took their profits and adjusted to shorter maturities to minimize losses when rates head back up."
 
Chase Manhattan
 At Chase, first-quarter profits of $141 million equaled 81 cents a share, up from $117 million, or 73 cents a share, a year ago. Chase wrote off as a loss $294 million of loans, up from $270 million a year ago but down from $319 million in the fourth quarter. To prepare for losses on other loans it has identified as weak, Chase added $300 million to its loan-loss reserve.
Although losses at Chase from bad loans remain high, Mr. Hanley of First Boston said the first-quarter numbers on bad loans showed that Chase's problems have stabilized and should decline later this year. Chase said it had $3.38 billion of loans that were badly delinquent or in such trouble that full repayment was not expected, little changed from $3.37 billion at the end of 1991 but up from $3.10 a year ago. Chase also held $923 million of real estate acquired through foreclosure, up from $907 million at the end of the year and $767 million a year ago.
Chase benefited in the first quarter from growth of its consumer businesses and $50 million in profits from the sale of investments in other companies and warrants it held in an unidentified subsidiary sold several years ago.
 
Dime
 At the Dime Savings Bank, the first-quarter profit of $8.1 million was equal to 35 cents a share and was up from $1.6 million, or 7 cents a share, a year ago. Dime's nonperforming assets have fallen two consecutive quarters to $1.10 billion, but the company remains troubled by a low level of capital and small reserve for losses that is equal to only about 32 percent of its troubled loans.
Dime's problems have been concentrated on residential mortgage loans, particularly those made in the Northeastern part of the country without a full-scale credit check of the borrower, rather than on the commercial real estate loans that have plagued large banks.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Futures Panel Choice Is a Professor in Utah

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The White House said yesterday that President Bush would nominate Steven Manaster to be a commissioner of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
Dr. Manaster, who is 43, is a professor of finance at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City, but he was the commission's chief economist from June 1989 to September 1990. As chief economist, he supervised a staff of about 100, engaged in analysis, research and market surveillance. 
 He specializes in the analysis of the terms and conditions under which futures contracts are settled by the delivery of a commodity. A futures contract is an agreement to deliver a set amount of a commodity in the future at a fixed price. Such contracts can also be written for stocks and stock indexes.
Implied price volatility, Dr. Manaster explained in a telephone interview yesterday from his home in Salt Lake, means examining the price movement of an option and inferring from that the price of the commodity. The technique is often used in stock options, he said, and "it is applicable to commodities or futures, with varying degrees of success."
When futures contracts expire and are settled with the delivery of a commodity, as opposed to a cash exchange, supply bottlenecks can affect prices, he said, and his interest was "how these 'pinch points' might affect futures contract prices."
Dr. Manaster, whose nomination is subject to Senate confirmation, would replace Fowler C. West, whose second term expired on April 15. The panel has five members, who serve staggered terms of five years each.
A 1970 graduate of Oberlin College, Dr. Manaster holds M.B.A. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Chicago. He has worked as a staff economist for the Federal Reserve Board, and he has taught at New York University, the University of Chicago and the University of Florida. He is also the former chairman of the University of Utah's finance department.
The futures commission faces numerous issues brought on by financial and technological change. Among these are a proliferation of foreign financial instruments being offered in the United States; 24-hour computerized trading, and dual trading, in which a floor broker trades on his account as well as his customers'.
The commission has also been involved in a lengthy dispute with the Securities and Exchange Commission over which should have jurisdiction over stock-index futures contracts, an argument that the futures panel now says it has won.
But the futures commission has been operating under a continuing resolution for two and a half years, because Congress has not passed legislation reauthorizing it, partly because of the jurisdictional dispute.

HEADLINE: Chain Takes Fashion Tongue-in-Chic

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
If exposed pipes, white walls and wooden crates are the height of store design and blue jeans and T-shirts the garb of national choice, then Express is a throwback to another age -- in fact, to another century.
Express stores, a division of Limited Inc., are a bit of Versailles tucked into 7,500 square feet of the local mall, and the young women's chic career and casual clothing they sell evokes Madison Avenue rather than Main Street. 
 But while its merchandising and marketing seem out of step, so is its success. Last year Express, with more than 600 stores, was at the top of the retail industry in profits, sales growth and productivity.
Last year, in the depths of the recession, Express's sales hit the billion-dollar benchmark for the first time. So, like any proud parent, the normally reticent Limited is suddenly willing to engage in a bit of uncharacteristic preening.
The Limited boasts that by most measures, Express as a stand-alone business would best even Gap stores, that darling of Wall Street and the media. Express's own executives are somewhat more modest.
"It's not that we get everything right, that we don't make mistakes," said Michael A. Weiss, Express's president and the impresario behind its growth since 1980. "It's that we're good at seeing what's working and then making it work for us."
Banana Republic, a division of Gap Inc., won the blue ribbon last year for the most sales in each square foot of space -- $576 compared with Express's $316, according to Goldman, Sachs & Company.
But Express is a champion at generating operating profits and growth, and in doing so has become a sort of yardstick against which to measure the performance of Gap stores.
"As the Gap continues to expand the fashion component of its women's business, they're going to become increasingly competitive," said Richard N. Baum, a retail analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
He estimates that Express's sales will grow 18 percent a year, more than twice the industry average, through 1995, and he predicts similar increases in operating profits.
Express is a tough challenger, as its sister store, the Limited, has discovered. While Limited stores have struggled to reposition themselves, like the rival Ann Taylor chain, as a source of affordable, well-made career clothing, analysts say Express has lured away many of its big sister's customers.
 
A Competitor Looks In
 Even Ann Taylor considers Express to be a bigger competitor than the Limited. In a recent interview at the Express store in the Menlo Park Mall in Edison, N.J., Mr. Weiss stopped abruptly at the big glass window looking out on the mall and playfully wagged his finger at a group gathered outside.
"Have you no shame?" he yelled at Sally Frame Kasaks, who used to head the Limited's Abercrombie & Fitch division and who recently became chairman and chief executive of Ann Taylor. "Is nothing sacred?"
Mrs. Kasaks and her executives were comparison-shopping for new ideas.
An actual customer, Tammy Winthrop, poked through a rack of floral print silk walking shorts and matching tops. "Shopping here is really like shopping," she said. "You can look for fashion instead of just buying jeans and a T-shirt."
Ms. Winthrop, a 25-year-old assistant at an investment bank, said she also shopped at Gap, but "that's for weekends and the beach," she said. "This stuff is good enough for the office."
Joseph H. Ellis, a partner at Goldman, Sachs who follows the retail business, said: "Express has marched right by the Limited division in serving customers 25 and older." While sales in Limited stores open at least one year declined between 4 percent and 7 percent last year, Mr. Ellis said, sales in Express stores open one year rose between 11 percent and 14 percent in 1991.
Many of those creative urges are simply an ability to see what is hot and quickly get it out on the selling floor, a hallmark of the Limited's divisions, which also include Victoria's Secret and Lerner's. When a young buyer told her superiors at Express that she wanted to purchase ribbed cotton jersey tunics in a rainbow of colors last summer, they were unexcited but agreed to her wishes. But the first month the tunics went on sale, store managers reported that the tunics were flying out the doors and asked for more.
Sewing machines around the world went into action, and Express sold four million tunics last year. "No test would have ever told us those shirts would sell like that," Mr. Weiss said.
Mr. Weiss and his colleagues have made a career out of borrowing ideas and giving them a slightly different spin. But unlike Armani A/X and the other Gap lookalikes springing up around the country, Express has borrowed from the reign of Louis XIV and Paris street fashion. "Basic" is the buzzword of the retail industry, but Express offers ersatz opulence.
The radio station playing French pop music over store speakers is a tape. Faux Fragonard and mock Magritte murals cover walls. Compagnie Internationale Express clothes, made especially for Express, are labeled in French, right down to the "fabrique aux Etats-Unis" -- "made in the United States." Not even the Venus de Milo is spared: free-standing, full-length mirrors scattered about the selling space are cut out in her voluptuous shape.
 
Whimsy and Low Prices
 "The stores are fun, and that's a big factor in retailing today," said Cynthia Cohen Turk, president of Marketplace 2000, a retail consulting firm. "When you're running a chain of hundreds of stores and have to maintain consistency in all of them, you can't rely on the product to be the fun and interesting element that draws people in."
Unlike Armani A/X, where "prices under $100" means most shirts and pants are $70 to $90, Express prices clothes so that a customer can easily put together an entire outfit for no more than $80.
Ms. Cohen Turk said the low prices and obviously tongue-in-cheek chic of the stores had helped them avoid the backlash against lavishness that stamped the start of the 90's.
Express began life as the Limited Express in 1980, when Leslie Wexner, founder, chairman and chief executive of the Limited, decided to try leveraging the success of his flagship chain. Attached to the Limited store in Chicago's Watertower Place, it was decked out in neon fixtures and stocked with clothes made of mostly synthetic fabrics.
It was an era when girls just wanted to have fun. Mr. Weiss, hired a year later after stints at A&S and Casual Corner, quickly moved to stamp the fledgling business venture with merchandise that was campy, trendy and way out, a far cry from the Express of today.
"If I wrote a book about launching Express," he says, "its title would be 'How to Make Midlife Crisis Work For You.'
"I was 40 years old, and I had decided that I had not done what I wanted to do, so I had better get on the stick. What better way to do that work in a store exclusively for girls who wanted funky clothes to go with their green and pink and orange hair?"
Having established itself, Limited Express became Express in 1982. And when multicolored hair began returning to more natural shades, Mr. Weiss turned off the neon and turned on more flattering lighting. In 1986 louvered wooden doors began replacing the plastic shower curtains that separated the dressing rooms, and cotton jersey started substituting for rayon. The stores dropped Limited from their name.
Express was growing up to get grown-ups. Says Mr. Weiss, "We figured out that a customer base with a salary was better than a customer base with an allowance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a time when "basic" is the buzzword of an industry dominated by Gap lookalikes, the Express division of Limited Inc. thrives by offering the opposite: ersatz opulence. Michael A. Weiss, Express's president, recently took visitors through the Express store at the Menlo Park Mall in Edison, N.J. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford's Jaguar Bet: Payoff Isn't Close

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COVENTRY, England

 BODY:
To Ford Motor Company shareholders wondering when to expect a decent return from Ford's $2.5 billion acquisition of Jaguar, the British luxury car maker, Nicholas Scheele's words will not be comforting.
When asked when that time might come, Mr. Scheele, Jaguar's new chairman, replied: "My boss at Ford said it took us close to 40 years to get any benefit from the acquisition of Lincoln. I hope it doesn't take us 40 years to get any benefit out of Jaguar." 
 For now, stanching the red ink is Mr. Scheele's main concern. Jaguar lost a total of $431 million in 1990 and 1991, after taxes, a result of sharply lower sales, and it will almost certainly post losses again this year.
 
 
Smaller, Sporty Sedan
 So much for Ford's plan 18 months ago to have Jaguar generating positive cash flow by this year, and to be able to self-finance an ambitious program to develop fresh cars, including a smaller, sporty model that might sell for $25,000 to $45,000. Analysts estimate that the program will cost about $2.5 billion.
Ford's multibillion-dollar bet is that a sporty sedan will attract younger professional buyers who cannot or will not pay $44,500 for today's least costly Jaguars and who turn up their noses at Ford's luxurious Lincolns. Instead, they buy cars like the BMW 5-series, Toyota's Lexus, Nissan's Infiniti and Honda's Acura.
While many dealers insist that Jaguar's distinctive, curvy look continues to give them an edge, several confessed that the new models, especially the sporty sedan, could not arrive soon enough.
"I'd love to have them all here next month," said Norman Gregersen, co-owner of Palm Beach Motor Cars Ltd. in West Palm Beach, Fla. "But from the lessons in the past, I don't want them until everything is absolutely right," in terms of quality.
 The success of a new, lower-priced model will largely determine whether Ford made a correct bet when it bought Jaguar in late 1989, with money that was badly needed to rejuvenate Ford's own car lines.
Already, Ford has trimmed its Jaguar sales target by a third. The original plan called for Jaguar to produce more than 150,000 cars a year by the end of the decade, including 65,000 units of the sporty sedan. Now the total target is 100,000 cars, about half of which would be the new, lower-priced model; the rest would be new versions of Jaguar's existing models.
Even that goal is ambitious. In 1988, Jaguar's best sales year, it sold just 49,494 cars.
Do Ford executives regret the price they paid? Rather than lament it, they seem to be doing their best to forget it.
"That's past," William J. Hayden, Jaguar's former chairman, said in an interview late last month on the eve of his retirement. "As Henry Ford once said, 'History is bunk.' "
 Mr. Scheele, who is 48 years old, insists that even with annual sales of 100,000 cars, Jaguar will be able to generate a respectable return. "It really depends on what price you get for the product, which depends on how good the product is," he said. So far, Ford has managed to improve Jaguar quality markedly.
But success also depends on continuing the improvements in efficiency Jaguar has been making since Ford bought it. Productivity has improved by about 35 percent, Mr. Hayden said. He would not say how many hours of labor it now takes Jaguar to paint, weld and assemble a car, but he noted that Jaguar was unquestionably still behind even the relatively unproductive German luxury car makers. The Germans need about 70 hours, experts estimate, and the Japanese about 20.
Jaguar reduced its work force last year by 4,100 people, to 8,000, and another 650 jobs will be eliminated this year. Jaguar's break-even point has been reduced to 34,000 cars, from about 50,000.
But analysts point out that with the intensifying competition, profit margins in the luxury car segment may never go back to where they were before sales began to drop.
"There's no way that Ford will ever get its money back on its investment in Jaguar," predicted Ronald A. Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco.
Several analysts say Jaguar will be lucky just to hang on to its current market share in the next few years as it develops replacements for its two existing, and aging, model ranges.
 
 
Bad Timing
 Ford's misfortune is that it bought Jaguar right before the collapse of the American and British luxury car markets, its two biggest. Total Jaguar sales last year plunged 40 percent, to 25,676, from 42,754 in 1990.
Besides the recessions in Britain and the United States, sales have been hurt by an American luxury tax on cars costing more than $30,000.
Jaguar's assembly plant here is still working only three days a week because of slack sales. And the company's executives are not exactly exuding confidence about achieving their modest goal of selling 27,500 cars this year, only about 2,000 more than last year.
Mr. Hayden, the former chairman, said that there had been some recent signs that Jaguar sales in America were beginning to recover. "But really you need another two or three months to determine if it's going to come back or not," he said.
 To make matters worse for Jaguar, the economies of Germany and Japan, its next-biggest markets, are now in recession or slowing. And the depressed global luxury car market seems to be doing little to deter other car makers, like Mazda and Mitusbishi, from joining the fray.
"Nick's got a huge job on his hands," said Prof. Daniel T. Jones of the Cardiff Business School at the University of Wales. "If he can keep Jaguar going and turn it around he'll be destined for big things at Ford." Professor Jones was a member of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology team that produced a seminal study of the world car industry in 1990.
 
List of Changes
 First on the product development list is a replacement for the XJ6 sedan. Next is a new version of the XJ-S grand touring coupe and convertible. British trade publications say they will be introduced in 1994 and 1996, respectively, and the sporty sedan in 1998. Generally confirming these dates, Mr. Scheele said Jaguar had been able to accelerate its development program by about a year.
The replacement for the XJ6 sedan, Jaguar's main model, will not be a totally new car. While it will have restyled body, Mr. Scheele confirmed reports that it will use many structural components of the existing model, as well as its glass, roof and suspension.
Is this a compromise? Jaguar executives say they are only trying to marshal their resources to get all three models out as soon as possible.
 
 
Ford's Shocking Discoveries
 While Ford executives had realized that Jaguar was in a sorry state when they decided to buy the company, they were shocked to discover just how bad product development and manufacturing were. With Ford's help, however, Jaguar has undeniably made great progress in these areas and in lowering component costs.
One reason Jaguar thinks it can accelerate its new car introductions is that Ford is designing the process and making the tools for stamping body panels.
The leadership installed by Ford also won a new union contract that removed archaic work practices like rigid job classifications and a piece-rate system that allowed workers to quit early after producing their quota.
As for quality, long a Jaguar bugaboo, the number of defects per 100 cars coming off the assembly line has plunged to fewer than 500, from 2,500 in early 1990.
 Mr. Scheele said customers were already noticing the higher quality -- an assertion backed up by dealers in the United States and by consumer research conducted by Auto Pacific Group Inc., a California-based consulting firm.
"Jaguar's quality now is right up there with Infiniti," said Hugh Weidinger, vice president of the Hempstead Auto Company, a big Jaguar and Infiniti dealership in Hempstead, L.I. "But it's probably the best-kept secret in the world."
He and other dealers hope that an imminent marketing campaign will change that. Jaguar has announced that its American advertising account is being reviewed for a possible switch of agencies that might lead to new ads. It is also about to extend the warranty on its cars in the United States to four years, from three.
 Jaguar executives are confident that productivity and quality will improve much more in coming years, especially when they introduce cars whose designs make them much easier to build than existing models.
 
Legacy of Quality
 As president of Ford's Mexican subsidiary, Mr. Scheele was responsible for Ford's plant in Hermosillo that made Escorts for the North American market. Its quality was the highest of any of the high-volume assembly plants examined by the M.I.T. team.
Until they get the new models, Jaguar leaders are counting on improvements in their existing cars to tide them over.
 With the stiffer competition, Christopher Cedergren, a senior vice president of Auto Pacific, predicted that even if the luxury market rebounded in the United States, Jaguar would continue to struggle there. "They probably are not going to move back to the volume levels they enjoyed in '89 and '90 until they come up with a new generation of products," he said.
In response to critics who wonder whether Ford has the expertise to make Jaguar a success, Mr. Scheele insisted that the skills needed to succeed in the luxury and high-volume segments were not "tremendously different. In both, they are "define the product, define the customer, establish a program, deliver the program and satisfy the customer," he said.
But the way he talks about Jaguar's great products in the past -- like the Mark II sedan of the 1960's -- shows that he knows the process is not really so mundane. He knows the consumer will be the ultimate judge, and the pressure is on.
"To me, the sports sedan is not the all-important model," he said. "Really, the all-important one is the first one we bring out, because it has to be a success from day one."

HEADLINE: Alamo Rent A Car Offering Uniform Rates Nationwide

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Alamo Rent A Car Inc. said yesterday that it was offering new, lower rates that would be uniform throughout its 102 locations nationwide.
But the rate cuts, which will last until June 24, did not immediately set off a widespread price war. Hertz was the only other car rental company to match any of the new rates offered by Alamo, whose share of the car rental market is estimated to be less than 10 percent. 
 Alamo said its uniform rates would make it easier for travel agents to promote the company and for consumers to know how much they would pay in any market.
Under what Alamo calls its "Great American Rates," daily rental prices for an economy car, which ranged from $17.89 in Orlando, Fla., to $33.99 in Washington, D.C., will be lowered at all its outlets to $15 a day. The rate will be $19 a day for a mid-size car and $29 a day for a Cadillac.
Alamo does not rent cars from La Guardia or Kennedy Airport, but the new rates will effectively halve its prices at Newark Airport, the company's location closest to New York City.
The new rates, geared to entice vacationers, require keeping the car over a Saturday night. Other restrictions include a 24-hour advance booking requirement.
Alamo said there were no other mandatory costs, except taxes. In the late 1980's, the Federal Trade Commission charged Alamo with failing to disclose mandatory airport surcharges and gasoline fees to consumers who called the company's reservation operators. Without admitting guilt, Alamo agreed to disclose the surcharges in the future. It also changed its fuel policy to give consumers more choice.
The Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest car rental company, responded to Alamo's move with a $14.99 daily rate for a subcompact, with similar restrictions, also through June 24.
The three other leading rental companies -- Budget, National and Avis -- maintained their current charges. Budget Rent A Car said it would continue to offer its current special rates, which have very few restrictions and offer a discount of $5 a day after the first day's rental. Budget's rates are roughly $10 to $15 higher than Alamo's new rates.
Avis said it planned no further discounts beyond the special $19 daily rate for a subcompact car it was offering for several weeks at most locations. A spokesman for National Car Rental said the company had not decided yesterday whether to follow suit.
About half of Alamo's airport operations lack counters at the terminals, unlike the company's larger competitors.
With its new program, Alamo is hoping to increase its share of the relatively flat, $11.4 billion rental car industry. Gary S. Rubin, executive editor of Auto Rental News, a magazine based in Redondo Beach, Calif., said Alamo would probably win new customers from the ranks of cost-conscious travelers.
But for the auto rental business, the move continues a trend of stiff price competition that has shaved more and more profit from revenues, Mr. Rubin said. "Rates on the whole in the industry are very low," he said. "And they keep getting lower and lower."
Warren H. Lieberman, a senior consultant with Arthur D. Little in San Francisco who tracks the travel industry, said Alamo's nationwide pricing flew in the face of the industry's current strategies that had resulted in hundreds of different prices according to local business conditions and demand. "It's an interesting experiment, and it's definitely innovative," he said.
He said some vacationers might spend more to get a larger model, like the Cadillac. Alamo may also win new customers who, once the rates are discontinued, may decide to rent from Alamo again, he said.
But Mr. Lieberman said the special rates would harm Alamo's revenue to the extent that they were used by some of the company's current customers.
An Alamo spokeswoman, Liz Clark, said Alamo was introducing nationwide pricing because it simplified its advertising and was easy for travel agents to remember, and therefore sell. The company also hopes that customers will think of Alamo as being easy to deal with, having simple prices and few restrictions.
 
Tactic Similar to Airline's
 Alamo's strategy to make the company's rates uniform follows a move by American Airlines two weeks ago to simplify its own fare structure -- sparking increased air travel and prompt responses by American's competitors. Mr. Rubin said Alamo's program would do little to create new travel, because car rentals were typically less costly considerations for vacationers than air fares and hotel rates.
Alamo devised its new rate program several weeks before American's announcement, Ms. Clark said. Alamo's standard pricing nationwide will not necessarily be extended beyond late June, but the company plans to keep offering special rates with minimal restrictions.
Alamo plans to start offering cars at La Guardia and Kennedy Airports within two years, Ms. Clark said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Tumble on Economic News

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday and long-term interest rates moved above 8 percent again as dealers reacted to stronger-than-expected economic reports released late last week and began to establish positions for the $60 billion worth of new coupon-bearing issues to be sold over the next three weeks.
The Government securities market was closed on Friday in most countries in observance of Good Friday. And European financial markets were closed yesterday for Easter Monday. 
 As a consequence, reaction was delayed to reports on housing starts and consumer confidence, and remarks by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, who told Congress Friday that the economy had probably expanded at a 2 percent annual rate in the first quarter and would gain momentum thereafter.
 
Large Financings Ahead
 In addition, the prospect of bidding this week on $14.75 billion of 2-year Treasury notes and $10.25 billion of 5-year notes, and in early May on 3-year notes, 10-year notes and 30-year bonds, is unsettling the market, traders said.
"We have to deal with the refunding auctions before we get any real sense of how the economy did in April," one government securities trader said. "That is a concern."
Employment data, usually the most important economic statistics released each month, are not expected until May 8, the day after the Treasury completes its quarterly refunding auctions.
The Treasury is expected to announce the size of the refunding auctions on April 29. Most analysts expect the Treasury will need to sell around $35 billion of securities.
 
Negative Sentiment
 "It seems as if the bears are in command right now, and that's worrisome," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at Pittsburgh's Mellon National Bank. "If bond yields rise on each and every sign of economic improvement, that is going to choke off this very fragile recovery, which is barely visible in many parts of the country."
Yesterday's selling helped push up rates at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills. Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.69 percent, up from an average rate of 3.60 percent at last week's auction.
Bids on the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 3.86 percent, up from an average of 3.73 percent a week earlier.
 
Higher Long Bond Rate
 But the rise in short-term bill rates was modest compared with the sharp rise in longer-term notes and bonds. By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 9925/32 , down more than a point, or more than $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.01 percent, compared with 7.92 percent late Thursday.
Given the market's current mood, Mr. Robertson and other market analysts said that bond yields could rise as high as 8 1/8 percent before the refunding auctions.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 9917/32 , down 29/32 , to yield 7.56 percent. And the 7 percent seven-year notes were offered at 9823/32 , down 23/32 , to yield 7.23 percent.
In the when-issued market, the two-year notes that will be sold tomorrow were offered late yesterday at a price to yield 5.48 percent. Last Thursday, those securities had been offered at a price to yield 5.28 percent.
 
5-Year Note Trading
 Meanwhile, the five-year notes to be sold on Thursday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.90 percent, up sharply from the 6.75 percent level they were offered at last Thursday.
The erosion in Treasury prices had a dampening effect on issuance of new corporate and tax-exempt debt securities and pushed down prices of outstanding investment-grade issues in those markets.
Only one new issue was priced yesterday, a $225 million offering of high-yield five-year notes from Arkla Inc.
The 9 7/8 percent notes, which are noncallable for life, were priced at $99.896 to yield 9.90 percent, three percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which was increased in size from $150 million due to strong demand.
The securities are rated Ba-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Corporate traders said that prices of outstanding intermediate-term securities fell by 1/4 point to 3/8 point, while long-term bond prices moved as much as 3/4 point lower.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 5/8 point to 3/4 point, market participants said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Quiet Trading On European Bank Holiday

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly lower in extremely quiet trading yesterday, softened by the four-day Easter weekend in Europe.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fell 50 cents a troy ounce, to $336.90. Later, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $336.75, off 25 cents. 
 Foreign exchange and gold markets were closed in Europe for a bank holiday following Easter Sunday. Most European markets were also closed on Good Friday, and the currency market closed early in New York on Friday.
The dollar moved in narrow ranges.
"There was no activity with Europe being closed; New York dealers were left to their own devices," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange for the Bank of Boston. "We were lucky the market got off the ground today."
In early trading, there was no news to stimulate the market, Mr. Lawrie said.
Later, a plunge in stock prices prompted the dollar's slight selloff against some currencies. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 30.19 points at 3,336.31.
Dealers said many investors went into the extended weekend with large dollar holdings and some took profits yesterday.
Mr. Lawrie said there was underlying demand for the dollar, but investors were expected to wait for news or new economic data to move the dollar before jumping in.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 134.25 Japanese yen, up from Friday's 133.95 yen. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.32 yen, to 134.22 yen. Later, in Middle East trading, it was quoted at 134.24 yen.
Sterling in New York was quoted at $1.7495, compared with $1.7455 Friday. The British pound was quoted at $1.7440 in the Middle East, compared with $1.7448 in Milan Friday.
Also in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6655 German marks, down from 1.6690 Friday. In the Middle East, the dollar was quoted at 1.6715 marks. That compared with 1.6686 late Friday in Milan, one of the few markets open on Good Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's levels, were: 1.5385 Swiss francs, down from 1.5445; 5.6270 French francs, down from 5.64325; 1,251.00 Italian lire, down from 1,255.00, and 1.17965 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1816.

HEADLINE: Hershey Follows Mars on 5 Refund

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Take that candy wrapper out of the waste basket.
Hershey, following in the footsteps of its archrival M&M Mars, said yesterday that consumers would get a 5-cent refund for each candy wrapper mailed to the company. 
 When Mars introduced a similar program last week, candy experts said Hershey would be quick to follow.
The two giants are battling for control of the $9 billion candy industry. The companies have been trading the No. 1 spot for several years, both with a little over a third of the market, and sales are so close that neither company is currently claiming supremacy.
"Mars and Hershey are engaged in quite a contest for leadership in the candy industry," said Jerry Prescott, president of the King Group, a candy distributor in Ann Arbor, Mich. He said the two companies combined accounted for 80 percent of the chocolate sales in the country and about 70 percent of candy sales. In addition to its signature Hershey Milk Chocolate line of candy bars, the company makes Mr. Goodbar, Kit-Kats and Reese's Peanut Butter Cups. Besides M&M's, Mars makes Snickers, Three Musketeers and Milky Way candy bars.
Natalie Bailey, a spokeswoman for Hershey Chocolate U.S.A. in Hershey, Pa., acknowledged that the Hershey rebate program was a direct response to the move by Mars. "Very often when one manufacturer introduces a promotion, others will counter to stay competitive," she said. "We expect this will have a positive impact on sales and profits."
The Hershey offer will run until Oct. 31, two weeks longer than the Mars offer. Both companies said nibblers must submit at least 20 wrappers at a time. As an added incentive, Hershey said it would send coupons for four free candy bars for consumers who respond by July 31.
The rebates follow a flat year for candy sales in the United States. While dollar sales were up by about 4 percent last year because of a price increase, volume failed to increase.
Mr. Prescott said the nickel increase in candy bars last year hurt sales with price-sensitive consumers. "Prices were reaching a point where there was some consumer resistance," he said. The average candy bar now costs 45 cents.
 
'Not Recession-Proof'
 "We are recession-resistant but we are not recession-proof," said Dick O'Connell, president of the Chocolate Manufacturers Association, a trade group in McLean, Va.
While candy industry executives hope the refunds will stimulate sales, some marketing experts are skeptical. "I find it hard to believe that people are going to mail something in," said Susan Small-Weil, chief planning officer for Warwick, Baker & Fiore, an advertising agency in New York. "It seems to me to be too much of an effort at a time when there are so many existing coupons for people to use."
But Mary Ellen Dougherty, a spokeswoman for Mars, in Hackettstown, N.J., said the response had been strong so far. Mars also cut its wholesale prices last week.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

Gordon Henderson's Future
Gordon Henderson, a New York designer who seemed on a star track two years ago, may be shopping for a new backer if he loses the support of his licensing partner.
Mr. Henderson's designer collection is produced and sold under a licensing arrangement with World Hong Kong, which is headed by Ricky Sasaki, a mercurial Japanese garment executive with wide-ranging manufacturing interests in Asia. 
 Neither Mr. Henderson nor Mr. Sasaki returned phone calls yesterday. Peter Clements, the president of World Hong Kong U.S.A. in New York, said: "The company is currently negotiating with Mr. Henderson regarding how to go forward. With the economy as it is, there's a lot of re-evaluating going on."
Sales of Mr. Henderson's designer collection -- that is, the styles shown on the fashion runway -- have been depressed by the economic slump, Mr. Clements said.
World Hong Kong has enjoyed greater successes with its private-label clothing for department stores, he added, as well as with But Gordon, a less-expensive spinoff collection designed by Mr. Henderson.
 
A Friend for Perry Ellis
Of the voices praising last week's appointment of Ellin Saltzman as fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman -- an industry chorus as upbeat as "Oklahoma" -- some of the loudest were executives for Perry Ellis.
This spring, for the first time, Bergdorf did not order a Perry Ellis collection designed by Marc Jacobs, although the spring show, with its sequined bandanna skirts and other whimsical Western wear, had been widely acclaimed. The store also eliminated its in-store Perry Ellis boutique, hanging the clothes with other labels.
"They just didn't like it," said Robert Duffy, the president of Perry Ellis. "We're sold there in bits and pieces, but they didn't buy it as a collection. It was definitely unusual."
As corporate fashion director of Macy's and I. Magnin, Mrs. Saltzman has been a consistent fan of the Perry Ellis collection.
 
Ribbons, Jewels and AIDS
Red lapel ribbons, like those worn during the Academy Awards presentation to show support in the struggle against AIDS, are still being seen around town, including a glittery jeweled version. The beaded pins are the work of James Arpad, a jewelry designer, who is donating the profits to an AIDS charity.
"I thought I would take it one step further and make it something of permanence," Mr. Arpad said. The pins are hand-jeweled with Austrian crystal pave on leather, to approximate the feeling of the ribbon.
"A few people wore them at the Oscars, including Richard Pryor," Mr. Arpad said. "And Elizabeth Taylor wore one at last week's Amfar benefit."
Originally created by a group of artists in downtown New York about a year ago, the red ribbons have become a fashion accessory. Mr. Arpad's version cost $100 and can be ordered by calling (212) 944-9406. The profits will be donated to the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS.
 
A Movie Role for Mizrahi
After seeing Isaac Mizrahi's fall fashion show a week ago, Barry Sonnenfeld, the director of "The Addams Family" movie, said he wanted to stage a fashion-show scene for his next movie in the same location, a ground-floor loft at 440 Lafayette Street, across from the Public Theater. Mr. Mizrahi is to take a bit part in the movie, "The Concierge." He plays the fashion designer.
