HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Olympia Gets Short-Term Bank Loan

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 21

 BODY:
Olympia & York Developments Ltd. has raised nearly $100 million through a bank loan and the sale of its stake in one of Canada's biggest financial services companies, Toronto and New York financial officials said today.
Olympia & York, the Reichmann brothers' embattled property company, has been scrambling for funds to avoid bankruptcy. 
 "They're not enough, but they do buy time for the negotiating process to go on," Alain Tuchmaier, an analyst for McLean McCarthy Inc., said of the funds raised.
 
A Psychological Boost
 The $30 million loan from its most important bank lenders, including the Royal Bank of Canada and the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, is a short-term loan intended to get the company through the next few weeks, when it needs to pay taxes and operating expenses in Canada, several people involved in the talks said.
Even though Olympia had been seeking $85 million, the loan is psychologically important. Until now, banks were believed to be unwilling to provide any of the fresh funds the company says it needs to restructure about $5 billion of its $18.5 billion of debt.
The company has been playing a game of brinksmanship, betting that its banks would come up money rather than precipitate a bankruptcy that could lead to the fire sale of billion of dollars of commercial real estate in New York, London and Toronto.
Olympia & York, whose problems have been caused by the recession, a glut of commercial office space and the drain of cash from its huge Canary Wharf project in London, also raised $64 million in Canadian currency ($54 million United States) from the sale of 7.1 million shares in the Trilon Financial Corporation.
 
A Deal Done Quietly
 The sale, which took place April 10 but has yet to show up on the insider trading reports of the Ontario Securities Commission, was disclosed today by Trilon's president and chief executive, Kenneth R. Clarke. Toronto financial officials later said the buyer, at $9 a share, was the Ontario Teachers Pension Fund.
Trilon, which has $45 billion (Canadian) in assets, holds major interests in insurance, trust companies, investment banking and real estate. It is controlled by one of the other major Canadian family business groups, the Edper enterprise of Edward and Peter Bronfman.
Mr. Clarke disclosed the transaction in responding to reporters' questions at Trilon's annual meeting today. He declined to disclose all the financial details or the buyer and said in an interview it was "a private transaction but obviously of interest to us."
The Reichmanns had held 8.8 million shares, or 11 percent of Trilon. They acquired the shares about 10 years ago, when Trilon bought the Royal Trust Company, then Canada's largest trust company and controlled by the Reichmanns. The Reichmanns still retain about 1.6 million shares in Trilon.
 
'Orderly Liquidation'
 Brian Berner, president of Berner & Company, a Toronto securities firm, described the sale as part of "the orderly liquidation of unnecessary assets" in the Reichmann controlled empire.
Other financial analysts said the Reichmanns had been selling preferred shares of many companies they control and are attempting to sell other assets as well.
The company placed its net equity last week at $5.5 billion. Analysts noted, however, that that was based on the assets' estimated current market value, not on what they would yield in a quick liquidiation.
The only other major company where the Reichmanns and the Bronfmans share an ownership stake is the Trizec Corporation of Calgary, Alberta, which owns 313 income-producing properties, including shopping centers and commercial buildings, chiefly in Canada and the United States. Olympia owns 36 percent of Trizec and Edper 40 percent.

HEADLINE: Big Banks Post Rises In Profits

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citicorp said yesterday that it earned $183 million in the first quarter, thanks to higher profits in its consumer business and to gains on the sale of various investments and subsidiaries. Its stock rose $1.50, to $18.25, in active trading on the earnings news, even though its loan losses remained high.
Several other leading banks -- including Chemical, Bankers Trust, Wells Fargo and Banc One -- reported strong earnings yesterday, sending their stocks up. 
 Chemical Banking said cost savings and other benefits from its merger at the end of last year with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation had helped its profits rise 44 percent, and its stock gained 87.5 cents, to $34.75. Bankers Trust reported a 9 percent earnings increase and its shares rose $1.50, to $55.125.
Wells Fargo reported a much- stronger-than-expected profit of $119 million. That was down 21.7 percent from a year earlier but contrasted sharply with the $215 million loss the company reported in the fourth quarter of last year. Its stock surged $9.875, to $76.125.
The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, which has largely avoided the real estate losses that have plagued other large banking companies reported a record profit of $179 million, up 37.7 percent from a year earlier. Its stock, already traded at a higher level relative to its profits than most banks, gained only 25 cents to close at $43.25.
Following are the details of the banking companies' results:
 
Citicorp
 Citicorp's profit of $183 million, or 37 cents a share, was up 96.8 percent from $93 million, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier before an accounting change. Net income in last year's first quarter was $550 million, or $1.48 a share, after the accounting change.
This year's income remains far below a healthy level for the nation's largest banking company. Indeed, the company would have had a loss, had it not sold nonessential businesses and various investments at a $218 million after-tax profit.
Earnings were also helped by a cut in overhead expenses to $2.36 billion, from $2.50 billion a year earlier. Revenue rose to $3.99 billion, from $3.58 billion a year earlier.
"Citicorp is making progress, but they are clearly not at the end of the line in terms of making themselves an above-average banking company," said Diane B. Glossman, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers.
She noted that the $260 million profit Citicorp earned in its consumer businesses around the world was up from $161 million a year earlier, but that the company needed to continue with the cost-cutting efforts it started at the end of 1990. Its work force of 85,000, as of March 31, was down 8,500 from the peak in late 1990.
Citicorp's biggest problem remains loan losses. It wrote off $435 million of consumer loans and $568 million of business loans, mostly for real estate in North America and London. The reserve for loan losses, which many analysts say is too low in relation to its loan problems, was increased by $237 million.
John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday that costs of writing off bad loans and setting aside reserves to cover future losses would remain about the same this year as in 1991, when the company wrote off $4.93 billion of loans. But he said losses in the second half of this year should be lower than the first half.
By the end of the year, Mr. Reed said, he expects Citicorp to be earning a profit at a rate that if continued for a year would equal about $1.5 billion. That would be less than Citicorp's best year, 1988, when the bank earned $1.86 billion and its bad-loan write-offs were $1.75 billion.
 
Chemical Banking
 At the Chemical Banking Corporation, the first-quarter profit of $260 million, or $1 a share, was up from $181 million, or 84 cents a share, a year earlier. An increase in the spread between the interest paid for deposits and other funds and the interest earned on loans and investments -- to 3.72 percentage points from 3.07 percentage points a year earlier -- added $173 million to the company's income.
Chemical also benefited from a $113 million increase in fees from trading and other banking activities. Overhead costs were reduced $50 million as a result of its merger, and the company said it was on target for merger-related savings of $225 million by the end of this year and $750 million by 1995. The two bank subsidiaries -- the Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover -- will be merged on June 19.
Chemical's earnings were reduced by the $375 million it provided to the loan-loss reserve, which was up from $279 million a year earlier but down from $450 million in the fourth quarter of 1991.
 
Bankers Trust
 The Bankers Trust New York Corporation earned $175 million, or $2.02 a share, up from $160 million, or $1.85 a share, a year earlier because of strong gains in investment management, corporate finance fees, and profits from its investments in other corporations. Revenues from securities and foreign exchange trading fell 42 percent, to $216 million.
Overhead expenses at Bankers Trust fell by $48 million, or 8 percent, from a year earlier, as bonuses declined, and the company benefited from a previously announced 9 percent reduction in its staff.
 
Wells Fargo
 Wells Fargo & Company's first-quarter profit of $119 million, or $2.09 a share, was down 21.7 percent from $152 million, or $2.86, a year earlier, but contrasted sharply with a $231 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1991.
Weakness in the California economy, particularly in real estate, where Wells Fargo is one of the state's most active lenders, caused a big increase in loans that are badly delinquent. Real estate acquired through foreclosure rose to $2.49 billion at the end of the first quarter from $1.59 billion a year earlier. The company provided a loan-loss reserve of $215 million, down from $700 million in the fourth quarter.
Wells increased the difference between the interest rates it pays and the interest rates it charges to 5.70 percentage points, from 5.06 points a year earlier and 5.22 points in the fourth quarter.
 
Banc One
 The Banc One Corporation earned $179 million, or 86 cents a share, up from $130 million, or 67 cents, a year earlier. Banc One increased the difference between the rates it pays and the rates it charges to 6.82 percentage points, from 6.17 points a year earlier and 5.93 points in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Restaurant's Rebirth: A Breeze Blows in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
IT is an eerie experience, to wander through a vast, deserted restaurant where more than 2,000 people once ate at the same time. More than a million people a year are said to have come to F. W. I. L. Lundy Brothers to inhale lobster, steaks and the best biscuits in the whole world.
Then, Irving Lundy, the owner, died in 1977. Sputtering efforts by family members failed to maintain the restaurant at Emmons and Ocean Avenues in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. Whoever was last in charge seems to have just walked away, leaving the place looking as if a neutron bomb exploded sometime around 1980. Only people were obliterated. 
 Owners have come and gone, the dirt has drifted like snow. Glasses still sit on drying racks, bottles of liquor are half full, stuffed fish swim ever grungier walls.
Here is the clam bar where a dozen bivalves commanded $4. There, coral and turquoise-colored chairs are piled to the ceiling. A discarded sign promises "Free Parking for Big Capt. Bob," a clock is forever stopped at 5:27 and dusty light filters through stained glass. With the regularity of a clock ticking, the roof leaks.
"I love it," exuded Peter Romeo, who kept lusting after the Gothic-style lamps. "I'd restore these for free."
Mr. Romeo, now a lighting restoration entrepreneur, is a man who has traveled many highways, including that of a hard-nosed bill collector. But it is in his latest metamorphosis, a super-charged civic volunteer, that he has begun to achieve renown, including congratulatory letters from the Mayor.
First, he brought together a flock of fellow blue-collar craftsmen to help restore the Lefferts Homestead, a 200-year-old house in Prospect Park. Then, he began a still-unrealized campaign to string high-powered lights on the sadly defunct Coney Island parachute jump.
And now, he yearns to restore a grand restaurant he once frequented.
Well, not all of it. Only the outside. And that only for a while.
But the fact is that his small initiative comes when things may be looking up for an institution long threatening to be reborn. Something like a dozen reopenings have been trumpeted, then forgotten. But last month, the Landmarks Preservation Commission ordered that the Spanish Colonial Revival-style building be preserved.
Simultaneously, the owners, one a former Lundy's busboy, have begun a new drive for more than $10 million in bank financing, the key to renovations needed to reopen. City economic development agencies are helping.
But the freshest breeze is the volunteers Mr. Romeo has recruited. By painting bright pictures on panels along the building's walls, they intend to at least put a fresh face on things. When the local students, artists and neighborhood improvers are done, passers-by will glimpse scenes of merry diners instead of boarded-up, graffiti-smeared windows.
It matters little that they are improving someone else's property for free, not when a local landmark that has sunk lower and lower can be made to snap to attention. Maybe even the banks will notice.
Mr. Romeo summoned a grab bag of the volunteers to his bayside apartment a few blocks from Lundy's. Over coffee and cake, they remembered a classier Sheepshead Bay and pledged to make it sparkle again.
"To see Lundy's not open all these years is very painful to me," said Cynthia Myers, an art teacher from Cunningham Junior High School whose class will paint a panel.
David Pasacreta, whose students at William E. Grady Vocational High School will actually construct the panels, said this work would otherwise have cost at least $16,500.
Frank and Jerry Bisogno, two diehard Brooklynites, waxed elegiac over Lundy's. Frank, author of a book about Brooklyn celebrities, told of a police car's being stolen in front of Lundy's, leading to the title of the television sitcom, "Car 54, Where Are You?" A bit incongruously, he said he heard the story from a limousine driver for a Nevada brothel.
Jerry, who is contemplating a run for the State Senate, figures the key to Lundy's rebirth is a big parking garage.
Sal Raio, who repairs transmissions for a living, dropped by with a check for $530 to pay the rent for office space. I. Stephen Miller, president of the Sheepshead Bay Historical Society, told the tangled story of how Irving Lundy's estate was swindled of $10 million.
Carol, Mr. Romeo's wife, recounted how Lundy's heavenly blueberry pie came in a heavy pan you could take home, providing you paid a $5 deposit.
The morning added up to a nice mix of nostalgia and hope in a community where good news has become too rare. Mr. Romeo was having a ball.
"People go to bed, they go to work, they sit on their couch and that's their life," he declared. "This thing takes me in directions I never dreamed of."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Romeo, right, is heading an effort to beautify Lundy's, a restaurant in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, that has been closed since 1980. He spoke with Aryeh First, an artist, in front of the building. (Lee Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Emigres Lend a Hand In Homelands

 BODY:
In the last tumultuous days of World War II, when Soviet troops attacked the fiercely nationalistic town in Ukraine that had nurtured his relatives for generations, Orest Baranyk and his family fled, living in refugee camps before coming to the United States in 1950.
Mr. Baranyk was 6 years old when he arrived, and he grew up in the exile culture that thrived in Chicago, speaking Ukrainian at home. But Ukraine itself remained alien to him, for the Communist Government would not allow him to return for even a brief visit. 
 Now the collapse of the Soviet Union and the independence of Ukraine have given Mr. Baranyk, a 48-year-old architect, the chance to rebuild ties severed so early in life. Though he is an American citizen, he has dedicated himself to the rebuilding of Ukraine by working as an adviser to the fledgling Government in Kiev.
"Ukraine has been struggling for independence for so many centuries," he said. "I've always felt that those people who wound up in the Ukrainian diaspora had an obligation to help it get to that final goal: true independence."
 
Providing Talent, Not Money
 As the nations of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union try to re-create themselves with the collapse of Communism, they are attracting hundreds of Americans and Canadians who either left those lands decades ago or are the descendants of emigrants.
The vast majority are not returning permanently, for their roots are now in North America. But they are going back for short periods to use their language ability and skills in engineering, law, finance and other fields to help governments fashion new economies and new systems of administration.
"They've said to us, 'Don't send your dollars, send us your talents,' " said Gabija M. Petrauskas, a 41-year-old official in the Canadian Government whose parents left Lithuania after World War II. In January she began a two-year stint in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, as an assistant to the country's Prime Minister, Gediminas Vagnorius.
"This is the kind of economic assistance people can provide," said Mrs. Petrauskas, who speaks fluent Lithuanian. "We cannot provide the millions of dollars to set up their economy."
As these countries express interest in Western expertise, organizations like the United Nations and the United States State Department are joining fraternal groups like the American Czechoslovak Society in recruiting advisers.
 
This Aid Comes Cheap
 Nessim Shallon, a senior adviser at the United Nations Development Program, said the bewildering number of problems these countries had faced in the last year had become all the more intractable because their officials were so inexperienced.
Mr. Shallon runs a program called Tokten -- Transfer of Knowledge Through Expatriate Nationals. In the last year it has placed about 60 Western advisers of Polish descent in Poland, and is expanding into other countries in the region. The advisers stay from two weeks to three months.
For the State Department, these programs provide an inexpensive vehicle for sending aid, particularly at a time when foreign aid budgets are coming under growing scrutiny. The countries themselves see the advisers as catalysts who can help jump-start bureaucracies that have grown sluggish and ineffective from years of Communism.
"They were appreciative of the fact that there were people who were concerned about the country where they have their roots," said Mr. Baranyk, who led a team of lawyers that monitored the referendum on independence in Ukraine in December. He plans to return to Ukraine a few times each year to help rebuild the country's buildings and roads.
Lucien N. Nedzi, a former Congressman from Detroit, recalled that when he visited Warsaw for a week last year to advise the new Parliament on how representative bodies work, officials were still using a vote-counting machine that did not distinguish between yes and no votes -- a vestige of Communism.
"The trouble was that they were good politicians, but they had absolutely no experience in parliamentary activity," said Mr. Nedzi, 66, a second-generation Polish-American who speaks Polish.
 
A Charge of Meddling
 Mrs. Petrauskas, who is setting up a program in Lithuania to train civil servants, said the enthusiasm of the officials she advises had often been tinged with anxiety or even resentment. The more they work with her, the more they realize how backward their Government is, she said, adding that she had heard that a few officials have called her "the meddler" behind her back. She said she had realized from her work in Vilnius that she would never be fully accepted there, despite her Lithuanian roots.
Indeed, many of the Westerners working as advisers in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union said their experiences had forced them to re-examine their identities: where do they lie, in the New World or the Old?
"If I say I'm more American, the Hungarians get upset, and vice versa," said Paul G. Teleki, a 54-year-old geologist advising the Ministry of Industry and Trade in Budapest. Now an American citizen, Mr. Teleki fled Hungary in 1956 when the Soviet Army crushed the uprising there. For the last year, he has divided his time between Budapest and his home in Herndon, Va.
"You always have an attraction to your place of birth," he said. "On the other hand, I've spent two-thirds of my life in the United States, so I feel very comfortable and grateful to be here. So I try to be in both places at once."

HEADLINE: Record Pace for U.S. Deficit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
The Federal deficit at the midpoint of the 1992 fiscal year has ballooned to nearly $200 billion, far ahead of last year's record pace, the Government said today.
Deficit spending in March totaled $49.4 billion, bringing the deficit for the first six months of fiscal 1992 to $196.9 billion, 29 percent greater than the six-month imbalance a year earlier. 
 The deficit appears to be on pace to meet the Bush Administration's projection of $399.7 billion by the end of the fiscal year, Sept. 30.
Because of a financing disruption in the savings and loan bailout program, however, many private economists now are projecting a somewhat smaller deficit, although still well ahead of last year's record of $269.5 billion.
Economists said the extensive Federal borrowing, by eating up investors' savings, is keeping mortgage rates and other long-term interest rates relatively high and hindering the economy's recovery from recession.
To stimulate economic growth, the Federal Reserve has pushed short-term interest rates down by about 4 percentage points over the last year and a half. But long-term rates, over which the central bank has little influence, have fallen only about 1.5 percentage points.
"Fiscal realities are an abysmal state of affairs," said Kathleen Stephansen, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. in New York. "The deficit as a percentage of the gross domestic product will be in excess of 6 percent.
"Historically -- before the 1980's -- it's been at 2 percent. That puts tremendous pressure on interest rates," she said.
In March, the deficit was 20 percent higher than the $41.2 billion in March 1991, when the deficit was held down by $12.9 billion in contributions from allies to help pay for the Persian Gulf war.

HEADLINE: Baker Spells Out U.S. Approach: Alliances and 'Democratic Peace'

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d spelled out America's approach to foreign policy in the post-cold-war world today, saying it must aim to build a "democratic peace" around the globe, while sharing the burdens of that peace with Washington's allies through "collective engagement."
Speaking to the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations, Mr. Baker charged those who advocate isolationist, "America first" patriotism with "avoiding the challenges of our times by pretending they do not exist." 
 He argued that now that the cold war is over, the United States should increasingly conduct its foreign relations as the leader of coalitions, rather than as a lone superpower.
His speech, the text of which was distributed in Washington, appeared to be part of an increasing effort by the Administration to win domestic support for aiding the former Soviet republics, by trying to explain to Americans why that is in their interest and how it connects with broader American foreign policy goals.
 
Help From Prosperous Allies
 "Our idea," said Mr. Baker, "is to replace the dangerous period of the cold war with a democratic peace -- a peace built on the twin pillars of political and economic freedom. By supporting democracy and free markets in Russia and Eurasia, we can extend the 'zone of peace and prosperity' further east across Russia and Eurasia and bring these new states into the democratic community of nations. That is good for American interests and values."
Mr. Baker then went on to put in the best light possible the fact that America alone no longer has the resources -- as it did after World War II with the Marshall Plan -- to help erect that democratic peace. Therefore, it must increasingly rely on world institutions, and broad coalitions, to do together what the United States might once have done alone.
"The community of democratic nations is larger and more vigorous than at the end of World War II," Mr. Baker said. "That is why we plan to build a democratic peace by pursuing a straightforward policy of American leadership called 'collective engagement.' "
"Germany, Italy and Japan are now strong and prosperous allies," he said. "By working with our other allies and the international institutions we created in the aftermath of World War II -- the United Nations, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund -- we need not go it alone. Instead, we can build a democratic peace together."
 
Global Trust and Power
 Mr. Baker contended that the fact that the United States must now increasingly rely on the help of others to implement its values and many of its interests does not mean that Washington must abdicate its leadership position.
"As the most powerful democracy on earth, we must act the catalyst, driving forward where we can," said Mr. Baker. "As President Bush has said, 'The world trusts us with power. They trust us to do what's right.' Because of this American record we are able today -- if we will -- to work with our partners to share responsibilities and costs, and to advance together on common problems. That's American leadership through collective engagement."
He went on to cite several areas where that policy has already been employed in recent years -- from the Persian Gulf War to Western assistance programs for the former Soviet republics.
"In each case," Mr. Baker said, "we did not have to do it alone, but without us it could not have been done successfully. Despite the doubts and the doubters, the verdict is in. Collective engagement works. To put it simply: We led, we had partners and together we succeeded."

HEADLINE: Health Care the Way It Used to Be;
Dinkins Idea Is Tried and True. Can It Work Here and Now?

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
Melissa Lopez sat in the waiting room of the William F. Ryan Community Health Care Center yesterday, waiting for a pediatrician to examine her feverish niece. She had heard, she said, about the health care plan proposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins on Monday, but she wondered what was new. The Mayor's proposal that each Medicaid patient have a personal doctor sounded to her like the way care is already provided at the Ryan center, where she has been going for nearly five years.
The Dinkins administration's plan to eventually provide every poor person in the city with a family doctor is not new. The concept has been discussed for decades in New York and around the country as the ideal approach to preventive health care. Similarly, the plan, known as managed care, is not untried. Already there are more than a dozen city clinics like the Ryan Center, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, which serve as models for the new clinics proposed by the Mayor. 
 What is new, judging from the details released so far, is the scope of the plan's long-term goals. Most of the managed-care programs that already exist are private, providing care to the relatively small populations of their immediate neighborhoods. The Dinkins plan, in contrast, would be an ambitious attempt by government to coax a large number of Medicaid patients to seek primary care in clinics rather than hospital emergency rooms, in effect returning to the way medical care used to be but has not been for a long time.
 
'Have to Start Somewhere'
 "It's a new bottle, old wine," said Dr. Merle C. Cunningham, medical director of the Sunset Park Family Health Care Center of the Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn, whose clinic assigns doctors for the continuous treatment of Medicaid patients. "This was a great idea in the 60's. It was a great idea in the 70's and in the 80's, and it's still a great idea, just as long as the city does it right."
What it would take to do it right is the subject of much debate. In announcing the program, Cesar Perales, Deputy Mayor for Health and Human Services, said the goal was to provide doctors where there currently are none, giving patients an alternative to the emergency room for their basic medical care.
Initially, he said, three new centers would be built and 17 existing clinics would be converted into full-service 24-hour health centers, at an estimated cost to the city of $20 million. Another $13.9 million would be spent to hire 600 doctors, nurses and other workers for those centers.
Those 20 centers would only be able to meet about 5 percent of the need, Mr. Perales said, but "you have to start somewhere."
The centers would be run like health maintenance organizations and would be paid a flat monthly fee by Medicaid for each patient. Patients who do not qualify for Medicaid would be charged a sliding fee based on their incomes. In exchange for that fee, the clinic would provide all the patient's care, including referrals to specialists when needed.
That approach is known as capitation, or per-head payment. Critics say it encourages doctors to undertreat patients because the fee remains the same regardless of how often a patient comes to the clinic. Supporters say that capitation encourages preventive care, because if a patient becomes sick he will be a greater economic drain on the clinic.
Health care experts described the plan as a start, but only a start, toward better care for the poor. There is concern that the announcement might be only a political move, one in a spate of proclamations of increases in city services as Mr. Dinkins's re-election campaign nears.
"If there's no long-term commitment, the program will die," said Barry L. Liebowitz, president of the Doctors Council, which represents the 3,000 doctors employed by the city. "This can't just be the idea of the month."
Mr. Perales, who calls the proposed plan "my baby," said he regrets that the timing of the announcement came in the middle of "good news week," at City Hall. "The timing is unfortunate for me," he said. "But this has been in the works a long time and it represents a long-term commitment."
 
'A Little Skeptical'
 There is concern, too, that the plan is too ambitious for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation and the Department of Health, which will run the new centers. The city's municipal hospitals, run by the hospitals corporation, are currently overcrowded and financially troubled. Similarly, many Health Department clinics are inefficient and dingy.
"Reading what has been happening with the city hospitals, I feel a little skeptical about the city taking on this new plan," said Dr. Pedro Plamenco, the associate director of adult medicine at Sunset Park.
Specifically, there are questions about whether the city can find enough doctors to staff the clinics. Both the hospitals corporation and the Health Department regularly have problems finding and retaining doctors.
Dr. Liebowitz said the doctors would have to be paid enough to keep them, a figure he put at $100,000 a year. At the Ryan Center, staff doctors are paid between $75,000 and $80,000, said Barbara Minch, the deputy director. Turnover, she said, is "not a problem." Mr. Perales said no salary has been set for the doctors.
Dr. Emilio Carrillo, who resigned as president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation last year and who is now the medical director of the Ryan Center, said it would take more than money to find doctors for the new centers. He said the city would have to rethink the entire relationship between the city hospitals and the private medical centers that staff them.
The medical centers must create more training programs in such primary care specialties as obstetrics, pediatrics and family medicine, Dr. Carrillo said.
Even skeptics agree, however, that when managed-care centers in poor neighborhoods work, they work well.
Both the Ryan Center and the Sunset Park Center are clean, modern places, with comfortable chairs and a cheerful staff. Recent visits found that patients wait longer than they might like but not as long as they would in a local emergency room.
"You do have to wait, but you have to wait everyplace," said Carmen Ortiz, who was at Sunset Park with her 7-month-old daughter, Jennifer.
Ms. Ortiz said she particularly likes that the same doctor sees her daughter at every check-up and that she was even allowed to change doctors when she did not feel comfortable with the first one assigned.
Most patients said that they would prefer to have a private doctor in a small personal office, but that they could not afford that luxury.
"The private doctor was more personal," said Louis Rodriguez, who lost his insurance recently when he lost his job. "Now I have to resort to this. Generally it's not that bad. The care I've seen is O.K."

HEADLINE: Bank Yields Are Lower For Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money-market accounts and certificates of deposit were down for the week that ends today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, but the decline was modest compared with that of a week ago.
New York rates were flat, analysts said, compared with yields offered at 20 large commercial banks nationally. Robert K. Heady, publisher of the interest-rate publication, noted the mixed signals but added that the fair-sized cut in yields at commercial banks outside New York might have resulted from the interpretation of remarks last week by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. 
 Mr. Greenspan had said he was upbeat about the economy's growth, but bankers seem to feel there is room for further Fed easing, which could filter down and get more banks to lower their prime rates.
 
 
Bill Yields Move Up
 While bank yields may have backed down, the Treasury's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills resulted in higher yields. A three-month bill was up 6 basis points, to 3.69 percent, and a six-month bill rose 13 basis points, to 3.86 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 The closely watched auction is sometimes a harbinger of what many banks eventually pay customers.
Mr. Heady said the climate was such that he would not be surprised to see bank rates decline again despite the low levels of recent months.
Yields at New York-area banks slipped only slightly compared with the drops last week. The average yield on a money-market account was down 2 basis points, to 3.55 percent, while a three-month certificate remained unchanged at 3.61 percent. For a six-month certificate, the yield was off a basis point, to 3.75 percent.
 
 
Savings Banks Cut More
 Commercial banks offered money-market accounts with an average rate of 3.28 percent, down 2 basis points from a week earlier. Three- and six-month C.D.'s were unchanged at 3.41 percent and 3.50 percent, respectively.
 At savings banks, the yield cuts were a little meatier, with money market accounts down 4 basis points, to 3.81 percent, and three- and six-month certificates off 2 basis points, to 3.81 percent and 4.01 percent, respectively.
The biggest changes in yields among New York-area banks took place at Crossland Savings, which cut its money-market rate by 20 basis points, to 3.75 percent, and at Marine Midland, which increased its three-month certificate by 15 basis points, to 3.30 percent. Greater New York Savings Bank cut the yield on its six-month certificiate by 10 basis points, to 3.90 percent.
For 20 large banks outside the New York area, yields fell a little further, with the average money market rate down 7 basis points, to 3.45 percent, and a six-month C.D. rate down 8 basis points, to 3.79 percent.

HEADLINE: Pessimism and Bitterness on Eve of Trade Talks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Anticipating a failure of trade talks on Wednesday between President Bush and European Community leaders, American and European officials laid the groundwork today for blaming each other.
Both sides insisted that further concessions were out of the question while adding that they were eager to negotiate if the other side made a new offer. But in private, trade officials were gloomy about the likelihood of fresh offers and described an especially poisonous atmosphere on the eve of the talks. 
 At stake is the five-year-old effort to expand international free trade rules to include not only most manufactured goods, but also agriculture and service industries like investment banking and accounting. A report released in Paris today said that success in the 108-nation talks to broaden the rules, known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, would raise annual world economic output by $195 billion within a decade.
 
Service Industries vs. Agriculture
 But European officials said today that they saw little flexibility on the part of American officials. They stepped up their criticism of the United States' reluctance to apply free trade rules to its aviation, maritime and long-distance telephone service industries.
A senior Bush Administration official said that the burden was on the European Community to change its stand, and that there had been "no hints" of a fresh offer from the community to limit government assistance to farmers. The official said divisions among European countries were blocking progress.
Senior Administration officials said less progress had been made on the issue than previously reported. Hopes for an agreement in global trade talks rose slightly in late March when European officials responded enthusiastically to an offer from President Bush to exempt some subsidies from cuts.
But a senior official told reporters at the White House today that European officials had had several difficulties with the American offer.
Another senior Administration official said the two sides could not agree on the most basic issues of what subsidies to exempt and for how long. The United States wants exemptions to be temporary and limited to subsidies that have no effect on production, like payments to farmers who retire or let their land lie fallow, he said. The European Community wants the exemptions to be permanent and embrace many more subsidies.
 
European Disputes U.S. Version
 A European official said the Americans were playing down the level of agreement and were wrong to attribute the stalemate to a division among European Community members. "The question is not confusion, it's that our position is not acceptable to the U.S.," the official said.
The White House and the European Community obliged their officials to speak on condition of anonymity today, as neither side wanted to commit itself publicly to any position on the eve of the talks. Conducting the talks on the European side will be Jacques Delors, the president of the European Community, and Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal, whose country currently holds the Community's presidency.
While a breakthrough to restart the GATT talks seems unlikely, officials on both sides tried to figure out whether some cosmetic bargains could take its place. But the White House appears reluctant to step in and force a deal at the risk of antagonizing American farm groups, Administration officials said.
A failure of Wednesday's trade meeting would make it unlikely, although not impossible, that a GATT agreement would be reached this year, trade officials said. The Presidential election campaign could be a complicating factor, although a senior official at the White House said President Bush would not allow the elections to slow negotiations.
Japan, which has resisted allowing rice imports as part of a trade agreement, has also been trying to deflect blame for a failure of the 108-nation GATT talks. Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe sent a letter to Washington and Brussels earlier this month urging the United States and the European Community to resume stalled negotiations on tariff reductions and the opening of service industry markets even as they try to settle their differences on agriculture.
Remarks by some American officials today signaled a toxic atmosphere. One senior Administration official accused the European Community of having waged a campaign of press leaks to raise expectations for the talks.
But even though European officials made optimistic comments last month, the European Community's spokesman in Brussels began warning more than a week ago that Wednesday's talks were unlikely to result in a breakthrough.
Not even on the agenda is a draft accord struck on March 31 by American and European negotiators to limit government subsidies to the commercial aircraft industry. Talks have since reopened on the exact level of some subsidies, and the GATT talks have been infected by recriminations over who is backing away from the original deal on aircraft.

HEADLINE: Payoffs for Lotto Winners

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 21

 BODY:
An unemployed aircraft mechanic and a telephone company technician who had declared bankruptcy each claimed checks today for $440,523, the first installment of their share of a record-setting $44.4 million Pick-6 Lotto jackpot.
Derrick Webb of Newark and David N. Demarest of Woodbridge held two of the four tickets sold for Monday's drawing with the winning numbers of 16, 21, 23, 26, 31 and 37. 
 Each winner will receive nearly $11.1 million over 20 years before taxes.
One ticket is being verified and the holder of the other has not yet come forward, said Frank Pelly, the lottery executive director. Those tickets were sold in Passaic and Essex Counties.
Mr. Webb, 33 years old, has been unemployed for 10 months. An 11-year member of the Air Force Reerve, he had been an aircraft mechanic at McGuire Air Force Base and a bus driver for N.J. Transit. "This is more money than I've ever thought about having in a lifetime," he said.
 
To Pay Off Debts
 Mr. Demarest, 51, said he might consider early retirement from his job as a communications technician with New Jersey Bell. He said he would use part of his winnings to pay off debts that pushed him into personal bankruptcy last year.
More than 25.7 million tickets were sold for Monday's drawing, Mr. Pelly said. Total sales for the seven drawings that led to the Monday jackpot were $67.6 million, sending more than $28.4 million to the fund for education and state institutions.
The $44.4 million jackpot broke the previous mark set on Jan. 30, when the prize of $30.8 million went to three players. The $16.8 million in Pick-6 sales on Monday was also a record.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Finish Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as dealers and retail accounts responded to the big selloff on Monday by buying short- to intermediate-term note issues. Bond prices, however, remained under pressure.
Even though all major financial markets were open again after the long Easter holiday break and the Chicago Board of Trade was fully operational for the first time since last week's flood, market participants said the pace of business was only marginally more active than the lethargically slow pace of the last few sessions. 
 "Things were a little busier, but not much more," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. "It still seems pretty slow."
Most of the session's focus was on auctions today and tomorrow of new two-year and five-year Treasury notes. Despite the usual anxiety that accompanies big debt sales, traders said that at current yield levels demand for the securities will probably be quite good.
 
Note Sales This Week
 The two-year notes to be sold today were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 5.44 percent. And the five-year notes to be auctioned on Thursday were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 6.86 percent.
American banks, who have been big buyers of two-year and five-year securities for a year, were urged by John Robson, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, to shift their focus and make loans that would stimulate the sluggish economy.
Speaking in Washington, Mr. Robson also said the Federal Reserve Board should be more concerned with restimulating the economy than with fighting inflation.
Mr. Robson's comments were seen as highly political and had little or no effect on prices in the credit markets. But some credit market analysts said that money managers did not take as benign a view on inflation as the Treasury.
"Our clients are beginning to get concerned about inflation," said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "We are getting questions from them because of the seemingly inexplicable half-point rise in consumer prices last month, and Alan Greenspan's suggestion that 2 percent growth is not enough."
 
Fear Termed Overblown
 Mr. Held added that in his view the fears were overblown.
"The main determinant of inflation is labor costs, and wages are under control," he said. "I'm not saying the market can't continue to trade off on these fears, but ultimately they will be proven wrong."
Inflation fears may have had something to do with the dip in bond prices yesterday, but so too did a report on Market News Service.
During the afternoon, Market News reported that Argentina would probably buy zero-coupon Treasury bonds directly from the Treasury to collateralize Argentine Government securities to be swapped for commercial bank loans in a coming debt restructuring.
For weeks, there has been speculation that the Argentines might buy the securities in the secondary market. Such purchases, which the speculation put as high as $30 billion, would sharply depress bond yields.
 
In the Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 9923/32 , down 2/32 , to yield 8.02 percent, compared with 8.01 percent late Monday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 9921/32 late yesterday, up an eighth of a point, to yield 7.55 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 1002/32 , up 3/32 , to yield 6.85 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.68 percent, up 1 basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged on the day, at a late offered rate of 3.84 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Province of New Brunswick offered $200 million worth of 30-year noncallable debentures through an underwriting group led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 8 3/4 percent securities were priced at $99.703 to yield 8.778 percent, 77 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In its initial venture into the open market, Harvard University offered $115 million worth of 15-year securities through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 8 1/8 percent notes were priced at $99.473 to yield 8.186 percent, 65 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's and by Standard & Poor's.
New-issue activity was exceptionally heavy in the tax-exempt municipal securities market, as roughly $3 billion worth of new securities were priced.
Despite the heavy issuance, traders in the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
For Swissair, Modernism On the L.I.E.

BYLINE: By David W. Dunlap

 BODY:
RENOWNED for his crisp, elegantly detailed modernist compositions -- and best known today for his work on the Getty Center arts complex in Los Angeles -- Richard Meier is not an architect one would instantly associate with a building along the Long Island Expressway.
But Swissair wanted a structure for its North American headquarters that would convey a sense of meticulousness and corporate responsibility. So the Zurich-based airline chose Richard Meier & Partners as architects of the building near Exit 49 in Melville, L.I., the design of which is to be formally introduced today. 
 Mr. Meier "has a style which is different than what you find on Long Island," said Peter Luethi, general manager of the airline's North American organization. "But at Swissair, we consider ourselves a little bit different than the rest of the airlines.
"One could look at many buildings that are available in Long Island," Mr. Luethi added, "but we felt that we wanted to set our own tone."
The project, which is scheduled to be finished in November 1993, will cost about $20 million, including land acquisition and construction.
Mr. Meier, who practices in New York and won the 1984 Pritzker Architecture Prize, one of the highest honors in the profession, is the first to acknowledge the seeming incongruity of his presence on the L.I.E. But he is just as quick to note that the architectural environment along the expressway has been changing.
"For a long time, what one saw there were back-of-the-town-type sites," he said in an interview yesterday. "But I think people realized that there's such a high visibility on the expressway that the quality of buildings has improved immensely.
"That's probably why Swissair chose us," Mr. Meier continued, "because they realized that it was a site that many people pass by."
A push for distinctive architecture along the expressway has been led by the Spector Group, which is based in North Hills, L.I., but also has offices in Manhattan and Brussels. Among its projects have been the Long Island Financial Center in Huntington, a four-building complex; two office buildings in Jericho, and the Computer Associates headquarters in Islandia.
"Even through the mid-1980's, most clients on the island were not trying to create an image building," said Michael Mannetta, a partner in the Spector firm and its director of design.
In recent years, however, he said that developers had come to recognize that "they were paying prime dollars to have locations on the expressway and the extra investment had to be justified.
"When you have hundreds of thousands of people passing by on a daily basis," Mr. Mannetta said, "you're paying for one of the biggest billboards possible."
Mr. Meier, too, used the word "billboard" to describe one of the functions of the Swissair project, although its dignity and restraint give new meaning to that word.
"The clean cut and detailed layout of the building from the outside certainly expresses the seriousness of us as a company and us as an airline," Mr. Luethi said.
The Swissair building, which sits on a five-acre site, is to have 58,000 square feet on three levels. The all-white structure will be clad either in painted aluminum or porcelain-enameled steel.
The principal facade of the new headquarters, facing south, will be 200 feet long. It will present a kind of screen to the expressway, a practical measure to cut down on the noise that reaches the offices inside. Narrow horizontal window slits will pierce this wall and through these openings, beams will project at regular intervals.
Several other distinctive features are meant to break up the mass of the facade, including a cylindrical, two-story conference center that will jut out from the east end and a fire-stair and elevator tower at the west end.
The south side of the building will have a loggia opening on to a sunken court, which will bring light and a view of greenery into what otherwise would be cellar space. Daylight will also pour into the building from skylights.
There will be curtain glass walls on the north and east sides, with a service core on the west side. In time, the structure can be expanded northward by an additional 20,000 square feet.
"It's a very straightforward, economical building," the architect said, "but there will be a quality of light, openness and spaciousness that will give people a happy working environment."
And Mr. Luethi said that made business sense. "If employment conditions are pleasant, it has a direct effect on the customer," he said.
Some 220 employees will work at Melville, about 20 percent of whom are now at the airline offices in the Swiss Center, 608 Fifth Avenue, at 49th Street, in Manhattan. The other 80 percent will come from Swissair's administration building at John F. Kennedy International Airport.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A model of Swissair's new North American headquarters building in Melville, N.Y., designed by Richard Meier & Partners. The view is looking north, from the Long Island Expressway. (Jock Pottle/Esto)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Climb Sharply, Rising From Six-Year Lows

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices bounded higher yesterday in a performance that left some analysts convinced the metal had enough upward momentum to leave behind recent six-year lows.
Silver futures also rallied on New York's Commodity Exchange. 
 Gold for April delivery rose $4.20, to $341.10 an ounce, in New York, its strongest one-day gain since Feb. 27. April silver rose 2.8 cents, to $3.991 an ounce.
Analysts said the rally began overnight when Middle Eastern speculators who sold gold several weeks ago began buying it back on overseas markets.
"They finally gave up waiting for the worst predictions" to come true that gold would drop to $320, said George Milling-Stanley, precious metals analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York.
The New York market opened about $1 higher and steadily rose as the rally drew in commodity funds and additional Middle Eastern buying, he said.
Analysts traced gold's turnaround to the market's inability in recent days to break below $336 an ounce. On Monday, for example, the spot April contract dropped to $336.30 but bounced back to finish the day at $336.90.
"I think we may have hit bottom," said Peter Cardillo, research director with Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York.
Gold was trading near $370 an ounce last July. It weakened in response to low inflation, which removes an incentive to invest in gold, and heavy sales of gold by Russia and other former Soviet republics to gain hard currency.
Energy futures rose modestly on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of a weekly report from the American Petroleum Institute that showed unexpected increases last week in United States stocks of crude oil, gasoline and petroleum distillates.
Crude oil for May delivery rose 1 cent, to $20.25 a barrel; May heating oil rose 0.69 cent, to 57.36 cents a gallon; May unleaded gasoline climbed 0.70 cent, to 62.48 cents a gallon; May natural gas rose 5.1 cents, to $1.468 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Most livestock and meat futures retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as worries about wintry conditions in the Midwest and eastern Plains faded. Traders had feared the storm would delay hog marketings.
Live cattle for April delivery fell 0.15 cent, to 77.57 cents a pound; April feeder cattle slipped 0.10 cent, to 79.17 cents a pound; April live hogs fell 0.22 cent, to 43.55 cents a pound; May frozen pork bellies dropped 0.70 cent, to 34.32 cents a pound.
Soybean futures rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade, which was fully operational for the first time since last week's flooding in Chicago. Soybeans gained on speculative buying in the absence of selling pressure from Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer.
The grain markets ended mixed with near-term deliveries higher and deferred deliveries mostly lower.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Mixed Results Posted by 3 Newspaper Companies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Two newspaper publishing companies reported better earnings results yesterday than they had in the comparable 1991 quarter, when news-gathering costs were raised by coverage of the Persian Gulf war and advertising was reduced by the recession.
Knight-Ridder Inc. posted a 58 percent increase in first-quarter earnings and the Washington Post Company reported it had returned to profitability. However, the Tribune Company, which had a loss in its newsprint business, reported a 27 percent profit decline. 
 Lower newsprint prices this year have helped newspapers that buy most of the paper they use but hurt companies with newsprint manufacturing investments.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Knight-Ridder
 The Miami-based Knight-Ridder media company earned $25 million, or 46 cents a share, in the January-March period, up from $15.8 million, or 32 cents a share, in the 1991 quarter.
Revenue in the quarter edged up 1.8 percent, to $555.4 million, from $545.4 million in 1991.
The newspaper division, which produces 29 dailies, earned $54.4 million, up 20 percent from $45.4 million in the first quarter last year.
"We began to see faint but distinct signs of improvement in newspaper advertising revenue during the quarter," said Robert Singleton, the company's chief financial officer .
Classified advertising revenue was down 3.6 percent in January but up 4.8 percent in March -- the company's best performance since September 1990. Revenues from help-wanted ads were down 11 percent in January but up 9.4 percent in March.
But Mr. Singleton attributed the improvement primarily to a two-tenths of 1 percent decrease in total operating costs, including a 15.3 percent drop in the cost of newsprint, ink and supplements.
 
Tribune Co.
 The publisher of the Chicago Tribune earned $15.4 million, or 17 cents a share, for the first three months of this year, down from $21.1 million, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier.
Revenue edged up to $471.4 million from $470.1 million.
The earnings decline was attributed to a $14.7 million loss in its newsprint manufacturing business, which made a profit of $4.3 million a year earlier.
Newspaper publishing profits rose 12 percent in the latest quarter and broadcasting and entertainment profits climbed 55 percent.
Tribune publishes seven daily newspapers, operates six television and four radio stations, owns the Chicago Cubs baseball team, produces and syndicates information and entertainment, and manufactures newsprint.
 
Washington Post
 The Washington-based media company earned $19.7 million, or $1.66 a share, in the first quarter in contrast to a loss of $35.4 million in 1991.
The 1991 results included a one-time charge of $47.9 million, or $4.04 a share, for an accounting change.
Revenue for the quarter rose 3.8 percent to $329.1 million, from $317.1 million in 1991.
"Although still weak, the advertising environment showed some improvement when compared to the first quarter of 1991, which included the effects of the Persian Gulf war," the company said. "This sluggish rebound in advertising, coupled with substantially lower newsprint costs, were the major reasons for improved operating results in the first quarter."
Revenue in the newspaper division rose 2 percent from last year. Advertising volume at The Washington Post was off 2.8 percent, and the newspaper's daily circulation was flat.
Revenue for Newsweek magazine was up 9 percent, while the broadcast division showed a 2 percent gain, and the cable television operation showed an 8 percent rise.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Profits Rise At 3 Drug Companies

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Three leading pharmaceutical companies, the Warner-Lambert Company, the Schering-Plough Corporation and Marion Merrell Dow Inc., reported strong first-quarter earnings yesterday, sending their stocks up.
Earnings at Warner-Lambert rose nearly fivefold, in large part because of an accounting change, and its stock rose 75 cents, to $62.375. Schering-Plough's net income rose 11.6 percent and the stock gained $1.75 to close at $54.625, and Marion Merrell's net income climbed 22.3 percent, sending its stock up 25 cents, to $34.75. 
 At Warner Lambert and Schering-Plough, pharmaceutical sales exceeded analysts' estimates, but consumer product sales were below expectations. Marion Merrell's sales rose by 21 percent in the quarter, led by the company's anti-allergy drug, Seldane.
Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
Warner-Lambert
 Profits increased to $163.6 million, or $1.22 a share, from $33.5 million, or 25 cents a share, a year earlier, when earnings reflected an after-tax charge of $106 million, or 79 cents a share, because of the adoption of new standards for post-retirement benefits other than pensions. Sales rose 7.4 percent, to $1.31 billion from $1.22 billion.
Warner-Lambert, based in Morris Plains, N.J., said its worldwide consumer sales rose 1 percent but American operations were hurt by a sluggish economy and "sales force realignments." Its brands inlcude Lubriderm skin care products, Tetra pet care products, Listerine antiseptic mouthwash, Rolaids antacid, and Schick razors and blades.
In the pharmaceuticals sector, sales rose 19 percent, helped by a 28 percent surge in sales of Lopid, an anticholesterol drug, to $142 million. The company's other pharmaceuticals include the anticonvulsant Dilantin, the cardiovascular drugs Accupril and Dilzem, and the analgesic Ponstel.
Warner-Lambert's sales growth is likely to slow in January 1993 when Lopid's patent expires, said Robert Hodgson, an analyst at Cowen & Company.
 
Schering-Plough
 Schering-Plough, based in Madison, N.J., reported first-quarter net income rose to $193.3 million, or 96 cents a share, from $173.2 million, or 79 cents, a year earlier on an 8 percent rise in sales, to $1.02 billion from $949.3 million.
In the United States, pharmaceutical sales increased 12 percent, benefiting from higher sales of the asthma products Proventil and Vanceril, and Eulexin, a therapy for advanced prostate cancer. Sales of the company's health-care products declined 7 percent, in part because of lower sales of Gyne-Lotrimin, a vaginal antifungal sold over the counter.
International sales rose 14 percent, led by Intron A, an anti-cancer and anti-viral product, and Claritin, a non-sedating antihistamine. Sales of Losec, an anti-ulcer drug, were also high.
"Future earnings growth at Schering-Plough depends on approval of Claritin and Leucomax, a colony stimulating factor for white blood cells, in the U.S.," said James Keeney, an analyst at Mabon Securities. Food and Drug Administration approval of these two products is expected in 1993, he added.
 
Marion Merrell Dow
 Marion Merrell Dow, based in Kansas City, Mo., said first-quarter net income increased to $170 million, or 60 cents a share, from $139 million, or 49 cents, while sales rose to $779 million from $644 million.
Seldane anti-allergy products continued to lead as sales reached $206 million in the first quarter, up 30 percent from a year earlier. The Cardizem group of cardiovascular products registered an 18 percent rise in first-quarter sales to $233 million.
Sales of Carafate anti-ulcer medication declined 14 percent, to $47 million in the first quarter, reflecting wholesale buying patterns.
"Our strategy is to firmly establish these line extensions of key Marion Merrell Dow franchises, while developing other new drugs for the mid-1990's and beyond," said Fred Lyons Jr., the company's president and chief executive.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Higher In Uneventful Trading Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher yesterday in uneventful trading on world currency markets.
Trading was quiet as dealers in Europe returned from a four-day Easter holiday. Analysts said the dollar had held to a relatively narrow range throughout the session, with little news to move the market. 
 But sentiment toward the dollar remained cautiously bullish. "There is a general perception that things are getting better in the economy," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Firmer evidence of the recovery is expected tomorrow, when the Government will report on durable goods orders for March. "People are looking forward to a good report," Mr. Donney said. "Orders are expected to show a 1 percent jump."
Traders are reluctant to test the dollar's highs until they have more concrete proof that a recovery is under way.
In Tokyo the dollar rose 0.25 yen, to a closing 134.47 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 134.20 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 134.25 yen, unchanged from Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7495, from $1.7477 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.7500 to buy one pound, more expensive than Monday's $1.7495.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.6695 German marks, up from 1.6655; 1.5460 Swiss francs, up from 1.5385; 5.6395 French francs, up from 5.6270; 1,253.50 Italian lire, up from 1,251.00, and 1.1823 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1797.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6685 German marks, up from 1.6665; 1.5460 Swiss francs, up from 1.5420; 5.6380 French francs, up from 5.6320; 1.8780 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8760; 1,253.00 Italian lire, up from 1,252.50, and 1.1809 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1822.

HEADLINE: Unisys Posts A Profit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BLUE BELL, Pa., April 21

 BODY:
The Unisys Corporation, the long-troubled computer company, reported a better-than-expected profit today for the first quarter, in contrast to a large loss a year ago.
It was the second consecutive strong quarter for the company, the nation's third-largest computer maker. Last year Unisys closed plants and cut 10,000 employees to end its losses. 
 "The results are a clear indication that our turnaround actions and product and marketing programs are on track," James A. Unruh, the Unisys chairman and chief executive, said.
Unisys said it earned $48.3 million, or 11 cents a share, in the first three months this year, in contrast to a loss of $98.2 million a year earlier.
Revenue was down slightly, to $2.01 billion from $2.06 billion. But last year's figure included $62 million from the company's Timeplex subsidiary, which Unisys sold effective June 30, 1991.
The company said it reduced debt by about $100 million and generated $121 million in cash flow from operations.
Operating expenses were at their lowest quarterly level in six years and down 17 percent from the 1991 quarter. Interest expense dropped 24 percent because of less borrowing and lower rates.
The company reported growth in orders, especially in American orders for computers. The strongest gains were for its large, recently introduced mainframes, Unix-based computers and software.
"While we remain very cautious about the timing and scope of a global economic recovery, we may be experiencing some early signs of an improving U.S. market," Mr. Unruh said, adding that the company expects to report a profit for all of 1992.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
As Phoenix Rises In East Europe

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WILL Poland end up as a prosperous colony of Germany, the bread basket for the colossus of central Europe? Might Hungary vault past its neighbors and forge strong trade ties with America? Could Russia become a major, cash-on-the-barrel importer of Japanese goods?
Such questions sound fanciful with the former Soviet satellites struggling to avoid potholes on the road to capitalism, and Boris Yeltsin wondering where his next bowl of borscht will come from. But viewed through the prism of development economics, the recovery of the European Communist economies seems likely: If Thailand and Taiwan can make the leap to modernity, so, too, can the better-endowed lands of the failed empire. 
 Hence the significance of the ambitious computer simulations by Carl Hamilton of the Institute for International Economic Studies in Stockholm and L. Alan Winters, an economist at the University of Birmingham in Britain. Their analysis, published this month in the journal Economic Policy, suggests that Eastern European trade will be far larger and more diverse than is widely assumed. And while this is good news -- trade, after all, has proved its mettle as an engine of growth -- it points to political friction ahead.
Mr. Hamilton and Mr. Winters rely on what is oddly called the "gravity model" of open trade, a simple but generally accurate predictor of country-by-country import and export flows based on income, population and location. They go back to 1985, a time when the East bloc's output was at its peak, and compare actual trade with simulated flows for open, market-driven economies.
As expected, the simulation suggests that the bulk of the $100 billion worth of trade within the bloc was dictated by the Kremlin's wish to make the socialist world self-sufficient. What should surprise, though, is the degree to which the total volume of trade was suppressed by the cold war.
The model predicts total imports from the West equaling $261 billion, almost five times the actual flow. In terms of absolute volume, the European Community and Germany in particular would have reaped the biggest gains in exports -- a five-fold increase to $133 billion. But the biggest single winner would have been America, with a thirteenfold increase in sales to $50 billion.
Note that these trade numbers do not apply to some distant happy future in which Eastern Europeans all drive Saabs and escape winter on the beaches of North Africa. They are about a not very successful Eastern Europe that merely regains the level of physical productivity it managed the year Mikhail S. Gorbachev was elected chairman of the Soviet Communist Party -- a goal attainable, with any luck, by the end of the decade.
The catch, of course, is that trade is a two-way street. While developing countries might be expected to run substantial trade deficits in the early years in order to finance industrialization, only Ronald Reagan's America has ever dared to imagine a world in which foreign suppliers would accept a nation's i.o.u.'s indefinitely. Thus to reap the likely benefits of wide-open exports to Eastern Europe, other economies must be ready open their markets to Eastern European goods.
That may not be easy. Consider agriculture, probably the sector in the old East bloc economies most amenable to rapid productivity growth. If the world opened its borders to Eastern European farmers, the simulations project export increases ranging from threefold for dairy products to sixfold for pork and poultry. Consumers everywhere would benefit. But their gain would hardly bring joy to European Community's farmers, who would have to swallow sharp cuts in sales and prices.
Industrial exports may prove less problematic. With wage levels that would send South Korean or Taiwan workers out on strike, one might expect Eastern Europe to specialize in the low-tech, labor-intensive goods -- notably clothing -- that are protected by quotas in Western Europe and the United States. But the researchers think not.
Previous studies have shown a correlation between the technology content of exports and science education levels. And by this measure, Eastern Europe runs with the bigger boys on the block. In fact, Hungary ranks ahead of Sweden and Singapore, and even Japan. Thus Eastern Europe's advantage in trade may well be in the broad range of middle- and high-tech products now sold in relatively open world markets and which the European Community has already agreed to accept from Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary.
Much, of course, could still -- and probably will -- go wrong. But Eastern Europe does hold a formidable trump card: If Western Europe won't take its goods, it may end up with its people.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Plant Is Closing In Norwich, Conn.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NORWICH, Conn., April 21

 BODY:
Less than three years after being wooed to the area by state officials, National Print and Mail will be shutting down, leaving 165 workers without jobs. The company's president, Anthony Aveni, said the plant here would be closed by June 20. 
 Mr. Aveni said the operations of the Norwich plant would be transferred to a plant in New Jersey. The company came to Norwich in July 1989 after being recruited by the state's Department of Economic Development. The company employed 195 people when it opened, 95 percent of whom were unemployed at the time.
