HEADLINE: A Hard-Boiled Look at Midwest Foods

BYLINE: By MARIALISA CALTA

DATELINE: IOWA CITY

 BODY:
"NEVER eat at any place called Mom's," counseled Nelson Algren, a writer who spent his life chronicling the travails of the lost souls of America in books like "The Man With the Golden Arm."
It's the kind of snappy aphorism (with its corollaries "Never play cards with any man named Doc" and "Never sleep with anyone whose troubles are worse than your own") that suited Algren, who won the first National Book Award, in 1950, and who died in 1981 at the age of 72. He was known for his gambling, drinking and womanizing as well as for his novels, which also included "Walk on the Wild Side," and numerous short stories. They were peopled by prostitutes, drug addicts, con artists and the like. It's a piece of advice that, to date, is probably Algren's most public association with food. 
 But on May 5, the University of Iowa Press is publishing, for the first time, "America Eats," a short work that Algren wrote in the 1930's for the Works Progress Administration. It is a portrait of Midwestern foodways, and includes recipes for international foods from apple pie to zabaglione. In "America Eats," he brought to food the same attention to detail he used in describing Frankie Machine shooting heroin in "The Man With the Golden Arm."
Of an Old Settlers Picnic in Nebraska, he wrote: "Heaping bowls of ripe sliced tomatoes are placed every few inches across the table; other bowls are laden with fresh sliced cucumbers. Sweet pickles, dill pickles, bread-and-butter pickles, pickled peaches, pears and crab apples by the gallon wait in crocks. Then there are coleslaws, mixed-vegetable salads, fruit salads and gaily colored pickled eggs. Plates piled high offer hot rolls, hot corn bread, plain white bread, Swedish rye, Russian rye packed with caraway seeds, Swedish twist with a garnish of poppy seeds, whole wheat bread, and the popular sweet raisin bread."
Instead of the cheap whisky and cheaper beer that permeate most of Algren's fiction, "America Eats" is infused with the warm, kitcheny scents of blinis, goulash, Portuguese walnut pudding, breakfast scones and polenta.
The university acquired the 86-page manuscript -- neatly typed on yellow copy paper with the words "Am. Eats Algren" scrawled in pencil at the top of the first page -- as part of an astonishing collection of more than 11,000 cookbooks and culinary writings that date back to 1499 and cover an enormous range of subjects from cannibalism and Antarctic cookery. The collection was donated two years ago by Louis I. Szathmary, a cookbook author and chef in Chicago. The Algren book, available from the press for $22.95, is the second in the Iowa Szathmary Culinary Arts Series. The next, due out next fall, is a Persian cookbook from 1839.
Mr. Szathmary (pronounced SAHT-mah-ree), a Hungarian, first met Algren, whom he calls "that most American of writers, " in the early 1960's in Chicago, where the writer lived for much of his adult life. He frequented Mr. Szathmary's restaurant, the Bakery on the Near North Side of Chicago. Mr. Algren often looked "like a bum," Mr. Szathmary recalled in a recent telephone conversation. But, "he had excellent manners," and, Mr. Szathmary said, "he knew good food and enjoyed it."
"Do not forget that he was the lover of Simone de Beauvoir, the dining companion of Jean-Paul Sartre," Mr. Szathmary said. "On some level, he was an elegant bon vivant."
But Algren hardly had a typical bon vivant's approach to life. On meeting de Beauvoir for the first time, in 1947, Algren took her on a tour of Chicago which included psychiatric wards and an electric chair; their affair took place in both Chicago and Paris.
In his preface to "America Eats," Mr. Szathmary writes of his first visit to the writer's apartment: "Even blindfolded, I would have been able to recognize Nelson's home by its smell. It was an odor typical of a bachelor's apartment inhabited by one who stored huge amounts of magazines and papers for a long time, who chain-smoked with other chain-smokers over the poker table set up in the kitchen, who kept his clothing clean but never threw anything out. The undertone of beer, bourbon and wine mixed in with the cold, stale smoke. The kitchen faucet dripped, perhaps for years, into some foil pie dishes piled in the sink. Yes, the odor of dripping water was also a part of the general aroma, as were the shaving cream and soap smells from the bathroom."
It was in this apartment, in 1975, that Mr. Szathmary first laid eyes on the "America Eats" manuscript, which was on view as Algren auctioned off many of his possessions to finance a move from Chicago to New Jersey. "That apartment depressed me," Mr. Szathmary said. "One of the greatest American writers living such a life! It was clear he needed money, but he would never take it if I offered to give him some." Instead, Mr. Szathmary bid on the manuscript, offering a generous sum which he declines to disclose. "Nelson thought I was sheer mad," he said.
According to Mr. Szathmary, the author told him, "the recipes in it are lousy." Algren explained: "It was a Government writer's project. I did it because I needed the money."
Algren had been desperate to join the W.P.A., according to his biographer, Bettina Drew. In "Nelson Algren: A Life on the Wild Side" (University of Texas Press, 1991) Ms. Drew wrote of the writer's depression over the financial and critical failure of his first novel, "Somebody in Boots," published in 1935, a suicide attempt soon after, and an enforced stay in a mental hospital. Penniless and unemployed, she said, Algren pulled every literary string he could to get hired on at the Illinois Writers' Project, a branch of the W.P.A.
As a project member, along with other future literary stars like Saul Bellow and Richard Wright, Algren helped write travel guides and collect folk tales. David E. Schoonover, curator of rare books at the University of Iowa, said Algren's writing on Midwestern eating habits was part of a national project to record regional foodways. These manuscripts, he said, were filed away as the Federal Government turned its energies to mobilizing for World War II.
Although food was not Algren's usual subject, "America Eats" comes alive with the same vivid writing and feeling for the underclass that illuminate his fiction. His chapter on the settling of the plains, for example, describes white settlers who "desolated the Indian lands" by slaughtering the buffalo for sport and littering the plains with carcasses. "By the time of the War Between the States the white had modified the Indian's natural diet in more ways than one," Algren writes. "In fact, he had just about put a stop to it altogether."
The book is peopled with "braves in buckskin," "blue-turbaned voyageurs," "drawling steamboat men," "Negro fish vendors," "Irish section hands." In its pages, hard-working women of every ethnicity -- including Armenian, Chinese, Hungarian, Welsh, Norwegian, Flemish, Italian, Mexican, Danish, Polish, German, African, Austrian and Dutch -- slave over wood- and coal- and gas-fired stoves to produce the foods of their homelands.
The book is also laced with the humor that, in his fiction, Algren employed to lighten the otherwise unrelievedly bleak landscapes of urban poverty and human despair. Michigan is dubbed "the land of mighty breakfasts." He writes of an "old French custom" that "lends an added zest to holiday suppers," the making of bouillon using stolen chickens: "To invite a neighbor to dine on his own fowl is considered a social grace, to be caught prowling in the henhouse is something else."
In describing a Wisconsin dinner of lutefisk, a Norwegian dish of dried codfish, he wrote: "When great quantities of lutefisk, boiled potatoes and lefse [potato pancakes] have been consumed, the lutefisk-supper habitue sits back for ten or fifteen minutes, then starts all over again. At breakfast the next morning he unfolds his newspaper, glances quickly at the war news, and then scans the minor columns for an announcement of the next lutefisk supper."
Algren's text, which the university press has illustrated with period photographs from the State Historical Society of Iowa, needed minimal editing, Dr. Schoonover said. The recipes were another matter. Mr. Szathmary, mindful of Algren's warning that the recipes were "lousy," took it upon himself to test them and found that Algren's description fairly accurate. Whether given to Algren by home cooks who assumed others would be deeply familiar with the dishes, or carelessly recorded by the writer, many of the recipes did not work, Mr. Szathmary said. With a team of culinary students from Johnson and Wales University in Rhode Island, Mr. Szathmary reworked and tested all the recipes, including the corrected versions along with Algren's originals at the back of the book.
The result is an international melange of dishes like Welsh skillet bread, French brunoise (vegetable soup garnish), stews from Flanders and Arabia, and Chinese sweet-and-sour pork.
"These are the foods of many nations, brought from many lands to nourish one land," Algren wrote. "They are all the Old World ways which have gone into the great melting pot of the Middle West, to come out behind the counter of the all-night hamburger stand on U.S. 66 or in the quick-service businesman's lunch on any downtown street in Minneapolis, Akron or Omaha.
"Many foods, many nations. Yet one food, one nation. Many lands, one land."
 
Goulash and Spatzle
(Adapted from "America Eats")
Total time: 2 1/2 hours, plus overnight refrigeration
 
For the goulash:
 
2 teaspoons salt, plus more, to taste
1 tablespoon sweet Hungarian paprika
 1/2 teaspoon fresh ground pepper, plus more, to taste
 1/8 teaspoon garlic salt
2 pounds beef chuck, cut into 1-inch cubes
 1/2 cup lard or chicken fat
2 large onions, peeled and chopped fine
1 1/2 2 tablespoons flour
3 cups beef broth or water
2 tablespoons tomato paste
1 teaspoon caraway seeds
 
For the spatzle:
 
4 large eggs, lightly beaten
1 cup milk
3 cups flour
2 teaspoons salt
6 tablespoons butter, cut into small pieces
1 cup minced parsley.
 1. To make the goulash, combine the salt, 1 teaspoon of the paprika, pepper and garlic salt in a small bowl. Season the meat with the spice mixture. Set aside.
2. In a large casserole, heat the lard or chicken fat over high heat until it begins to smoke. Add the pieces of meat in one layer and, while stirring constantly, quickly fry the meat until evenly browned, about 2 to 3 minutes.
3. Add the onions and cook until wilted, about 3 minutes. Sprinkle the flour over the meat and stir until blended. Add the remaining paprika, reduce the heat to medium low, and stir for an additional 2 minutes.
4. Add the broth or water, tomato paste and caraway seeds. Cover, and simmer over low heat until meat is tender, about 1 to 1 1/2 hours. Set aside to cool, cover and refrigerate overnight.
5. Reheat the goulash over low heat and season with salt and pepper to taste.
6. To make the spatzle, combine the eggs and milk in a large glass or ceramic bowl. Set aside. Combine the flour and 1 teaspoon of the salt in a separate bowl. Slowly add the flour mixture to the eggs and beat until smooth. Set aside at room temperature for 30 minutes.
7. Preheat oven to 200 degrees. Bring a large pot of water to a boil, and add the remaining salt. Reduce the heat to a simmer, drop 1/2 teaspoons of the dough into the water and simmer until cooked through, about 2 to 3 minutes after they rise to the surface. Drain, rinse under cold running water, drain again and transfer the spatzle to an ovenproof baking dish. Add the butter, stir, and keep warm in the oven until ready to serve.
8. Divide the spatzle into individual bowls, spoon the goulash over, and garnish with parsley.
Yield: 6 Servings.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
YOU'VE been driving your beat-up car for years. Looks awful but runs fine. Then your neighbor comes home with a flashy new job, and for the first time you are embarrassed by your old clunker.
That's the way it is with petite sirah. Long a staple of the California wine scene -- never a star but never exactly a bit player, either -- it was an acceptable grape producing an acceptable, occasionally attractive wine. 
 Then one day someone -- it may have been Joseph Phelps -- came out with a wine made from a grape called syrah. Syrah, we were told, was the real thing: a famous grape from the Rhone Valley with a pedigree going back to Persia.
O.K., we all exclaimed in unison, but then what is this petite sirah we've been drinking? Oh, that, replied the experts; that's some mutt of a grape from the Auvergne or some other disadvantaged region. Forget about it. And, of course, we promptly did.
Subsequently, the syrah has become what the French would call tres a la mode in wine circles. Along with mourvedre, cinsault and grenache, it has ridden the wave of recent enthusiasm for Rhone grape varieties.
The idea was this: California wine makers have spent 30 years now grafting, cloning and in other ways perfecting their versions of some famous French grapes, notably cabernet sauvignon, chardonnay, sauvignon blanc and, more recently, pinot noir. But are not these the grapes of France's temperate zones: Bordeaux, Burgundy and the Loire? And are not California's wine regions more on the latitude of North Africa, climatically nearer to the Rhone Valley than to the Loire or the Garonne?
Yes, said the experts, but there are all these microclimates where one can do un-Californian things with grapes.
Fine, said the proponents of the new varieties, but why not take California for what it is rather than seek out exceptions to the rule? So they planted their Rhone varieties and have enjoyed considerable success. As almost anyone who has tasted the wines of Bonny Doon Vineyard, Edmunds St. John, Cline Cellars or McDowell Valley Vineyards will agree.
And so the image of petite sirah plunged. It was never more than a blending grape, anyway, scoffed the trendier wine people as they ran to shell out big bucks for the new Rhone-style offerings.
Perhaps the ultimate humiliation for the poor grape came from McDowell Valley. Experts decided that some 36 acres of old vines that McDowell had always billed as petite sirah were actually syrah with a y. In other words, the real thing. McDowell quickly changed the name.
Petite sirah is actually a grape known in France as the durif. The name has an Arabic intonation to it, but it is misplaced. The grape was named after a nurseryman, Dr. Durif, who propagated it in France in the 1880's. It has all but disappeared in France, but it has long enjoyed a steady popularity in California, if only as a blending grape, good for beefing up the flavor and color of lighter wines.
At the beginning of the Rhone adventure in the early 1980's, there were some 11,000 acres of it planted in the state. For a few years, a small winery in the Santa Cruz mountains actually bottled it under the durif name. How it got to be called petite sirah is a mystery.
At its best petite sirah, like syrah, produces a big, vigorous, tannic wine that makes up for its lack of elegance with rich fruitiness and plenty of unsubtle flavor. Which is why it was long popular as a blending wine. There have always been wine makers intrigued enough by the grape to bottle it as a varietal. One of its loyal fans is Paul Draper of Ridge Vineyards, who has made some superb petite sirahs over the years, while at the same time using it sparingly as a part of some of his blends.
Gemello, Hop Kiln, Guenoc and, of course, McDowell, have all produced petite sirahs over the years. One from Guenoc won high honors at a major wine competition in San Francisco last year. Sotoyome Winery, under its new Christopher Creek label, has just released a 1988 petite sirah that was aged in French oak.
Other producers include Fetzer Vineyards, Louis M. Martini, Field Stone Winery and Vineyard, Bogle Vineyards, Stag's Leap Wine Cellars and Stags' Leap Winery. At least one winery, Preston, in the Dry Creek Valley in Sonoma County, has hedged its bets, producing several vintages of a syrah-sirah blend.
Even so, the petite sirah grape has steadily declined in importance in recent years. Some 91 wineries were growing it in 1981, while a decade later the number had declined to fewer than 60, and much of the wine was destined for blending. From those 11,000 acres of the grape in 1980, the plantings had dropped to about 3,000 acres in 1990.
One of petite sirah's staunchest supporters -- and producers -- is the Foppiano Vineyards in Sonoma County. The Foppianos have been growing and vinifying the variety for 80 years and have no plans to stop.
Lou Foppiano is not optimistic about the grape's future. American wine drinkers have moved away from big, tannic wines to lighter, more elegant varietals, which means that chardonnay and cabernet sauvignon are more profitable grapes for both growers and wine makers. "As bottom-line economics force the industry to focus on only the most profitable varietals," Mr. Foppiano said recently, "petite sirah will surely become more difficult to find."
For the moment, however, there are still some good examples around for anyone willing to look for them. And most petite sirahs are reasonably priced -- if you consider $10 reasonable. The Foppiano 1990, which includes wine from 80- 50- and 20-year-old vines, is available for about $10.
 
TASTINGS
Shafer Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon Hillside Select, 1987; about $35.
 Shafer Vineyards, in the prominent Stags Leap viticultural area in the Napa Valley of California, produces two cabernets. One, from grapes grown on the valley floor, is usually blended with merlot and presents a softer, more approachable aspect when young. The other is the winery's star, the 100 percent cabernet sauvignon Hillside Select. This wine, made only in the most favorable years, is produced from grapes grown on steep, terraced slopes climbing up from the valley at its eastern edge. The soil is shallow, rocky and volcanic, and it puts desirable stress on the vines. The wines are aged two years in oak and about 30 months in bottle before release. Even when young, the Hillside Select shows great concentration and richness. If properly cellared, it should improve for another decade. The price is high but the wine will hold its own with competitors that cost much more.

HEADLINE: Higher Education -- or Lower?

 BODY:
Virtually no public service can escape its share of the cutbacks that tough times impose on New York State. But the reductions imposed on public universities now cut so close to the bone that it's becoming impossible to ask them simply to take the pain. They cannot keep making cuts this deep and fulfill their assigned mission.
Something has to change. Either there has to be more money, or less mission. And it's none too soon for New Yorkers, like responsible citizens of other states, to argue out what it is they expect of higher education, public and private. 
 The Legislature and Board of Regents might take the lead. Gov. Mario Cuomo might create a blue-ribbon commission as the forum for such a debate. But one way or another, the public has to stop pretending that it can maintain quality higher education without paying the price.
New York has long prided itself on providing good higher education through three systems: the 64 campuses of the State University of New York; the 21 senior and community colleges of the City University of New York, and 130 independent colleges and universities that since 1967 have received state support.
But lately, New York's pride has turned into New York's pretense. In the last academic year, close to 4 percent of state taxes went to expenses of public colleges and universities. The U.S. average is 7 percent, nearly twice that.
Under the 1992-93 budget, SUNY will suffer an $83 million cut even assuming a $500 tuition increase awaiting approval. CUNY will suffer a $40 million cut after a similar increase. And the independent colleges will lose $33 million in state aid.
Decreased state support has prompted needed self-examination. Colleges and universities have imposed efficiencies like consolidating departments and increasing teaching loads. But there's a limit. SUNY has cut 5,000 faculty and staff positions since the mid-1970's, out of 26,000. Access is threatened by more selective admissions. Some students can't finish in four years because important courses are overflowing, or aren't offered every year.
Maintaining the quality of research facilities and faculty expertise is critical to the state's economic and social health. Such resources are drawing cards for research grants, top-flight personnel and students.
There are short-term palliatives. The Legislature could ease some of the pain by passing an early retirement incentive program. But the larger question can no longer be avoided: What kind of higher education system does New York want?
Perhaps the state needs to give up on universal access to higher education, raising admissions standards and tuition and reducing scholarships. Elimination of whole campuses needs examination from both the political and the educational perspectives. Perhaps the state should try to maintain present quality and access -- by maintaining present levels of aid.
The hard questions are surely not limited to SUNY and CUNY. The independent colleges enroll 40 percent of the state's undergraduates and confer 58 percent of its undergraduate and 72 percent of its postgraduate degrees. To cut their aid more only risks driving students to the public campuses.
These are not merely painful budget-balancing questions. They go to New York's attitude toward economic development, individual opportunity, upward mobility and its posterity. They need to be openly and thoughtfully confronted now, well before the next bloody budget battle.

HEADLINE: Unfair Trade, and Its Victims

 BODY:
There will be $200 billion a year at stake when President Bush meets today with President Jacques Delors of the European Commission. That's what an international trade agreement is worth to the world economy -- and what will be lost if Mr. Bush and Europe don't stop squabbling about protectionist farm policy.
The Uruguay Round of trade talks, begun five years ago, was designed to forge a grand bargain. The third world would agree to rules governing foreign investment, services, copyrights and patents. In exchange, the developed world would open its borders to imports of food and textiles and stop pummeling third world farmers by dumping subsidized food exports. 
 Poorer countries appear willing to uphold their end. But the E.C. does not. It's hanging onto protectionist policies, thereby inviting collapse of the talks. Three issues block agreement. The E.C. rejects U.S. and third world demands for tight limits on subsidized food exports. It insists on raising tariffs on U.S. exports of cereal substitutes. It further insists on replacing farm price supports, which create the food surpluses that are dumped abroad, with direct income payments to farmers.
A smidgeon of compromise would go a long way. The U.S., for example, could allow the E.C. a few modest tariff increases, as long as the Europeans agreed to phase them out quickly. The U.S. could also permit indefinite income support for E.C. farmers, but only if the payments did not become a backdoor production subsidy.
The U.S. cannot tolerate loose restrictions on E.C. export subsidies. That could force third world countries to back out of the Uruguay Round. There are other disputes between the U.S. and E.C., but settling the farm dispute is the key.
The U.S. and Europe will not be the big losers if talks collapse. The E.C. would likely focus on new internal links; the U.S. would probably engage in bilateral negotiations and unilateral threats. The loser would be the most vulnerable countries, desperate to eke out a living by selling to Westerners. For them, an accord is essential to survival.

HEADLINE: Gains in Deciphering Genes Set Off Effort to Guard Data Against Abuses

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Genetic engineers' success in reading the blueprints of life is touching off wide-ranging efforts to regulate the way information about heredity can be collected, used, maintained and disseminated.
These efforts, including action by state legislatures and in Congress, are prompted by rapid progress in gene research and fears that the technology could set off bitter disputes between those who seek to keep their genetic makeup private and employers, insurance companies or even prospective spouses who want to know all they can about a possible employee, customer or mate. 
 Some experts fear the result could be a conflict between fundamental ideals of fairness, equality and privacy and imperatives of economic efficiency and free enterprise.
 
Identification of Genes
 Researchers have identified about 3,000 of the estimated 100,000 genes that compose human DNA, the blueprints of heredity. Among them are those suspected of causing many of the 4,000 known hereditary illnesses as well as genetic "markers" that may signal susceptibility to conditions previously thought to stem from environmental factors, like cancer. Eventually, scientists hope to identify individuals with a predisposition to common illnesses like arteriosclerosis and arthritis.
Although genetic engineering is still in its infancy, it is already being woven into the social fabric. In the Persian Gulf war, for example, the American armed forces began collecting DNA samples of military personnel as a way to identify mutilated corpses. And a study two years ago by the Office of Technology Assessment, a research arm of Congress, found that 5 percent of Fortune 500 companies use genetic profiling for screening and monitoring employees. Some simply ask questions about the health of employees' family members; others actually use DNA analysis. And 55 more companies said they might start using the tests by 1994.
The fear of attempts to try to improve the human species through hereditary factors has led to increasing efforts to control access and use of genetic profiles. Legislatures in 21 states have considered laws to limit "genetic discrimination," and four states have passed laws to prohibit employers from discriminating on the basis of genetic information.
A bill now before Congress would forbid the release of genetic information without written consent, except in medical emergencies or, in the case of criminal investigations, after showing probable cause for suspicion.
In opening a recent hearing on the bill, Representative Robert E. Wise Jr., a West Virginia Democrat, called the new technology "an especially complex and far-reaching area."
"The range of policy problems goes far beyond traditional privacy concerns," said Mr. Wise, who heads the Subcommittee on Government Information, Justice and Agriculture. "We may also be required to reconsider the doctor-patient relationship, re-examine the basic principles of life and health insurance and decide generally how we are going to treat individuals in light of the new information that will become available."
The Congressional study on genetic testing of employees by companies found that half of the employers' health officers considered the practice to be generally acceptable and that 62 percent said it should be the employer's decision whether and when to perform such genetic tests.
"The F.B.I., the military, the insurance industry is going to find it irresistible," said George J. Annas, director of the Law, Medicine and Ethics Program at the Boston University Schools of Medicine and Public Health. "You can use this thing in all kinds of ways that aren't very nice. Ultimately, it's a tool for a much more centralized, obtrusive government."
 
Fear of Invisible Barriers
 Ethicists say the technology threatens to create an invisible barrier that will prevents large groups from finding work or buying insurance. Ultimately, they say, genetic discrimination risks could become as pervasive as racial discrimination.
So far, the issue is most often raised in the workplace, especially as genetic screening makes it increasingly easy and cheap to identify employees or prospective employees who are susceptible to health problems or workplace hazards.
"If we can pick out the truly risky, they become uninsurable," said Arthur Caplan, director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota. "Not only do they become uninsurable, they become untouchable. We wouldn't want to marry them. We wouldn't want to biologically interact with them. The obvious step then is to prevent, remove, engineer away the genetic problems."
While the current prevalence of such discrimination is debated, experts who follow the issue say it is spreading rapidly and will become even more common as techniques to collect genetic profiles are refined and become less expensive. Paul Billings, chief of genetic medicine at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center in San Francisco, said an informal survey found 50 cases in which people had been denied jobs, insurance claims or other benefits because of their genes in the last two years.
Among the four states that have passed laws to prohibit employers from discriminating on the basis of genetic information, Florida, Louisiana and North Carolina specifically prohibit discrimination against people carrying the gene for sickle-cell anemia, which mainly strikes blacks.
The law in the fourth state, New Jersey, is broader than the others. It prohibits discrimination based on an "atypical hereditary cellular or blood trait." That includes cystic fibrosis, the most common lethal inherited disease among whites, as well as blood disorders like sickle-cell anemia and Tay-Sachs disease. In addition to those states, at least 17 others, including New York, have considered some form of genetic legislation in the last two years. A bill introduced in New York would provide screening and counseling for Tay-Sachs disease, and includes provisions to keep the information confidential.
In the broadest measure, the California Legislature passed a bill last year to give hereditary information civil rights protection -- what amounts to a genetic bill of rights. But the legislation was vetoed by Gov. Pete Wilson, who said it would discourage testing and brand employers as bigots if they sought to control health-care costs.
The House bill, sponsored by John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Government Operations Committee, would regulate the collection, maintenance, use and dissemination of such information by the Federal Government, its contractors and recipients of Federal grants. The bill would forbid the release of genetic information without written consent except in medical emergencies or, after showing of probable cause, in criminal investigations.
But some critics say the bill is too narrow. They also argue that people with genes for inherited diseases and abnormalities should be covered by the 1990 Americans with Disabilities Act, which prohibits discrimination against the handicapped.
Critics say extending the law's protective umbrella to people carrying genetic defects would be extremely expensive for employers.
A Congressional study released this month said the growing use of detailed genetic profiles might have far-reaching effects on Americans' ability to find work, insurance and medical treatment. "We are opening a Pandora's box in which genetic information may be used as a discriminatory weapon against individuals," Mr. Conyers said.
 
Genes and Destiny
 "The danger is that genes are not destiny," said Prof. Mark Rothstein, director of the Health Law and Policy Institute at the University of Houston. "You may have a mild case and be unaffected. You may have a brief and brilliant career that you should be able to enjoy."
While the developing genetic technologies will greatly expand the ability to make rational, informed decisions about personal health care, many ethicists say it will be almost impossible to keep that information private. For example, a recent study at the University of Minnesota found that at least 50 people had access to each patient's medical charts.
But Dick Godown, president of the Industrial Biotechnology Association, an industry group of 117 companies, argues that requiring strict privacy -- even if possible -- is counterproductive. "The answer for society can't be to hide the information," he said. "It has to be to put it to the best use. Your doctor needs it, your employer needs it. Your marriage partner needs it. The real question is where to draw the line. That's tough."

He is chief of genetic medicine at the California Pacific Medical Center, formed last year by the merger of Presbyterian Medical Center in San Francisco, where Dr. Billings was chief of genetic medicine, and Children's Hospital of San Francisco.

HEADLINE: A Higher Rock Bottom For Many New Air Fares

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
American Airlines has spent two weeks trumpeting the broad cuts it has made in air fares. What it has not talked much about is that on hundreds of routes, including ones as well traveled as New York to Chicago, its rock-bottom fare actually rose -- sometimes as much as doubling.
Between Chicago and Birmingham, Ala., for example, the lowest American round-trip fare has gone from $128 to $260. Typical of an airline's lowest fare, the former price was for non-refundable tickets requiring an advance purchase, and the price was available only on certain flights each day. 
 Robert Crandall, the chairman of American, said the aim in simplifying the fare structure was to eliminate fares with such complex restrictions. But for travelers willing to put up with any restriction as long as they get from one place to another, the result is a higher fare.
Though roughly 95 percent of fliers have been receiving some type of discount, under the old system relatively few could take advantage of the lowest fare because they did not have the flexibility to meet all of the restrictions.
American has also followed the unusual policy of keeping these higher fares in effect even as leading airlines have often failed to match them. It thus stands to lose business to carriers offering lower rates, but American apparently hopes the others will fall in line.
 
A Spot Check of Routes
 On Monday, American announced that it was lowering full-coach and discount fares on many routes, in a calculated warning to weaker carriers that had undercut the simplified fare structure American announced less than two weeks ago.
Even with those cuts, however, American's lowest fares in many other markets are now higher than they were before the company's fare-simplification plan went into effect.
In a spot check of 286 routes, mostly out of Chicago, Andrew Shepp, an airline industry consultant, has found that in 41 markets American's lowest fare is now higher than the lowest fare before its broad changes.
Barbara Amster, American's vice president for pricing and yield management, said, however, that the former lowest fares were those "that comedians make jokes about" because of the complexity of the restrictions.
If one takes into account the more widely used regular discount fares, she said, in most markets there was a considerable cut. Thus for the New York-to-Chicago route the more widely used discount fare was $338, she said, while American's new lowest round-trip discount fare is $260. A highly restricted round-trip fare of $178 was good on only certain flights, while the $338 fare was available on all of American's 20 daily flights, with fewer restrictions, Ms. Amster said.
With all the cuts, it is not clear whether the ratio for the spot-check sample used by Mr. Shepp, in which American's fares were higher in 15 percent of the markets, would hold up if other markets were analyzed. American flies between about 12,000 pairs of cities.
 The higher fares in some markets and the elimination of special fares for the military, conventiongoers and people traveling to relatives' funerals, have caused some fliers to question American's credibility.
"They supposedly lowered the fares," said Paul Margulies, a businessman who makes a hobby of keeping track of air fares and who in recent days has called American about discount fares. "In many cases they raised them."
He said that while the savings to business travelers were sizable -- being cut 38 percent and more in about 1,500 markets on Monday -- the trade-off was that for leisure travelers in some markets, some low fares were eliminated.
The latest round of fare shifting has not impressed those who monitor companies' ability to pay their debts. Standard & Poor's, the rating agency, said yesterday that it might lower its rating on $19.5 billion of debt of seven major United States airlines.
Philip Baggaley, the airline analyst for Standard & Poor's, said the fare cuts and the new fare structure had "confirmed that despite the general upturn in the economy the airlines haven't been able to obtain significant pricing improvement."
He added, "We've been concerned for a while about the sluggish economic recovery, slow growth in overseas markets, the gap in spending and internal cash flow at the airlines and reduced access to capital for the airline industry."
The rating agency listed as candidates for possible downgrade the Alaska Air Group; American's parent, the AMR Corporation; Delta Air Lines Inc.; Northwest's parent, NWA Inc.; Southwest Airlines; United's parent, the UAL Corporation, and the USAir Group.

HEADLINE: Welfare Plan Linked to Jobs Is Paying Off, a Study Shows

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Four years after Congress passed major legislation aimed at moving welfare recipients into jobs, the first study of its effect shows it has raised the earnings of people on welfare and reduced the amount they receive in public aid.
But analysts are already at odds over whether to deem the gains large or small, and whether they hold much of an answer to the nation's welfare problems. 
 The results of the study, which focused only on six California counties, is being greeted as big news in some research circles, with many saying the gains were larger than expected for a new program and a harbinger of more substantial successes.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who helped design the 1988 welfare law, which requires recipients to join a work, education or training program, called the report "very positive." He said he was especially heartened by the report because the program it evaluated is "still in what's basically a start-up mode."
But with election-year attacks on the welfare system rising, the report is certain to touch off a debate about whether the law will ever produce results that are large enough to bring significant reductions to welfare rolls, which are now at record highs.
The study found that program participants earned an average of $271 more than those in a control group, and received $281 less in welfare.
"You're going to get small, positive benefits, but they won't be big enough to solve the problem," said Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Northwestern University, reflecting the view of many who have studied welfare-to-work programs. "If you want to cut the caseload 50 percent," he said, "you're going to have to do something much more dramatic."
A report last month by researchers at the State University of New York at Albany sounded a gloomier note by questioning the commitment of officials in many states to the program. That study, unlike the one from California, did not look at the experiences of welfare recipients.
Part of California's relative success may stem from its long history of running welfare-to-work experiments, one not shared in many states that are now struggling to get programs under way.
The California report comes as many officials from President Bush on down are making extravagant promises about putting welfare mothers to work but are offering proposals that typically amount to little more than tinkering.
The study, which will be made public on Thursday, comes from the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a nonprofit research group based in Manhattan.
In examining the experiences of single parents, the study found that a year after being referred to the California program they had earned 17 percent more than a control group of those who had not joined the program. And those in the program had received 5 percent less in welfare payments.
Despite the gains, the overall earnings of the people remained low, with those referred to the program earning an average of $1,902. The researchers said the state of the local economy did not seem to dictate the program's success.
A year after being referred to the program, 73.4 percent of the single parents were still on welfare. That contrasts with a figure of 76.4 percent of the single parents in the control group.
Gail R. Wilensky, a domestic policy aide in the White House with responsibility for welfare, said the California program's accomplishment is "important, it's significant, it's moving us in the right direction, but it hasn't answered the question of how to break down welfare dependency for the whole population."
 
Lessons Remain Unclear
 Among the study's most intriguing findings is that one county, Riverside, had much greater success than the other five -- Alameda, Butte, Los Angeles, San Diego and Tulare. The earnings of single parents in Riverside County rose 65 percent and their welfare payments dropped 12 percent.
But the lessons of its greater success remain unclear. It might stem from Riverside's decision to push its welfare clients into the job market quickly, even if their initial pay was low. Other counties put a heavier stress on educating clients, a strategy that seeks better jobs but runs the risk that clients may get discouraged and quit. By investing in education, other counties may show more impressive results later.
Riverside's success might also stem from the fact that it was quicker than other counties to reduce the grants of welfare recipients who refused to join the program.
The 1988 welfare law, called the Family Support Act, requires every state to run a work, education or training program for people on welfare, and provides up to $1 billion a year in Federal matching funds. By 1995, states will have to enroll one of every five people on welfare in such a program.
California's program, called GAIN, for Greater Avenues for Independence, began several years before the Federal legislation made it compulsory. About half the 33,000 people in the study started the program before 1989, when it was modified slightly to meet the new Federal standards.
 
Strikingly Different Results
 The report on the California study, written by James Riccio and Daniel Friedlander, found strikingly different results among the six counties.
The earnings of single parents on welfare rose by 18 percent in Alameda, 16 percent in San Diego and 15 percent in Butte. But they dropped 1 percent in Los Angeles County, which accounts for about a third of the state's welfare caseload, and 8 percent in Tulare County, compared to a control group.
While overall earnings remained low, some experts emphasized that only about 63 percent of those counted as participants actually joined the program. Others were evaluated but excused because of problems with health, transportation or child care.
The 5 percent overall reduction in welfare payments comes from several sources. Some people in the program got jobs that paid enough to let them leave welfare altogether. Others, in increasing their earnings, qualified for smaller welfare payments.
Unlike the research group's previous reports of such programs, this one did not include a cost-benefit analysis, which looks at whether the savings exceeded the program's cost.
In a telephone interview this week Lawrence Townsend Jr., the director of Riverside County's welfare program, said he thought there were two reasons for the county's success.
The first, he said, was its decision to move people quickly into jobs. The second is enthusiasm. "You have to put a high priority on this," he said. "You have to select your best staff."

HEADLINE: Queens Tennis Center Plan Is Announced and Denounced

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
With tennis world luminaries to provide glamour and support, Mayor David N. Dinkins, New York City's best-known recreational tennis player, began his campaign yesterday to win approval of plans to expand the site of the United States Open in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens.
He watched as city officials publicly signed an agreement with the United States Tennis Association, the Open's organizer, setting out the terms under which the National Tennis Center would expand in the park, and he lauded what he said would be the boon to the city created by the improvements that the association says it needs. 
 But on the periphery of the signing ceremony, held at the center, there was a taste of the opposition that would have to be overcome. Critics of the project from northern and central Queens neighborhoods around the sprawling, three-mile park were in the audience and complained that the plan was an unjustified "giveaway" of scarce and valuable parkland to "special interests."
One opposition leader challenged aides of the tennis association to debate the plan in public. One of the aides termed the opponents a "small vocal minority" that did not reflect the views of most Queens residents, whom he described as "supportive."
The expansion proposal was first announced 14 months ago, and since then the city and the tennis association have been negotiating major financial and other terms. The results of those negotiations were embodied in the agreement formally announced yesterday before a crowd that included local political figures and such celebrities of the sport as John McEnroe and Arthur Ashe.
The plan, however, is still subject to approval by the City Council and the State Legislature.
Under the proposal, the tennis association would lease an additional 31 acres immediately east of its present site and finance the $180 million expansion. It would demolish the three existing stadiums, which have a total of 29,000 seats, and erect three new ones with a total of 38,500 seats.
The proposed lease would have a 25-year term with options for a total of 99 years. City officials estimated that the first year's rent under the new lease would be close to $900,000, compared with the $265,000 the tennis group paid the city last year.
Mayor Dinkins said the terms were "fair to the city as well as to the U.S.T.A." and would "substantially increase the city's economic gains from the U.S. Open" -- the amount he said fans spend in the city at the annual two-week event -- to $130 million each year from $112 million.
One opponent in the audience was Benjamin M. Haber, a lawyer and civic leader in Kew Gardens Hills nearby who is vice chairman of the Committee for the Preservation of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.
"We perceive this to be an unwarranted and illegitimate use of public parkland for private special interests," he told reporters.
Other critics questioned the highly precise figures given by city and tennis officials about the Open's contribution to the local economy.

 BODY:

Companies
The Justice Department has accused Teledyne of systematically falsifying tests on one of the most basic components of sophisticated weapons and spacecraft, according to a lawsuit. The civil suit asserts that Teledyne routinely certified to the Government between 1983 and 1990 that the electrical components had passed rigorous reliability tests when they had not. [Page A1.]
Mobil said its earnings plunged 82 percent, while Amerada Hess said it lost $23.4 million. [D2.] 
 Intel introduced a credit card-sized product that can hold 20 megabytes of memory -- as much as some hard-disk drives. [D4.]
The 1585 Broadway office tower in Manhattan's theater district may be finished soon if a settlement goes through. [D7.]
General Electric said it had begun an internal investigation into charges that some of its officials conspired with DeBeers to fix the price of industrial diamonds. [D10.]
European Travel & Life ceased publication, a victim of declining tourism and advertising. [D21.]
Braniff, in its latest incarnation, often fills nearly all the seats on its handful of flights. [D1.]
Nationsbank said it planned to sell about 3 percent of the company's shares to 55,000 employees. [D4.]
 
International
President Bush and European leaders failed to resolve their differences in global trade talks, making it less likely that a deal can be concluded before the elections. [D1.]
Toyota turned down an offer to buy Rolls-Royce, leading Vickers, Rolls-Royce's owner, to say it had held discussions with a number of international companies. [D1.]
I.B.M. and American Airlines are working on a deal to build a computer reservation system for Aeroflot. [D1.]

The I.M.F. sharply reduced its forecast for the world economy, saying growth would be only a sluggish 1.4 percent this year. [D9.]
 
The Economy
Americans' per-capita income shrank in 1991, adjusted for inflation, for the first time in nine years, the Government said. Personal income totaled $19,082 a person last year, just 2.1 percent more than in 1990, but that was about half the inflation rate. [D1.]
More than 230 cases of suspected banking fraud in New England that could amount to more than $1 billion are being investigated by Federal authorities. [D1.]
A judge decided not to intervene in an S.E.C. case that is becoming a political embarrassment to Richard C. Breeden. [D2.]
The Fed adopted tighter limits on the amount a bank is allowed to lend to its directors, executives and large shareholders. [D8.]
 
Markets
Stock prices were mixed in a lackluster market again propped up by bank stocks. The Dow fell 4.48, to 3,338.77. [D12.] Prices of Treasury securities eased slightly. [D19.]
Corn futures prices dropped sharply amid mostly speculative selling after the May delivery price hit an eight-month low. [D20.]
The dollar fell except against the Canadian dollar in dull trading. Gold prices retreated. [D20.]

HEADLINE: Braniff Aims at the Infrequent Flier

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
It has fewer daily departures throughout its entire system than USAir has from Indianapolis alone, and its fleet of 10 planes is hardly a threat to the 485 that fly the friendly skies for United.
But Braniff airlines, by charging passengers $100 or so less than its larger competitors, often manages to fill nearly all the seats on the 50 routes it does fly. And at a time when the airline industry continues to bleed red ink, Braniff has made an increasingly larger, though still modest, profit in each of the last four months. 
 So goes the latest incarnation of Braniff -- Braniff International Airlines Inc., to be precise -- which in addition to its continental United States routes flies twice a day to San Juan, P.R., and once to St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. Based in Dallas, Braniff also operates its 164-seat 727's from Newark and from Islip, L.I., to several cities in Florida.
In 1989, after the old Braniff's second bankruptcy, Jeffrey R. Chodorow and Arthur G. Cohen, two real estate developers, paid $313,000 for what was essentially the Braniff name and operating manuals. They then acquired Emerald Air, another bankrupt airline, and changed its name to Braniff.
"We welcome anyone who wants to fly with us," said Mr. Chodorow, Braniff's chairman and co-owner, "but our main target is the infrequent flier."
Make that infrequent fliers with plenty of time on their hands. Passengers cannot book Braniff tickets through travel agents. They must either call a toll-free reservations number, or go to a Braniff ticket counter, neither of which is easy.
Until recently the odds of getting through by telephone were somewhere between drawing to an inside straight and winning the Irish Sweepstakes. From mid-January to mid-February, three million phone calls overwhelmed the reservations number. After adding hundreds of additional operators and tripling the number of phone lines, Braniff still can handle only 500,000 calls a month.
And when passengers arrive at one of the 16 airports that Braniff serves, they often must contend with long lines as beleaguered agents write tickets by hand. The agents are still awaiting the arrival of electronic ticket printers from France.
So heavy has been the demand for some flights, and so high the frustration level of people bumped from oversold flights, that riots nearly broke out among angry Braniff passengers earlier this year at MacArthur Airport in Islip.
Braniff, for all its turbulence, has continued to grow from the four original routes it started last summer. In the last two months it has added daily flights from Boston; Atlanta; Columbus, Ohio, and Minneapolis-St. Paul. It hopes to add more Caribbean cities.
"Braniff has done what you have to do -- find a niche and stick to it," said Lee Howard, the president of Airline Economics, a research firm in Washington.
 
Not Like the Old Days
 All this is a far cry from the original Braniff, whose bold, multicolored airplanes helped pioneer routes to South America during the 1960's.
After the carrier ran into financial problems following the deregulation of the airline industry in 1978, Braniff filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors in 1982 and again in 1989. In 1988 a majority interest was bought by Bia-Cor Holdings Inc., a Philadelphia-based company, whose chairman is Mr. Chodorow.
From about 50 planes and 5,000 workers a few years ago, Braniff now has only one-fifth the number of aircraft and employees. Many of them, including pilots, were with Braniff in either or both of its previous incarnations.
 
Frills? Forget It
 Braniff's formula can be summed up in two words: low fares. Braniff's lowest round-trip ticket between New York or Newark and Orlando or Miami is $198, and that will drop to $158 for the period May 1 to June 30, to widen the gap further between Braniff fares and those of competitors. The airline limits the number of seats sold at those fares on each flight. But it does not require advance purchase and payment or require travelers to stay over a Saturday night, restrictions common on other airlines.
Braniff's New York-Orlando fares compare with United's lowest round-trip fare for the route: $262 with a 14-day advance purchase, down from $358 before the recent fare restructuring. For this discount fare, however, United imposes most of the usual restrictions.
Nine months before the major airlines went to their new simplied fare structures, Braniff had only three fares. It also allowed passengers to reschedule flights for a $25 fee, an option the majors also just now adopted.
 
'You Can't Beat the Rate'
 On every route, Braniff's approach remains the same -- rock-bottom prices, no private clubs at airports, no frequent-flier miles, no first-class or business-class seats. Only two of its routes, Newark-Fort Lauderdale and Boston-Newark, have as many as two flights a day. Even those are spaced at least nine hours apart, meaning that if a plane is canceled, passengers booked on that flight are likely to be out of luck.
But not always. Rosalie Swenson, arriving back at Newark International Airport from Fort Lauderdale one recent day, said that on her trip down to Florida, Braniff had canceled the flight she was booked on, but was able to seat her on another Braniff plane.
"They served a good meal and you can't beat the rate," she said of her $198 round trip.
 
Late, Early, Crowded
 While the Braniff flight from Miami that day was three hours late, the airline's flight from Fort Lauderdale rolled up to the gate at Newark almost 20 minutes ahead of schedule. "I've never been on a flight before that was early," said Patrick Joyce, who added that he would fly Braniff again.
Awaiting her Braniff return flight from Newark to Boston, Esther Cohen said her flight to Newark a few days earlier had been "jam packed."
"It was a big plane, and every seat was taken," Mrs. Cohen said. She coupled praise for Braniff's prices with criticism for the paucity of the airline's signs at both airports. Braniff's Newark ticket counter is better marked, but the carrier is squeezed between Delta and Air France, awaiting possible relocation.
In January, the Transportation Department received 25 complaints against Braniff -- 10 for cancellations or delays, a high number for such a small a carrier. But complaints fell to 18 in February, the last month for which figures are available. And Mr. Chodorow said they would drop further after Braniff takes delivery of two additional 727's in May, to serve as spares.
Mr. Chodorow, 42 years old, lives in North Miami Beach, Fla. but spends most of his time at the Dallas headquarters. He has hired a search firm to find a president to run the carrier day to day, but meantime he is overseeing operations himself, as well as choosing Braniff's new routes. He had not expected the airline to grow so fast, he said, but the collapse of Pan American and Midway last year forced his hand.
"The dilemma," he said, "is that if you don't take advantage of the opportunity, somebody else will."
Braniff's success from MacArthur Airport has not gone unnoticed; Destination Sun Airways of Fort Lauderdale hopes to begin flying this summer between its home airport and Islip. But as long as neither niche carrier flies more than one or two flights a day each, analysts say, the major airlines are unlikely to try to match their lower fares.
 
End of Bankruptcy Is Seen
 Mr. Chodorow said that Braniff's Chapter 11 filing last August resulted from unresolved issues relating to the Emerald purchase and to the sudden cancellation of its landing rights at Los Angeles International Airport.
Since then, Braniff's preliminary reorganization plan has been accepted in principle by the creditors' committee, Mr. Chodorow said, and the carrier will emerge from Chapter 11 with no debts, he said.
Meantime, Mr. Chodorow said the carrier had profits of $28,000 in December, $138,000 in January, $197,000 in February and probably even more in March, for which figures are still being compiled. Braniff's costs are down to about 6 cents a mile, extraordinarily low compared with 8.2 cents for T.W.A. and about 9 cents for the other major carriers.
And, as if putting competitors on notice, Mr. Chodorow added, "We expect to do even better than that when our spare planes arrive."

HEADLINE: U.S. Reacts Coolly to Peruvian Leader's Program

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 22

 BODY:
The United States today kept up the pressure it has maintained on President Alberto K. Fujimori since he assumed near dictatorial powers by holding back any clear endorsement of his proclaimed timetable for restoring constitutional rule.
Margaret Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said in Washington that the series of referendums and votes that Mr. Fujimori outlined in a televised address to the nation on Tuesday night would restore democracy more quickly than his earlier proposals, but she added, "In our opinion, it would still leave Peru without constitutional processes for nearly a year." 
 She said the United States would consult with the Organization of American States about the proposals.
The timetable, issued as the President sought to rebuff charges of illegitimate rule, called for a national poll on July 5 that would ask voters whether they approved of his suppression of Parliament and curbs on the judiciary. Under his proposal, this would be followed on Aug. 31 by the publication of proposed ammendments to the Constitution and on Nov. 8 by a referendum on these.
The President foresaw parliamentary elections for the end of February, with the new legislature to be sworn in on April 5, exactly a year after he moved to quash the old one.
 
Japan Won't Halt Aid
 The hesitant stand by the United States comes as it is emerging as the country mounting the greatest pressure on Mr. Fujimori. The Japanese Foreign Ministry, in contrast, announced today that Mr. Fujimori's plan represented an "important step toward normalization."
Perhaps more important for Mr. Fujimori was a report that the Japanese have at this point decided not to halt or suspend the $126 million in development aid it pledged to give Peru when Mr. Fujimori visited Tokyo in March.
For its part, the United States has halted all its economic and military aid, with economists estimating that as much as $1.3 billion in economic assitance from Washington has been put on hold in the last 17 days. In addition, Washington has enlisted the cooperation of Germany and Spain as well as the multinational lending groups in sending a message here that there will be no new aid, no restructuring of Peru's debts, no "reinsertion" in the world economic community until democracy is restored.
"The key pressure point is the bilateral aid from the United States to Peru," said an American official here. "If we withhold that, it has a domino effect on other aid packages."
Economists within the Government have reportedly told President Fujimori that his tough and initially successful program to maintain discipline over Government spending, fight inflation, and privatize dozens of state-owned companies is unworkable without international aid.
American officials here say they are prepared to freeze aid until Peru demonstrates that its democratic changes have the support not only of the populace, but of many of the country's political groups.
While making Peru feel the pinch on the economic front, the United States is having less success in trying to broker a settlement that would bridge the gulf between the democratically elected President and the legislators he dismissed. American officials who have been holding discussions with members of the Fujimori Government and the ousted Congress said that with the swearing in of Maximo San Roman as a rival, but seemingly powerless, President, by the deposed legislators, polarization has increased. .
Political analysts also warn that while there is a willingness on the part of important members of Mr. Fujimori's Government to negotiate, the President himself is not known for backroom deals.
Of growing concern to economists here is that an increasingly isolated President Fujimori will have to look for substitutes for the lost economic aid. He has indicated that he may want to tap the $1.4 billion in reserves held by Peru's Central Bank, a step many fear will deflate the value of the Peruvian currency and rekindle inflation.
 
Economy Minister Quits
 The tough stand on the part of lending institutions and industrialized countries, forged by the United States,appears to have already brought about the resignation of Peru's Economy Minister, Carlos Bolona, and several of his top aides. They resigned after the visit of Mr. Bolona to Washington last week during which Adminstration officials told him there would be no new funds available to Peru.
"We've been able to shut down pretty much everything," an American said.
In a two-hour meeting with President Fujimori on Sunday night, Mr. Bolona reportedly outlined the bleak outlook.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: TV Critic's Notebook;
In a 'Lone Ranger' Role, Perot Builds an Audience

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Since Ross Perot notified Larry King in February that if his admirers could get him on the ballot in all 50 states he would run for President, the electorate has been able to watch the candidate presumptive on many channels. Those appearances have constituted his entire campaign so far.
What is it about him that seems to appeal to an audience of millions? What is it that accounts, as Mr. Perot puts it, for "all these everyday folks that make the world go round writing me in longhand?" 
 To begin with the image on the tube, Mr. Perot rides up as the richest and toughest outsider that side of the Pecos. In a year crowded with ambitious men professing to be the authentic lone stranger, outsidership has been somewhat devalued. But where Edmund G. Brown Jr. will take no more than $100 per contributor, the newcomer drops the ante to $5 and says he does not even cash those checks.
In this anything-you-can-do-I-can-do-cheaper competition, a billionaire can outpopulist anybody. And unlike career pols like George Bush or Bill Clinton, a fellow who has made it in the real world can present himself as someone who does not need to be President, psychologically illogical though that may be.
As Mr. King gently noted on his CNN program, Mr. Perot is no showboat. He is not built to Texas proportions, and his reedy voice cannot reverberate across the canyons; he looks more like Porter Hall than Gary Cooper. Morley Safer said he resembled a shoe salesman. The product he is selling remains fuzzy, but the can-do, will-do sales pitch on television is as sturdily American as the Norman Rockwell original on his office wall that he interpreted for "60 Minutes."
Viewers have also had plenty of opportunity to see action scenes from the movie about the rescue of two of his employees in Iran. Unfortunately, Burt Lancaster played not Mr. Perot but the colonel he hired to lead the raid; nevertheless, the boss can still oppose the Persian Gulf war without worrying about being written off as a weak-stomached wimp. You do not make billions without some notches on your guns.
Although his present targets -- "these guys with their alligator shoes and their briefcases running up and down the halls getting their special deal cut" -- have been much riddled this year, viewers seem impressed with Mr. Perot's marksmanship. "When Ross Perot says he'll do something, he'll do it!" a believer told the "Today" show.
What precisely would he do outside of cutting the military budget and cleansing the temples of Government of fraud, waste and alligator shoes is much less sharply defined than his figures of speech: "When you see a snake, you kill it; you don't form a committee." On "Good Morning America," Joan Lunden inquired what he had in mind for health and education. He answered that he would call on the people to start acting like owners of their country. End of interview. Is he speaking truth to power or commercials to the powerless?
Either way, you cannot saddle him with the pretension, common to candidates in the throes, that he has an instant solution to every problem, or to any problem. Mr. Perot's visit to the ABC News program "This Week" was a stand-off: He expressed annoyance with the questions; George Will indicated exasperation with the non-answers.
Last week Mr. Perot disclosed to Mr. King that he considered the Middle East, the environment and gun control serious matters and would get together the brightest and the best to deal with them.
At least one interviewer seems to have given up. On Tuesday's visit to "CBS This Morning," Mr. Perot was not asked a single question about his policies.
Still, on at least one dangerous issue, he has been as up front as any honest lawman. He told Katie Couric on "Today" that he would cut Social Security and Medicare for "people who don't need it." That category could use some refining, but it is a daring promise of the sort that helped Paul E. Tsongas lose Florida.
Like Mr. Tsongas and other departed Democrats, Mr. Perot says at every appearance that he wants Government to support business intelligently, the way America's international competitors do. But he puts the case more pungently than the rest: "I don't mean subsidize business. I don't mean burp them and diaper them. But I mean let's stop breaking their legs first thing every morning."
The muscular imagery gives this non-campaigner that special something. It is catching. One supporter on a news program called him "tough as pig iron." Mr. Perot lays on emblems of his manliness in good-old-boy lingo: "If we have a losing football team, we know what to do -- get a new coach, get a new quarterback." He compares the economy to a fighter on the ropes and dismisses quick fixes as "Novocain in the knee shots." (Sometimes the shootist misfires, as when he described his supporters as locusts moving across a wheat field. On the other hand, likening the national debt to the crazy aunt that nobody in the family talks about gets across his point.)
What sort of show is this? The stranger lopes into a town that needs help, but even with his endless supply of silver bullets he knows better than to try to clean up the place single handed. And although he has learned to direct his lines smack at the camera, he cannot fill the screen like Big John and send the baddies scurrying with a squint. Yes, "60 Minutes" caught or placed him in the saddle, but he still does not come across like a man on horseback.
So he makes do with tough talk on talk shows and with being just plain folks. This made-in-America billionaire trashes General Motors but, as noted on "60 Minutes," he drives a 1984 Oldsmobile. There he is, the man who can afford pheasant, digging into a slab of beef at his favorite barbecue joint.
He promises all interviewers that his first act as President would be to create an electronic town hall where every week or so "the owners of the country, the people," would have all sides of an issue served up to them and be able to tell Congress which slice they prefer. Barbecue politics.
In this season of mistrust of Washington, nurtured but not created by television, Ross Perot is riding the distaste for politics of any sort, not excepting representative government. Polls suggest that the welcoming response is less an expression of faith in them personally than a measure of the suspicion and disgust that insiders have earned.
This is television, and as the performance stales, the performer could easily fade into the sunset of last season's miniseries. In one of his less felicitous images, Mr. Perot asked his supporters to promise that "if we got lucky and climbed the cliff, you wouldn't climb out of the ring the day after election." Well, everyday folks that make the world go round may decide that climbing along with Ross Perot way up there amid those high winds of strong-man populism sounds a little unsettling.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ross Perot, right, appearing last week as a guest on the "Larry King Live" television show on CNN. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Mobil's Profit Falls 82%; Amerada Posts Deficit

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 22

 BODY:
The Mobil Corporation said today that earnings plunged 82 percent in the first quarter, while the Amerada Hess Corporation said it lost $23.4 million.
Recession, lower prices for crude oil and natural gas crimped profits for most global oil companies in the quarter, and analysts expect that the industry will report profit declines of 50 percent or more from operations in the period. The Amoco Corporation, for instance, said Tuesday that its operating income declined 52 percent. 
 Bryan Jacoboski, oil analyst at Paine Webber in New York, said global business conditions for the industry were improving modestly, except in Japan, where Mobil is a major refiner and marketer. "Demand is starting to recover in the U.S., and refining and marketing profit margins have started to improve," he said.
Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company after the Exxon Corporation, is one of a few oil giants not likely to show rising profits in the current quarter, Mr. Jacoboski said.
But with prices for crude oil and natural gas higher than in the first quarter, most companies will post modest gains in operating income this quarter, he added. "The first quarter will prove to be the low point for the full year," he said.
The following is a breakdown of the first-quarter results for Mobil and Amerada Hess:
 
Mobil
 Net income was $127 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $710 million, or $1.73 a share, in the 1991 quarter when the company reaped huge profits from surging prices for refined products in the Middle East and Europe during the Persian Gulf war.
Revenues fell 8 percent, to $15.2 billion from $16.6 billion.
Excluding one-time charges, Mobil's operating income fell 70 percent, to $213 million, or slightly better than analysts' estimates. Mobil's shares fell 50 cents today, to $61.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mobil, based in Fairfax, Va., said its results included a $75 million charge related to layoffs and other cutbacks in United States operations, plus a $30 million charge for a dry hole in Peru. One-time costs for cutbacks begun in Canadian operations were put at $11 million.
Mr. Murray said Mobil had scaled back its spending and would delay investments "until business conditions improve," a position adopted by most oil giants in recent weeks.
"Although the second quarter has opened with what appear to be early indications of an upturn in the U.S. economy and a recent firming of crude oil prices, it is still too early for substantial optimism," he said.
Operating earnings in oil-and-gas exploration and production fell to $232 million, from $371 million, mainly because of lower prices for oil and natural gas. In worldwide refining and marketing, profits fell to $52 million, from $390 million, because of weak demand in Asia, Europe and the United States.
The United States refining and marketing operations, hampered also by unusually warm winter weather, did not earn a profit. The chemicals unit earned $10 million, down from $92 million a year earlier.
 
Amerada Hess
 The first-quarter loss compared with a profit of $75.7 million, or 93 cents a share, in the first quarter last year. The 1992 figure included a gain of $13.1 million from a tax refund.
Revenues for the New York-based company fell 29 percent, to $1.45 billion from $2.03 billion.
A large East Coast refiner and marketer of gasoline, Amerada Hess lost $39.7 million in the quarter in its refining and marketing unit, compared with a loss of $43.6 million in the period a year ago.
Income from its oil-and-gas exploration and production unit was $29 million, down from $134 million a year earlier. Earnings for the 1991 quarter included a one-time gain of $46.2 million from a legal settlement.
Amerada Hess's stock fell $1.50 a share today, to $40, on the Big Board.
