HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Environment;
Clinton Links Ecology Plans With Jobs

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 22

 BODY:
Acknowledging his shortcomings on environmental matters as Governor of Arkansas, Bill Clinton said today that states like his have suffered at the hands of Republican administrations that promoted "short-term tradeoffs between jobs and the environment."
In a speech timed to coincide with the annual observance of Earth Day, the Democratic Presidential candidate told an audience at Drexel University here that President Bush had been "reactive, rudderless and expedient" in addressing environmental concerns. 
 But Mr. Clinton's own record on environmental matters was quickly and sharply criticized by top aides to Mr. Bush and by the Arkansan's only remaining major rival in the Democratic race, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.
 
Higher Fuel Efficiency
 Mr. Clinton said that as President he would raise automobile fuel efficiency standards to 45 miles a gallon, from the current standard of 27.5 miles a gallon. He also said he would buy vehicles powered by natural gas for the Federal fleet and redirect spending away from nuclear power and toward renewable resources.
"I've spent the last decade, and then some, as Governor of a poor state, fighting to keep jobs and make up for lost time," Mr. Clinton said. "I know how much our people are hurting after the longest recession and slowest economic growth in the last 50 years.
"In the 80's, frankly, I also faced the old short-term tradeoffs between jobs and the environment, tradeoffs that were made tougher by Federal cutbacks in aid to clean up the environment and the lack of clear national policies in areas which allowed states to be played off against one another in jobs versus the environment conflicts," he said. "And in that context, I've made the choice, from time to time, for jobs because my state was a poor one without either enough jobs or enough Federal help to clean up the environment."
Mr. Clinton accused the Bush Administration of promoting the notion that economic growth and environmental protection cannot coexist. He said the White House Competitiveness Council, which is headed by Vice President Dan Quayle, "lets major polluters in through the back door at the White House to kill environmental regulations they don't like."
It is a charge that Mr. Clinton is familiar with. He has been criticized by some environmentalists in Arkansas for appointing industry representatives from major agricultural polluters like the state's chicken industry to sit on watchdog boards and to comply with state regulations only voluntarily.
David Gardiner, the legislative director of the Sierra Club, an environmental group, praised Mr. Clinton's proposals today in a statement distributed by Clinton campaign officials before the Governor delivered his speech.
In an interview later, Mr. Gardiner said the Sierra Club was aware of the problems some Arkansas environmentalists have had with Mr. Clinton.
"I don't think we're completely happy with Governor Clinton's record in Arkansas, but we have more substantial concerns with President Bush's record," he said.
The White House responded swiftly and angrily to Mr. Clinton's remarks. Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press secretary, said: "He does know pollution. He's got it, he's caused it, he's nurtured it and he's done nothing to clean it up."
Mr. Fitzwater cited a national study that showed Arkansas rated last in environmental protection and enforcement. The study, the 1991-1992 Green Index, was put out by the Institute for Southern Studies, a nonprofit research group based in Durham, N.C.
Michael Deland, chairman of the President's Council on Environmental Quality, said Mr. Clinton's "slippery attempt on Earth Day today to gloss over that deplorable record gives new meaning to the word 'oil slick.' "
The White House attack marked the first time that the Bush camp has taken Mr. Clinton on directly, and the ferocity and swiftness of the response was a clear hint that the Bush campaign intends to use environmental issues against the Governor if he is the Democratic nominee.
Mr. Brown, who came to Washington to deliver his Earth Day speech, was unstintingly critical of Mr. Clinton's environmental record. "For the Democratic Party to even think about putting Clinton at the top of the ticket is to invite an environmental backlash of no small dimension," Mr. Brown told a crowd on the Washington Mall.
 
Brown Points to His Record
 The former California Governor said Mr. Clinton has "one of the worst environmental records in the country." Mr. Brown cited his own commitment to energy conservation and environmental protection and asserted it was time for "Congress and the Democratic Party" to step up to the challenge.
Some Bush campaign strategists have begun speculating that Mr. Clinton's environmental record can be held against him by showcasing sites like the polluted White River region in northwestern Arkansas, where waste from millions of animal farms has tainted miles of streams.
Mr. Clinton, who served as Governor from 1978 to 1980 and again from 1982 until now, did not appoint a study group to address the problem until 1990.
The Governor challenged Mr. Bush to join him at the White River so he could show him what the problems were there. "If you really want to clean up the problem, I'll make a deal with you," Mr. Clinton said he would tell the President. "We'll outline the Federal and the state responsibility and we'll get results in cleaning up one of the most wonderful rivers in this country. Our people in Arkansas are tired of the politics of blame."
Recalling Mr. Bush's effort to turn the environmental debate against Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee in 1988, Mr. Clinton asserted: "I will not let this become the Boston Harbor. So, Mr. President, if you want to place the blame, you're going to have to shoulder some of it, too."
 
National Standards Urged
 Mr. Clinton said that national standards must be put into effect to deal with pollution like the agricultural runoff that has created so much of his state's environmental problems.
The Governor said Mr. Bush was "single-handedly blocking" global efforts to address environmental concerns by hesitating over whether to attend the international conference on the environment, to be held in Rio de Janeiro in June.
Mr. Clinton called for "a new covenant for environmental progress" that would include debt-for-nature swaps, in which poorer nations would be allowed to satisfy debt by setting aside land for preservation. He also urged American participation in United Nations programs aimed at curbing global population growth.
Mr. Clinton also said that he would develop "revenue-neutral" incentives to encourage conservation and tax automobiles that are less fuel-efficient. And he said he would encourage further development of solar energy alternatives and pass a national bottle bill that would place a refundable fee on recyclable bottles, cans and other containers.
He did not say how much the measures he has proposed would cost taxpayers or the Federal Government.

HEADLINE: New England Now Focus of Bank Inquiry

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Federal authorities are investigating more than 230 cases of suspected banking fraud in New England that could amount to more than $1 billion, shifting the chief focus of their banking inquiries from the Southwest.
Officers of financial institutions are suspected in some cases, while the institutions were the victims of outsiders in other cases, the authorities said. 
 Thomas A. Hughes, the special agent in charge of the Boston office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said in an interview today that the number of cases involving allegations of large-scale fraud has increased sharply in the last two years at financial institutions in New England.
 
'We Are Talking About Fraud'
 The dimensions of the New England investigations were first reported by The Boston Globe today, and Mr. Hughes told the newspaper: "We're not talking about business ethics here. We are talking about fraud."
Nearly all the cases reportedly involve real estate, including false loan applications, hidden second mortgages and straw borrowers who purportedly received kickbacks for the use of their names in getting loans for others.
John C. Eckenrode, a supervisory F.B.I. agent, told The Globe, "The numbers are astounding -- the number of cases, the amount of lost money and the exposure -- and it's all tied to real estate speculation."
In the interview today, Mr. Hughes said, "We saw the beginnings of the problem in the early 1990's," prompting the Justice Department to augment its investigative task force in New England. "Clearly, at that time, the caseload of significant fraud was mushrooming," he said.
The Boston office is responsible for investigations in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Maine, and is looking into fraud allegations involving institutions in all of those states.
Other law-enforcement officials emphasized that though the New England cases of financial fraud were serious and extensive, they were unlikely to ever reach the scale uncovered in the Southwest.
"The numbers don't approach anything like what you had in Dallas," said Laurence Urgenson of the Justice Department's criminal division. "You had single institutions in which losses are larger than what is expected in New England."
For example, in the case of Vernon Savings Association of Texas alone, losses totaled to $1.3 billion, Federal regulators said.
But Mr. Hughes said in today's interview that the Boston office currently ranked second only to Los Angeles in the volume of financial fraud cases currently under investigation with losses greater than $1 million. Many of the big cases resulting from the Southwest investigations have already been prosecuted.
In explaining why the widespread fraud that was apparent in the Southwest and West by the late 1980's is only now emerging in New England, Mr. Hughes cited the stress of the recent economic decline, along with a recent drop in real estate prices, as possible factors in bringing the fraud into the open.
The New England cases are unlike those in the Southwest, which often involved freewheeling savings and loan operators and high-risk investments. "The ratio of banks to savings and loans is different," Mr. Urgenson said. "The prototypical high-flying buccaneers are not anywhere near as prevalent in New England."
Mr. Hughes said there were 153 cases currently under investigation by the Boston office involving losses of more than $100,000, compared with 68 such cases in January 1990. In addition, there are 79 cases currently under investigation involving losses of $1 million, compared with 58 such cases in January 1991.
Mr. Urgenson added that the extent of the problem took longer to emerge in New England because fewer institutions were as financially depleted as those in the Southwest, and regulatory agencies generally exerted greater scrutiny over their activities.
Mr. Hughes said the heavy volume of cases led Federal authorities to establish a profile of transactions to isolate potentially fraudulent transactions. He said loans to watch included those for large condominium projects, all financing obtained from 1983 to 1989, loans at or near default, loans involving borrowers who appeared not to meet eligibility requirements and loans in which there was a small or no down payment.
Criminal fraud is suspected to have played a factor in the collapse of a increasing number of New England financial institutions, Mr. Hughes said. The number of failures rose from three in 1990 to 20 at present.
The Globe reported that a number of the cases under investigation were similar to one involving U.S. Funding of America, a now-closed mortgage brokerage and lending company in Massachusetts. A Federal grand jury last week indicted 15 people on charges of defrauding nearly 40 lending institutions about $20 million from from 1985 to to 1989.

HEADLINE: Tuition at SUNY to Rise $500; Increase Is the Third in 2 Years

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 22

 BODY:
Trustees of the State University of New York today approved the system's third tuition increase in the last two years, raising the annual charge for attending a four-year campus to $2,650 -- nearly twice what students had to pay in September 1990.
The $500 increase, which will take effect in the fall, continues the erratic tuition changes for the 400,000 students in the SUNY system. Flush fiscal years and student pressure had kept the tuition frozen at $1,350 for seven years, from 1983 to 1990, but the gravity of New York's budget troubles have more recently caused tuition to skyrocket. Tuition went to $1,650 in January of 1991 and to $2,150 last fall. 
 Many other state university systems, meanwhile, have imposed annual increases pegged to inflation that ruled out the years of zero increases that SUNY students enjoyed, but also prevented the huge tuition increases they have been hit with in the last two years.
The tuition is separate from room, board and other fees, which add thousands of dollars to a student's costs.
 
Middle-Income Concerns
 University officials said today that they expected that students in families making between $30,000 and $60,000 a year would be hit hardest by the increase because students below that scale would be eligible for more financial aid while those above it would probably be able to afford it.
"The people who are getting hurt are very definitely those in the lower middle-income bracket," said Patrick Hunt, the associate vice chancellor for university relations.
Overall, SUNY, which previously had one of the lowest tuition rates of any public university system in the country, would now edge just above the national average of $2,263 with the increase, according to figures compiled by the National Association of State Universities and Land Grant Colleges in Washington.
Last week, the City University of New York announced an unprecedented plan to charge higher rates for incoming freshmen this fall with the promise that they can attend their final semester before graduation free. But the SUNY trustees rejected any move to vary tuition among its undergraduate students according to their grade level.
 
Community College Cap
 But top SUNY officials have repeatedly expressed interest in gaining authority from the Legislature to set different tuition rates among the system's 29 state-operated four-year campuses. Chancellor D. Bruce Johnstone of SUNY reiterated today that he would be interested in such a plan, under which students at the full-fledged "university centers" in Albany, Binghamton, Buffalo and Stony Brook would probably pay more than those at four-year colleges.
Nearly every other state in the nation, including California, Texas, Florida and Michigan, already set different rates according to the type of campus. But in New York it cannot be done without the approval of the Legislature, which has so far balked at such a plan partly out of lawmakers' concerns that it could aggravate perceptions that some campuses were of a higher quality than others.
In a separate action, the trustees set a new annual tuition cap of $2,100 for the system's 30 community colleges, most of which offer two-year degrees and whose tuition rates, other than the cap, are set by local boards.
Although Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would most likely be a leading player in any fight here over the variable tuition plans, he has so far steered clear of either endorsing or rejecting them, arguing that it is up to the university officials to make the case for the plans.
Mr. Cuomo proposed steep cuts in both the SUNY and CUNY budgets this year and then gave the university boards the authority to offset them partly with tuition increases. Technically, the decision on the increases is then solely up to the boards, but both the Governor and the Legislature tend to bear the brunt of student ill-will when tuition rises.
The only person on the 13-member SUNY board to vote against the tuition increase was its student member, Randy Campbell, who attends the Stony Brook campus. He said a vote in favor would send a signal that university officials tolerated the budget cuts that state leaders have forced on them in the last few years.
The plan approved today is not final because a public comment period is required under state law, but there was virtually no expectation that the SUNY board would vote to reverse itself in its second vote in July.
Among other increases, the tuition rate for out-of-state students would rise by $800 to $6,550 a year for undergraduates and $7,316 for graduate students.

HEADLINE: Rush-Hour Subway Cuts Reversed by M.T.A. Chief

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday scuttled plans to reduce rush-hour service on nine subway lines because of declining ridership. He urged transit officials instead to work aggressively to entice more people to ride the subway.
The action of the chairman, Peter E. Stangl, followed several weeks of intense lobbying against the service reductions by consumer advocates, Mayor David N. Dinkins and dozens of state legislators. They had argued that to reduce service now would increase crowding on rush-hour trains and ultimately drive more riders away from the subway. 
 The plan would have eliminated 43 trains during the morning and evening rush hours and 13 trains at other times. The Transit Authority, the M.T.A. subsidiary that runs the city subway and buses, estimated that the cuts would save $2.9 million a year.
Mr. Stangl had hinted at his opposition last month at a meeting of the M.T.A. board, saying that the notion of trimming rush-hour service "cuts to the heart of what we do."
 
Plaudits of Consumer Groups
 Consumer advocates praised his decision. "Peter Stangl wasn't railroaded into this," said Gene Russianoff, staff attorney of the Straphangers Campaign, whose group was among at least three riders' organizations that had pushed Mr. Stangl to kill the plan. "He deserves the reputation that he has as a service-oriented transit official."
In his previous job as head of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, another M.T.A. division, Mr. Stangl earned high marks for increasing ridership through innovative marketing and scheduling strategies.
The Transit Authority's plan, which would have taken effect in July, was described by proponents as a limited reduction on sections of some of the lines with the most significant declines in ridership: the A, B, C, D, F, J, N, Q and R lines. Overall, ridership has declined 7.7 percent since 1989.
Alan F. Kiepper, the president of the Transit Authority, had described the cuts as minor, saying they would add only one or two minutes to the wait for trains during rush hour. Mr. Kiepper contended that, under service guidelines approved five years ago by the M.T.A. board, transit officials had to trim service on lines that were underutilized. He said the adjustments would make the subway more efficient and would save the financially strapped system money.
 
Moratorium on Cuts
 But opponents said the service cuts -- the first rush-hour reductions on a broad swath of lines in more than a decade -- would set off a spiral of decline. A loss of riders would lead to fewer trains, which would lead in turn to an additional loss of riders, they said.
Mr. Stangl eventually sided with the opponents. He said he had asked Mr. Kiepper to withdraw the plan because rush-hour service is a vital part of the subway's mission, and because eliminating trains might cause more riders to forsake the system.
Mr. Stangl also called for a three-month moratorium on all cuts in subway and bus service that are in response to declining ridership.
Mr. Stangl said in an interview that he had asked the Transit Authority "to find ways to increase ridership rather than just passively adjusting service downward as the economy drives our ridership down."
"I have a bit of a philosophic problem when we are not aggressively trying to increase ridership," Mr. Stangl said. "I said: 'Let's slow this down. Let's take a deep breath. Let's see if rather than decreasing service maybe we can target a line and increase service a little bit.' "
 
'Glare of Publicity'
 Even though the proposed cuts were within M.T.A. guidelines, Mr. Stangl said he had rejected them because the authority's market research "suggests that frequency of service during the rush hour is an important issue in whether people use our service."
Mr. Stangl made public his decision in a news release, just a day before a scheduled meeting of the M.T.A. board. Although the service reductions did not require approval of the board, the four members appointed by the Mayor had said they would seek a moratorium on the cuts. Several opponents of the Transit Authority's plan said yesterday that they were uncertain whether they would have mustered enough votes on the board to approve the moratorium.
Andrew Albert, the chairman of the Transit Authority Advisory Council, an independent riders' group, said he thought Mr. Stangl decided to act on his own to prevent a divisive struggle at the M.T.A. board. "I think he knew there was going to be a battle, and I think he knew that the glare of publicity would be on this," Mr. Albert said.
"This is a victory for the riders," he added.
Mr. Stangl said there had been many positive developments in the subway system, including a decline in serious crime and greater reliability in service. He said he wanted the Transit Authority to find creative ways to build on those improvements -- through scheduling and marketing -- to entice more people into the subway. "Maybe we will fail," Mr. Stangl said, "but we've got to try."

HEADLINE: Meeting On Trade A Failure

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
President Bush and European Community leaders failed today to resolve their differences in global talks on reducing trade barriers, making it much less likely that an overall deal can be concluded this year.
Even last-minute efforts to find a face-saving compromise on a minor issue were unsuccessful, leaving the leaders here able only to pledge yet again their political commitment to continued negotiations and an eventual compromise. Previous meetings between the President and various foreign heads of state have produced similar declarations, as have the last two annual economic summit meetings of the leaders of the Group of Seven major industrial nations. 
 Countries that conduct nine-tenths of the world's trade have been engaged for five years in talks to broaden the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a 103-nation pact setting rules for trade, mostly in manufactured goods.
 
Freer Trade Is the Goal
 The goal of the talks is to lower worldwide tariffs on manufactures, to limit countries' ability to restrict imports unilaterally and to apply free-trade rules to agriculture and services like investment banking and accounting. But progress in all areas has nearly stopped because the United States has been insisting unsuccessfully that the European Community severely prune its sprawling system of farm subsidies.
The continued stalemate in the GATT talks is forcing American policy makers to pay increased attention to the proposed addition of Mexico to the current free-trade area with Canada.
But those talks are also moving slowly, and trade frictions with Canada are growing. They were worsened today with a Canadian Government decision that American carpets were being dumped at unfairly low prices. [Page D5.]
American proponents of broadening the GATT talks say that a successful deal would allow American farmers and businesses to sell more abroad, creating jobs and wealth in the United States. The Bush Administration contends that its proposals, if accepted by other nations, would leave the average American family of four better off by $17,000 after 10 years.
But critics say that the United States' ability to restrict imports that hurt domestic industries would be hampered and that under a new pact American laws to protect public health and the environment might be weakened.
 
Summit Meeting in July
 Jacques Delors, the president of the European Community's executive commission, and Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said they now hoped a breakthrough on agriculture might come before the next economic summit meeting, scheduled for July in Munich. But they cautioned that no deadline had been set. "All parties would like it to occur, but nothing happens but disappointment if it does not occur," Mrs. Hills said.
Today's session was the latest semiannual summit meeting of European and American leaders, and its theme was the GATT talks, although troubles in Yugoslavia, the former Soviet republics and Angola were also discussed. Officials said today that they had scheduled no further trade meetings. Mrs. Hills said the most likely next step would be a meeting by mid-level officials on technical issues, followed by a meeting between her and senior European officials.
Up to five months of negotiations with other countries are expected to be needed even if the United States and the community can settle their dispute, making it virtually certain that no overall deal will be struck before the November elections.
 
Four Troublesome Issues
 The failure today may signal troubled trade relations between the United States and Western Europe, as four simmering issues come to a boil:
*American steel producers are filing anti-subsidy trade cases with the Commerce Department against their European rivals. An international attempt to limit government subsidies collapsed last month in Geneva.
*A draft trans-Atlantic pact to limit commercial aircraft subsidies is unraveling.
*The United States may receive international permission next week to retaliate against European soybean industry subsidies.
*The Administration has set aside money to step up its farm export subsidies in competition with Europe's.
President Bush told reporters on the South Lawn of the White House that some "new ideas" had been presented today, without providing any details. But Mr. Delors, who was with the President on the lawn, said later at a newsconference that the proposals on both sides were "modest."
Mrs. Hills said later that the two sides had simply reviewed ways to combine existing offers.
In private, senior Administration officials were caustic about the European proposals. "Their proposals were so modest, they were feeble, so they weren't even worth discussing," one top official said.
 
Wide Difference on Subsidies
 The official said that the European Community had asked that its tonnage of subsidized exports be reduced by only 18 percent in the coming years, in contrast to the 24 percent proposed by Arthur Dunkel, the director general of the GATT. The United States, which originally sought a 100 percent reduction, then a 90 percent cut, and then a one-third cut, is not going to settle for 18 percent, the senior American official said.
Thomas Niles, the Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian affairs, blamed the European Community for the failure of the talks. He said the community lacked a unified bargaining position on agriculture and was locked in its own internal debate over how to change its farm subsidy programs to meet budgetary pressures.
Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal, whose country currently holds the presidency of the European Community, denied that. "At this very moment, I think the community on the main issues is not divided," he said.
 
Complaint With U.S. on Services
 The European Community has been pushing for the last two months to link agriculture to services, and then blame the United States for seeking broad exemptions from free-trade rules for its telecommunications, banking, maritime and aviation industries. But European officials were circumspect today about blaming the United States. They even said that services were not discussed in today's meetings.
Administration officials insisted that the November elections were not blocking the United States from considering possible compromises, and European officials have not accused their American counterparts of playing politics with the negotiations.
But while President Bush says he remains personally committed to the negotiations and has made many telephone calls to foreign heads of state in the last six months to push them along, Republican strategists have told Mrs. Hills repeatedly that a poor deal could antagonize large blocs of voters in key states. The steel industry in Pennsylvania, for example, has lost money and jobs because of imports.

HEADLINE: Manhattan Skyscraper Agreement

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The enormous 1585 Broadway office tower in Manhattan's theater district, which has been suspended in a state of near-completion while its sole tenant battled the developer, may be finished soon if a settlement announced yesterday goes through.
Under the settlement, the chief lenders would finance the final round of construction at the 42-story skyscraper between West 47th and West 48th Streets, and the tenant, the law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn would begin paying rent, which it has withheld since October. 
 "Important obstacles have been removed to the leasing of the unoccupied space in the building," Proskauer said in a statement. The firm occupies 365,000 square feet of the 1.3 million-square-foot tower. The settlement would also release Proskauer from a requirement to take two more floors in addition to the 11 floors it now occupies.
Four months ago, the development partnership, 1585 Broadway Associates, which is controlled by David S. Solomon, the New York developer, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
The additional financing is to come from the principal mortgage lenders: the New York branch of the Swiss Bank Corporation; the New York branch of the Bank of Montreal, and the Grand Cayman Islands branch of the Toronto-Dominion Bank.
Because the building is unfinished, Proskauer sued the developers and the lenders earlier this year, saying that neither Mr. Solomon nor the banks were putting enough money into the building.
A list of the work that is needed to complete the building is being prepared, so there is no price tag yet.
If the settlement is approved by the Federal Bankruptcy Court, Proskauer will begin paying rent next month.
In an interview in January, Herbert T. Weinstein, a partner at Proskauer, cited conditions at 1585 Broadway that included an incomplete facade, unfinished paving, unreliable elevators and unwashed windows.
But yesterday, the chairman of Proskauer, Stanley Komaroff, said that with the settlement, the building would become a "showcase facility which can serve our law firm, future tenants and the Times Square area well."
Mr. Solomon said that "we are working through" the reorganization that began with the bankruptcy filing. Two weeks ago, he announced that lenders, led by Citibank, had agreed to a debt reorganization plan for the 750 Seventh Avenue tower at West 49th Street. That building has no office tenants, though Caroline's Comedy Club opened there last month.

HEADLINE: Homeless Man Set on Fire; 3 Bronx Youths Are Held

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
Three Bronx teen-agers, overheard laughing as one shouted, "We're going to kill somebody tonight," set a homeless man on fire in a subway stairwell in lower Manhattan early yesterday, the transit police said.
But the sleeping 60-year-old victim escaped injury because of two subway riders who put out the fire and then led the transit police to the suspects. 
 The assault yesterday, shortly before 1 A.M. in the J line station at Fulton and Nassau Streets, was the seventh incident since Jan. 26 in the subway system in which homeless people have been set on fire. Of eight victims to date, one man has died. There have been two arrests in one of the other cases.
 
Viewed as Copycat Crimes
 The police believe that only two of the attacks might have been committed by the same people, said a transit police spokesman, Albert O'Leary. But transit officials and an advocate for the homeless said they thought that most of the incidents were copycat crimes, rather than a trend of violence against homeless people.
It was unclear what prompted the most recent attack, but Detective Sgt. Stuart Friedman of the transit police major case squad said, "The way it occurred and the way the individuals who have been arrested explained it to us, at this time it looks like something they thought to be fun or an opportunity-type thing. We don't think they are involved in any other incidents."
The three suspects, Gregory Castro, 16, of 1050 Carroll Place, Timothy Porter, 16, of 1695 Hoe Avenue, and Leonard Stewart, 17, of 1020 Grand Concourse, were portrayed yesterday by relatives and friends as troubled but not especially bad young men who nevertheless could be led into wrongdoing by others. But they found it difficult to believe the youths could have been involved in such a vicious act.
At first, the youths pretended to be police officers, rousting the sleeping homeless and ordering them to get moving, Mr. O'Leary said. But then one of the youths, who was not identified, began pouring the contents of a rum bottle on two of the prostrate men and put a match to one, identified as Jose Ramirez.
 
Saved by Intervention
 Mr. O'Leary said that if not for the intervention of William Lee, 31, and Hector Albizu, 43, both of Manhattan, who were entering the station at that moment, Mr. Ramirez could have been seriously injured.
Mr. Lee, a deliveryman for a Chinatown foods company, said he and Mr. Albizu, an unemployed handyman, were heading home after a night at the South Street Seaport, chatting by coincidence about crime in the subways, when they saw the youths harassing four homeless people in the stairwell.
"They were laughing," Mr. Lee said. "They were laughing and saying, 'We're going to kill somebody tonight.' "
When the fire erupted on the blanket of one man, the two men raced to the victim's side. Mr. Albizu tried to smother the fire with his body and hands while Mr. Lee yelled for him to wake up.
"I was thinking about the person inside the blanket," Mr. Albizu said. "It's a life, you know."
Then the youths "ran right upstairs and we just shot right behind them," Mr. Lee said. The two men stopped a passing transit police car and told Officers Kathleen Iburg and Scott Roberts what had happened. The officers arrested the three suspects about a block away. Among the charges they face is attempted murder.
Peter Smith, president of the Partnership for the Homeless, said he was alarmed by the number of assaults in so short a period but called it an apparent "copycat pattern."
Mr. Stewart's grandmother, Ruth Singletary, a minister of the World Evangelical Church on Third Avenue in the Bronx, said his father lived in Mexico and his mother was a secretary. Speaking in her apartment, decorated with religious artifacts, in a building with a doorman, she said Mr. Stewart was "a good kid" who sang at her church in a gospel group and played the drums but had dropped out of school.
After his arrest, Mrs. Singletary talked to him by telephone. "He just said he was with the other guys who did it," she said.
She added, "I don't believe he would set the fire."
At Mr. Castro's apartment, where he lives with his grandmother and an extended family of about 10 people, including a younger sister and two brothers, his uncle, Reimundo Castro, 29, said, "He's a very kind fellow, but he's almost like walking dynamite."

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Lee, left, and Hector Albizu, both of Manhattan, came to the aid of a homeless man who was set on fire yesterday by three Bronx teen-agers in the J line subway station at Fulton and Nassau Streets. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Vanguard in the Battle for Dwindling Open Space;
A Growing Cadre of Private Land Trusts Takes On Developers, and Politicians Too

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Conn.

 BODY:
In the next few days, 81 acres of shady woods and sunny meadows near the center of this tranquil village will be turned over to the local land trust, to be kept as it is -- without houses, apartments or office buildings -- for all time.
Barbara Quigley, who works at her family's bookstore here and looks with horror at the development that surged in nearby Southbury several years ago, praises the efforts of the land trust, a private, nonprofit preservation effort. "We're a small town," she said, "and we want to stay a small town." 
 Across Connecticut, and across the nation, such sentiments have led to the formation of hundreds of land trusts. There are now 900 in the United States, twice as many as a decade ago. Most of the growth has taken place in the last five years and has been concentrated in the densely populated Northeast, said Jean Hocker, president of the Land Trust Alliance, based in Washington, D.C.
Land trusts hold about 2.7 million acres nationwide, Ms. Hocker said. They have a broader mandate than organizations like the Nature Conservancy, a national group that protects the habitats of rare and endangered species, because the land trusts can set aside land for recreational or esthetic purposes as well.
But the 90's may turn out to be a time of reckoning for land trusts. While most have charters stating that their purpose is to preserve land in its natural state, critics contend that they can produce less uplifting results as well. More than once, land trusts have been accused of trying to prevent development of unwanted housing -- low-income and otherwise -- by buying up land.
And in a battered economy, keeping land open instead of developing it to increase the tax base is not always popular with local governments.
"You can't substitute the work of land trusts for the work of communities deciding what they want to be when they grow up," said Robert Pirani, director of environmental projects for the Regional Plan Association in New York, who nevertheless thinks land trusts have been "a real success story in American policy."
"Construction of affordable housing is an issue in communities throughout the region," he said, "and land trusts have to understand their responsibilities, in terms of those societal needs."
Others see potential for abuse. "It's a perfect foil for anti-moderate-income housing," said Robert A. Wieboldt, executive vice president of the New York State Builders Association, a lobbying group based in Albany. "It's sort of a restrictive zoning tool."
 
Competing Priorities
 Even land-trust officials see possibilities for conflict.
"Priorities are in competition," said Martin Rosen, president of the Trust for Public Land, a national organization based in San Francisco. "There's a lot of anxiety these days: Are we taking land off the tax rolls? What's going to happen to jobs, to housing?"
With 114 land trusts, Connecticut has more than any other state except Massachusetts, with 116. Some, like the Bethlehem Land Trust, are relatively new, while others date to the early part of the century. Elsewhere in the region, New Jersey has 20 land trusts and New York has 64, according to the Land Trust Alliance.
The groups, which get most of their funds from private contributions, vary widely in their approaches. Some own the land they manage, after receiving it as a donation or purchasing it. Others oversee conservation easements, which means someone else holds title to the property but has agreed, in writing, to leave it in its natural state. Often the trusts are based in individual towns, although some larger ones, like the Trust for Public Land, operate on a national scale.
The groups have attracted wide popular support. As environmental sensitivity grows, so does an awareness that open space is limited and should be preserved, experts say.
But land trusts can also take actions that alienate public officials and undercut town planning. In the mid-1980's, for example, officials in Mamakating, N.Y., saw conservationists outmaneuver developers planning to build luxury condominiums.
 
'Subterfuge' Is Charged
 Quietly, using a purchase agent known as a nominee, the Open Space Institute, a large land trust based in Ossining, N.Y., bought small parcels totaling about 2,000 acres in the Shawangunk Mountains, some of which had been marked by the owners for development. The trust then sold the land to the state in 1986 for parkland. As a result, the town lost the tax dollars the condominiums would have brought in, said Dennis L. Greenwald, the Town Supervisor at the time of the deal, who retired from government in December.
"It's a conspiracy," said Mr. Greenwald, now a pharmacist in Middletown, N.Y., who is still fuming about the tactics used by the land trust and the state. "They buy it in subterfuge, with front men, private corporations, and shills."
Under the original plan, he said, the town would have had its taxes and the condominium development would still have preserved the majority of the land "as God left it."
Peter R. Borrelli, vice president of the Open Space Institute, said that if the land trust had tried to buy the land openly, it would never have been able to put together the acreage that went to the state. "Because of the hostility in the area, decisions were made to do this quietly and with a nominee," he said, adding that the technique is used by others, including the Federal Government.
"This action frustrated development," he added, "and therefore frustrated some people who wanted to see the ridgetop developed."
Since then, however, the Open Space Institute has decided not to use nominees except under very specific circumstances, Mr. Borrelli said. "It's not a practice that has been outlawed," he said. "But its widespread use is probably not good public policy. It runs against the grain of public disclosure."
 
Paying Taxes
 Another issue facing land trusts is how to maintain the property they control. The 81-acre parcel in Bethlehem was donated by the estate of a resident, Caroline Ferriday, and includes a $25,000 endowment for upkeep. At first the land was managed by a local chapter of the Nature Conservancy, but because the property harbored no species that were at risk, the Conservancy is turning the land over to the Bethlehem Land Trust, said Carolie Evans, director of land protection for the Nature Conservancy in Connecticut.
A large expanse of land can be more cost-efficient to keep up than several small plots, especially in rural areas, experts say. However, in urban neighborhoods, even a small plot is welcome because open space is so rare. A few groups, known as community land trusts, accept buildings, with the intention of providing affordable housing.
Some land trusts pay taxes on their land, although many are exempt, Ms. Hocker said, depending on the local jurisdiction. A few land trusts pay taxes even though they are not required to, she said, "just to build good will."
What is behind the boom in land trusts? "Generally, they are a group of citizens who really care about their community, what it looks like," Ms. Evans said. "They see certain places they'd like to see protected, and realize that the Federal and state system is not going to do it for them, and neither is the town, so they should do it for themselves."
There is also several hundred million dollars in Federal aid available to private land trusts every year, through the Land and Water Conservation Fund, to acquire open space, Mr. Rosen said.
 
Lack of Planning
 But the real force behind the formation of so many land trusts may be that local planning boards have failed to adequately regulate development, Mr. Borrelli said.
"What should be driving the development equation is good planning and good design and meeting the needs of a growing population," he said. "That will lead to consumption of less open space.
"We've been saying, 'Let's save all the open space, and the social benefit will come from that,' " he said. "But it hasn't happened that way."
Officials of land trusts say they are not universally opposed to development, and in fact often invite local developers to serve on their boards. Still, the question of when land is best left open remains a point of argument among the trusts, the developers and local governments.
 
Taxes and Services
 "We're looking at the property-tax impact of open space versus development," said Tom Whyatt, executive director of the three-year-old Westchester Land Trust, which tries to acquire buildings as well as open space. "In rural areas, open space pays more in property tax than it costs in services, like garbage collection and schools. Residential development costs more in town services than it pays in taxes.
"We hope to analyze this town by town," he said. "I believe we're going to show that open space is a friendly use of land, on a property-tax basis."
Mr. Wieboldt of the builders association sees it differently. "There's a legitimate market need, and a legitimate open-space need," he said. Developing one corner of a large parcel and leaving the rest as open space can serve both purposes, he contended.
"You can keep farmers in the area and keep the characteristics of the area," he said. "But you can't let it happen to the total detriment of folks' right to live in certain areas."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Trims Global Growth Forecast

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund sharply reduced its forecast for the world economy today, saying growth would be only a sluggish 1.4 percent this year.
Last October the I.M.F. predicted 2.7 percent growth for 1992. Fund officials said today that they cut that forecast largely because the United States had taken longer than expected to begin its climb from recession. 
 The fund said the world's economy was gathering steam, however, and would grow by a healthy 3.6 percent next year.
Although the growth in most of the major industrial countries has stumbled, the report did not forecast a recession for the industrial world as a whole. It predicted the industrial countries would grow 1.8 percent this year and 3.3 percent next year.
 
Growth of 2.3% Seen for U.S.
 In its World Economic Outlook report, the I.M.F. said the American economy was beginning to turn up. It forecast that the nation's output would grow by 2.3 percent from the fourth quarter of 1991 to this year's fourth quarter. In a news conference today, Michael Mussa, the fund's chief economist, added that he would not be surprised if the nation's economy grew by 3 percent for the year as whole.
The report said it would be unwise for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates further because the recovery appeared to be taking hold. "Barring evidence that growth continues to falter, a further significant reduction of interest rates does not seem warranted in the United States," the report said.
 
Concerns About Inflation
 The I.M.F. said the decline in interest rates already in place should produce the long-awaited strengthening of activity.
Worried that further monetary easing could ultimately overstimulate the economy, the report said that underlying inflation in the United States "still appears to be above long-term objectives." The report said consumer prices would rise 3.1 percent both this year and next year, compared with 4.2 percent inflation last year.
"The significant decline in short-term interest rates in North America and Japan -- made possible by the continued moderation of inflation -- is expected to contribute to a strengthening of growth during 1992," the report said. But it noted that long-term rates remained high, partly because of the huge American budget deficit.
Mr. Mussa said that the construction slump and military spending reductions meant the American economy would not rebound at the 5 percent or 6 percent rate generally seen in the first year after other post-World War II recessions.
 
Outlook for Japan and Europe
 The report said Japan's economy would grow by 3.2 percent from fourth quarter to fourth quarter, the same as the year before, but would rise to 3.9 percent next year.
It said Japan's economy had slowed recently because growth in fixed investment fell to 3.5 percent this year, compared with more than 10 percent a year in the late 1980's. The report said that industrial output declined in the first two months of this year but that a pickup in government spending would help spur Japan's economy.
The I.M.F. predicted continued weak growth in Europe, as Germany's high interest rates drag down the Continent. In pointed language, the report urged Germany to move more aggressively to reduce its budget deficit, which has been caused largely by efforts to help eastern Germany. The nation's central bank has pushed up interest rates to slow the inflationary pressures fueled by the massive spending.
Most other European countries have raised their rates along with Germany to keep their currencies from falling against the German mark. "For most European countries the spillover has restrained demand when activity was already generally quite weak, and when inflation was abating," the report said.
 
Former Soviet Bloc
 The report said Eastern Europe's economy was beginning to bottom out, but added that the former Soviet Union would probably suffer further output declines.
For Eastern Europe, the report projects a 1 percent drop in output this year, but growth of 3.7 percent next year. That follows a plunge in production of 16.6 percent last year. Inflation in the region is forecast at 95 percent this year, from 135 percent last year.
For the former Soviet Union, the report sees a decline in production of 17.5 percent this year, following a plunge of 17 percent in 1991. The report also sees inflation of 1,000 percent in the former Soviet Union this year.

HEADLINE: Canada Puts Duty on Rugs From the U.S.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 22

 BODY:
In addition to beer, automobiles, lumber and magnesium, a new issue is adding to trade tensions between the United States and Canada: carpets.
Finding that American carpet companies are "dumping" their goods in Canada at unfairly low prices, the Ottawa Government has just imposed a duty averaging 12 percent on virtually all American carpets shipped here. The trade tensions are causing new strains in the two countries' relationship. 
 United States carpet sales to Canada last year were $425 million, or 41 percent of the market, up from 8 percent in 1988.
 
U.S. Rationale Resembles Japan's
 But the American industry, borrowing a leaf from what Japanese auto makers have been telling their American counterparts for years, insists that the reason for the increased sales is not unfair trade but greater efficiency.
Also echoing Japanese arguments, the American industry says the Canadian Government decision, which has the effect of raising carpet prices in Canada, will harm consumers.
"The carpet industry is undergoing a global revolution," said Ronald E. VanGelderen, president of the United States Carpet and Rug Institute in Dalton, Ga., seat of 60 percent of the American industry.
"The U.S. industry has undergone that revolution over the past 8 to 10 years through consolidations and the modernization of our equipment so that it is the best in the world," Mr. VanGelderen said. "Canadians are unfortunately lagging behind."
Michael B. Kronick, executive director of the Canadian Carpet Institute, which filed the dumping complaint last year, welcomed the ruling, which he said would give the Canadian companies extra duty protection for at least five years to make themselves more competitive.
He said the decision by the Canadian International Trade Tribunal, an agency roughly equivalent to the International Trade Commission in Washington, was "good news for the Canadian industry" and should help preserve jobs.
Canada's 10 leading carpet manufacturers are mostly based in the provinces of Ontario and Quebec. In Ontario the industry employs about 750 workers, half the work force of four years ago.
 
Official Finding of Dumping
 In December, Revenue Canada, the national fiscal agency, found that the American companies were dumping -- selling their products for less than their price in the United States -- and imposed a temporary duty.
On Tuesday, the International Trade Tribunal, a separate agency, made the duty permanent with a finding that American carpet imports were injuring the domestic industry. A determination that harm is caused to a domestic industry is an internationally mandated requirement before dumping duties can be finally authorized.
The carpet case is different from most of the others that have soured the trading relationship between Washington and Ottawa in recent months. In the automobile, lumber and magnesium industries, the United States is seeking protection against imports from Canada. In beer, each country complains that the other has unfairly restrictive practices.
Most analysts agree that trade issues have become unusually sensitive because of the recession in the two countries over the last 18 months, as well as coming elections on both sides of the border.
Despite the strains, the two countries, which have been joined in a free trade area since Jan. 1, 1989, and are by far each other's biggest trading partner, say they have no intention of breaking off talks for a broader North American free trade zone that would also embrace Mexico.
Those talks have been under way for nine months. Negotiators are working toward a possible agreement later this year.

HEADLINE: Incomes Rise, but Prices Rise Faster

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Adjusted for inflation, Americans' per-capita income shrank in 1991 for the first time in nine years, the Government said today.
Personal income totaled $19,082 a person last year, just 2.1 percent more than in 1990, the Commerce Department said. But that rate was only slightly more than half last year's 4.1 percent inflation rate as measured by the department's index for personal expenditures. 
 It was the first time since 1982 that growth in per-capita income failed to keep pace with rising prices.
And, it was the third consecutive annual decline in the growth rate. Each year of the Bush Administration has seen smaller income growth than the year before. Per-capita incomes grew 5.4 percent in 1990, 6.9 percent in 1989 and 7.1 percent in 1988.
The income figures also showed the continuing reversal of a mid-1980's trend, dubbed the bicoastal economy, of incomes growing faster on the East and West coasts than in the country's heartland.
 
State Trends Reversed
 In general, the Commerce Department said, the states with the fastest-growing incomes in 1991 had endured some of the slowest growth in the 1980's. Conversely, many states experiencing the slowest growth last year had led the 1980's boom.
Only seven states managed income increases equal to or better than the national inflation rate last year: Wyoming, 5.1 percent; Montana and North Dakota, each 4.8 percent; Hawaii, 4.6 percent; Louisiana, 4.2 percent, and New Mexico and Arkansas, 4.1 percent.
Still, income growth was lower in 1991 than a year earlier in all 50 states, reflecting the recession that began in July 1990 and continued through 1991.
The sluggishness was much more widely dispersed than in previous years. In 1990, 40 states reported slower income growth than the previous year. Twenty-five states reported a slowdown in 1989.
Last year, six states registered income gains of 1 percent or less: Rhode Island, two-tenths of 1 percent; Nevada and Maine, seven-tenths of 1 percent; New Hampshire, nine-tenths of 1 percent, and Idaho, 1 percent.
The states with the five highest per-capita incomes and the five lowest remained the same in 1991 as the previous year. The highest per-capita income, in Connecticut, was 94 percent greater than the lowest, in Mississippi.
The five highest were: Connecticut, $25,881; New Jersey, $25,372; Massachusetts, $22,897; New York, $22,456, and Maryland, $22,080. Per-capita income was $24,439 in the District of Columbia.
The five lowest were: Mississippi, $13,343; West Virginia, $14,174; Utah, $14,529; Arkansas, $14,753, and New Mexico, $14,844.
The Commerce Department derived the per-capita income figure by dividing total income -- $4.81 trillion nationally in 1991 -- by the total population 252.2 million.
Personal income is measured before taxes but after Social Security deductions and includes income from all sources -- wages, investment earnings, Government payments like welfare and others.
Nationally, Government employees reported the strongest income gains, 5.2 percent, followed by service sector employees, 4.2 percent.
Construction workers suffered a 6.6 percent income decline. Incomes of workers producing durable goods like automobiles and appliances slipped five-tenths of 1 percent.
People producing nondurable goods like clothing and food products saw their incomes rise 3.1 percent, while mining and oil-drilling workers experienced a 3.4 percent gain.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President of Reynolds To Become Chairman

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that Richard G. Holder would become chairman and chief executive on May 1, replacing William O. Bourke, who is retiring.
Mr. Holder is now president and chief operating officer, and those posts will remain unfilled. The Richmond, Va., company also announced several other executive changes, including the creation of two vice chairman positions. 
 R. Bern Crowl, 60 years old, executive vice president and chief financial officer, will be become a vice chairman, with responsibilities that will include corporate and financial development and strategic planning.
The other vice chairman will be Yale M. Brandt, 61, executive vice president, who will focus on a companywide push for quality, as well as developing new technologies and working with the automotive industry.
Mr. Bourke, 65, has been chairman since 1986, and during his tenure has overseen a corporate restructuring that resulted in a doubling of revenues and a one-third cut in the work force, to about 30,000 employees.
The new vice chairman posts were established by Mr. Holder, 60, who wanted to place more emphasis on the issues those executives will supervise. But little else will change in the company's strategy, he said yesterday in a telephone interview. "You're not going to see dramatic change in direction," he said.
That direction includes trying not only to weather the recession but also to cope with severely depressed aluminum prices. In the last year the London Metal Exchange has been flooded with aluminum ingot by former Soviet republics seeking to amass hard currency.
In response, Reynolds has cut costs and eliminated some production capacity. The company is also seeking to find more uses for its products. It expects the amount of aluminum used in automobiles, for example, to roughly double this decade to more than 300 pounds a vehicle. Mr. Holder said yesterday that the company was seeing the first glimmers of an economic recovery in increased distributor orders for its consumer products, like its Reynolds Wrap aluminum foil and Sure-Seal freezer and sandwich bags.
Mr. Holder has spent his entire career at Reynolds, which he joined as a trainee in 1953 after graduating with a business administration degree from Vanderbilt University. He held many sales and marketing positions before becoming president in 1986. He and his wife, Patricia, have four adult daughters, and live near Richmond.
The company also named two executive vice presidents yesterday. They are Henry S. Savedge Jr., 58, who will succeed Mr. Crowl as executive vice president and chief financial officer. Mr. Savedge is now vice president of finance.
J. Wilt Wagner, 50, will succeed Mr. Brandt as executive vice president, fabricated industrial products. He is vice president and general manager of the Mill Products division.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Decline; Gold Retreats in the U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against all major currencies except the Canadian dollar in dull trading yesterday.
Gold prices retreated after rising overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $1.80 to settle at $339.30 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $338.40 an ounce, off $1.85. 
 Analysts said trading was uneventful. The only significant move came overnight in the British pound, which posted a healthy gain on the belief that political stability has returned following the country's general election earlier this month.
Elsewhere, however, "the dollar was locked in a very tight range," said John McCarthy, chief dealer at ABN-AMRO Bank N.V.
"Concerns about weakness in some of the European currencies keeps the dollar at the high end of the range," he said, "but the overwhelming factor that prevents the dollar from breaking out of that range is interest-rate differentials."
With yields on fixed-income securities higher overseas, investors have greater incentive to put their money abroad, thereby increasing their need for foreign currencies.
Analysts said today's durable goods report for March might lend some fresh direction to trading.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.22 yen, to a closing 134.25 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 134.16 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 134.18 yen, down from 134.25 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7630, from $1.7495 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.7625 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.7500.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6620 German marks, down from 1.6695; 1.5410 Swiss francs, down from 1.5460; 5.6135 French francs, down from 5.6395; 1,248.00 Italian lire, down from 1,253.50, and 1.1850 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1823.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6630 German marks, down from 1.6685; 1.5415 Swiss francs, down from 1.5460.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
New York State Is Offering $2.3 Billion in Spring Debt

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The State of New York went to market yesterday with a three-part, $2.3 billion offering of tax and revenue anticipation notes and tentatively priced the short-term issue through an underwriting group led by Bear, Stearns & Company.
The so-called spring borrowing is the largest debt sale in the municipal bond market each year, but its importance to New York is being phased out. 
 Earlier this month, Edward V. Regan, the state's Comptroller, said the borrowing would be cut substantially and amount to only 8 percent of New York's operating budget, down from as much as 22 percent in 1985.
One portion of yesterday's financing includes $300 million in 3.5 percent notes due Sept. 30, 1992, that are priced to yield 2.90 percent; another part, consisting of $550 million in notes with a similar interest rate and due Dec. 31, 1992, is priced to yield 3 percent.
The final and largest part, consisting of $1.45 billion in 3.65 percent notes due March 31, 1993, is offered at a price to yield 3.2 percent.
The financing carries a short-term investment-grade rating of MIG-2 by Moody's Investors Service and SP-1 by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Moody's said that the reduction in the size of this year's note issue, like last year's reduction, reflected compliance with the requirements of long-term borrowings by New York's Local Government Assistance Corporation, which are intended eventually to eliminate the need for the state's annual spring short-term borrowing.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Mirror Net Up 57%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 22

 BODY:
Cost-cutting and lower newsprint prices helped to push first-quarter profits up 57 percent at the Times Mirror Company, the latest media corporation to post sharply higher earnings.
Times Mirror, whose newspapers include The Los Angeles Times, Newsday and New York Newsday, and The Baltimore Sun, said today that it earned $36.6 million, or 28 cents a share, in the first quarter. That compared with $23.3 million, or 18 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1991. 
 Revenues rose 1.5 percent, to $867.8 million from $854.4 million.
Operating profit for the quarter increased 67 percent, to $80 million from $47.8 million, mainly because of cost reductions, lower newsprint prices and the favorable timing of subscription shipments by the company's legal information publisher.
The company's chairman and chief executive, Robert F. Erburu, attributed the results to successful cost-cutting and revenue and earnings gains at operations that are not dependent on advertising. He was cautious in his outlook, however.
"While we exceeded our expected improvement over a weak first quarter in 1991, continued softness in the Southern California and New York regional economies is affecting advertising revenues," he said.
Times Mirror stock rose 37.5 cents today, to $36.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Paring Down For the 90's (Well, Sort Of)

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
YOU can whisper money, coo money, sing money, talk money, moan money, gurgle money, sigh money, murmur money. Just please, don't scream money.
"This doesn't scream money," said Stephen Mallory, referring to the neo-Gothic rosewood and ivory console plunked against the wall of the library he designed for the 20th annual Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club Decorator Show House. 
 Leather-bound books don't scream money. Neither does an 18th-century English bamboo chair or a Schiaparelli pink burlap and silk sofa with Chanel-style buttons. But a gilt Louis XV bombe chest?
Click your heels three times and repeat: There is no place like the Kips Bay Show House. Here the work of 19 designers will be on splendiferous view through May 12 in a neoclassical town house at 32 East 70th Street.
This year's K is for kumquats, the favorite prop of the moment. I is for interior decor. P is for papyrus in the garden. And S is for feng shui to guide the placement of it all.
Long viewed as an exit poll of current design trends, the 1992 show house might be subtitled "Accessorizers Anonymous," as decorators struggle against their innate impulse to gild that sweet little chair leg and put down that extra gewgaw.
They really are trying to pare down for the 90's. But what do you do when you are presented with a double-height Edwardian oak-paneled room, with finely carved swags and garlands on the wall and a magnficent cast plaster ceiling?
"I tried to work with the room," said Juan Pablo Molyneux, the Chilean-born decorator. Witness the rare George III commodes, the Titian and the Veroneses on the walls and -- apocalypse watchers, take note -- a re-creation of Michelangelo's "Last Judgment," containing a muscular depiction of Mr. Molyneux, on the ceiling.
"I was determined to make the most beautiful room in New York," he said. "It's a very complicated simplicity."
Complicated simplicity, the decorator equivalent of "I Didn't Inhale," abounds in the 19 rooms of the show house, where fake bird calls waft through the hallways and asphyxiation from potpourri and scented candles is a constant threat.
"People are getting used to the idea that the recession is on and the 80's are finished," said Richard L. Ridge, speaking from his black and white Salon du Soir, which is anchored by a pair of life-size 18th-century porcelain maidens. "Opulence is gone."
Opulence is not to be confused with elegance, the decorators say. But there is plenty of opulence at Kips Bay's rooms. The majority exhibit what one decorator calls a "timeless classicism": pretty, sometimes fuddy-duddyish rooms that could have been designed anytime. Anyone under the age of 65 who is seeking new ideas will have to forage to find rooms to relate to at Kips Bay.
Like the Academy Awards, to which Kips Bay is often compared in the decorating world, there are a few technical milestones, among them George Lucas's THX sound system in Gary Crain's Deco-inspired at-home movie theater. The air of riveting unreality is heighted by the felt-tipped markers carried by decorators to hide scuff marks and the fact that there is only one working bathroom out of dozen or so in the house.
Show houses are nothing but ephemeral; it is even possible to gauge a room's intent without stepping into it (if it's a Paganini violin concerto, it must be classical and expensive; if it's Windham Hill or Carly Simon, it's got to be "young"). But those seeking a deeper meaning might do well to contrast the master bedroom suite by Stephen Stempler with the garden room by Clodagh.
The function of both rooms -- luxurious boudoirs for waiting expectantly in -- is essentially the same. Mr. Stempler's is very Marie Antoinette (it contains the show house's most intriguing accessory: what Mr. Stempler called Marie Antoinette's worry beads). The bedroom has a king-size bed crowned with a valence, around which cascade a crown of swags with bells. The dressing room has fabric-covered walls printed with monkeys playing instruments and a kidney-shaped dressing table covered in blue silk and lace.
Mr. Stempler calls all this "rollickingly feminine." In a guide to the room, he describes the 1990's woman like this: "She may compete and work in a bare and minimal high-tech world, but it needn't follow her home." Here, she is free to indulge in what Mr. Stempler calls "guilt-free femininity." (Note to Susan Faludi: Mr. Stempler's room is on the third floor.)
Clodagh, who quotes Yeats and used a feng-shui specialist, is also trying to define the woman of the 90's. Stepping into her copper and burgundy casbahlike space feels a little like landing on the underside of a gigantic mushroom. The room features mildly New Age music composed especially for the show house by Jeff Talman, in contrast to Mr. Stempler's Cole Porter, and love lights on a dimmer, rather than swags.
Inspired by Moorish and Tuscan courtyards, the sculptured space has a lowered ceiling "so you feel as though you are entering a teahouse," Clodagh said. Filled with a scent called Night in Brazil, it is indeed a sensuous, mysterious lair, with a chenille daybed and objects by contemporary designers. It leads into an exotic garden where papyrus grows beneath a copper waterfall.
Whether you call it "guilt-free femininity" or "design as a healing art," these rooms are both about "Love in the Afternoon," to paraphrase Clodagh. Pick your role model: Marie Antoinette or Shirley MacLaine.
Unlike designing for a client, one of the curiosities of a show house is the fact that the decorators are designing for themselves. This can be painful. So painful that they will often invent a make-believe character you would never want to sit next to at dinner.
This device worked well for Greg Jordan, who designed a breezy indoor-outdoor sitting room and terrace for a "groovy grandmother." The room was full of clever techniques: painted murals (instead of pricier paintings) and bouquets of flowers painted on scrimlike draperies of silk crepe with satin binding. In a pretty canvas-tented outdoor sitting room, with gutters in case of rain, the cartoony silhouettes of iron furniture were left bare in a sort of Roy Lichtenstein interior come to life. "Today everything has to have a purpose," Mr. Jordan said. "There aren't a lot of clients we buy marble grapes for."
Like cream, some of the younger ideas floated to the top floors. Libby Cameron, a designer for Parish-Hadley, decorated her bedroom windows with tin valences painted with blue and gold stars. In a design for a pigeonless planet, Ralph Harvard and Hethea Nye of R. Brooke Ltd. designed an outdoor sleeping porch with a trellis frame and bed draperies of unlined silk. In a bedroom suite, Kenneth Hockin played with the tensions between the high and the low: a brass crown bed shown in its glory without a canopy; a silk chaise trimmed with jute fringe; a lamp with a simple linen shade and a gilded urn base.
There was much to ponder throughout the show house, including an abundance of browns and not-so-subtle mirrors. Also worth noting:
* Utter fearlessness: Kevin McNamara's lone use of chintz.
* Drapiest drapery: Sandra Nunnerley's 150 yards of silk taffeta held up by Chinese medallions.
* Most obsessive detail: Faux Post-its and Scotch tape on the wall of the telephone room by Michael Nichols, a decorative painter.
* Second most obsessive detail: a step stool, painted in a sea-foam green taken from murals of Pompeii, in NDM Kitchens' sixth-floor kitchen.
* Best defense: the telescope on R. Brooke Ltd.'s outdoor sleeping porch.
* Cutest couple: the topiary boxwood bust, without a chin, and its 18th-century marble companion in Mr. Molyneux's room.
* Second cutest couple: Mr. Moly neux's pair of Sistine Chapel pillows.
* Best hardware: the old-fashioned fixtures in Lembo-Bohn's bathroom.
* Best deterrent: mirrored french doors encasing two large refrigerators in Beverly Ellsley's kitchen.
* Best credentials: Gilles Dupuis, a restorer at Versailles, who painted the walls in the main entrance hall for Noblesse Oblige, a French design concern.
* Most elastic client list: Stephen Stempler's, which includes Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and Garry Trudeau and Jane Pauley.
* Object to treat delicately: Juan Montoya's enormous and extremely fragile-looking chrome and lead crystal chandelier.
* Possible campaign issue: Sanctions against the excessive use of decorative paint.
* Thought for the day: "Life is layered. Relationships are layered. Your relationship to a space is layered." -- Clodagh.
* Second thought for the day: "Entering a new space is exhausting." -- ditto.
* Most sympathetic design element: wilted tulips, a metaphor for how the average Kips Bay-goer feels at the end of the day.

HEADLINE: WHERE TO FIND IT;
Making Old Stoves Hot Again

BYLINE: Terry Trucco

 BODY:
TO some people, they are just old stoves, a prosaic kitchen accouterment at best. But not to David Erickson, who restores and sells vintage cookers at Erickson's Antique Stoves in Littleton, Mass. "These things are mechanical works of art," he said. "They're gorgeous."
The old stoves in question range from nickel-plated Victorian coal-burners to huge white 1950's models loaded with chrome. Cast-iron gas ranges from the 1920's are particularly distinctive, with an exposed, nickel-plated gas pipe on the front and stately Queen Anne legs. Stoves from the 30's are more streamlined and, with fewer surface details, easier to keep clean. And boxy 40's stoves look more like today's models. 
 In recent years, old-fangled stoves have become increasingly popular in newfangled kitchens, notably in older houses and apartments where a retro kitchen looks comfortable. But the stove rehabilitation business extends to recent restaurant models, which have sleek contemporary lines and are designed for durability. Even 60's stoves in harvest green and yellow are being restored by their owners and, occasionally, selling to collectors.
"Many people are distressed by the quality of new stoves," said Mr. Erickson, a stove restorer since 1980. "The old ones have a unique style and heavy-duty construction. They just need a good, solid tuneup every 40 to 50 years."
A properly rehabilitated gas stove is essentially a new stove in an old body. Mr. Erickson, who completely dismantles each old stove, installs an automatic safety pilot; in bygone times, owners struck a match to light the oven. He also rebuilds old thermostats. If the original thermostat is still not reliable, he installs new components.
Mr. Erickson, who handles stoves from the 1870's to the 1950's, became a stove enthusiast -- and restorer -- by chance. A former industrial arts instructor, he bought an old Victorian train depot, then fixed up a Victorian stove to heat it.
These days, the depot is his workshop and showroom, where he has about 200 stoves. He can pick up and deliver stoves for repair nearly anywhere in New England, New York and New Jersey. Major repairs cost $500 to $3,000. Stoves rehabilitated by Mr. Erickson start at around $1,700.
 
First, Remove the Mice
 Gus Elias, a partner in Artco Restaurant Equipment Company, sells and restores mostly new and used commercial stoves. "People have been putting commercial stoves into their homes for about 10 years," he said. But his 12-year-old company also rehabilitates stoves from the 1930's through the 70's. A lot of things can be wrong with an old stove. Mice can eat away the insulation. And often an entire stainless steel side rots away, particularly if water has leaked onto it. Burners can also crack and warp from heat.
Stove rehabilitation entails several basic steps. Grease is removed with a thick, non-abrasive solution. Grates and burners are sandblasted, then painted. Enamel must be repaired. And for newer stoves, a stainless steel exterior must be fashioned if the old one cannot be saved.
If the proper parts are hard to find, Mr. Elias often fabricates replacements. But he needs to look at a stove to know whether he can repair it.
Restoration costs about $400 and up.
 
Back to Wood-Burners
 Bea Bryant rehabilitates antique stoves in the tiny town of Thorndike, Me. But her old stoves have been shipped all over the world. (Her company, Bryant Stoves/Music Inc., recently sent an old kitchen stove to Euro Disneyland outside Paris.)
Mrs. Bryant, a stove collector for more than 40 years, deals mainly in stoves from the 1880's to 1930's. She also rehabilitates gas and wood combination stoves. Business took off in the early 70's when the energy crisis made the old models more economical, she said. "People needed cheap heat."
Mrs. Bryant, a past president of the Antique Stove Association, personally prefers very old models, including those from the 18th century. "The newer the stove, the plainer they got," she said. "People spent a lot of time designing the older ones."
Her company, in business since the late 1960's, specializes in restoring Clarion, Atlantic and Kineo stoves, from old Maine companies founded in the mid-19th century. Her rehabilitated kitchen stoves start at $1,000. A free catalogue is available.
 
Here's Where
