HEADLINE: What if Bosnia Had Oil?

 BODY:
When Saddam Hussein sent his divisions plunging into helpless little Kuwait, President Bush proclaimed an inviolable principle: Aggression would not stand. Hah, cynics said, the issue is not principle but oil. If Kuwait were not rich in oil, the West would not have rushed half a million soldiers to the Persian Gulf.
Was the President following a double standard? The world now looks to the aggression, every bit as cruel and unprovoked, by Serbia's Slobodan Milosevic against Bosnia and Herzegovina. That newborn state has no oil -- and no defenses. Will the U.S. and Europe stand up for principle as strongly as they did for petroleum? 
 Bosnia is just the place for the Administration to show it means what Secretary of State Baker says about collective engagement to secure peace. Yet the State Department does no more than mumble, as if innocent Bosnians were equally to blame. How much more Serbian terror is required to get the Administration to talk and act sternly, to turn Serbia into a pariah until it lets go of Bosnia?
Mr. Milosevic bears chief blame for the bloodletting. Bosnia preferred to remain in a loosely confederal Yugoslavia. But when he whipped up Serbian nationalism, driving out other republics, Bosnia was forced to flee a Serb-dominated rump state. Now, ignoring the latest U.S. entreaty, he seems determined to dismember Bosnia. Serb irregulars and the Serb-led Yugoslav Army are stepping up their barrages against Bosnia's defenseless towns. They have seized two-thirds of Bosnia and driven tens of thousands from their homes.
There are several concrete ways for the United States to take the lead now:
 Deny recognition to Serbia as Yugoslavia's legal heir; break relations with the Yugoslav shell; expel the Milosevic gang from international organizations like the United Nations.
 Work to increase U.N. peacekeeping forces in Sarajevo and disperse them through Bosnia.
 Tighten, and enforce, the economic blockade on landlocked Serbia. Without oil, weapons, ammunition and spare parts, Serbia's war machine will eventually grind down.
To be effective, these diplomatic and economic pressures require full cooperation from Europe. Much as it did in the Persian Gulf war, Washington can mobilize a unified Europe. No one has a greater stake in territorial integrity than the rest of Europe, East and West. Europeans cannot -- dare not -- tolerate Mr. Milosevic's dangerous attempt to change Bosnia's borders by force.
Stepping up the pressure may at a minimum rouse Serbs opposed to aggressive Milosevic nationalism. Many have fled or gone into hiding rather than march with a marauding Yugoslav Army. If the rest truly care about protecting kinsmen in Bosnia and elsewhere, they will press their Government to stop the terror and get out of Bosnia. If Americans believe in the principle that aggression is intolerable, they will stand up for it, oil or no oil.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: When Welfare Tries Fingerprints

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As New York State prepares a pilot program mandating fingerprinting of welfare applicants and recipients in Onondaga and Rockland counties, we should look closer at the fingerprinting experience in Los Angeles (news article, April 6) and its likely ramifications in New York.
Any reduction in welfare fraud to be achieved by fingerprinting is realized by limiting the access of needy people to the welfare system. From our experience with hundreds of community groups around New York State, we know that recent immigrants, Holocaust survivors, older people, political asylum seekers, psychiatric patients and those frequently most in need of government assistance are frightened by fingerprinting -- frightened enough to forgo needed medical, food and housing assistance if fingerprinting is required. 
 Los Angeles County claims that it has saved $5.4 million from its experiment fingerprinting welfare applicants and recipients. This figure was arrived at by including as a cost saving more than 3,000 people who refused to be fingerprinted and were cut off from receiving rent, food and medical assistance. The computer system Los Angeles uses for the fingerprinting system costs nearly $2 million a year. Only nine people have been uncovered as "welfare cheats." Consequently, the fingerprinting system costs the County of Los Angeles more than $222,000 for every case of welfare fraud discovered.
Applicants and recipients of public assistance in New York State's pilot fingerprinting project have a significant basis for concern about the confidentiality of their prints. Inappropriate disclosure of AIDS virus status and other information regarded as confidential is not uncommon in crowded and hectic welfare centers. Whether by mistake or breach, confidential information about welfare applicants and recipients is too frequently disclosed in welfare centers around the state.
When Social Security numbers were first instituted, their sole purpose was a narrow one -- the opening of a Social Security account. Today, Social Security numbers are used on college identification cards, bank accounts, loan applications and public-assistance applications. Information collected by Government bureaucracies tends to proliferate. Fingerprinting information is unlikely to be kept confidential for very long.
Fingerprinting reflects the intrusiveness of the governmental "Big Brother" into the lives of low-income people for the questionable social goal of scaring people away from Government assistance. Fingerprinting public assistance recipients is a quasi criminalization of low-income people that no government would institute toward middle-class people. How would we collectively react if Los Angeles or New York proposed to fingerprint all Social Security or income tax filers? The rate of fraud and abuse in these systems equals or surpasses welfare fraud.
Being poor is not a crime. If we are serious about trying to save money in the welfare system, then we should
look to programs that create jobs and to programs that redirect eligible welfare recipients toward veterans benefits, disability, unemployment and more appropriate benefit programs. Fingerprinting is not the answer.
 
JEFFREY PLAUT
Coordinator, City-Wide Welfare Advocacy Network
Bronx, April 9, 1992

HEADLINE: Abortion and the Law;
Sketches of 3 Lawyers In Abortion Argument

 BODY:

Kathryn Kolbert
American Civil Liberties Union lawyer
One of three senior lawyers for the A.C.L.U. Reproductive Freedom Project. . . . Successfully argued the case of Thornburgh v. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists before the Supreme Court in 1985. . . . As state coordinating counsel for the Reproductive Freedom Project since 1989, the 40-year-old Philadelphian assists the A.C.L.U.'s state offices and other local groups in lobbying for abortion rights. . . . Litigated challenges to Pennsylvania abortion laws for the Philadelphia-based Women's Law Project from 1979 to 1988. . . . Graduated from Cornell University School of Arts and Sciences and Temple University School of Law. . . . Two children.
 
Ernest D. Preate Jr.
Pennsylvania Attorney General 
 Elected Attorney General in 1989. . . . The 51-year-old Republican served three consecutive terms as Lackawanna County District Attorney, winning five death sentences against convicted murderers, a record for the state. . . . Has concentrated on drug crimes. . . . In his only other argument before the Supreme Court, Mr. Preate successfully defeated a challenge to Pennsylvania's death penalty and how juries are instructed in weighing mitigating circumstances. . . . Served as a Marine infantry officer in Vietnam in 1967 and 1968. . . . Earned a degree in economics from the Wharton School of Finance and a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. . . . Divorced. . . . Two children.
 
Kenneth W. Starr
U.S. Solicitor General
The Administration's chief litigator before the Supreme Court. . . . Appointed by President Bush, has served as Solicitor General since May 1989. . . . Raised in San Antonio, Mr. Starr, 45, received his law degree from Duke University School of Law in 1973. . . . Clerked for retired Chief Justice Warren E. Burger from 1975 to 1977. . . . As partner with Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher in Los Angeles and Washington, litigated Federal civil cases. . . . Served as chief of staff to Attorney General William French Smith. . . . Appointed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in 1983. . . . Lives in McLean, Va. with his wife and three children.

HEADLINE: Abortion and the Law;
Sketches of 3 Lawyers In Abortion Argument

 BODY:

Kathryn Kolbert
American Civil Liberties Union lawyer
One of three senior lawyers for the A.C.L.U. Reproductive Freedom Project. . . . Successfully argued the case of Thornburgh v. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists before the Supreme Court in 1985. . . . As state coordinating counsel for the Reproductive Freedom Project since 1989, the 40-year-old Philadelphian assists the A.C.L.U.'s state offices and other local groups in lobbying for abortion rights. . . . Litigated challenges to Pennsylvania abortion laws for the Philadelphia-based Women's Law Project from 1979 to 1988. . . . Graduated from Cornell University School of Arts and Sciences and Temple University School of Law. . . . Two children.
 
Ernest D. Preate Jr.
Pennsylvania Attorney General 
 Elected Attorney General in 1989. . . . The 51-year-old Republican served three consecutive terms as Lackawanna County District Attorney, winning five death sentences against convicted murderers, a record for the state. . . . Has concentrated on drug crimes. . . . In his only other argument before the Supreme Court, Mr. Preate successfully defeated a challenge to Pennsylvania's death penalty and how juries are instructed in weighing mitigating circumstances. . . . Served as a Marine infantry officer in Vietnam in 1967 and 1968. . . . Earned a degree in economics from the Wharton School of Finance and a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. . . . Divorced. . . . Two children.
 
Kenneth W. Starr
U.S. Solicitor General
The Administration's chief litigator before the Supreme Court. . . . Appointed by President Bush, has served as Solicitor General since May 1989. . . . Appointed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in 1983. . . . Lives in McLean, Va. with his wife and three children.

HEADLINE: UNIONS DEMANDING SHARE OF SURPLUS IN DINKINS BUDGET

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Leaders of New York City's municipal unions yesterday demanded a share of the budget surplus that the Dinkins administration disclosed a day before, and angrily denounced Mayor David N. Dinkins, saying he had previously distorted the budget picture to elicit labor concessions.
The Dinkins administration, which has vowed not to grant wage increases without productivity gains, sought to quell the clamor, and not just from the unions, as many contingents came forward yesterday to claim bigger pieces of the budget pie. 
 In Albany, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin said he expected the city to scale back its proposed tax package and to contribute a bigger share of the financing for the city's subways, buses, colleges and universities.
 
A Reminder of Challenges
 But the Mayor and the City Council stuck to their position of seeking approval for $115 million in new taxes from Albany and shored up their position with an agreement, after months of haggling, on exactly where the new taxes should fall. They include new taxes on tobacco, alcohol and gasoline.
In refusing to consider reducing the tax package, the administration told officials in Albany what it told others who made appeals yesterday for pieces of the budget surplus: that the money was already spoken for.
For Mayor Dinkins, who spent the last week releasing good budget news in plans ranging from longer hours at libraries to more low-income housing in the Bronx, yesterday was a dose of political reality. And it was a reminder not only that the Mayor still faces considerable challenges in balancing the city's budget but also that the surplus is not the fiscal panacea that it might have seemed. [News analysis, page B4.]
"It's not like we are now awash with new money that we can start spending all over the place," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. "We still have to maintain a very disciplined fiscal environment because the financial crisis of the 1990's is not over yet."
Conveying that message was only complicated yesterday as the administration prepared to announce it was restoring $1.7 billion of the $3.7 billion it had proposed to cut in spending for long-term construction projects just weeks ago. Those projects are financed by bonds, and the city had trimmed them to save on interest costs. But it said yesterday that it has found ways to avoid increasing those costs by adjusting the timing of the bonds and projects and rejuggling state and Federal money that had been earmarked for other purposes.
On Tuesday, city budget officials described the budget surplus for the fiscal year that ends on June 30 only as in excess of $200 million. Yesterday, they pinpointed it at $455 million. The surplus is composed of $110 million from the city's general reserve fund, $158 million in higher tax collections, $75 million in money set aside for contracts entered into that is no longer needed, $37 million from miscellaneous revenues and $75 million in underspending stemming from tighter controls.
The officials said the surplus would be used to eliminate the city's plans to borrow $250 million with the help of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation and to offset $200 million in Federal aid that the city had hoped for but will not receive. Bond raters and fiscal monitors had warned the administration that borrowing through the assistance corporation would lower the city's bond rating and advised against it.
"While the surplus is good news and important news in terms of helping us put together a fiscally balanced plan," Mr. Steisel said, "we don't want to give people the mistaken impression that a lot of the tough things we said we would have to do in January to balance the budget now don't have to be done. We still have to do the tough things."
 
Contributed to Surplus
 But Stanley Hill, president of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said the Dinkins administration had not been honest with the unions in portraying the city's fiscal condition and he called Mr. Dinkins's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, "a liar."
Mr. Hill said the unions deserved a share of the city's surplus because their members had contributed to the surplus through work force reductions and furloughs. "If they had told us then what they are telling us now, we would have never agreed to these concessions," he said.
Barry Feinstein, president of Teamsters Local 237, said the surplus meant that the city would have to revise its labor policies. "They have cried poor mouth all this time, saying that there will be no wage increases unless there is gain-sharing, but that now changes and we want raises up front," Mr. Feinstein said.
Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said in a statement: "The surplus means that the city has to get its act together and start negotiating contracts. Otherwise, it's going to see a lot of labor unrest." Ms. Feldman was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for further comment.
The city's Labor Commissioner, James F. Hanley, maintained yesterday that the city had negotiated in good faith with the unions. "We dealt with the hand that was there based on the facts as we knew them," Mr. Hanley said, "but the good news is still that the city has avoided layoffs." He acknowledged that the surplus would have an impact on the city's future negotiations with the unions but declined to say what that would be.
In Albany, Steven H. Greenberg, a spokesman for Mr. Weprin, the Assembly Speaker, said yesterday that given its substantial surplus, the city should reduce the amount of money that it is seeking in its tax package and increase its level of funds to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which operates the city's subways and buses, and the City University of New York.
"It's fair to say that the Speaker believes that Mr. Dinkins is now in a position to do more for the people of New York City than he was a few months ago," Mr. Greenberg said.
Overcoming that sentiment in Albany will be an uphill battle, a battle for which the Mayor and the Council began to prepare yesterday by agreeing on a tax package. Reluctant to pass new taxes in the first place, Albany has long refused even to consider such requests from the city unless the Mayor and the Council first agree.
Legislative leaders have said Mr. Dinkins's plan for a commuter income tax was all but dead, but the Mayor has insisted on pressing forward with it because he believes it is fair, his aides said.
But in a compromise with the Council, he agreed to press for other taxes it had sought and to drop his own plans for a 1 percent tax on the value of cars. The joint tax proposal includes taxes on gasoline, tobacco, alcohol and fuels that produce pollution.
In the past, state lawmakers have approved such "sin taxes" on alcohol and tobacco to make state budgets work, but whether they will allow the city to add to them is uncertain, especially in light of the city's surplus.
Even as the Dinkins administration released the details of the tax package yesterday, Mr. Dinkins was planning to announce today that he was restoring $1.7 billion of the $3.7 billion in proposed cuts to the city's capital budget for construction. The bulk of the restoration will go toward housing, education, parks, economic development and health care.
The administration is cutting the cost of construction by reconfiguring timetables for building and financing projects, taking advantage of low construction costs and applying for new Federal and state matching funds.
Aides at the city's Office of Management and Budget said yesterday that the Mayor's capital budget to be released today includes restorations of $600 million for education, $200 million for housing, $230 million for highways, $50 million for parks, $100 million for economic development and $70 million for health care.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. and American Air in Aeroflot Deal

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
I.B.M. and American Airlines, which teamed up 25 years ago to create the airline industry's dominant computer reservation system, are working together again on a deal to build such a system for Aeroflot, the world's largest airline.
For I.B.M. and American, the Aeroflot contract could eventually translate into more than $100 million in revenues and a big foothold for American's Sabre system in the highly competitive international computer reservations business. 
 Sabre, an advanced computerized system for handling reservations, tracking passengers and issuing tickets and boarding passes, changed the face of air travel in the United States and now handles more than 40 percent of computer reservations.
For five months, teams of business analysts and engineers from Aeroflot, most of which is based in Russia, have been receiving training at American's Fort Worth headquarters on using Sabre. And 18 Russian engineers are at American studying English and software programming. A third group of Aeroflot officials is scheduled to arrive next week. For its part, American has already committed 100 employees to the project.
When it is installed in many former Soviet republics, Sabre is expected to radically improve the nightmarish air travel system for an estimated 150 million passengers a year.
"It will bring Aeroflot from the Stone Age to the 20th century," said Boris Glasser, a Russian emigre and American's director of European business.
Mr. Glasser, who spent the first 22 years of his life in St. Petersburg before coming to the United States, described Russian air travel as a morass of endless lines, lost reservations and canceled flights. "Nothing works," he said. "The computer is always down. I once waited for three days at the airport. Aeroflot is the reason I left the Soviet Union."
 
No Way to Track Seats
 In 1990, Aeroflot reportedly had to turn away 30 percent of its ticketed passengers because there were no seats. The airline simply had no way to track the seats it sold. Tickets are not sold at the airport, only at downtown locations in Moscow and other cities. The ticket, according to George Van Derven, president of transportation automation services, a division of American's information services company, simply allows a traveler to stand on line at the airport where seats are given first to V.I.P.'s and foreigners and then provided first come, first serve to everyone else.
The concepts of advance reservations, seat assignments and boarding passes are simply nonexistent. And conditions since the breakup of the Soviet Union have only worsened, Mr. Van Derven said. "Sometimes there is no fuel, flights are canceled," he said.
The project, which began 18 months ago when I.B.M. won the contract from Aeroflot, is being hampered by political and economic uncertainty and confusion on exchange rates. But an I.B.M. spokesman said the company, which had already poured "significant money" into the project, is committed to making it work and is optimistic that the financing will be made available. The project is being coordinated by I.B.M.'s trade development office in Vienna.
"Getting Sabre into Russia is a big plus for American," said Daniel Kasper, director of transportation practice at Harbridge House, a Boston-based management consulting firm. "By getting Aeroflot, they are getting a whole virgin market."
 
Easier Travel Seen
 For United States travelers, the system will eventually make it far easier to make air travel arrangements within the former Soviet Union. Travelers, for example, will be able to book flights on Aeroflot through travel agents here.
While I.B.M. is pressing to solve the financial problems, American, acting as a subcontractor, is moving ahead on schedule. If the economic obstacles can be overcome, the project would take up to two years to complete, although the I.B.M. spokesman said computer hardware for the initial phase could be installed in a matter of months.
Mr. Van Derven, who has been American's catalyst on the project, said he had convinced Robert Crandall, American's chairman, of the value of the project by explaining that such a venture would give American access to a market with 300 million people and one-fifth of the world's land mass. He has shuttled back and forth to Moscow and the republics establishing ties to key Aeroflot personnel to make the project move ahead.
From a technical standpoint, the transfer of Sabre to Aeroflot is moving smoothly, Mr. Van Derven said, adding that the Russian programmers were "superintellectuals" who were quickly picking up the nuances of the complex system. American is intent on making the Russians self-sufficient in running the system and the engineers training in Texas will remain in the United States to work as members of actual American Airlines technical crews in Fort Worth or Tulsa, Okla.

HEADLINE: CRASH IN WASHINGTON SQUARE;
Car Plows Into Park, Killing 4 and Injuring Many

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET

 BODY:
A car driven by a 74-year-old woman careered out of control yesterday afternoon and plowed into crowds of people enjoying the first clear spring day in Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village. Four people were killed, including one who died last night after surgery. As many as 27 others were injured, some critically.
The idyllic scene was suddenly and violently transformed, witnesses said. The park, packed with sunbathers, street musicians and mothers pushing strollers in the warm afternoon, gave way to a chaos of people screaming as the speeding car jumped a curb, knocked down a fence and plowed into the crowd, stopping only after banging into another fence 200 feet into the park.
 
'Bodies All Lying There'
 Two victims were trapped beneath the car when it finally came to a stop, and a group of onlookers lifted the vehicle to free them. 
 "There were bodies all lying there," said John Arnold, 30, who was working at a book stall 30 feet from the point at which the gray 1987 Oldsmobile entered the park. "There was a girl lying in the middle of a walkway about 20 feet away from her sneaker. There was a guy lying there with a smile on his face. I don't know if he was dead. It looked like they were asleep."
Sam Catlin, 23, a student at New York University, said: "It was like war, total war. So violent."
The police identified the driver of the car as Stella G. Maychick of Yonkers. They said she lost control of her car after dropping her daughter off at her apartment building on Washington Place, less than a block from the park. Mrs. Maychick was unharmed in the accident.
 
No Immediate Charges
 A preliminary police investigation determined that that Mrs. Maychick should not be charged with any crime in what was being termed an accident, said Capt. Donald Kelly, commander of the First Detective Division. But he could offer few other details of the accident, other than to say that Mrs. Maychick had not lost consciousness. He said a more detailed investigation would be conducted.
Late yesterday, the police identified the victims as: Carlos Loyla, 19, 367 South Second Street in Brooklyn; Rubin Perez, 29, 501 East 170th Street, Manhattan; Ruth Zimmerman, 76, 54 East 8th Street, Manhattan; and Carol Trocchia, 84, 51 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan.
Some witnesses said that Mrs. Maychick's car was speeding before it swerved into the park at 3:18 P.M. and that they heard a screech as the car pulled away from the daughter's apartment building. But amid the confusion yesterday afternoon, this could not be confirmed by the police.
The police said that among the possibilities being examined was that the car may have had problems with its acceleration system. The car model, a 1987 Oldsmobile Delta 88, was the subject of a two-year Federal safety investigation into possible accelerator and throttle defects.
Mrs. Maychick had an accident in Westchester County that caused injury and property damage on Sept. 4, 1991, according to New York State drivers' license records. Further details were unavailable last night. Officers were still questioning the woman late yesterday.
 
Smashed Into Fountain
 Witnesses said the car entered the park from the middle of the east side, on Washington Place, and quickly jumped the curb and smashed into a concrete fountain, hitting two people who stood near that entrance. The car then veered onto a walkway and rammed into benches, hitting people gathered in crowds. At least two people were caught under the car and dragged, witnesses said.
Richard Crespo, 21, who is unemployed and lives on the Lower East Side, said he was walking through the park with his brother, Robert Calabrese, 15, when he saw Mrs. Maychick's car swerve into the park.
Mr. Crespo said that the car hit the gate, which in turn hit his brother. "I found him under a bench about 50 feet away. There were people lying all over the place, so I had to be looking for him."
Deputy Police Commissioner Suzanne Trazoff said that Mrs. Maychick's daughter, Diana, had driven the car to her apartment in Greenwich Village. The two had been shopping in New Jersey.
"The daughter got out of the car and Mrs. Maychick slid over into the driver's seat," Commissioner Trazoff said. "She told the cops at the Sixth Precinct that when she put her foot on the gas, the car just took off."
"There was a sense there was something wrong with that," said Ms. Trazoff. But late yesterday, the reasons for the accident remained a mystery.
One of the things investigators may examine is a two-year investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that found that in some cases the throttle cable of Delta 88's, like the one Mrs. Maychick was driving, would become stuck, causing the engine to race even with the driver's foot off the pedal. The manufacturer has recalled thousands of Delta 88's from 1987, the year of Mrs. Maychick's car, to deal with the problem.
Tim Hurd, a spokesman for the safety administration, said there were 686 complaints of "unintended sudden acceleration" in the car.
But at the same time, Mr. Hurd said that in most cases in which there were accidents and drivers blamed sudden acceleration, investigations revealed the fault was actually the driver's.
"We concluded that the explanation for many of these incidents was driver error," he said. "They put their foot on the accelerator, not the brake."
Whatever the cause, witnesses portrayed a shattering scene at the park yesterday.
Andrew Margolies, a 26-year-old Emergency Medical Service paramedic who was one of the first to arrive, said, "There were just people all over the place. It was like a bomb had exploded."
Witnesses said that after the car stopped, Mrs. Maychick stepped out in a daze. People approached her, screaming. At least one person started to attack her.
The crowd moved to her car, which had at least two people pinned, lifted it and began pulling people from underneath.
Evie Hantzopoulos, a 26-year-old New York University graduate student, said: "It was like a surreal experience. We couldn't believe what was happening. It was like a movie."
"First we heard noise and it sounded like gunfire," she said. "The car was just going through and it was almost like everything was going through slow motion. People were just trying to get out of the way."
The injuries ranged from a severed leg to multiple fractures to heart attacks and shock. The injured victims were moved quickly to four nearby hospitals: Bellevue Hospital Center, Beth Israel Medical Center, Cabrini Medical Center and St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center.
A spokesman for St. Vincent's said it had eight patients, four in critical condition and four with minor injuries. One woman had both legs fractured, another a ruptured spleen and shattered pelvis, a third a fractured pelvis and a fourth severe head injuries.
Vicki Ciampa, a Bellevue spokeswoman, said five "very critical" patients were brought into the hospital's emergency room.
Cabrini Medical Center admitted four patients.
At Beth Israel, a spokeswoman, Robin Mesger, said there were three patients in stable condition, one with a compound leg fracture. "The other, I'm not quite sure of, but he seemed pretty bad," she said. "His face was badly bloodied." The atmosphere in the emergency room, she said, was "chaotic."
Witnesses said emergency personnel arrived at the park within minutes.

HEADLINE: SCIENTISTS REPORT PROFOUND INSIGHT ON HOW TIME BEGAN

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
In a momentous discovery supporting the "Big Bang" theory for the birth of the universe, astronomers looking back toward the beginning of time have detected broad wrinkles in the fabric of space. Their discovery is the first evidence revealing how an initially smooth cosmos evolved into today's panorama of stars, galaxies and gigantic clusters of galaxies.
The scientists detected faint temperature fluctuations in microwave radiation echoing from the supposed instant of creation. Though the temperatures fluctuate by no more than a hundred-thousandth of a degree, they signal primeval variations in the universe's topography a mere 300,000 years after its explosive birth.
 
Creation of Gravity
 The variations in topography were large enough, scientists said, to create the gravity needed to attract more and more matter into increasingly expansive clumps. These variations had been predicted by theorists but were never observed until now. 
 The discovery, made by scientists analyzing satellite data, is being hailed as one of the most exciting and important developments in cosmology in this century.
"What we have found is evidence for the birth of the universe and its evolution," said Dr. George Smoot, an astrophysicist at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory and the University of California at Berkeley, who led the research.
"This is really a breakthrough, a revolution, in our understanding of the early universe," said Dr. Smoot, announcing the findings at a meeting of the American Physical Society here today.
 
Cataclysmic Explosion
 The nature of the matter creating the density "ripples" has not been determined. But the ripples themselves were created immediately by the original Big Bang. There would not have been time, the scientists said, for the texture to have changed under normal physical processes.
The Big Bang theory holds that the universe began in a single cataclysmic explosion and has been expanding ever since. The concept was first proposed to explain the discovery in the 1920's that distant galaxies are receding from view at enormous speeds, as if they started moving away from the same location a long time ago.
The theory gained its strongest previous confirmation, and wide acceptance, in 1964, when Dr. Arno Penzias and Dr. Robert Wilson of Bell Telephone Laboratories detected the hiss of microwave radiation in their radio telescope. It was the glow presumably left over from the Big Bang, existing everywhere and uniformly in cosmic background.
Astronomers assumed that as their instruments improved they would begin to see texture in this radiation, but to their dismay, when the Cosmic Background Explorer satellite, called COBE (pronounced COH-bee) by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in 1989, it found not the slightest hint of any initial variations out of which stars and galaxies could have developed by normal gravitational processes in the approximately 15 billion years since the Big Bang.
Where were the density fluctuations that seeded the development of large structure? It was the question astronomers have strained to answer for the last 28 years. The credibility of the Big Bang theory itself seemed to be at stake.
Describing the results as "unbelievably important," Dr. Michael Turner, an astrophysicist at the University of Chicago, said, "They have found the Holy Grail of cosmology."
Dr. Joseph Silk, an astrophysicist at the University of California at Berkeley, said: "They've really opened up the dark ages in cosmology. They've found the missing link in the evolution of large structure in the universe."
Dr. Edward Wright, a cosmologist at the University of California at Los Angeles, exclaimed, "The Big Bang model is alive and well, very well!"
 
'A Nobel-Class Result'
Noting that Dr. Penzais and Dr. Wilson won the Nobel Prize in Physics for their discovery in 1964, Dr. Stephen Maran, an astronomer at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., said: "If their measurements are as sensitive as they say, this is a Nobel-class result. It was even more difficult than detecting the microwave background."
Dr. Smoot and his colleagues said the findings not only strengthened the case for the Big Bang theory, but also for two subsidiary hypotheses about the pace of the early universe's expansion, the inflationary model, and about the existence of the so-called "cold dark matter," invisible subatomic particles believed to constitute as much as 90 percent of all the matter in the universe.
In the inflationary model, advanced a decade ago by Dr. Alan H. Guth of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the universe underwent a brief episode of extremely rapid expansion less than one-trillionth of a second after the initial explosion, then settled down to a relatively sedate pace of expansion. During inflation, tiny variations in energy from the Big Bang would become exaggerated, setting up the conditions favoring the evolution of large-scale structure.
The cold-dark matter theory, much favored by cosmologists, had suffered several setbacks recently from observational evidence suggesting that there was more large-scale structure than it could explain.
Some such exotic matter is required to provide the gravity responsible for galactic accumulations of stars and otherwise inexplicable motions of galaxies. But the dark matter has yet to be directly observed, though its presence, theorists said, should be indirectly determined through temperature difference in the background radiation.
 
Evolutionary Hypothesis
 Although most theorists at the conference favored this interpretation, Dr. Kenneth Brecher, an astrophysicist at Boston University, said the new findings did not necessarily support the evolutionary hypothesis incorporating both cold dark matter and inflationary theory.
"There is going to be a gold rush to check out our measurements," Dr. Smoot said. "Six months from now most people are going to believe inflation is right, and people had better get to work on finding the dark matter."
The decisive measurements were made by instruments on COBE that measure invisible electromagnetic radiation known as microwaves. These differential microwave radiometers recorded temperatures at three wavelengths, creating a map of the sky as it would appear if humans could see microwaves. Indeed, the map of the temperature variations looked like a topographic map with "hot" and "cold" regions marked off by contour lines.
The variations are on the order of six parts per million, detectable only after considerable computer processing of the generally cold temperature readings. The background radiation has a temperature of 454 degrees below zero Fahrenheit, barely above absolute zero, the temperature at which molecules cease to move.
Dr. Smoot said in an interview that scientists on his team had known of these results for more than a year, but had withheld any announcement until they could check and recheck for possible errors in the 70 million measurements for each of the three radiometers. "I have a reputation of being very conservative," he said, "and I believe our results are right."
Dr. Charles Bennett of the Goddard center, a member of the research team that analyzed the data, said a major challenge was to distinguish the Big Bang signals from others. "We compared the signals at different positions and at different wavelengths to separate the radiation of the Big Bang from that of the Milky Way galaxy," he said.
Dr. Smoot described the primordial cosmic texture as the "largest and most ancient structures in the universe." The largest of the wispy clouds of matter stretches 10 billion light years, or 59 billion trillion miles. The smallest span is 500 million light years, about 2.9 billion trillion miles.
"Over billions of years," Dr. Smoot said, "the smaller of these ripples have grown into galaxies, clusters of galaxies and the great voids in space."

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Climbed By 10.3% in Mid-April

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks built in North America rose 10.3 percent in mid-April over the period a year earlier, when sales were depressed, auto makers reported yesterday. But industry analysts said they saw few optimistic signs in the sluggish seasonally adjusted selling rate of 5.5 million cars.
"The question is, where is the recovery?" said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. He noted that industry sources had told him that both showroom traffic and closing rates were down in the period. "Normally you have a lot of discretionary buyers in spring, but we're not getting the discretionary buyers," he said. 
 Light-truck sales increased 18.6 percent, based on an average daily selling rate, to 110,612 in the April 11-20 period, while car sales rose 5.1 percent, to 154,818. There were eight selling days in mid-April, compared with nine a year earlier.
Although some analysts said they believed the Government statistics used to calculate the seasonally adjusted selling rate of 5.5 million represented a low estimate, they nonetheless said that sales figures remained weak.
 
Several Explanations Offered
 They cited several possible explanations for the sluggish market, including fewer sales to commercial fleets, higher prices on many models and lower incentives. "But there's no obvious reason why," said Harvey Heinbach, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.
Tom Webb, chief economist with the National Automobile Dealers Association, said that in light of rising employment rates and other factors, auto sales should be better. If they do not improve, he cautioned, "they are going to bring the recovery to a halt."
Dealers around the country reported mixed results in recent weeks. Sales at Herb Gordon Auto World in Silver Spring, Md., are down roughly 10 percent from a year earlier. "It's down pretty much across the board," said Richard H. Deranek Jr., Nissan sales manager at the dealership. "It's pretty quiet."
"There's no rhyme or reason to the market; it's very difficult to measure," said Robert Dreeben, general manager of Mark Subaru in Yonkers.
 
Consumer Worry Perceived
 But Jay Gould, general manager of several foreign and domestic dealerships in Texas, said sales picked up sharply in the previous two weeks, possibly because of improved weather there. Despite the gains, "there are a lot of people out there still worried about future employment prospects," he said.
The General Motors Corporation sold 73,278 cars during the period, 6.9 percent more than a year earlier, and 39,109 trucks, up 7.1 percent.
The Ford Motor Company sold 39,941 cars, up 10.7 percent from a year earlier, and 39,578 light trucks, up 25.7 percent.
The Chrysler Corporation reports its vehicle sales only once a month, but Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry publication, estimated the company sold 14,750 cars and 26,550 mini-vans and other light trucks in the 10-day period.
The Honda Motor Company sold 11,601 cars, an increase of 13.1 percent, while the Toyota Motor Corporation sold 7,341 cars, an increase of 15.3 percent. Toyota achieved its gains largely because of the popularity of its redesigned Camry model, which is assembled in Georgetown, Ky.
The Mazda Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company both reported continued declines in sales of cars made at their American plants. Nissan's sales dropped 21.9 percent, to 2,628, and Mazda's dropped 22.1 percent, to 2,112.

HEADLINE: Bush Eases Cold-War Trade Curb

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
President Bush announced this evening that the United States had loosened some controls on militarily sensitive exports and that he had ordered an acceleration of negotiations for a free trade agreement with Mexico, believing a pact possible before the November elections.
The Commerce Department disclosed three changes today in its export control regulations, to take effect next Tuesday. The changes allow more high-technology products with specific or potential applications in the operation and detection of aircraft and submarines to be shipped to Western Europe and Japan without export licenses. They would also impose fewer controls on re-exports of American high-technology goods from these countries. 
 "We relaxed trade restrictions on exports that served us well during the cold-war era, but are no longer necessary in our new world," Mr. Bush said at a meeting here of the Council of the Americas, a group of business executives from the United States, Canada and Latin American countries. The move is aimed at increasing exports as national-security threats appear to be dwindling, the President said. He said that $2.5 billion worth of annual American exports would no longer require licenses.
 
Supercomputers Involved
 The Commerce Department added nine categories of products to its list of goods that may be exported to Western Europe and Japan without prior Government approval; allowed foreign countries to re-export some American products without the Federal Government's permission, and allowed American companies to sell supercomputers to nine European countries and Australia with a single license, instead of seeking a separate license for each shipment.
High-technology American companies, particularly in the computer industry, have complained bitterly that the long delays involved in obtaining licenses have discouraged potential overseas customers and encouraged them to buy from other countries instead. But some arms control experts contend that looseness in American export control standards helped Iraq build up its army and communications networks and made it a more formidable opponent during the Persian Gulf war.
Mainly, President Bush used his speech tonight to bring public attention to negotiations for a free-trade agreement covering all of North America and to the Administration's plan for a more open trade and investment climate across the entire Western Hemisphere.
"Before I leave office I want manufacturers in Cleveland to enjoy virtually the same access to markets in Monterrey as they now have in Minneapolis," he said.
Congressional Democrats from auto-producing states criticized the President's call for accelerated negotiations. "The President's eagerness to conclude an agreement before the November elections makes me wonder if he understands the impact on the U.S. of a hastily negotiated" pact, said Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan.
Earlier today, Commerce Secretary Jaime Serra Puche of Mexico expressed considerable optimism to business executives at the same conference that an agreement could be concluded soon. One of his senior deputies told several reporters that he expected significant progress next week when most of the 19 negotiating groups for the three-nation pact meet in Mexico City. Yet, Mexican officials have consistently expressed optimism while offering few concessions, a senior Administration official said.
The main issues blocking an agreement are Mexico's reluctance to allow foreign investment in some oil industry activities; United States insistence that cars made in Mexico have many of their parts made in North America instead of imported from Japan, and requests by American and Canadian negotiators that some of their tariffs be reduced over longer periods than the current 10-year limit.
The President did not offer any specific reasons to support his belief that an agreement might be concluded by November; nor was his support for a prompt pact new. When asked by reporters on Feb. 27 in San Antonio, whether an agreement could be struck this year, Mr. Bush replied, "Well, we're hoping so, yes."
Many Republican strategists inside and outside the Administration feel that an agreement could help the President lure Hispanic voters in large states like Texas and California. But senior Administration officials say that it is very unlikely now that an agreement will be finished early enough to allow Congress to review it and vote on its approval.
 
Global Trade Mentioned
 The President mentioned only briefly this evening his support for a global agreement reducing trade barriers. His negotiations on Wednesday with European Community leaders failed to break a 16-month-old deadlock in the talks.
The easing of export-control restrictions brought a hostile response today from critics of the Administration's arms export-control policies, but did not go as far as sought by American exporters of computers and other high-technology products.
Gary Milhollin, the director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, said the Administration's decision was imprudent given the accumulation of evidence that many Western companies, including some in the United States, exported militarily useful products to Iraq during the 1980's.
"We should learn something from the gulf war," he said. "Here we are rushing out to change things when we're still trying to track the stuff down that we sold to Iraq."
But John Scheibel, the staff director of the Democratic-controlled House Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade, said the export control changes were mostly cosmetic.
The nine categories are semiconductor manufacturing equipment, certain computers, test equipment for aircraft and gas turbine engine design, coatings equipment, acoustical gear, materials and production equipment, certain aircraft and helicopters, and two groups of submarine gear.

HEADLINE: Cheers as Ex-Mayor of Washington Leaves Prison

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 23

 BODY:
The former Mayor of Washington, Marion S. Barry Jr., emerged from prison today and strode straight into the capital's politics by casually and confidently listing the City Council seats for which he might decide to run this fall.
In the course of his serving six months for cocaine possession, there has been wide speculation that Mr. Barry would run for the City Council this fall. Though he said that he had no specific plans, he immediately pointed out, "There are a number of seats open in the district." 
 Carrying a Bible and wearing an African textile hat and scarf almost identical to the ones he wore on the day he went to jail, Mr. Barry tried to bring his criminal episode to a close at a rally at a motel.
 
Taped Using Cocaine
 It has been two years since agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation videotaped him smoking crack cocaine with a woman friend at a Washington hotel. The arrest brought about his downfall as the leader of a coalition of diverse interest groups in the capital.
His re-emergence into the spotlight this afternoon took place on the sun-baked asphalt parking lot of the Days Inn here, where a rally and a luncheon was held in his honor. The motel is about 40 miles from the Federal prison in Loretto, Pa.
Supporters who came from Washington in a six-bus caravan sang gospel hymns and waited impatiently about an hour for Mr. Barry's cadre of handlers to set up his carefully orchestrated entrance.
Most were longtime backers of the former mayor who sat through his trial and saw him off when he was imprisoned. About 200 people from the Union Temple Baptist Church in Washington came in the bus caravan. When Mr. Barry's aides tried to prolong the suspense before his entrance, the crowd of mostly middle-aged women rebelled.
 
'Let Him Loose'
 "We want Barry," one yelled, while others shouted revival meeting-style: "Give us Barry, let him loose."
As the crowd was singing "Victory is Mine," Mr. Barry suddenly emerged and, appearing unfamiliar with the lyrics of the hymn, sang a few lines and then just smiled and waved his Bible at the cheering group.
Then he met with reporters to discuss what his future might hold:
"I have a number of options -- I cannot get involved ever again in my lifetime, I can wait and run later, or I can get involved this year."
He pointed out that several City Council seats would be open and that "the way the law in the district works, if I want to run I can move into the ward and run 30 days later."
He was convicted in August 1990 -- five months before the end of his third term as mayor -- on one misdemeanor count of cocaine possession. A jury acquitted Mr. Barry of another count and deadlocked on 12 other drug-related charges. A Federal judge rejected an appeal of the conviction only a week ago.
Mr. Barry was sentenced to six months in jail, and originally sent to a minimum-security facility in Virginia last October. But in January, Mr. Barry was moved to a more tightly controlled prison in Pennsylvania after being accused of engaging in a public sex act with a woman who visited him in prison. Mr. Barry denied the accusation.
If the former mayor intends to refashion his political career as a City Council member, he began today by presenting himself as a new man who found God, self-discipline and the plight of black convicts while in prison.
"I gained the realization that I came to experience a spiritual power outage," Mr. Barry said, his voice taking on the cadence of a religious sermon. "It caused me to get my life out of balance and out of control.
"I come out of prison better, not bitter," he shouted to a chorus of "Yes sir" and "Amen" from the crowd.
There is little doubt that if Mr. Barry runs for a council seat in one of Washington's poor, predominantly black wards he would have strong support. Many voters there think of Mr. Barry as the son of a Mississippi sharecropper who fought his way to the top of local politics but floundered when he made the mistake of using drugs. Most of these people seem to believe Mr. Barry has paid for that bad judgment.
"If he runs for anything, I will definitely vote for him," said Alberta Davis, a 68-year-old retired computer technician who got up at 5 A.M. to join the bus caravan.
Mark Plotkin, a political commentator for WAMU Radio in Washington, said Mr. Barry's "chances are pretty good. He's proven he can win Ward 8, which is the most economically deprived, voters there are the most forgiving, and the most open to his message."
That possibility has led Washington's Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly, and other City Council members to rally behind the Ward 8 council incumbent.
Before he was imprisoned, Mr. Barry was active in Ward 8, where the incumbent, Wilhelmina Rolark, has held the seat for 16 years. In 1990, before he was imprisoned, Mr. Barry made an unsuccessful bid for an at-large City Council seat. He lost, due mostly to widespread rejection in predominantly white areas, but in Ward 8 he got 2,000 more votes than Mrs. Rolark has ever received in a single election. Mrs. Rolark has declined to be interviewed about the possible threat from Mr. Barry.

HEADLINE: Big Business and Labor Join to Oppose Citizen Laws in New Jersey

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 23

 BODY:
Despite broad opposition by powerful lobbies, a bill to allow citizen lawmaking will be ready for a floor vote by mid-May, a committee chairman said today, making it possible to have the measure appear on the ballot in the general election in the fall.
A parade of opponents ranging from big labor unions to the state Chamber of Commerce to Roman Catholic bishops -- all major lobbying groups fearful of laws drawn by ordinary citizens -- lined up to oppose the bill at a committee hearing today. 
 Before the hearing, two citizens' groups, Common Cause and the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, held a news conference to release figures showing that the groups opposing citizen legislation spent more than $3 million in the last two years to elect favored candidates and promote favored bills.
 
'Most Extremist Elements'
 In their testimony, the opponents said repeatedly that allowing citizens to make or repeal laws through the process called Initiative and Referendum would allow "extremists" and "big-money interests" to push through legislation without deliberation by legislative committees.
"One only need to look at the proponents of I and R," as the process is called in legislative shorthand of the State House, "to recognize they are dominated by the most extremist elements in our society, both on the extreme left and the extreme right," said James C. Morford, executive director of the New Jersey Society for Environmental, Economic Development, a lobbying group that opposes environmental and other regulations on business and industry.
In addition to Common Cause and the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, the major organizations backing Initiative and Referendum are the League of Women Voters and two grass-roots antitax groups, Hands Across New Jersey and United Taxpayers of New Jersey.
Testifying against the concept today were representatives of the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce, which represents large and small businesses throughout the state, the New Jersey Education Association, which represents 138,000 teachers, the Employer Legislative Committees of New Jersey, representing small businesses, and the New Jersey Catholic Conference, which represents the state's 14 Catholic bishops.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds staged a late recovery to close narrowly mixed yesterday.
Bond prices fell as much as half a point early in the session after the Government issued economic reports that were seen by traders as further evidence of a recovery. 
 The 1.6 percent gain in durable goods orders reported for March was roughly in line with expectations, even though some analysts noted that the overall gain masked troubling pockets of weakness.
Prices weakened somewhat on the durable goods report, but the bulk of the early selling took place after the Labor Department reported that initial claims for unemployment insurance fell by 12,000 during the week ended April 11, the third decline in succession.
Most analysts had been expecting the claims numbers would show an increase. To traders, the decline implied that April employment data may be considerably stronger than expected.
While acknowledging the figures represent a somewhat brighter job outlook, some analysts said that credit market participants are reading too much into the recent numbers.
"There is no question that there is some improvement in the labor market," said Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers.
"But in the aftermath of the recessions in 1980 and 1982, it took declines in initial claims of 200,000 or so before you began to see meaningful increases in employment."
"People look at these numbers and say the recovery is on its way," Mr. Slifer added. "But the fact is that every time bond yields go higher, the rise threatens to reduce or wipe out growth."
The release of those two sets of figures came before the Treasury auctioned $10 billion worth of five-year notes.
Bids at the auction produced an average yield of 6.93 percent for the new securities, essentially unchanged from the 6.94 percent average yield at the last five-year note auction on March 25. Traders said the auction went about as expected. However, prices began to turn shortly after the results were announced.
Dismal 10-day auto sales numbers, which trickled in throughout the session, may have helped spark the price rebound.
 
Weekly Money Supply Data
 In addition, the weekly money supply figures from the Federal Reserve Board were in line with expectations.
The Fed said the two broadest money measures it follows rose in the week ended April 13. M-1, the narrowest measure, fell $1.1 billion.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 9915/32 , down 7/32 , to yield 8.04 percent, compared with 8.03 percent late Wednesday.
Prices of outstanding Treasury note issues, which had been lower early in the session, rallied to close slightly higher.
The 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered late yesterday at 9922/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 7.54 percent. And the 7 percent seven-year notes were offered at 9829/32 , up 2/32 , to yield 7.20 percent.
In the wake of the auction the new five-year notes also registered price gains. In late trading, they were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.87 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to slightly lower.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.66 percent, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged at a late offered rate of 3.83 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.07 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, J. P. Morgan Securities acted as lead manager on two debt offerings.
The investment-banking subsidiary of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was lead manager on a $200 million sale of 30-year debentures for Tyco Labs, and $200 million of 10-year subordinated notes for Kansallis Banking Group, a Finnish bank holding company.
The 9 1/2 percent noncallable securities were priced at $99.763, to yield 9.524 percent, 1.47 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing. The securities are rated Ba-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The $200 million worth of 10 percent subordinated notes sold by the Kansallis Banking Group were priced at $99.375, to yield 10.10 percent, 2.50 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The noncallable securities are rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities, traders said that prices of most widely quoted bonds fell by about 1/4 point.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of five-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: This Space for Rent: Red Square on May Day

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 23

 BODY:
Red Square is getting ready for a new May Day look. Posters of happy workers and peasants are out of fashion, as are giant portraits of Lenin, the founder of the Soviet state. This year, for its first post-Communist spring holiday, the city of Moscow is offering Red Square as a giant backdrop for Western advertisments, which will run from walls of the Kremlin to the airspace over the mausoleum where Lenin's body still lies in state.
The idea is just a week old and already an American company has expressed an interest in one-day monopoly rights to Red Square, for the round sum of $1 million, said an official at the Itar-Tass news agency, which is handling the account. 
 "A couple of companies have expressed interest in parts of the package, but one company has said they would like to buy the whole thing," said the official, Igor Makurin. Mr. Makurin is director of international business development for Itar-Tass, successor to the old Tass, which was once the official mouthpiece of the Kremlin.
By the whole thing, Mr. Makurin meant three sides of Red Square and two blimps flying above. To avoid assertions of disrespect, no advertising space is being sold by St. Basil's Cathedral or by Lenin's tomb. But a billboard will be available next to -- not on -- the Kremlin wall behind the traditional spectators' viewing stand, along the giant facade of the GUM department store, and down the side of the Moscow History Museum.
Each space has its own price, but the price for the whole is a non-negotiable $1 million, said Mr. Makurin, a former New York correspondent who said he had reactivated his old network of contacts to drum up business for the May Day extravaganza.
This year, the city of Moscow has decided to hold a big party on May Day rather than imitate the old parade of workers and Communist Party stalwarts who used to flock by the Lenin Mausoleum, waving posters and flowers at members of the Politburo lined up on top.
The festivities will be split between Red Square, the Manezh Square next to it, and the Alexander Gardens, which lie on the other side of the Kremlin. They will feature 3,000 performers, from the Bolshoi Theater to church choirs, who will play, sing and dance in five separate arenas, said Valery M. German, commercial director of the May 1 holiday.
With prices here rising almost weekly, the cost of the event soon stretched beyond the city's means, leading organizers this month to look for "sponsors." The word is common in Russia today as institutions, from schools to circuses, look for a magic solution to their financial crises. "Red Square is not for sale," Mr. German said, a bit defensively, "Sponsors of our holiday will simply have the right to display their advertising there."
After the holidays, which will turn into a long weekend for Russians, whatever is left from the $1 million the city hopes to get from the Red Square advertising will go back to the city budget, Mr. German said.
The main point of the holiday is to return to a traditional celebration of spring, which has been held on Red Square since the 12th century. "Until 1917 we had such celebrations, and now we have decided to return to them, after an unnatural interruption," Mr. German said.
Muscovites have already become used to buses and trolleys covered in advertisments for Pepsi-Cola and Camel cigarettes. Billboards for computers, chocolate bars and commodity exchanges are also commonplace. But organizers of the May Day event are conscious that advertisements on Red Square are likely to rub some people the wrong way.
Mr. Makurin emphasized that no one was interested in breaking taboos. "The mausoleum is not good for this kind of activity," he said, "but a commercial store like GUM? What is wrong with that? It is commercial district, and advertising is part of commerce."
"Some will be opposed," he said, "but then we are not voting for anything unanimously anymore. I don't think it will provoke any public discussion, or another revolution."

HEADLINE: Jobless Filing Fewer Claims

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Initial claims for unemployment benefits fell by 12,000 in mid-April, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said the number of newly laid off workers applying for unemployment insurance for the first time declined in the week ended April 11 to a seasonally adjusted 404,000. 
 The decline was the third consecutive weekly drop and pushed the number of claims down to the lowest level since 401,000 applications were filed in the week ended Oct. 5.
"We're now back down to a level consistent with employment growth," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
The four-week moving average, which many analysts prefer to track, fell to 427,250 in the latest report. It had been 438,000 the previous week.
 The Bush Administration, under criticism this election year for failing to do enough to improve economic growth, welcomed the report.
"America's labor market is looking stronger with each passing week," said Labor Secretary Lynn Martin. "It's not time yet to celebrate, but the three straight weeks of declining initial claims for unemployment insurance indicate that the fruits of the recovery are now reaching American workers and their families."
Still, many analysts believe that the overall jobless rate, at 7.3 percent in March, will not improve significantly for several months since employers often delay hiring until a lasting recovery seems sure.
The unemployment rate was 7.3 percent in February and March.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
American Express Net 76% Higher in Quarter

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
With its credit card business slumping, the American Express Company reported yesterday a 5.7 percent drop in first-quarter earnings to $249 million, or 51 cents a share, before an accounting change to cover income taxes.
However, after the accounting change, net income for the first quarter rose 76 percent to $465 million, or 95 cents a share, from $264 million, or 55 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. 
 Analysts described the quarter as part of an extended transition at American Express.
"We're beginning to see the first effects of some very important programs," said John Keefe, an independent securities analyst. While customer charge volume increased by 9 percent in the quarter, he pointed out, revenue from fees grew by only 5 percent, reflecting the cut in rates that American Express charges.
"They still have a long list of things to do, and they're about one-quarter of the way there," Mr. Keefe said. "There are big organizational changes that have to be made, that will ultimately be very healthy for the company."
Revenues at the financial services company rose to $6.68 billion from $6.34 billion.
American Express stock rose yesterday by 50 cents, to $23.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The earnings report was released after the market's close.
 
Shearson Is Leading Earner
 With the boom on Wall Street, American Express's biggest money maker has now become Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., its investment banking subsidiary.
Shearson's income before the accounting change rose 39.2 percent to $71 million, from $51 million a year earlier. Shearson's net in the 1992 period grew to $140 million, and its effective tax rate went to 48 percent from 20 percent in 1991's first quarter. In 1990, Shearson lost $966 million.
Shearson revenues, after paying interest expense, went up 16 percent to $1.6 billion from $1.3 billion in 1991's first quarter.
 
Credit Card Unit's Net Off
 In contrast to Shearson's performance, earnings at the Travel Related Services unit -- once the company's fastest-growing division -- declined 22.8 percent, to $125 million, from $162 million in the first quarter last year. T.R.S., as it is called within the company, includes the popular green card, as well as the company's other cards.
"What's interesting is that T.R.S. is running into difficulties just as the terrible problems at Shearson have been overcome," said Perrin Long, a securities analyst at First of Michigan in Detroit. "Difficulties at this stage are understandable. The company has had massive expenditures to keep at the forefront of the credit card business."
The company blamed increased marketing and promotion costs for the losses, which offset gains from lower interest rates. Competition among credit card businesses has been fierce, Mr. Long noted, and the travel business is likely to remain slow until the economy fully recovers.
At IDS Financial Services, the Minneapolis money managment unit, profits rose 19 percent to $61 million from $51 million a year earlier. IDS's mutual fund and annuitiy sales have risen steadily.

HEADLINE: A Reform Plan In California

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 23

 BODY:
A commission appointed by Gov. Pete Wilson to study California's deteriorating economy issued a stark warning today that the state faces a long-term decline in its competitiveness unless it undertakes sweeping reforms.
The bipartisan commission, which was headed by Peter V. Ueberroth, concluded that California "has real problems, and they are only going to get worse." 
 The commission recommended a series of reforms, most of which have long been discussed among business executives and elected officials and few of which stand much chance of being enacted soon.
Among them were recommendations that the state reform its workers' compensation insurance system, which is among the costliest and most fraud-ridden in the nation.
Other proposals included streamlining the state's regulatory processes to reduce the burden on business, and doing more to attract and retain industries that provide skilled, high-paying jobs.
Mr. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, who is often mentioned a possible Republican political candidate, said many of the problems were worsened by the paralysis of the state government.
"We need to remove impediments to business so they can grow and create new jobs," Mr. Ueberroth said.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Revival: A Shade Below Glorious

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The revival of United States manufacturing, one of the brightest spots in the 1980's economic landscape, may have been less spectacular than Government data have been showing.
New estimates from the Commerce and Labor Departments show that on three fronts manufacturing performance from 1977 to 1989 was more modest than previously thought. The output of American factories grew only two-thirds as fast; manufacturing's share of the economy is smaller, and the glorious gains in factory productivity previously reported now look less glorious. 
 The Labor Department now says, for example, that real output per hour in manufacturing grew 1.9 percent a year over the period, not the 2.7 percent in the old statistics.
"The revisions are large, and they change our view of the recovery in manufacturing," said Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, commented: "It's a more muted version of what we thought before. There was clearly a revival of productivity growth in the 1980's, and manufacturing is not disappearing."
But the new numbers, he acknowledged, show the revival "wasn't as robust as with the old measures."
The trouble with the old numbers is that the Government, in order to compare output in different years, uses prices in one year, the base year, to value gross domestic product over time. This greatly exaggerates the contribution of fast-growing industries, like computers, in which prices have been falling.
The new estimates are preliminary and some additional revisions, reflecting more detailed information on different manufacturing industries, are likely before the final figures are published this fall. Economists at the Commerce and Labor Departments warned that for technical reasons the new estimates might be understating manufacturing output in the late 1970's and early 1980's.
But Edwin R. Dean, associate commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said, "It does look as if -- after all the improvements in the data come in -- we will still have a slightly less rosy picture than we had before the revision."
The more subdued statistical portrait of the manufacturing rebound is likely to intensify the debate over the Reagan-Bush economic track record and provide new ammunition for those who argue that Washington should play a bigger role in industry.
"This will strengthen the momentum for industrial policy," predicted Lawrence R. Mishel, research director of the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research organization.
And Robert B. Reich, a political economist at the Kennedy School who is an adviser to Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the front-runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said: "Public investment is important. Efforts to improve manufacturing technologies may be critical. The question remains whether we can trust government with the job."
To be sure, the revisions do not wipe out the manufacturing rebound. Manufacturing productivity in the United States is still the highest in the world and still grew twice as fast in the 1980's as it did in the 1970's.
 
'Storm in a Teacup'
 "One should be wary of concluding that the share of manufacturing in the economy really declined," said Gordon Richards, chief economist at the National Association of Manufacturers. "This is a storm in a teacup."
The problem is that during the 1970's United States manufacturing productivity grew only about one- third as fast as among America's trading partners. And while the United States narrowed the gap during the 1980's, it did not -- as the old figures implied -- close it entirely.
The new manufacturing figures are the product of a major updating of the nation's core economic statistics. The results have been released piecemeal since December.
"The surprise was the magnitude of the effect on manufacturing," said Robert Parker, associate commissioner of the Bureau of Economic Analysis in the Commerce Department.
Earlier revisions of gross domestic product released in December showed that business investment, another yardstick of competitiveness, grew more slowly from 1977 to 1990 than the previous data showed and that investment's share of G.D.P. was no higher than in the 1970's.
"The revision of business investment was even more startling than the latest revisions for manufacturing," said Barry P. Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
 
Seemingly Innocuous Fix
 A seemingly innocuous technical change -- measuring inflation-adjusted G.D.P. and its components in 1987 prices instead of 1982 prices -- accounted for much of the downward revision in manufacturing output and productivity.
In order to be able to compare G.D.P. in different years, Government statisticians try to remove the effects of inflation by converting output reported in actual dollars into output in a single year's prices, say, the prices that prevailed in some base year. Periodically the base year is moved forward. In December, the Commerce Department switched from 1982 to 1987 prices in valuing inflation-adjusted G.D.P. but did not get around to restating the output of individual sectors of the economy like manufacturing.
Until recently the Commerce Department had been valuing a computer sold last year as if it cost the same as it did in 1982. But in fact, the cost of computing power has fallen by half, thanks to rapid innovation. "The computer on your desk that you bought for $3,000 would have cost $6,000 or more in 1982, " said Robert Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University.
"Not surprisingly the use of 1982 prices made the computer industry look twice as big relative to the rest of the economy." And since computer manufacturing was one of the fastest- growing industries, manufacturing's growth rate -- as well as those of investment, exports and imports -- were also exaggerated.
 
Computers and Productivity
 To give an idea of the large effect of computers on measured productivity, Mr. Mishel pointed out that productivity in durables manufacturing averaged 3.7 from 1979 to 1989 (using the old data). But productivity in computers grew 8.3 percent while productivity growth elsewhere rose at a modest 2.2 percent.
And indeed, Mr. Mishel said, the entire downward revision in manufacturing is caused by a lower estimate of durables output.
Statisticians had expected the shift from 1982 to 1987 prices to reduce growth in the 1980's. "Quite often using a new base will reduce G.D.P. growth because of sectors with lots of technological change whose prices are falling," said Mr. Parker at the Commerce Department.
But they were startled by the magnitude of the change.
"I knew there were going to be big effects, but I was surprised at how big," said Jack E. Triplett, chief economist at the Bureau of Economic Analysis. "If we had known how big we would have done something about it years ago."
 
Another Solution
 To prevent future surprises, economists at the Commerce Department have decided to solve the problem once and for all by publishing alternative measures to constant-dollar G.D.P. for the purposes of comparing changes in output over periods longer than a few years. The new indexes, sometimes called chain indexes, use a rolling average of different years' prices instead of prices of a single year.
The new indexes will not, however, displace the traditional constant dollar measures.
