HEADLINE: Amount of Cut Is Reduced In Dinkins Capital Budget

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City will cut its capital budget for long-term construction by 15.6 percent over the next four years, a move that will mean less money for jails, sanitation, parks and street repairs, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday.
But the $2 billion spending reduction was not as deep as the 30 percent cut of $3.7 billion that the Dinkins administration proposed in January as necessary to reduce the soaring debt service that the city pays on bonds used to finance the rebuilding. 
 The Mayor said yesterday that his budget aides had devised a way to restore $1.7 billion of the proposed cuts in the $10.27 billion capital budget but still reduce the interest and principal that the city pays on its bonds. Budget planning is done by the city for four-year periods, with specific budgets then issued for each fiscal year.
Details of exactly how the Dinkins administration plans to spend more on capital projects without increasing its debt payments were released for the first time yesterday as part of the Mayor's executive budget for capital spending.
 
'Still a Lot of Pain'
 By 1996, the city expects to spend 20 cents of every dollar in tax revenues to pay debt service on bonds, a figure that bond rating agencies have said is too high and must be reduced. City budget officials had estimated that the proposed $3.7 billion in cuts in the capital budget would save $250 million in debt service by 1996. They now say they will only have to cut $2 billion but will still realize the $250 million in savings.
"I'm pleased to announce a debt-service savings plan that will sustain the lion's share of our capital commitments without flinching from our original commitment to trim debt service by $250 million," Mr. Dinkins said. "There's still a lot of pain in this plan, but I believe that we have reconciled the need for bricks and mortar with the need for budgetary balance and sound management."
Under the Mayor's capital plan, the city will restore $1 billion in capital spending cuts by reconfiguring the timetables for building and financing the capital projects.
In the past, the city determined how many capital projects it could afford based on the higher long-term interest prevailing, even though some projects took less time to complete than others and generally were financed at lower interest. Now the city will plan all its capital projects based on their costs and duration, which budget officials said will allow them to pay for more projects.
Fiscal monitors, bond dealers and construction officials had expressed concern that deep cutbacks in capital spending risked damaging the city's fragile infrastructure even further and would hurt the economy, costing the city construction jobs.
 
Welcomed by Rohatyn
 Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier who heads the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up during the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's to sell bonds for the city, said yesterday that he was delighted that the Mayor had found a way to restore many of the capital spending cuts. "We think the restorations are good for the city and the economy," Mr. Rohatyn said.
As Mr. Dinkins noted, his capital budget does not come without pain. The city's capital spending will drop to $10.7 billion over the next four years from a planned $12.2 billion. The cut will mean that dozens of new schools will not be delayed and hundreds of low- and moderate-income apartments will not be built.
Cuts in the capital budget for highways will mean street reconstruction and resurfacing projects will be deferred, resulting in bumpier streets. And the city is also deferring jail construction, which budget officials said is less of a priority now because of a less crowding in city jails due to new efforts to speed court processing and send more inmates to state jails.
City officials said yesterday that capital spending on bridge reconstruction, courts, libraries and cultural institutions remained intact, as have water and sewer public-works projects, which are financed by separate bonds backed by water rates.
 
'Good News'
 "We have never sought to portray chicken filet as filet mignon," said Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, referring to the capital budget. "These restorations are good news, but all they mean is that we are not up against the wall as close as we were."
The Mayor's capital budget plan also restores $700 million for school reconstruction and repair by using state allocations for school rebuilding to pay the debt on the bonds that would finance the increased educational capital spending.
Budget officials said that in the past the city has not applied for its full share of the state education money, which is based on the amount of school rebuilding that municipalities undertake. The officials said the city has substantially raised its school capital spending in recent years and thus will qualify for a larger share of the state money.
Currently, the city receives about $40 million a year in state rebuilding funds, which the city has long used for general education spending. Budget officials said they expected the city to qualify for about $95 million of these state funds by 1996. They will continue to give $40 million to general fund but will use the additional $55 million for debt service.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
More Oil Companies Report Sharp Declines in Earnings

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 23

 BODY:
Three large oil companies, Exxon, Texaco and Occidental Petroleum, reported sharply lower quarterly earnings today. A large refiner, Ashland Oil, said it lost $9 million in the period.
Exxon's profit declined by 39.7 percent, while Texaco's plunged by 51.8 percent and Occidental's by 27.9 percent. Results at Exxon and Occidental were bolstered by special one-time gains unrelated to business operations. 
 The reports extend the pattern of depressed first-quarter operating results for the global oil industry, a result of recession in the United States, lower crude and natural-gas prices, and weaker profits in gasoline refining and chemicals. Amoco and Mobil reported sharply lower profits earlier this week, and Amerada Hess posted a loss.
Michael Mayer, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company in San Francisco, said industry profits should improve in the second half of the year if the American economy recovers as expected. Indeed, the price of leading oil stocks rose today, despite a slight drop in oil prices.
Mr. Mayer said he anticipated modestly higher prices for oil and natural gas, and stronger earnings for gasoline refining and chemicals in the United States. Companies reaping the biggest benefits from the turnaround will not be the global giants that generate most profits abroad.
Exxon's chairman and chief executive, Lawrence G. Rawl, said first-quarter profits were 21 percent higher than in the fourth quarter, with higher natural gas sales in Europe and improved profits in global chemical operations.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Exxon
 Net income for the world's largest oil company totaled $1.35 billion, or $1.07 a share, compared with $2.24 billion, or $1.78 a share, in the 1991 quarter. The company's revenues declined by 9 percent, to $27.91 billion from $30.68 billion.
The earnings for the Exxon Corporation, based in Irving, Tex., included $198 million in special items, with $115 million booked from asset sales and foreign tax credits amounting to $83 million.
Exxon's earnings in the first quarter of 1991 were the highest in the company's 110-year history, the result of sharply higher prices for refined products in the Middle East and Europe because of the Persian Gulf war.
But Mr. Rawl said the volume of oil and natural gas sales, as well as that of gasoline and other refined products and chemicals sold in the quarter, was stronger in each case than in the period a year ago.
Analysts had anticipated a 50 percent earnings drop and, perhaps because of the brighter results, investors bid up the price of Exxon's common shares. The stock gained $1.25, to $59.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
In exploration and production, Exxon's profits fell to $125 million, from $150 million, in the United States, but rose abroad to $785 million, from $721 million, because of the gains from tax credits.
Profits in foreign refining and marketing narrowed to $450 million, from $1.1 billion, and dropped to $23 million in the United States, compared with $256 million in the period a year ago. Profit margins in most regions were "significantly lower" than a year ago, Exxon said.
In chemicals, earnings slumped to $150 million, from $223 million.
 
Texaco
 At Texaco Inc., which is based in White Plains, net income was $200 million, or 68 cents a share, compared with $415 million, or $1.51 a share. The revenues for the nation's third-largest oil company, after Exxon and the Mobil Corporation, fell by 15.9 percent, to $8.56 billion from $10.18 billion.
The company said its average crude price in the United States fell to $14.48 a barrel, from an average of $17.66 in the quarter a year ago.
James W. Kinnear, the president and chief executive, referred to "difficult market conditions" that still prevail and restated Texaco's plan, announced last month, to pare capital spending this year by 10 percent because of weak markets and prices.
In the first quarter, capital spending fell to $641 million, from $791 million in the 1991 period, because of lower drilling activity in the United States and the British North Sea.
Earnings from exploration and production in the United States totaled $87 million, versus $204 million. Outside the United States, Texaco's profits fell to $53 million, from $78 million. Crude output rose in Indonesia and production began in a new field in China.
In refining and marketing, profits rose to $80 million in the United States, from $60 million, as gasoline prices increased by an average of 12 cents a gallon on the West Coast compared with a year ago. A pricing war pinched profits for refiners and marketers in the region last year. Worldwide chemical earnings fell to $9 million from $17 million.
Texaco's share price rose 87.5 cents, to $59.375, on the Big Board.
 
Occidental
 The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported net income was $98 million, or 32 cents a share, compared with $136 million, or 45 cents a share. Its revenues fell by 22 percent, to $2.15 billion from $2.76 billion, partly because of weak demand but also because Occidental auctioned several operations as part of a restructuring in the last year.
"As the economy improves, we will benefit from improved margins and continuing cost reductions," said Ray R. Irani, the chairman and chief executive.
The company's operating income fell by 36.8 percent, to $252 million from $399 million. Interest expenses fell to $153 million, from $209 million, as a result of lower interest rates and payments to retire debt.
Profits from the Los Angeles-based company's pipeline unit, which transports natural gas, rose to $141 million, from $126 million, but fell in three other operations. Chemical profits plunged to $31 million, from $139 million; oil-and-gas exploration earnings fell to $78 million, from $122 million, and coal profits were $2 million, compared with $12 million.
Occidental's share price rose 50 cents, to $19.625, on the Big Board.
 
Ashland Oil
 The $9 million loss for the large independent refiner, based in Ashland, Ky., compared with a profit of $26.5 million, or 48 cents a share. Ashland's total revenues rose by 4.6 percent, to $2.25 billion from $2.15 billion.
The company's refining unit, the Ashland Petroleum Company, lost $18 million from operations, compared with a $45 million profit. But the earnings at Ashland Oil Inc.'s Valvoline motor-oil unit more than doubled, to $11.6 million. Chemical profits rose slightly, to $24.8 million, and earnings from oil-and-gas exploration declined to $8.3 million, from $11.0 million.
Ashland's share price fell 25 cents, to $32.375, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Holding Vast Space and Vast Debt;
New York Lenders Shivering With Olympia & York's Ills

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
In New York City, no industry has wielded as much influence as real-estate, and within that community, no company in recent years has played a more prominent role than Olympia & York.
It is perhaps best known for having developed the World Financial Center office complex and its towering glass Winter Garden, with signature palm trees. Since the 1970's, the Canadian-based company has amassed over 22 million square feet of office space in Manhattan, nearly 10 percent of the total and three and a half times that of the next-largest commercial landlord. 
 At the same time, it has forged strong ties to the public sector through its hiring of highly regarded former city and state officials. John E. Zuccotti, a former first deputy mayor of the city, has been the head of Olympia & York U.S.A. since January 1990. And Meyer S. Frucher, the former president of the Battery Park City Authority and a longtime adviser to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, is an executive vice president of the United States subsidiary.
 
Crisis in March
 Given Olympia & York's prominent position in the city's business and social life, it is hardly surprising that its every move has come under close scrutiny since it conceded in late March that it had run out of cash. Real-estate brokers, the city's tax collectors, bankers, other property owners and companies looking to rent new office space are all closely watching the company -- and any possible response from the Dinkins administration.
When Olympia & York catches a cold, as the saying goes, others in the city stand to catch pneumonia. Banks could get even more skittish about making loans, especially to the real-estate industry. The city's tax base could suffer a loss in revenues, and potential tenants could shy away from Olympia & York properties, causing at least a short-term boost for office rents.
"This has big implications because you're talking about the biggest landlord in the city," said David Shulman, a managing director at Salomon Brothers.
It is too early to say exactly how the financial collapse of the Olympia & York empire will play out or the extent to which it will worsen the city's struggling economy.
The outcome will depend in large part on the position that the banks take toward the Reichmann brothers, who amassed the company's privately held real-estate empire. The brothers are trying to dissuade those who loaned the company money from engaging in a global scramble for secure assets, which would almost certainly result in its generally high-quality New York assets becoming encumbered. If it is successful, it may be able to minimize the turbulence.
 
Future Uncertain
 But even if lenders cooperate fully with the Reichmanns, backing them with new loans instead of demanding properties as collateral or forcing Olympia & York into bankruptcy, many said that life in the city would not be quite the same.
The biggest fear is that Olympia & York's troubles will make banks even less willing to lend. Citicorp and the Chemical Banking Corporation, both of which are based in New York City and are the largest consumer lenders in this market, have the largest exposures of any United States banks to Olympia & York, an estimated $500 million and $250 million respectively.
While Olympia & York executives have insisted that no bank will suffer any losses on loans, some banking analysts consider that scenario unrealistically rosy.
In the meantime, the concern is that troubles at Olympia & York, which had always been regarded as perhaps the banks' strongest real-estate borrower, will discourage banks from lending to others with lesser reputations.
"This will summon up existing fears about making new commitments to the real-estate area," said James McDermott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm that specializes in bank-stock research.
 
Credit Beginning to Loosen
 That cannot be good news for other property owners, who were already nervous about their bankers' willingness to roll over old loans as they came due. After several years during which many banks had simply stopped making loans to the real-estate industry, a few had finally begun to come out of their shells, partly under pressure from bank regulators.
"The biggest problem the industry has been having is the unavailability of credit," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. "We thought we had begun to see signs of improvement, but we think this will slow that down."
If access to credit continues to be denied to property owners, that could put more pressure on an already fragile real-estate market. In the worst-case scenario, more owners could be forced to default on loans, banks could have no option but to increase the number of buildings they foreclose on and still more properties could end up changing hands at fire sale prices. When these events have occurred in recent months, building values have fallen by about half.
The potential for further downward pressure on real-estate prices has the city's Department of Finance watching the Olympia & York situation closely. The city relies on property taxes for 45 percent of its total tax revenues. Manhattan office buildings play an especially important role in that equation: they account for about 30 percent of the total assessed value of all taxable real estate in the city.
 
City Tax Revenues
 Olympia & York properties, in turn, are an important part of that percentage. They are assessed at $1.3 billion, or 6 percent of the total for Manhattan office buildings. The company paid $142 million in property taxes last year, making it among the largest sources of commercial property-tax in the city. (The company also pays taxes on its corporate income, but those figures are not available to the public.)
Olympia & York is not delinquent on any of its property taxes, but the finance department fears that if real-estate values fall still lower, it would have to lower the values at which it assesses office buildings for tax purposes. The city already reduced the assessed value of commercial property by 12 percent this year. That did not lead to a corresponding decline in revenues, in part because tax rates were raised to make up the difference. But with a tax freeze promised by the Dinkins administration, there are limits to that approach.
"Of course I'm worried," said Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's finance commissioner. "If they went under, it could pull a lot else with it."
Real-estate owners and the city's tax collectors are not the only ones who could be harmed by Olympia & York's financial troubles. Companies seeking to rent office space may find, in a curious twist, that Olympia & York's problems make other landlords less willing to negotiate lower rents. That is because some prospective tenants are believed to have become wary about moving into Olympia & York properties, removing competition for other landlords who are trying to lease their vacant space.
 
Concerns Over Ownership
 Martin Turchin, vice chairman of E. S. Gordon, one of the city's leading brokerage firms, says he has already heard some clients express concern about whether Olympia & York has the resources to finance renovation work for new tenants or maintain its buildings. Also, tenants are generally reluctant to lease space in buildings where the ownership could conceivably change, especially in a bankruptcy situation.
"We represent several tenants who were seriously considering Olympia & York properties and say they won't now," said Mr. Turchin. As a result, the number of office-space alternatives those tenants are considering has dropped by half. "A significant amount of space is effectively off the market until the ownership question gets resolved and it becomes clear whether financing sources are available," said Mr. Turchin.
Of course, it is in the banks' interest to provide whatever assurances are necessary so that Olympia & York properties retain their attractiveness in the market. But Mr. Turchin notes that the banks are not the only parties involved: the company has several billion dollars of debt held by other public and private investors who may not be inclined to be so cooperative and whose presence will certainly make the negotiation process more unwieldy.
Given the potential damage that Olympia & York's financial problems could cause for the city, the Dinkins administration could decide to take some steps to help.
One issue that was already under consideration is whether tax incentives should be given to property owners in lower Manhattan to encourage them to convert older office buildings into residential or other uses. The city's planning department has identified about 6 million square feet of office space that could qualify.
 
Input to City Planning Office
 Robert E. Flahive, the director of the city's Manhattan planning office, said that none of Olympia & York's buildings fell into that category. But the company would clearly benefit if some of the excess office space in lower Manhattan were removed from the market. Over three-quarters of Olympia & York's properties are in lower Manhattan, a much higher proportion than other commercial landlords' properties.
Interestingly, the city's planning department is receiving input into its study of lower Manhattan from a private-sector group that has received significant financial backing from Olympia & York and is led by Mr. Zuccotti.
Mr. Flahive said that Olympia & York's recent problems would not have any effect on the pace or implementation of the planning study, but some are not convinced. Asked what implications Olympia & York's financial troubles had for the city, Mr. Shulman of Salomon Brothers cited, among other things, that "the city may have to offer tax concessions to provide help for lower Manhattan buildings."

HEADLINE: Union Coalition Supports Plan for Averting Layoffs

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
A coalition of unions representing Connecticut state employees approved a plan yesterday that would avert 3,200 layoffs by permitting the state to postpone $150 million in pension-fund contributions due this year.
In addition, the state will retrain and rehire many of the 336 workers who received layoff notices earlier this month, said Robert J. Krzys, the chief negotiator for the coalition, which includes teachers, office workers, health-care workers and state troopers. About $3 million will be set aside for training this year, with $2 million set for fiscal 1993. 
 The agreement, which is expected to be approved within a month by each of the 12 unions in the coalition, will prevent the layoffs planned as part of the $8.1 billion budget that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. unveiled in February. But the no-layoff promise only extends to the middle of next year.
"We would have been pleased to have a guarantee of no layoffs for four years," said Merrilee Milstein, vice president of the 9,000-member New England Health Care Employees Union, District 1199, which is based in Hartford.
The state's chief negotiator, Saranne P. Murray, said the Weicker administration welcomed the agreement. "We are particularly pleased that some of the new mechanisms for training and placing employees will mitigate the impact of layoffs," she said.
It is not the first time Connecticut's 45,000 state employees have had to choose between the benefits that go with their jobs and the jobs themselves.
In November, members of the state police union voted to delay a raise and other benefits that allowed about 111 laid-off troopers to be rehired. And other unions were locked in battle with the Governor for months last year over concessions he sought as part of his 1991 budget, which also imposed a personal income tax on residents. About 15,000 state workers ended up deferring a raise that some of them had already begun receiving.
The latest agreement, which was reached early Wednesday, is also subject to approval by the General Assembly.
 
Provision Rejected
 Last month, legislators rejected a provision of the Governor's budget that called for removing health-care and pension benefits from collective bargaining with the unions, whose contracts expire in 1994. The Governor had predicted $111 million in savings in the coming fiscal year, which begins on July 1, as a result of that change and reducing benefits in other ways, like freezing pensions and requiring workers to pay 20 percent of their health-care premiums, Mr. Krzys said.
After the legislature's Appropriations Committee scuttled Mr. Weicker's plan, the unions were told by legislators to make up the deficit, Mr. Krzys said.
The resulting plan lets the state delay some of the payments it makes toward the pension fund's projected future costs, known as unfunded liabilities, for workers who are not yet retired, Mr. Krzys said. The state will now pay $92 million, instead of $242 million, in the next fiscal year.
 
'A Re-amortization'
 "It's a re-amortization of the existing unfunded liability," Mr. Krzys said.
The retraining provision is expected to help most of the people who lost their state jobs this year, Mr. Krzys said. And those who cannot be retrained for jobs in state agencies that are hiring, like the Department of Correction and the Division of Children and Youth Services, will be guaranteed health insurance for the first six months that they are unemployed, he added.
"It's hard to say that everybody was fully satisfied with this, but there is a problem with pension funds," he said. "When you get into these budget pressures, the question becomes, can you find a way out while we're waiting for the economy to rebound."

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy? He Can Kiss It Goodbye

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., April 22

 BODY:
Reclining on a brown velour couch, David N. Demarest, one of New Jersey's newest wealthy citizens, fielded calls -- 6 in 10 minutes -- from accountant and broker types offering to help handle his first Pick-6 Lotto check. But after going bankrupt last year, the 51-year-old telephone installer and repairman said he had simple plans for the fat check sitting in his bank account.
"Some for my brothers and sisters," he said. "Some for my mother, of course, and my son and daughter. And my wife -- that is, ex-wife." 
 On Tuesday, Mr. Demarest and Derrick Webb, an unemployed aircraft mechanic from Newark, became the first of four winners in Monday night's state record-breaking $44.3 million jackpot to claim their initial prize of $440,523 -- the first of 20 annual checks.
They share the prize with Rosa and Adolfo Torres of Hillside, who came forward on Wednesday and had their winnings divided into seven checks, one for them and one for each of their six children. A fourth winning ticket was sold in Passaic County, where a group of office-workers in Wayne have said they hold the ticket and were waiting for the lottery commission to verify it.
 
Fancy Gadgets? Just Basics
 Whatever other lottery winners do, Mr. Demarest said, "I want to keep my life style."
Mr. Demarest said he had no desire to buy a fancy car, new clothes or new furniture. He may buy a Jeep Cherokee and give his 1987 Chevrolet Caprice wagon to his 22-year-old son, with whom he lives in a crowded one-bedroom condominium overlooking the New Jersey Turnpike. Then again, he may buy "something even more basic."
"When I bought my current car, I asked for manual locks, windows you crank up and down and a basic dashboard," he said. "I'm not a fan of fancy gadgets." He continued: "What winning means is that deep down, I know I have financial security. That's a good feeling."
In September, he may take early retirement from New Jersey Bell, where he has worked for almost 25 years. And then he might move to Colorado Springs, where his 19-year-old daughter and ex-wife live.
 
O Debt, Where Is Thy Sting?
 "We get along well," he said of his former wife.
While friends and co-workers keep calling him to tell him how lucky he is, the Metuchen native, who was divorced eight years ago, said his life had been trying in recent years. Credit-card debt and an ill-advised second mortgage on his home forced him into Chapter 13 bankruptcy, he said. He has been working overtime -- about 700 hours in the last year -- to help offset the $400 docked from his weekly paycheck to fulfill his bankruptcy obligation.
Like millions of others, Mr. Demerast said he had long pitched his hopes of financial security on winning the lottery. He has been playing $5 twice a week for several years and spent $50 for Monday's drawing.
"And I'm gonna keep on playing," he said. "People have been known to win twice."
His immediate plans involve going back to work for one day before a hernia operation on Friday, six weeks of recovery time and two weeks of vacation.
"People tell me I should get my phone number changed or move to avoid all the people who'll be calling me asking me for money," he said. "A lot of people want to give me advice. But I think I'll stay as I am."

HEADLINE: McDonald's Net Up 11%

 BODY:
The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 11 percent, fueled by strong growth overseas.
McDonald's earnings rose to $187.4 million, or 51 cents a share, from $168.5 million, or 46 cents a share, a year earlier. Quarterly revenue grew 4 percent, to $1.62 billion from $1.55 billion. Systemwide sales, which include franchises as well as company-owned stores, were up 9 percent, to $4.9 billion from $4.5 billion. 
 McDonald's stock rose $1.375 a share yesterday to close at $42.375 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
McDonald's management characterized the quarter's results as "excellent." The company said business in the United States benefited from its emphasis on lower-priced food, coupled with efforts to cut costs.
United States sales grew 5 percent and operating income increased by 7 percent. Revenue fell 1 percent as a result of the sale of some company-operated restaurants to franchisees; the company said such sales increased profits for the company, but lowered revenues.
McDonald's, which has been hurt by the recession and heavy competition in the United States, said that promotions like its N.B.A. basketball trading-card program helped build the company's domestic business in the quarter. "This marks a continuation of a turn for them in the United States," said Becky Barfield, an analyst with First Boston.
Ms. Barfield said McDonald's results were better than she expected, both domestically and abroad.
Hugh Zurkuhlen, an analyst with Weiss, Peck & Greer, commenting on the improvement in McDonald's operating income, said, "It hasn't been that good in five years."
Outside the United States, sales rose 14 percent, even though the company was hurt by weaker foreign currencies. Revenue increased by 10 percent. Operating income grew 19 percent. The company said profits would have grown by 23 percent if exchange rates had remained at 1991 levels.
McDonald's opened its first restaurant in Beijing yesterday. The two-story restaurant seats 700 people and is the largest McDonald's in the world. Jack Greenberg, the company's chief financial officer, said the restaurant served 40,000 customers yesterday.
Mr. Greenberg, the company's chief financial officer, said two important foreign markets, Britain and Canada, continued to lag. But he said that sales in Canada should get a lift next quarter from the national introduction of pizza there recently. "I'm hopeful about that," he said.
Fast-food sales were hurt by the recession, despite the improvement at the company, Mr. Greenberg said. "We're a little unsure of whether the economy is improving or not," he said. "It may be company specific."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Favorable Economic Data Fail to Give Dollar a Lift

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against major currencies yesterday despite better-than-expected news about the United States economy.
Gold prices retreated after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell 60 cents, to $338.70 an ounce. Later, the Republic National Bank quoted a bid of $338.10, off 30 cents. 
 Strong figures on the German money supply suggested that German interest rates would remain firm, dampening demand for the dollar, said Mike Faust, senior currency strategist at MMS International. The Bundesbank said money supply grew by 9.7 percent in March, above the target of 3.5 percent to 5.5 percent.
 
Remarks Hurt Yen
 In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6605 German marks, down from 1.6620 late on Wednesday. In Europe, the dollar fell to 1.6615 marks, from 1.6630 late on Wednesday.
The yen was hurt yesterday, dealers said, by the comments of David C. Mulford, Treasury Under Secretary, who said Japan had room to ease interest rates.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 134.15 Japanese yen, from 134.25 yen on Wednesday. In London, it later rose to 134.45 yen. The dollar closed in New York at 134.65 yen, up from 134.18 late on Wednesday.
The economic data released yesterday, however, did not move the market, Mr. Faust said. Currency analysts say the market will need a substantial change in the economic picture for exchange rates to react significantly.
"Foreign exchange traders aren't using slightly better-than-expected numbers to move the market," Mr. Faust said.
The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time unemployment insurance claims fell to 404,000 in the week ended April 11, an unexpected drop from 416,000 a week earlier and the lowest level since early October. And the Commerce Department said factory orders for durable goods rose 1.6 percent in March, a slightly bigger gain than anticipated.
In New York, the British pound rose to $1.7660, from $1.7625 late on Wednesday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7650, from $1.7630 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Crucial Issue Politicians Ignore

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
EVERYBODY, Republican and Democrat, wishes the Federal budget deficit would just go away. But it gets worse. The latest monthly Treasury statement shows that during the first six months of fiscal 1992, which began Oct. 1, the deficit widened to $196.88 billion, from $152.19 billion in the first half of fiscal 1991.
For all fiscal 1991, the deficit was $268.7 billion; this year the Administration projects it to climb to about $400 billion. That estimate reflects an anticipated on-budget deficit of $449.1 billion, offset by an off-budget surplus of $49.4 billion. 
 Much as the savings and loan disaster was minimized and dismissed in the 1988 election campaign, the swelling national debt is being largely ignored in the 1992 campaign.
But the facts are these: At the end of 1981, the gross Federal debt totaled slightly less than $1 trillion after 205 years of United States history. By the end of fiscal 1992, the Federal debt will have quadrupled to $4.08 trillion, according to Administration estimates. Just the interest on the public debt will reach $293 billion this year. And the gross Federal debt is projected to hit $4.5 trillion by the end of fiscal 1993.
Does it matter? Some economists, both on the left and the right, insist it matters little. Many monetarists say only money matters, and, if the debt is not monetized, there's nothing to worry about. Anti-government crusaders say big deficits may even be a good thing by forcing politicians to cut spending.
Some liberals insist conventional definitions of the deficit are wrong -- it's smaller than you think. Most tempting of all to politicians is the argument that if they just stimulate growth by cutting taxes, raising expenditures or both, the deficit will vanish. This was the original case for the Reagan tax cuts.
But a wide band of economists, including conservatives and liberals, still see the deficit as a root cause of the nation's economic weakness. A leader of this school is Prof. Benjamin Friedman of Harvard, author of "Day of Reckoning," a prophecy that appears to have come true in this long spell of recession, sluggish growth and personal income stagnation. In an unpublished paper, "Learning from the Reagan Deficits," he lays out the data to show the linkages between the deficits and the nation's eroding economic growth.
The Reagan cuts in marginal tax rates did not increase but reduced tax revenues, contrary to supply-side theorists. And lower tax revenues did not restrain government spending enough to prevent the soaring of the deficits to unprecedented heights, contrary to the anti-government ideologues.
The widening public deficits did not result in greater private saving, as some economists had predicted. Contrary to the so-called Ricardian equivalence theorem that public dissaving through the budget deficit would be offset by greater individual saving and higher business profits, private saving moved in the opposite direction, compounding the effect of bigger public deficits. Net national saving, which averaged 7.3 percent of gross national product from 1951 to 1980, shrank to 2.6 percent from 1981 to 1990.
In consequence, real interest rates -- nominal rates adjusted for expected inflation -- rose. As measured by the commercial paper rate minus the growth of the G.N.P. price deflator, the real rate of interest rose from an average of eight-tenths of 1 percent from 1951 to 1980 to 4.7 percent from 1981 to 1990.
The bigger budget deficits, drop in national savings and rise in real interest rates caused a sharp decline in investment. Net private domestic investment, which averaged 7 percent from 1951 to 1980, fell to 4.4 percent in 1981-90. The fall would have been even greater had it not been for the net inflow of foreign capital. But even with America's swing from creditor to debtor nation, the fall in its capital formation caused a decline in productivity growth and stagnation of real wages and living standards, and the United States lost competitiveness against foreign producers, in markets both at home and abroad.
On the issue of what is the correct definition of the budget deficit, Professor Friedman says it is not just the level but the "trajectory" of budget deficits that affect the economy's performance. Whatever the definition used, it must be applied to both the base and the terminal dates, and United States deficits have seriously worsened in the last dozen years.
The deficit remains the hidden issue of the 1992 campaign because of the political dangers to candidates of proposing solutions, whether by raising taxes or cutting entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare. If the deficit issue goes unaddressed, the United States will continue to be frustrated in attacking domestic problems and meeting its international commitments.
Weak in wallet, the United States cannot play its role as world leader or even effective partner. And, in an interdependent world, the United States cannot retreat to its home base without aggravating its economic problems.
The day of reckoning has arrived, but not yet in American politics.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Longtime Executive at Mead Is Selected for the Top Posts

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Mead Corporation, the large paper, wood products and electronic-publishing company, named Steven C. Mason, a 35-year employee and Mead's vice chairman, to be chairman and chief executive yesterday. Mr. Mason will replace Burnell R. Roberts, who has been chairman since 1982 and who plans to retire on May 6, when he becomes 65.
Mr. Mason, 56, came to Mead in 1957 in the company's white-paper division and worked in a number of engineering and manufacturing positions. For many years, he was general manager of Schoeller Technical Papers, which was a Mead subsidiary. 
 He was named executive vice president of Mead's paperboard group in 1975 and its president in 1978. He was named senior vice president of operations for the entire company in 1981 and served as president and chief operating officer from 1982 until last year.
Like other paper companies, Mead, based in Dayton, Ohio, was hard hit by the recession. The downturn particularly affected the commodity side of the business. The price of pulp dropped by more than 40 percent the last two years.
But Mr. Mason said that the company was seeing signs of a rebound and added that Mead planned to place a greater emphasis on its coated-board business, the cardboard products used in packaging beverages.
"We just finished a $580 million expansion of a facility that will double our production of coated board," Mr. Mason said in a telephone interview. "We think that will be an important area of growth for the company."
Mr. Mason said the company would see stronger sales and earnings in lumber and various paper products. "We look for a pickup, and, in fact, we're already starting to see it," he said. "Our electronic publishing business is off to a good start. We see a bounce in coated board, and lumber prices are going up again."
Mr. Mason graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology with a degree in mechanical engineering in 1957, and he completed the management development program at the Harvard Business School in 1973.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
A Rebound At Tandem

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CUPERTINO, Calif., April 23

 BODY:
Tandem Computers Inc. said today that it had returned to profitability in the second quarter after posting a big first-quarter loss primarily because of a restructuring.
The company, which makes "fault tolerant" mainframe computers with redundant parts to prevent crashes, earned $8.8 million, or 8 cents a share, for the three months that ended on March 31. That was 51 percent lower than net income of $17.9 million, or 17 cents a share, for the 1991 period. Tandem's revenues rose 3 percent, to $502.9 million from $489.3 million. 
 Earnings were down from the 1991 quarter because the company's costs and expenses rose more than the modest gain in revenues, said George Elling, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Research in New York.
Mr. Elling, who had expected earnings of up to 5 cents a share, said he was "cautiously optimistic" about Tandem's report.
Tandem, like other makers of large computers, was hurt by the recession. In the first quarter of 1992, Tandem lost $94.6 million after taking a $98 million charge for layoffs and other restructurings to help cut costs in an increasingly competitive market.
"We are pleased that our efforts to restructure Tandem did not disrupt our business and are beginning to show results," said James G. Treybig, the president and chief executive.
He said domestic business was up, suggesting that the United States recession may be dwindling, but business was mixed in Europe and down in Asia, usually a strong area for the company, he said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Get Two Signs Of Better Days Ahead

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
For the New York Mets, the 13-inning victory was sweet. The fact that a fielding play and a pitching performance produced a feeling that two of their players were coming of age in new roles, made a long afternoon of baseball all the more special yesterday.
The fielder in question was Dave Magadan, a first baseman turned third baseman who tries to win a bigger portion of the job as well as win over skeptics every time he steps onto the field. Yesterday, he took huge leaps toward the latter goal in the Mets' 1-0 victory over St. Louis. Turning in an exemplary performance, Magadan especially took charge in the 11th, making two key plays as the Mets wriggled out of a no-outs, bases-loaded jam. 
 The pitcher who benefited from the defense was Jeff Innis, a reliever forcing his way into consideration as a setup man with a growing series of gutty performances.
Innis started off shakily when Ozzie Smith, a pinch-hitter, singled off Innis's glove. Another hit would follow, then a walk in which Ball 4 was nearly a wild pitch. Just as the fans started to turn on Innis, the pitcher started turning on the Cardinals, first getting Todd Zeile on a chopper to the alert Magadan, who charged and threw Smith out at the plate.
Then came Pedro Guerrero, a free swinger who more than matched his reputation on this day. Innis, staying far away from the strike zone, threw pitches high and outside to the Cardinals' first baseman. Guerrero, swinging wildly, missed once, fouled off a ball, then missed again. "You're thinking, just get one guy, just get one guy," Innis said. "Then you think, if he's going to wave at those pitches, you're going to have a chance."
"No excuse," Guerrero said. "I'm just terrible" -- or words to that effect.
The inning, though, was far from over, Innis knew all too well. "That's when you have to bear down," he said. "You can't relax because this kid, Jordan, is a pretty good player." Jordan, a rookie in this game, a starting defensive back in the National Football League, looks like the real thing at many turns. But, on this occasion, he could do no more than ground sharply to third. Again it was up to Magadan and again, sure-handed and with a true throw, he got his man, gunning out Jordan at first.
 
'It Was a Roller Coaster'
 Magadan, modest in his assessment, professed to be grateful just to have been in the game at that point, having avoided being lifted for defensive purposes. "I felt they had confidence in me," he said. As for the two plays, he said: "Those are the kind that I need to make. They help change everybody's feelings about the situation."
Innis knows the feeling. For he turned doubters into believers in the course of one inning. "It was a roller coaster, everybody booing, then cheering," he said. "Any time you get out of something like that, it's new life. You're expected to give up at least one run, maybe two. It would have taken the wind out of our sails."
But Innis helped prevent a major deflation. And though the official victory would go to a teammate two innings later, it was Innis who could count himself the biggest winner. For the pitcher who wandered through last season in virtual obscurity, with no victories, no saves, continued to shout his presence. Now 2-1 with a 3.12 earned run average, his April is turning out to be as impressive and improbable as his holding action was in the 11th inning yesterday.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Trashing the Saudis

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Where there's a juicy news leak, there's usually fire. But sometimes there isn't.
The juicy leak in question was a Los Angeles Times article. It said the Saudis had been trafficking in illegal transfers of U.S. arms to Iraq and Syria. 
 The principal purpose of the leak was to dampen the Bush Administration's apparent fire to sell Saudi Arabia 72 potent F-15 fighter-bombers.
But the leakers did not know a central fact: President Bush had already decided against asking Congress to approve the F-15 sale this year -- though the $5 billion order would preserve defense jobs in an ailing economy and though he believes the Saudis should have the planes.
Why would Mr. Bush refrain from doing what he believes is right and good politics? The answer is also politics and good policy, as you will see when you hear out this story.
About the L.A. Times report, it is enough to say that the leakers falsely accused the Bush/Reagan Administrations of failing to notify Congress of the illegal Saudi transfers, and that they wildly exaggerated the Saudi sins.
The leakers wanted to hurt Mr. Bush. But their main aim was to show that the Saudis could not be trusted with advanced U.S. arms, that such arms would find their way to outlaw states. The truth is that Riyadh's record is no worse, and maybe even better, than most U.S. arms buyers.
The leakers' goal was to stop the F-15 sale. And they had good reason to think the sale would go forward this year. The Saudi Air Force, inspired by its U.S. counterpart, was pressing for a decision. McDonnell Douglas, the manufacturer of the F-15, was lobbying hard for the order to keep open its production line. George Bush was worried about unemployment, and would especially not want to see jobs lost among supporters in the defense industry.
But there were countervailing considerations neglected by the leakers. All worked decisively against the sale.
Mr. Bush could not ask Congress to bless the sale before mid-May. He has scheduled a little-noticed Mideast arms control conference for that time in Washington. To go ahead with a $5 billion sale of advanced fighter-bombers in the face of such an unprecedented meeting would make him an international joke.
Nor could Mr. Bush beard Congress before late June. That is when Israeli elections will be held, and Prime Minister Shamir would use the sale to show a Bush tilt toward the Arabs. Israeli voters would probably share Mr. Shamir's resentment and re-elect him and his hard-liners -- against all Mr. Bush's hopes.
Nor does it make sense for Mr. Bush to test this issue before November. Whatever the polls show, he is running scared and does not want to further irritate American supporters of Israel.
Mr. Bush had something else up his sleeve, which the leakers seemed not to know. King Fahd of Saudi Arabia had sent word that he was in no hurry about the sale. He did not want to put his friend George Bush in an awkward political situation. Unsaid, the King also has a cash problem.
The Saudis can afford to wait. They understand that Congress would not approve the sale in an election year anyway. More importantly, they appear to have Mr. Bush's private assurance that he will press for approval if re-elected.
But whatever promises have been made and whoever the next President is, the sale will be a tough issue. True, the Saudis have been helpful in the current peace process with Israel. And they do need and merit U.S. military support for their perilous position as neighbors of Iraq and Iran. Also, even if the U.S. refuses to sell high-performance aircraft, others have before and will again.
On the other hand, the version of the F-15 sought by the Saudis would give them a new and powerful attack capability against Israel. And the sale would surely undercut efforts at Mideast arms control -- which deserve a full run before any big new arms sales.
Meantime, the leakers of the L.A. Times story got their just desserts. They planted a phony tale and were found out. Had they waited for the right moment to unload their trash, they could have muddied the debate.
In their haste, they lost. And Washington gained a better chance to grapple fairly with this critical security issue next year.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Premature Favors From the Mayor

 BODY:
Graced with a modest budget surplus, Mayor David Dinkins now promises to keep New York City libraries open longer and build new health clinics. It's hard to quarrel with his impulse to provide these and other worthy programs. He has been plagued from the beginning with nothing but bad economic news. And the city could use a lift.
Even so, the Mayor's generosity sends the wrong signal. The city is still in recession and must have the cooperation of its unions and the Legislature to balance next year's budget. By hinting now that good days are here, Mr. Dinkins undermines his own efforts to enlist the help he needs. 
 The city's surplus of $455 million, which will eliminate some city borrowing next year, is only a tiny fraction of the city's $29 billion budget. It represents some prudent cost-cutting and planning, pessimistic forecasts, higher state aid and a bit of good luck. But it's hardly proof that New York's recession is over.
The benefits Mr. Dinkins announced are not all that expensive -- about $50 million. But by announcing them before he presents his entire budget for the next fiscal year on Monday, he distorts their importance and encourages the unions and legislators to make their own demands. The unions want a piece of the surplus and legislators want the city to shrink its proposed tax package and provide more financing for mass transit and higher education.
New York needs more concessions from its unions, not fewer. And without the $115 million in taxes it wants Albany to approve, the city will have to cut more to balance its budget. But how can union leaders ask sacrifices from workers who read about budget surpluses? And how can legislative leaders ask lawmakers to vote for higher taxes when the city seems to be doing well?
The first rule of politics is not to embarrass potential allies. The second is to get priorities straight -- in this case getting the Legislature and the unions on board first, and indulging in good-news politics second.
Unions and legislators know the city is still in difficult straits. But by pursuing short-term benefits, Mr. Dinkins opens his credibility to question and hurts his efforts to get help for next year.

HEADLINE: Ross Perot, One-Way Wizard

 BODY:
Millions of Americans fed up with drift, deficits and overdrafts think they've found a savior in Ross Perot, the $2.5 billion man who'll run for President if enough people ask him. Mr. Perot's sudden notoriety springs partly from public disaffection with traditional politics. But it also owes much to the fact that not much is known about Ross Perot. Like the Wizard of Oz, he has been an amplified one-way voice, untested and unchallenged.
True, it's hard to turn on the TV and not find Mr. Perot. But as Bill Clinton told reporters the other day, "You all haven't had the chance to put him through the meat grinder." The tough questions are sure to come when Mr. Perot formally announces, transforming the idea of Ross Perot into a living candidacy. 
 Little is known, for example, about his views on foreign affairs. Mr. Perot opposed the Persian Gulf war -- Kuwait's regime, he argued, wasn't worth the risk -- and he favors aid to the new Soviet republics. He also argues that America will be weak abroad if it's weak at home: "You can't be a superpower unless you're an economic superpower." But it's not clear how that translates into policy. More free trade? Patrick Buchanan-style protectionism? Japanese-style industrial policy?
He's clear on one point: The nation risks permanent decline unless it balances its books. He offers two challenging prescriptions: a Paul Tsongas-like proposal to save money by making cuts in benefits to wealthy seniors and in the defense budget. His other ideas are warmed-over or wishful. He'd save $100 billion with more efficient tax collection (Michael Dukakis tried that one). He'd trim $180 billion in waste and abuse (Ronald Reagan's annual promise). Poof, end of deficit.
He's outspokenly pro-choice but maddeningly vague on other issues like taxes and drugs. Cleaning up the drug traffic, he says, will be a "dirty deal. It won't be pretty." Meaning what?
How Mr. Perot would govern is also a mystery. Newsweek called the Perot campaign "talk show democracy," and Mr. Perot himself has said he'll use "electronic town halls" to help him shape policy in the White House. He and various experts will lay out options, and voters will punch in their choices. That would reduce the influence of messy intermediaries -- Congress, for example -- which, he believes, clog and corrupt the system.
"Once you decide what needs to be done," Mr. Perot explains, "you go to the American people and say, 'It's up to you, folks.' "
There's something disarmingly attractive about this. It suggests efficiency. It suggests citizen democracy on a massive scale. But it is not always easy to tell from Mr. Perot's words exactly who's going to be leading and who's going to be led.
Furthermore, the partnership he envisions assumes a President more interested in listening than manipulating. Is Mr. Perot a listener? As an executive and concerned citizen, he was often bold and creative. He was also, by many accounts, autocratic and thin-skinned.
Who Ross Perot is matters as much as what he believes. The country is largely ignorant on both counts. It's one thing for him to flourish simple answers. It will be another when he has to start answering Americans' hard questions.

HEADLINE: The Part-Time Education President

 BODY:
President Bush says he'll make education his top domestic priority in his second term. Second term? He pledged that en route to election in 1988. Yet from the start his ideas have lacked conviction and scope. His latest proposal focuses on only one slice of the problem and seems derivative, too.
As part of what appears to be a "theme of the week" re-election campaign, Mr. Bush said he would give all Americans a $25,000 line of credit for education through the Student Loan Marketing Association. The credit would be available to anyone, from the student taking full-time courses to the retired worker taking a single class. The interest rate and repayment schedule would be determined on the basis of income. 
 Increasing access to education is a fine idea. But Mr. Bush's embrace comes long after Bill Clinton offered a similar plan -- a government trust fund that would lend money to anyone wishing to attend college. Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, loans would also be repaid on a sliding scale based on income, or through a term of national service.
Mr. Bush's version won't have any impact on the Congressional debate over reauthorization of student financial aid programs. Both the House and Senate have passed bills; a conference to reconcile differences is set to begin soon.
The proposal, hurriedly served up during a primary campaign trip through Pennsylvania, reinforces the suspicion that Mr. Bush's interest in education remains more rhetorical than real. He has never seriously addressed issues of equity like overcrowded classes, deteriorating buildings and underpaid teachers. Instead he has concentrated on giving parents more flexibility to choose schools.
It's easy merely to pronounce yourself the education President the first time around -- and it gets easier every time you do it.

HEADLINE: At the Bar

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
They have names like Mabel, Juliana, Beatrix, Isabel, Cecily and Margaret. They lived, became pregnant, and died six or seven centuries ago, and they presumably lie forgotten in English country churchyards. But they all made history, and as the Supreme Court weighs the future of abortion rights, that history is being reconsidered.
If Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania v. Casey is any indication, the High Court is not just liked but well liked. A total of 25 "friends of the court" filed briefs in the case, which was argued Wednesday. Two came from clashing sets of legal historians, each of whom found support for their positions by poring over parchment. 
 The first was written by Clyde Spillenger of the University of Wisconsin Law School on behalf of 250 American historians, with the help of Jane E. Larson of Northwestern University Law School and Sylvia A. Law of New York University Law School. It argued that Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision declaring abortion a "fundamental" constitutional right, is deeply rooted in the country's history and tradition.
Professor Spillenger contends that abortion was known and tolerated from America's earliest days, and was eventually outlawed not out of moral qualms or concerns for the fetus, but by a consortium of turf-conscious doctors, husbands who viewed their wives as vassals and vessels and immigrant haters fearful of "race suicide."
When the brief first appeared, the weekly newspaper Legal Times speculated that the heavy emphasis on precedents from early New England was a not-so-subtle pitch to Justice David H. Souter, one of the few remaining swing votes on the issue and a man who, until his recent move to Washington, spent his entire life within an hour's radius of Boston. This notion was denied by Roger Evans, Planned Parenthood's director of litigation.
A contrary view is put forth by Joseph Dellapenna, a professor of law at Villanova University, on behalf of the American Academy of Medical Ethics. Professor Dellapenna reaches back even further, at least to the 13th century -- to demonstrate, as he put it, "that abortion and other killings of unwanted children were condemned by all respected legal authorities in England from the start of the common law."
He, too, cites cases, including those of the women mentioned above. He also offers a macabre tour of early abortion technology. Old abortion-inducing drugs included castor oil, ergot of rye, hellebore, tansy tea and thyme. There were more lethal agents -- aloes, arsenic, rat poison, snake venom -- as well as a host of ineffective "abortifacients" like goat dung, raw eggs and hops.
Throughout the 19th century, Professor Spillenger writes, American courts uniformly ruled that women seeking an abortion committed no offense, at least as long as the fetus was not yet "quick." Even in the age and milieu of Hester Prynne -- that is, the tightly knit, religiously homogenous communities of early New England -- cookbooks contained recipes for common abortifacients. Abortions were common, and increasing, when the Constitution was drafted, a time when one in three New England brides was pregnant.
But as the 19th century progressed, he continued, a variety of forces combined to curb abortion. One was concern for the health of mothers, understandable in light of the prevailing barbaric practices. Another was that abortions were seen as threatening to male authority. A third was the medical profession's wish to protect its economic interests against encroachments by unlicensed practitioners.
A fourth was nativism: the fear that white, prosperous Protestants were not having enough children to maintain long-term hegemony over more prolific Roman Catholic immigrants. Largely absent from the debate, he maintains, were moral qualms about the practice or an insistence on the personhood of the fetus.
By contrast, Professor Dellapenna claims that criminal indictments for abortion are recorded as far back as the year 1200. While many of these prosecutions were eventually dismissed on other grounds, there were clear indications that punishments were meted out.
These attitudes, Professor Dellapenna said, carried over into the New World. In Maryland alone, he writes, there were three abortion prosecutions before 1660. In 1683, a Rhode Island woman received 15 lashes for fornication and attempted abortion. As for charges that 19th-century anti-abortion statutes were largely the handiwork of psychologically or economically threatened men, he notes that many prominent feminists had moral qualms about abortion.
One of them, he noted, was Margaret Sanger -- one of the founders of Planned Parenthood.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 30, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
The "At the Bar" column on the Law page on Friday referred impreciselyto the authors of a brief submitted by 250 historians as "friend of the court" in Planned Parenthood of Southern Pennsylvania v. Casey, the abortion rights case now before the United States Supreme Court. It was written jointly by Clyde Spillenger of the University of Wisconsin Law School, Jane E. Larson of Northwestern University Law School and Sylvia A. Law of New York University Law School.

HEADLINE: Rohatyn Warns New York City It Risks Loss of Millions in Aid

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn, yesterday demanded to know how New York City had generated a budget surplus. He also warned that if the city increased the size and cost of government, it would risk losing at least $100 million in aid he has promised, and maybe more.
In issuing the warning, Mr. Rohatyn joined an angry chorus of municipal labor leaders in pressing the city to explain how it managed to produce a $455 million cushion in the budget for the fiscal year that ends June 30. But he did so with precisely the opposite objective: Labor now wants raises from the city, while Mr. Rohatyn insists it cannot afford them. 
 "What is most troubling to me is that it seems that what's happened has really jeopardized, if not destroyed, the ability for the city to come to an overall long-term understanding with its unions that deals with the reality of the situation," Mr. Rohatyn said. "And I think that's a terrible cost which we're all going to have to pay for over a long time."
Mr. Rohatyn's warning came at the end of a roller-coaster week that started with Mayor David N. Dinkins announcing that he had found enough savings to renew some programs previously cut, then finished with the unions and legislators accusing the Mayor of having cried wolf to win concessions and state aid from them, only to learn that City Hall had eked out a surplus.
For months, Mr. Rohatyn has urged the city to craft a long-term plan for shrinking the size of government, tempting it with the prospect of borrowing hundreds of millions of dollars using the assistance corporation to ease the pain. But the two sides could never agree on terms, and the administration now hopes the surplus will enable it to abandon the borrowing plan, as well as efforts to satisfy Mr. Rohatyn, and begin charting its own course.
Still, Mr. Rohatyn, who is appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and has dominated municipal finances since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, retains considerable sway. The city is counting on the $100 million in aid he has already promised to help balance its $29 billion budget for the coming year. Without it, the city would have to make deeper spending cuts or find new money. Mr. Rohatyn also controls another $200 million in corporation money that the city wants to use as a bargaining chip with the unions in exchange for improved worker productivity.
"We fully expect him to honor his commitment," First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said, adding that the Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, and the new Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Barry F. Sullivan, would meet with Mr. Rohatyn to discuss his concerns. Mr. Steisel said they would also discuss a plan Mr. Rohatyn is pressing to have the assistance corporation issue new bonds to help finance long-term construction projects for the city.
Speaking on condition of anonymity, city officials said they believed Mr. Rohatyn was trying to perpetuate his influence one way or another.
Mr. Rohatyn's stand against union raises might seem to ally him with City Hall, since the Mayor contends that all of the surplus will be needed just to replace hoped-for Federal aid that was not won and avoid the costly borrowing deal that Mr. Rohatyn first supported, then opposed.
But in the strange world of the city's budget, it is not that simple. The city was first able to reduce the borrowing plan -- and thus minimize Mr. Rohatyn's influence over its affairs -- because he promised in February to give it $100 million, which he generated by refinancing some of the corporation's bonds to take advantage of lower interest rates. Now, Mr. Rohatyn wants to make sure that by giving the money, he will not lose leverage in his campaign to force the city to cut costs permanently.
He was concerned enough about protecting that leverage that he made two unsolicited telephone calls to The New York Times to state his case. He is worried that the surplus -- patched together from higher than expected tax revenues and tight cost controls -- will put political pressure on the Mayor to abandon his vow to grant raises only in exchange for greater efficiency and make more cuts in the size of the work force. In fact, the Mayor is to announce on Monday that he expects to trim the payroll by about 3,500 fewer jobs over the next four years than he previously announced, due mostly to greater hiring for special education and social services.
 
'Perfectly Good Faith'
 "We're going to ask the question, "What did the city know and when did it know it?' " Mr. Rohatyn said, adding that he has asked the Budget Director, Mr. Michael, to explain the surplus to the corporation's board next month to satisfy them that the $100 million in aid was not obtained under false pretenses.
"It may well be that at the time, they really didn't know, and were acting in perfectly good faith," Mr. Rohatyn said. But in the past, he said, the assistance corporation has provided money to the city for one purpose only to see them used for another. He said he wants to make sure that does not happen again. For years, mayors have wrangled with Mr. Rohatyn over the use of money controlled by the corporation, which was set up to borrow on the city's behalf in the last fiscal crisis, issuing bonds backed by the city's sales-tax revenues.
Mr. Michael said the city had been candid with Mr. Rohatyn about its plans for using assistance corporation money, and had told him in February it expected a surplus of $150 million or more. The full extent of the surplus became apparent only in recent weeks, he said.
"We're doing precisely what we said we were trying to do in February," Mr. Michael said. "Everyone should be applauding."

HEADLINE: President to Ease Rules on Sale of Public Property

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
President Bush will issue an executive order next week making it easier for state and local officials to sell public assets like airports, roads, bridges and sewage treatment plants to private businesses, White House officials said tonight.
Plans for the order are the latest move in a campaign of deregulation and privatization driven in part by the Administration's ideology but also aimed at showing a President coping with domestic issues in an election year. 
 Only today, the Administration announced new steps in a continuing effort to lighten regulation of financial institutions. At the same time, White House officials said Mr. Bush was expected to announce next week an extension, into the summer, of the 90-day Government regulatory moratorium he ordered in January as one step to fight economic sluggishness.
The order dealing with local governments' sale of public property was first reported tonight by NBC News. In confirming plans for it, White House officials said its main provision entailed giving such governments a financial incentive to let private business take over some of their assets.
 
How the Incentive Would Work
 Airports, sewage treatment plants, bridges and other installations operated by local governments are often built with the help of Federal money. Under current Federal rules, Washington is entitled to a share of the proceeds from the sale of such property.
For example, if the Federal Government paid 60 percent of the cost of building a local airport, it may be entitled to 60 percent of the proceeds. That kind of provision discourages the local authority from selling.
Speaking on condition of anonymity, White House officials said tonight that the new executive order would reduce the share of the proceeds to be paid to the Government. The Administration has not yet settled on a formula that will determine that share.
Administration officials said the Government would not lose any money under the arrangement because the current regulations are so restrictive that hardly any sales now take place in any case.
 
Response by Governors
 Asked about the effect of the new order, James L. Martin, director of state-Federal relations at the National Governors Association, said he was not aware of any great desire by governors to sell state-owned properties to private investors.
Similarly, Michael W. Brown, a spokesman for the United States Conference of Mayors, said he had not heard much discussion of such sales. "This issue has not hit our agenda as yet," Mr. Brown said.
But an Administration official said the President's order would give local officials an incentive to put the issue higher on their agenda. "In general," said this official, "we think it's good to privatize government services."
Indeed, like the Reagan Administration before it, the Bush Administration contends that many government activities can be performed more efficiently, at lower cost, by businesses.
Independent assessments have questioned that premise, however.
The General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative and auditing arm, warned in November that "the Government should not contract out its responsibilities to serve the public or to exercise its sovereign powers."
Specifically the accounting office said that several Federal agencies, including the Transportation Department, the Energy Department and the Environmental Protection Agency, had probably gone too far in hiring private contractors to perform Government functions. The accounting office said that many tasks being contracted out by those agencies were core Government responsibilities and that in any case the use of contractors sometimes cost more than if the agencies performed the work themselves.
As for the steps announced earlier today on lightening regulation of financial institutions, the most significant was the issuance of a final rule by the Environmental Protection Agency to protect lenders from financial liability for damage to the environment caused by their borrowers. Some lenders fear that under Federal law they may be held responsible for the cost of cleaning up contaminated properties.
The American Bankers Association welcomed that action, saying it would help banks that lend to such businesses as dry cleaners, gas stations and farms.
The Administration also announced a program to establish uniform policies for Government examination of financial institutions. The four Federal agencies supervising such institutions agreed to work together to overcome what the White House called the "balkanization" of authority.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says a C-130 Was Hit by Gunfire From Peru

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 24

 BODY:
An unarmed American military transport plane, flying on a routine counter-drug mission off the northern coast of Peru, was fired on by a Peruvian Air Force plane this afternoon, a spokesman for the American Embassy said this evening.
One crew member was missing, reportedly falling out of the plane when a door on the C-130 transport plane was blown open by the machine-gun fire from the Peruvian aircraft. Two other crew members were reported wounded, one superficially. 
 The C-130 managed to land at an air strip in Talara in the northern coast of Peru near the Ecuadoran border, said the spokeman, Donald R. Hamilton.
Mr. Hamilton said the American Ambassador, Anthony C. E. Quainton, had called President Alberto K. Fujimori about the incident and expressed "alarm and concern."
 
Apology From Fujimori
 Mr. Hamilton said that Mr. Fujimori had apologized for the incident and that the President said he would begin a full investigation.
"Exactly what happened is not yet clear to us," Mr. Hamilton said, adding that Ambassador Quainton was on his way to Talara. "It was a routine flight and clearance for the flight had been granted."
The incident happened about 5 P.M. Lima time. The plane, based in Panama, was hit by one of two Peruvian Air Force planes. Mr. Hamilton said that the aircraft was unarmed and that there were no radio warnings before the attack.
The Pentagon did not release the identity of the missing crew member or either of the wounded. It was not known how many were on the plane when it was hit, but Mr. Hamilton said it was a small crew.
The C-130 is a principal transport planes for the United States Air Force and many are used by the military in Latin American.
Peru has recently been nervous about its northern border with Ecuador and southern border with Chile. For decades there have been border disputes between the countries that at times have brought them close to conflict.
Pentagon officials said the United States military base in Panama had dispatched a plane with emergency medical and repair equipment to the landing strip in Talara.
When President Alberto K. Fujimori seized broad powers on April 5, he explained the move as necessary to fight the Shining Path guerrilla movement. Today, claiming a major strike against the guerrillas, Peru's counterterrorism police provided details today of a series of raids in which they shut down El Diario, the clandestine newspaper that had regularly circulated the directives and views of the Maoist revolutionary organization.
The announcements, dribbled out Thursday and today, assert that 23 suspected staff members of the paper were arrested and printing presses and paper were seized in operations on April 13 and 14 in southern Lima. The announcements reflected the most dramatic Government move against the guerrillas since President Fujimori seized broad powers.
The Government continued to face upheavals. This afternoon, Foreign Minister Augusto Blacker Miller resigned, as did the Minister of Industry, Commerce, Tourism and Integration, Victor Joy Way. Prime Minister Oscar de La Puente assumed the office of Foreign Minister, and Jorge Camet, a businessman, was sworn in as Industry Minister.
The future of Carlos Bolona was still uncertain. His resignation as Minister of Economy and Finance, submitted earlier this week, was withdrawn, officials said..
As the police proudly proclaimed their achievement, independent experts on the Shining Path acknowledged that suppressing the paper was a blow to the guerrillas. But they said the success of the raids owed nothing to the President's decision to suspend Parliament and curb the judiciary.
"Capturing El Diario doesn't need a coup or new laws," said Diego Garcia-Sayan, head of the Andean Commission of Jurists, a human-rights organization. "It just shows that one of the few organizations that is efficient here is Dircote," he said referring to the anti-terrorist unit.
During the news conference, the police paraded the accused Shining Path members in front of journalists. The police said typewriters, presses, two Macintosh computers and large amounts of Shining Path literature were confiscated.
"Shining Path has been affected in an important way," Interior Minister Juan Briones Davila told reporters. Dircote officials said the next issue of El Dario had been planned for April 15.
Some of the independent experts said they did not think the paper would be out of business permanently.
"If you look at what was seized, it was all easily replaceable stuff," said Gustavo Gorriti, author of a book on the Shining Path. "The Shining Path needs a newspaper now. I'd say it will appear within two months, maybe within a month."
In recent years, El Diario had become the main propaganda and communication organ for the Shining Path.
El Diario carried speeches by and interviews with the Shining Path founder and leader, Abimael Guzman, also known as President Gonzalo. Shining Path would also use El Diario to explain why it killed certain people. Experts studied each issue to identify shifts of policy, mood or strategy.
A legal radical left-wing paper in the 1980's, El Diario was slowly infiltrated by Shining Path sympathizers and eventually taken over. As an illicit organ, the paper claimed a circulation of more than 5,000. It was not sold openly on the streets of Lima, but it could be bought in some neighborhoods and was sent through the mail.
Among the 23 suspected members of the "cell" that published El Diario, the most important figure, experts say, is Jorge Duran Araujo, considered the director of the operation. Mr. Duran is the brother of Maximiliano Duran, a known Shining Path leader who is based in Paris and raises funds and promotes the group's causes in Europe. Maximiliano Duran is considered a likely successor to Mr. Guzman.
