HEADLINE: Exiled Haiti Leader Urges Tougher Oil Sanctions

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Calling for stronger sanctions against Haiti's military-backed Government, the nation's ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, urged the world yesterday to establish "a real blockade" by tightening an oil embargo.
On a visit to New York, Father Aristide made his appeal at a news conference at City Hall after a meeting with Mayor David N. Dinkins. Emphasizing that Father Aristide was Haiti's first democratically elected President, the Mayor pledged to "do all we can to assure that he is returned to office." 
 In a statement, Mr. Dinkins accused Washington of failing "to intervene and help this democratic movement in its moment of crisis." And the City Council issued a proclamation saluting "President Jean-Bertrand Aristide for his continuing efforts on behalf of the disenfranchised of Haiti."
When the exiled Haitian leader was asked what was needed to make the economic sanctions against Haiti's military rulers more effective, he said: "Without petrol, those who led the coup cannot resist. That should be just a question of days."
In the first action to enforce the embargo since the coup in September, the United States seized a tanker in Puerto Rico on March 31 after it delivered 250,000 gallons of diesel fuel. The Associated Press reported yesterday that officials in Washington said the Administration was considering additional steps to restore democracy in Haiti, including a tightening of the oil embargo.
Questioned about the devastating effect of sanctions on the Haitian people, Father Aristide said that to have democracy restored in Haiti, the people "accept these big sacrifices" and "say yes to the embargo."
He said the main obstacle to the return of democracy is "a gang of thugs in the army, those who led the coup, who still have the same weapons." For that reason, he said, Parliament was not free to ratify the political agreement promoted by the Organization of American States.
Addressing the human-rights situation in his country, Father Aristide said more than 2,000 people had been killed since the Sept. 30 coup and asked why the world had not done something to stop "this tragedy."
When asked by a Haitian television reporter if he had any doubts about his return, the deposed President said: "Tell them I will be back. In my mind there is no doubt."
Father Aristide and Mr. Dinkins are expected to attend a rally organized by New York's Haitians at the Great Lawn in Central Park tomorrow beginning about 3 P.M.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Are Higher

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 24

 BODY:
Japanese stocks ended higher today as institutional buying and bargain-hunting propelled prices in the run-up to a weekend meeting by the world's leading industrial powers.
 But brokers also said that profit taking checked the market's gains. 
 The 225-share Nikkei average closed at 17,542.45,, up 140.40 points, or 0.81 percent, with about 300 million shares changing hands.
 The Nikkei ended at its highest level for a week, though still 38.24 points below last Friday's close.
 "A rumor that Japan may lower interest rates further following the G-7 meeting in Washington gave afternoon sentiment a boost," said Masahiko Tsuyuzaki of Tachibana Securities. The G-7, or the Group of Seven industrial nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- meets this weekend in Washington.

HEADLINE: Abortion War, Buffalo Front: Top Guns Use Battle Tactics

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, April 24

 BODY:
Several days into a long-planned struggle over abortion rights here, leaders of the national anti-abortion group Operation Rescue took stock of the battlefield and saw less than a victory. The skirmishes in Buffalo did not bode well for their next major target, the Democratic Convention in New York City this July.
So they called in reinforcements. "We got the word," said a regional director from the West Coast. The other side was using a strategy to defend the clinics here that had been successfully used in California. 
 "So they called us in as tactical team," said Dave Conrardy, a field coordinator with Operation Rescue's Los Angeles office.
 
Lessons Learned, Defenses Hold
 Their mission: counter clinic defenses coordinated by Katherine Spillar, the Los Angeles-based national coordinator of the Feminist Majority, who six weeks earlier had come to Buffalo to instruct abortion-rights advocates on the lessons learned in other states.
So far, those defenses have held. Though hundreds of anti-abortion protesters spilled into Buffalo through the week, willing to go to jail to make their point, Operation Rescue did not shut down any abortion clinics here this week. Even so, both sides in the debate say the real showdown should come on Saturday.
With the United States Supreme Court hearing arguments this week about a Pennsylvania law that would impose restrictions on abortions and possibly give the Court an opportunity to reverse the abortion rights established by Roe v. Wade in 1973, Buffalo has become the human battleground in the emotional debate.
 
Setting Course for Many Issues
 Protesters on both sides of the police lines believe the resolution of the abortion issue will set the course for a broad spectrum of future political decisions varying from the rights of homosexuals to the definition of pornography. As a result, the top guns on both sides of the debate have descended on this gritty northern city, tying up phone lines and dominating the nightly news.
A National Organization for Women board meeting was hastily moved from Florida to the front lines in Buffalo. N.O.W.'s past president, Eleanor Smeal, shuttled between her Washington office and defense lines outside the clinics here. Elizabeth Holtzman, the New York City Comptroller and a candidate for the United States Senate, made the shorter trip from New York.
In a week of protests here a small army of praying, chanting and crucifix-bearing supporters have snarled traffic in parts of Buffalo, put the city's collective nerves on edge and attracted the attention of television cameras and reporters from across the country.
More than 250 people have been arrested, including more than 70 anti-abortion protesters who were arrested today. Most of those arrested have refused to post bail and are still in police custody.
 
A Floating Chess Game
 For both sides, the issue is an extravagant, moving chess game that shifts from city to city.
The Rev. Paul Schenck, a 33-year-old Assembly of God pastor and major figure in the local Operation Rescue effort, speaks of the need for a "spiritual revolution" that could return the United States to a "pro-family" nation. He talks of an America in which families are defined by "the overt leadership of a father-husband and the covert leadership of a mother-wife."
Ms. Spillar says she believes the Operation Rescue effort is nothing more than a thinly veiled drive to undercut women's rights in all their forms. "They want women to put their aprons back on and retreat to the kitchens," she said. "They are very threatened."
 
Partly Sport, War and Show
 It is difficult to say if the stylized, highly coordinated demonstrations this week were more sports event ("Hey, hey! Ho, ho! Boot 'em out of Buffalo!"); military maneuvering ("Let's go for a diversion in the front, then slam through their rear") or travelling road show replete with souvenirs.
But both sides call this war. And to wage it, each has used its own armies of the morning. Before dawn, Operation Rescue volunteers gather at a church outside Buffalo to pray and plot their strategy. Team organizers hand out maps and sometimes speak in codes that refer to "rescues" where they hope to prevent a woman from obtaining an abortion. They pray for strength and perseverance. They prepare themselves for arrest.
As the Operation Rescue volunteers meet, abortion-rights supporters with Buffalo United for Choice, a group formed specifically to counter Operation Rescue, handle six phone lines at their command center and jot down notes from reports coming in from the field.
 
Training Sessions and Spies
 Outside, downtown and in nearby Amherst, volunteers conduct 5 A.M. training sessions, linking arms and running through mock exercises to repel physical assaults. The morning's crop of volunteers are warned of tactics used by Operation Rescue in the past and taught how to counter them. Their ranks are infiltrated, too, by Operation Rescue supporters sent over on reconnaissance. Each side acknowledges that it spies on the other and is spied on.
By dawn, the movements begin. A convoy of up to 100 cars heads into the city. Another, perhaps, goes toward a clinic in the suburb of Amherst. Radios crackle and the chants begin. In the cold morning air, site leaders chat with "peacekeepers" wearing orange vests. Quadrant leaders monitor the area of the defensive line to which they have been assigned, give pep talks and review instructions with the 50 to 100 clinic defenders gathered outside.
Their fear is that the Operation Rescue workers will be able to chain themselves in front of the clinics and jam the entrances. Volunteers are warned not to let even police officers through without a trained escort from the Pro-Choice Network, to prevent confusion.
When the protesters arrive, the struggle starts. Abortion-rights supporters shout about Nazi tactics and call the protesters facists. Feet away, "Spring of Life" volunteers respond with prayers and shouts of "murder."
Coordinators of each group stand on the sidelines, refining tactics, moving volunteers and barking orders into cellular phones. Some approaches work only briefly. Early in the week, the Rev. Joseph Slovenec, a Cleveland Heights pastor who is one of Operation Rescue's regional leaders, was surrounded by abortion rights advocates, to "keep him away from his flock." By Thursday, Mr. Slovenec had solved that problem, arriving at a demonstration outside the Erie Medical Center with two cellular phones -- one pressed to each ear.
 
An Odd Staging Ground
 Buffalo, a quiet industrial city no longer in its prime, is an odd staging ground for this battle. Yet there was a certain inevitability to the confrontations. "Operation Rescue had an interest in Buffalo for three years," said Mr. Schenck. "We had a good, strong pro-life political base. We had a strongly pro-life Catholic base." The question was always 'when,' not 'if.' "
Late last year Operation Rescue was publicly welcomed by Mayor James Griffin. And organizers eager to find a warm-up site for even larger protests scheduled during the Democratic Convention agreed to start on April 20. The announcement was made about Christmas, giving both groups 16 weeks to prepare.
Mr. Schenck, a longtime friend of Operation Rescue's national coordinator, Randall Terry, who has not appeared at the demonstrations, said that the Operation Rescue movement grew out of a 36-hour prayer meeting in Binghamton in 1987.
Protests started in 1988, at the Democratic Convention in Atlanta. From there, it moved on to California, where it faced organized resistance.
"We decided we had to devise a clinic defense strategy," to prevent protesters from gaining access to clinic entryways, Ms. Spillar explained. Opponents of abortion lay down in front of clinic doors and chained themselves together and to building fronts. "They were only using about 500 people," said Ms. Spillar, "yet they were creating the impression in the media that there was a massive grass-roots anti-abortion movement in the country, when there was not."
When Operation Rescue began protests in Wichita last summer, abortion-rights supporters offered the clinics help. The Kansas clinics said they preferred to let the police handle any crisis alone. In fact, the police could not. The protests continued for 46 days with several clinics being closed down and 2,600 people arrested. Abortion-rights supporters vowed it would never be repeated.
 
Volunteers Mobilize
 Thus, when the current "Spring of Life" protest was scheduled, there was a flurry of phone calls to Buffalo from people offering to help. At first, the reaction was tepid. The Pro-Choice Network, which had supplied escorts to Buffalo area clinics during four years of picketing here (and at least 454 arrests of abortion opponents), wanted to ignore the protests.
But eight other groups banded together with thousands of volunteers and formed Buffalo United for Choice (B.U.C.). Fund-raising events and mailings started immediately. Training and tactics came later.
Mr. Schenck and other leaders, meanwhile, prepared their side. Seven breakfast meetings with clergy members were held to drum up support. Volunteers were found to house as many as 1,000 anti-abortion protesters. And financing was sought for the $2,500-to-$3,000-a-day expenses.
While leaders on each side carry broad notions of what is at stake here, those who come to pray or shout on the sidelines come for reasons of their own.
Lucille VanZandt of Ann Arbor, Mich., a 33-year-old mother and child care worker, stood with her head bent in prayer with Operation Rescue members outside the Erie Medical Center on Thursday. She was there, she said, because she had an abortion years ago and never recovered from the experience. "I didn't know the Lord Jesus then," she said.
Not 20 feet away, Darcy D. France, a 31-year-old social worker and mother of two, said: "I made a very tough decision one day in my life. I had just finished school and I was unemployed. It's a terrible decision. But I don't want anyone dictating to me what I should do with my body."

Okoniewski for The New York Times)(pg. 28)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Beer Dispute Compromise Being Sought

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
American and Canadian trade negotiators tried to strike a compromise this evening on a dispute over beer that has disrupted supplies on both sides of the border and become increasingly irritating in diplomatic relations. The talks broke off tonight and are scheduled to resume on Saturday.
Administration officials said that if no agreement could be concluded quickly, they would have to announce punitive duties on Canadian beer imports. These imports have dropped off sharply since April 14, when the United States confused and angered Canadian breweries by saying it was considering whether to impose much higher duties and make the increases retroactive. 
 The United States has been seeking the elimination of many marketing rules set by Canadian provinces to protect local breweries. The Bush Administration contends that these rules unfairly restrict American beer sales there, and it most recently set a deadline of July 1 for a solution.
 
Alcohol Taxes Are Debated
 Canada has complained that Federal and state alcohol taxes in the United States have unfairly limited Canadian beer sales, but this issue is being negotiated on a separate and slower track.
The United States imports about $150 million worth of Canadian beer a year, or less than 2 percent of the overall American market. But high-priced Canadian beers, like Moosehead, Labatt's and Molson, hold larger market shares in Northern states, including New York, and in affluent urban areas where more people can afford them.
The United States and Canada had not expected to deal with the issue until later this spring. But they were forced to act quickly when the seemingly minor announcement last week by American officials about the increase in duties had the unintended effect of shutting down much of the cross-border beer trade, hurting companies on both sides.
 
Retroactive Penalty Duties
 The Bush Administration announced last week that if it eventually imposed steep penalty duties on Canadian beer imports, the duties would be collected retroactively on all Canadian beer crossing the border after April 12.
American trade officials said at the time that they wanted to prevent Canadian breweries from shipping thousands of gallons of beer across the border into United States warehouses to beat the imposition of new tariffs. But Canadian companies, led by Moosehead and Labatt's, responded by cutting off many beer shipments because they did not want to risk owing enormous duties later that might wipe out their profits.
The Canadian breweries' decision prompted the provincial liquor purchasing agency in Ontario to stop buying American beer last week, angering breweries south of the border. The National Beer Wholesalers Association, a trade group based in Falls Church, Va., then entered the dispute on Thursday of this week, publicly threatening a lawsuit if the issue was not sorted out.
 
Compromising Under Way
 Even before the threat of litigation emerged, Administration officials had already concluded this week that they would at least have to announce the level of tariffs quickly. The intention was to reassure Canadian breweries that the duties would not be astronomical while allowing them to start including higher beer duties in their prices.
Also this week, the Canadian provinces offered to accelerate their liquor industry reforms to meet American demands. Like previous Canadian offers, this proposal was made not to American negotiators at the Office of the United States Trade Representative, but indirectly through the National Security Council.
Both the trade office and the security council are part of the White House, and Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, officially outranks Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser in the Administration hierarchy. But Derek H. Burney, the Canadian Ambassador, has developed a friendship with Mr. Scowcroft during annual economic summit meetings, and Mr. Burney has been using the relationship to argue that trade frictions hurt overall relations between the countries, Administration officials said.

HEADLINE: Hard Choices for Russians

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 24

 BODY:
After nearly 75 years of deliberate isolation, Russia is expected to rejoin the world economy next week, when it should be formally accepted as a member of the International Monetary Fund. This is occurring at a critical time for President Boris N. Yeltsin, who must make some politically difficult decisions to keep his vaunted economic reform moving.
Without these decisions -- primarily to restructure the bulky industrial economy and thereby bring about the inevitable displacement of thousands of workers -- the reform could fail to go far enough to get the billions of dollars of aid being prepared by the I.M.F. and Western nations. Russian leaders know that to receive the much needed Western aid, they will have to submit to I.M.F. discipline and tighten the collective economic belt ever tighter.
 
Credit Is Expanded
 But already some serious signs of slippage have occurred in Mr. Yeltsin's program of economic reform. Aware that the sudden rise of prices without a similar rise in income has led to widespread grumbling, the Russian Government in recent weeks has begun to loosen up on its tight-money policy. 
 Timed to the recent Congress of People's Deputies meeting, where criticism of the free-pricing reform was expected, Mr. Yeltsin and his top economic adviser, Yegor T. Gaidar, allowed incomes to rise and expanded the supply of credit to enterprises.
These steps have caused concern in Washington and Western Europe, where leaders are pressing Mr. Yeltsin to be politically bold in letting Mr. Gaidar's reform plan go ahead. Leaders of the Group of 7 industrial nations, which have promised billions of dollars of aid, also gather in Washington this weekend, with the state of Russian reform high on their agenda.
Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gaidar have promised Western leaders and the international lending agencies that the recent loosening of tight money and expansion of credits -- after only three months of the reform -- are temporary, and that the reforms will continue despite a verbal battering over the last two weeks from conservatives in the Russian Parliament.
Today, for instance, the Russian Government announced that there would be a 150 percent increase in the price of gasoline at the pumps, making a full tank roughly equivalent to a week's wages for the average person. Under the new rules, producers of oil can sell it to distributors for 2,200 rubles per metric ton, or about $18 at the current exchange rate. This is triple the current domestic price of 720 rubles per metric ton, or $6, but only a fraction of the world market rate of $148 per metric ton. Western economists have urged the Russian Government to raise their oil prices to the world level to bring in more income and avoid waste.
But other than price increases, which had begun to level off in some areas, and in fact had led to some modest improvement of supplies of food in some locales, there has been almost no structural reform of this distorted economy, Western diplomats and bankers say.
 
Unprofitable Concerns Survive
 In particular, large unprofitable state enterprises, once the bellwether of Soviet industry, are staying alive, thanks to continued credit, both from the state and one another, and have done little to make themselves efficient or profitable. The Government has done little to privatize them, or to create competition in an economy structured around huge factory complexes that were monopoly producers of goods from light bulbs to tractors and tanks.
If such structural change is going to happen, as Western experts believe it must, many large enterprises will have to reduce their workforces sharply and alter their products or go bankrupt.
This would be more painful than the price rises that began in January, increasing the political cacophony from the Congress of People's Deputies.
Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gaidar emerged relatively unscathed from the recent two-week session. While it tested the will and relative political strength of major social forces, it actually represented only a first round in the struggle for the future of Russia and the reform.
"Gaidar promises that the essence of the reforms will continue," a senior Western diplomat said. "But how you define 'the essence' is crucial. And that leads to the real question: Can the Government stick with it, now that reform will start getting really painful? Was the Congress a tactical trimming, or the beginning of a collapse of will?"
 
Bankruptcies Feared
 Over the next three months, he said, if reforms are pursued and the loosening of credit is not followed by further loosening, large enterprises will start to go bankrupt, throwing employees out of work. The Congress will come back into session, and then the problems will really begin to mount.
In an effort to balance political survival and reform, Mr. Yeltsin made some pre-emptive concessions to so-called conservative forces -- representing the bureaucracy and the managers of large state enterprises and collective farms -- before the opening of the Congress on April 6.
By loosening credit, postponing increases in energy prices and sanctioning a bigger budget deficit, Mr. Gaidar diluted the economic discipline considered vital to the reforms, and to Western support for them.
As a result of these concessions, deficit spending will rise in the second quarter of the year from 1.5 percent of gross domestic product, which is roughly 5 trillion rubles, to 5 percent. That includes 200 billion rubles in increased credits designed for state enterprises engaged in key activities like energy production and food processing.
However well designed to prompt growth in an economy that has shrunk for four years now, this increased spending has sparked public expressions of concern from people like Michael Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, who worry that increased credits may become a habit.
 
Ruble Stabilization Demanded
 Speaking Thursday in Washington, Mr. Camdessus said Russia would have to carry out credible economic policies, including control over credit and realistic interest rates, to qualify for promised Western aid of some $24 billion, including a ruble-stabilization fund of $6 billion. "That could take some time," he said, since Russia and the I.M.F. must still agree on strict financial targets in a formal lending plan, which must itself be in place before any ruble-stabilization fund can be instituted.
What worries Western experts is the lack of change in large enterprises, which employ millions of workers and waste millions of rubles.
The enterprises are still living off credit and avoiding hard economic choices. Some are simply paying their workers without producing anything, while others are producing but neither selling nor lowering their prices in response to falling demand, because they fear higher inflation to come.
If the Government's credit spigot remains open, the result will be hyperinflation, which will make stabilizing the ruble almost impossible.
 
Respect for Yeltsin's Courage
 Despite the concern, there is respect for Mr. Yeltsin's courage.
Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gaidar had to begin somewhere to stabilize an economy in free fall, make the ruble convertible, privatize state enterprises and demonopolize manufacturers, all vital to a market economy. They started with prices, which had come to bear no connection to costs. The price reform in January has produced better supplies in some sectors. After rapid increases, market forces have started to work, and some prices have begun to come down.
This is also true outside the major cities, but shortages still exist. The newspaper Trud did a survey of 132 Russian cities in March and the first week of April, and found that price rises have slowed, while beef, sausage and onions have become cheaper in some towns.
But on the day of the survey, there was no beef at all in 11 cities, no fresh fish in 108 cities, no vegetable oil in 34 cities, no hard cheese in 48 cities and no cottage cheese in 34 cities. In 10 cities, the paper said, there was no bread.
Some Westerners have made much of the huge private bazaars in the major cities, where private citizens sell food, drink and clothing. Today, for instance, there were at least 6,000 people buying, selling and gawking around Red Square alone.
But the mentality of the market has yet to take hold among the mass of retailers, who still work for the state. Western diplomats are frustrated with the refusal of many shopkeepers to lower prices to encourage sales -- of beef that is about to go bad, for instance. Not paying for the meat themselves, shopkeepers have no great incentive to increase sales or cut losses.
In the meantime, wages continue to drop in real terms, despite increases to try to adjust for higher prices. But this is also considered necessary pain. If wages rose faster the prices, inflation, already about 30 percent a month and which Mr. Gaidar wants to bring down to 3 or 4 percent a month, would grow even faster.

HEADLINE: Natori Planning to Cast a Wider Net

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO

 BODY:
Who would have thought that a successful career in stocks and bonds would prepare someone for success in the world of nighties and slippers?
But Wall Street is where Josie and Ken Natori acquired the business expertise to assault the frilly pink and white domain of lingerie with bold colors, prints and appliques. Then they popularized innerwear-as-outerwear, finding a broad new market for bodysuits, leggings and nightgowns beyond the bedroom. 
 Now, the Natori Company is trying to crack markets that are already crowded. The company plans to make lower-priced lingerie and to take on an assortment of licensees to produce Natori underwear, Natori travel accessories, Natori fragrances, Natori sheets, Natori tableware, Natori jewelry and Natori furniture. There will be Natori boutiques throughout the United States, and more Natori everything for sale in foreign countries.
The company aims to grow from $28 million in sales last year to $100 million by 1996, with half of that from licensed products. Customers will be able to live a full Natori life style. Ralph Lauren, are you listening?
Already among the most influential figures in their field of fashion, Josie and Ken Natori now face some calculated risks in extending their reach. Like the economy in general, the intimate-apparel industry is growing only slowly. Donna Karan's new lingerie line will collide with the Natori line, where prices average $120. And the success of Victoria's Secret and other makers of moderately priced lingerie pose a challenge for Natori's new Josie label, with prices averaging $20 to $30.
"She's going to have a more difficult time with the Josie line because she'll be competing with people like me and other firms that have a solid ground in this area," said Norman Katz, president of the I. Appel Corporation and chairman of the Intimate Apparel Council. And Mrs. Natori might be competing with herself, he continued, adding: "The question is can she maintain a look for Natori and a look for Josie? If Josie looks too much like Natori, why buy Natori?"
But in the fashion industry, where many entrepreneurs begin with imaginative designs but no money sense, the Natoris still count on their business background to give them an edge.
"It was good that I wasn't just a designer," said Josie Natori, 44 years old, who rose from stockbroker to vice president in investment banking at Merrill Lynch before changing careers. "I started a business with an understanding of the mechanics of business, of economics and cash flow. I don't know how anyone can survive without that."
Her husband, Kenneth R. Natori, 48, was senior executive vice president of the brokerage then called Shearson American Express before he become his wife's business partner in 1985. He is now the lingerie company's chairman, responsible for operations, finance and licensing. Mrs. Natori, as president, is far more visible, focusing on the creative side.
 
Philippine Connection
 Having Josie's father, a Philippine contractor, build the company's factories in the Philippines allowed Natori to pursue a distinctive style based on traditional Philippine embroidery and appliques. In competition with established lingerie companies like Christian Dior and Fernando Sanchez, Mrs. Natori has created a comfortable niche at the upper end of the $7 billion lingerie industry. "She established herself as the prime designer of better intimate apparel," Mr. Katz of I. Appel said.
The Natoris are, above all, experts in marketing themselves. They manage to go out several nights a week to fashion industry events and charity parties. Josie's French couture wardrobe -- her business uniform is a tailored jacket by Dior, Pierre Cardin or Yves Saint Laurent, with a short skirt and high-heeled pumps -- and outgoing personality have added to her visibility. She flies around the country for store appearances and frequently jets over to Paris, where the Natoris have had a boutique and a showroom since 1987. Their products are currently sold in 40 countries.
"Josie knows how to present herself," Mr. Katz said. "When she goes into a store for a personal appearance, her personality really comes through to the consumer."
 
Starting With Nightshirts
 The Natoris share a spacious corner office decorated with fresh flowers and Chinese celadon plates on stands. Mr. Natori sits at an antique partners' desk with a leather top while Mrs. Natori uses a modern one topped with black marble. They are so seldom in the office together that they celebrate their few lunch dates by bringing in seafood salad and white wine.
It all started when Mrs. Natori imported a few embroidered shirts from the Philippines. She visited a Bloomingdale's buyer, who suggested she lengthen them into nightshirts. She quit her job, flew to Manila in May 1977, and by August had assembled a small collection of nightshirts.
"We did it slowly, initially showing in our apartment," Mr. Natori said. "On Saturday, I acted as a butler, serving wine to her buyers."
The cold-calling skills Mrs. Natori learned as a stockbroker came in handy for calling on department stores. In April 1978, the business had grown enough for the couple to spend $200,000 of their savings to open a small showroom on East 34th Street in Manhattan. The business has grown so much that the company now has a whole floor, plus a design studio in a building around the corner.
 
New Evening Wear Line
 A new evening wear line, called the Josie Natori Collection, evolved out of a meeting in 1990 with Lynn Manulis, the president of Martha International. "She started showing me bodysuits and this georgette nightgown, and I said, 'Let's take this out of the bedroom,' " Mrs. Manulis recalled. "I said, 'Let's do a small collection of bodysuits, leggings and nighties that go out.' "
The timing was right, as lace bras and beaded bustiers to wear in public were showing up in fashion collections.
The Josie Natori Collection also soon attracted Bergdorf Goodman and Fred Hayman. After a year and a half of working on the line herself, Mrs. Natori decided earlier this year to hire a fashion designer and broaden it into a collection of dressy evening sportswear, not just lingerie to wear out. Prices range from about $160 to more than $2,000.
 
Approach to Licensed Products
 For licensed products, the Natoris spend years honing their approach before turning production over to an outside company. They made their own bed coverings for four years before licensing another company in 1990 to make their sheets, towels and comforters. They have recently put together a presentation of their wallpaper and home fabric ideas, the first step in establishing a full range of furniture, rugs and tableware.
The Natoris keep a close eye on their licensed products, overseeing design and sales. "The most important thing we have to franchise is our name, and we protect it at all cost," Mr. Natori said.
Bestform Foundation Inc. of New York has made bras, panties and the like for the Natori line and is about to introduce the moderately priced Josie products.
Despite stronger competition as the company appeals to a broader market, Mrs. Natori said that stores reacted so favorably to the Josie line's initial offering in March that it should surpass her expectations. "We had projected to do $5 million the first year," she added, "but now we expect to do $8 million."
 
Negotiations Abroad
 Not that the Natoris will rely on just the domestic market. They are negotiating with a Spanish company to open a Josie boutique in Madrid and to develop a European catalogue. And in mid-May they expect to sign contracts with Pola Cosmetics, a $2 billion Japanese company, to open Natori shops in Japan.
All part of an orderly expansion plan, Mrs. Natori said. "Everything we do connects, from sleepwear to at-home to home furnishings to bath products," she said. "Bathing suits could connect. But not career wear."
She paused a second. "At least not yet," she said.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Move Higher in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher and interest rates inched lower yesterday in very thin trading.
Market participants said that most of the day's activity was telescoped into the first two hours of trading, and it was primarily concentrated in the purchase of short-term bills and notes. 
 "There has been tremendous demand for short-term paper," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
Mr. Sullivan said that much of the money going into bills and notes was probably being rolled into those securities from maturing instruments like Treasury cash management bills. Analysts said that more than $14 billion worth of those securities matured this week.
 
Announcement Wednesday
 "With the refunding auctions little more than a week off, the play is in the short end," said Jay Goldinger, a principal at Capital Insight, a bond brokerage firm in Beverly Hills, Calif.
On Wednesday the Treasury is expected to announce how many new 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds it will sell at auctions beginning May 5. Most analysts expect a total of $37 billion worth of those securities will be auctioned.
Bond prices, which had been weak through most of the session, rallied near the close and ended higher on the day.
While the looming supply of new bonds is a concern to traders, some analysts said that fears of a vigorous recovery that would rekindle inflation seemed to be abating among bond investors.
"Recent economic data have reinforced our view that the recovery will be sluggish," analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, wrote in their daily market commentary. "And predictions of a robust recovery are losing popularity."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 9919/32 , up 3/32 , to yield 8.03 percent, compared with 8.04 percent late Thursday and 7.93 percent on April 17.
Among Treasury note issues outstanding, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 9930/32 , up 7/32 , to yield 7.50 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes auctioned earlier in the week were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 5.32 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates fell.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.65 percent late yesterday, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.80 percent.
 
Kroger Offer
 In the corporate bond market, the Kroger Corporation offered $250 million worth of seven-year senior subordinated notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The noncallable 10 percent securities were priced at $100, or par, 2.80 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service and B by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
JP Morgan Securities, a subsidiary of J. P. Morgan & Company, acted as lead manager for an offering of $75 million worth of noncallable five-year notes for the Trinova Corporation.
The 7.95 percent securities were priced at $99.653 to yield 8.036 percent, 1.15 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.

HEADLINE: U.S. Call to Cut Deficit Draws German Ire

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Just two days before the Group of Seven's finance ministers are to meet here to discuss the world economy and aid to the former Soviet Union, the German Government lashed out at Washington's call for Germany to do more to spur world growth.
Using unusually harsh language, a senior German Finance Ministry official said today that the United States should not meddle in Germany's internal affairs. He said American officials had made "false" and "one-sided" statements on Thursday when they urged Bonn to lower its budget deficit to give Germany's central bank some latitude to lower its interest rates.
 
Seeks Lower Rates
 American officials have long asserted that the economic slowdown that Germany's high rates have caused in Europe will make it far harder for the states of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union to make the transition to a market economy. On Thursday, Treasury Under Secretary David C. Mulford called on Germany to move faster to lower its interest rates, saying that Germany's high rates were slowing growth in Germany, Europe and the rest of the world. 
 Horst Kohler, the state secretary in Germany's Finance Ministry, attacked Washington's criticisms, saying, according to Reuters, "It was not acceptable that the deliberation of the G-7 ministers should be burdened by one-sided and partly false public comments by a senior official."
International economists said they were surprised at how much wrath Germany was directing at Washington. "In a sense the reaction is unrepresentatively singling out U.S. criticism when the same criticism comes from many others," said William R. Cline, a senior fellow with the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "It is of course awkward for the U.S. to be billed as the party doing the criticizing because our own house has been out of order for so long. But the fact is the U.S. is expressing a sentiment widely felt in Europe and elsewhere."
In his Thursday news conference, Mr. Mulford, echoing pleas made recently by the French Government and the International Monetary Fund, criticized Germany's large budget deficit for stimulating inflation and pushing Germany's central bank to raise interest rates to extraordinarily high levels.
 
'Major Spillover Effects'
 "Germany has a large fiscal deficit and a tight monetary policy, and this is having major spillover effects for Europe," Mr. Mulford said. "It's causing high interest rates, slow growth, and contributing to unemployment."
In a reference to Washington's need to borrow from abroad to finance its nearly $400 billion deficit, Mr. Kohler said the "important thing is that Germany is financing its public deficits from its own savings."
"We will not be put in the dock," he added. Two weeks ago, American officials were praising Mr. Kohler in particular for having worked closely with them on setting up a $24 billion international aid package for Russia.
In his remarks, Mr. Mulford took pains to say he did not "want to get involved in the domestic question" of German economic policy, but he said that when he recently traveled to Europe with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, many European officials complained to them about Germany's high interest rates.
Germany's budget deficit has mushroomed over the last two years because of the cost, estimated at hundreds of billions of dollars, of helping finance the rebuilding of eastern Germany.
"The true cost of unification has yet to really be borne by the West German people and that issue has to be addressed in the budget at some point," Mr. Mulford said. "In the meantime, the high rates transfer part of those costs to the rest of Europe and elsewhere in the form of lower growth."
Mr. Mulford said that Bonn had said that its budget deficit was running from 3 to 3.5 percent of gross domestic product, but he said that when the cost of eastern Germany's state-owned privatization agency, the German state-owned railroads and the German post office were included, total public sector borrowing came to 6 percent of G.D.P.
Mr. Mulford acknowledged that the United States also has a large budget deficit, but according to Government estimates the American budget deficit represents a smaller share of G.D.P. than Germany's overall deficit.
The respected economics institute in Kiel, Germany, estimated that the deficit for Germany's federal and local governments would be 3.6 percent of G.D.P. this year, that the deficit including financing to help eastern Germany would be 4 percent of G.D.P., and that total public sector borrowing would be 5.9 percent of G.D.P.
The Bush Administration's pleas received some support today from Helmut Schlesinger, president of Germany's central bank. In a speech in Stuttgart, Mr. Schlesinger said, "The one-sided policy mix of expansionary financial policies, expansionary income policies and restrictive monetary policies will not be good for our nation over the long term."
Continuing Washington's yearlong push to get other industrial nations to focus more on growth, Mr. Mulford also urged the Japanese Government to act more aggressively to spur growth as that nation's economy weakens. In words far less tentative than those addressed to Germany, he suggested that Japan should lower interest rates and present a supplemental budget to increase public spending
Mr. Mulford voiced sympathy for Germany's central bank, saying its desire to raise rates to pull down inflation caused by a large budget deficit was understandable.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Mostly Lower; Quiet Group of 7 Talks Seen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved mostly lower yesterday as traders predicted that few substantial developments would emerge from this weekend's meeting of finance ministers from the seven leading industrial nations.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery was quoted at $336.90 an ounce, down $1.80. A late bid at the Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold at $336.30, also off $1.80. 
 Jay Tucker, currency trader for the First Boston Corporation, said many analysts had few expectations for the scheduled Group of Seven meeting in Washington.
He said there was little interest in the dollar during the quiet session, with most of the trading occurring in European currencies or the Japanese yen.
"Any time we have a move, it is totally unrelated to the dollar," Mr. Tucker said. Many currency traders are frustrated at the dollar's inability to stage a significant advance in the face of good domestic economic news, including rebounding bank stocks, a fall in unemployment claims and an advance in the housing sector.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 134.65 Japanese yen from 134.15 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 134.51 yen. The dollar closed at 134.45 in New York, down from 134.65 at Thursday's close.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7715, from $1.7650 late Thursday. In New York at closing, the pound fetched $1.7750, less expensive than $1.7660 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.6500 German marks, down from 1.6605 late Thursday; 1.5295 Swiss francs, down from 1.5400; 5.5715 French francs, down from 5.6090; 1,241.25 Italian lire, down from 1,249.50, and 1.18595 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18695.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Insurance Review Is Suggested Now

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
In today's low-interest-rate environment, many consumers need to review their life insurance policies, experts say. Many need to increase coverage, while others may find they are paying for coverage they no longer need.
"Thousands of people have policies buried away in safe-deposit boxes or drawers, and they just haven't addressed them or looked at them," said John Peterman, an account executive for Dean Witter & Company in New York who began evaluating insurance portfolios as a service to clients and has since developed an active business in the area. 
 The first reason for reviewing life insurance in light of today's low interest rates goes to the basic reason for having the insurance: death benefits, which provide financial security for a family or spouse in case the policyholder dies.
Joel S. Isaacson, partner in charge of personal financial planning for Clarfeld & Company, a New York certified public accountancy firm, said, "Suppose someone wanted to provide $80,000 a year for his family -- $1 million invested at 8 percent would do it," and that is the interest rate many people projected in recent years, viewing it as conservative.
"But with interest rates where they are now, people may want to re-evaluate their assumptions," he added. "They may feel more comfortable with 6 percent than 8 percent."
That would mean a policyholder would have to increase coverage to $1,333,333 to provide capital that could be invested for the same $80,000 income stream. Mr. Isaacson said 6 percent was a reasonable figure because insurance proceeds are generally invested in long-term, fixed-income securities, not in short-term holdings like Treasury bills or money market funds, which now pay less than 4 percent.
Of course, in planning how much income must be replaced if one spouse dies, families must consider a number of factors, including how much each spouse is earning, whether there would be additional child-care costs, what benefits might be available to the survivor from a corporate pension plan or Social Security, whether a home mortgage would be paid off and how long the replacement income will be needed.
Mr. Peterman told of one woman who had bought a $200,000 policy years ago, originally paying a $350 annual premium, to provide for her two children if she should die. But they had since graduated from college, so this year, facing an $1,800 premium, she dropped the policy.
On the other hand, a couple with whom he worked needed additional coverage. They owned a business and had a 10-year-old son. The husband was insured for $150,000; the wife was not insured. If either spouse died, the surviving spouse, the business and the son would all suffer financially, so all those needs had to be considered in setting up the right coverage.
Ralph M. Solomon, president of Ralph Solomon & Associates, an insurance brokerage in Boca Raton, Fla., and New York, said the varieties of insurance available today created "catacombs of confusion," so people need to review their coverage annually with an honest and scrupulous agent.
One adverse impact of low interest rates and the plunge in the real estate market, he noted, is that cash balances are earning less in whole and universal life policies. Unlike term insurance, which provides only a death benefit, those policies also provide an investment component. "Years ago no one ever heard of an insurance company reducing the dividend scale," he said, but that is happening today.
As a result, some policyholders who expected their premiums to vanish after seven or eight years, when the cash values built up enough that the dividends would pay the annual premium, are now being billed for additional premiums.
Mr. Isaacson told of one client in that situation who was so furious at his insurance agent that he was ready to give up the policy. "It was at a top-quality company, and he needed the coverage," he said. "I had to talk him into keeping it."
Mr. Peterman cited a number of reasons that a policyholder might be better off keeping a policy than switching. "The premium may be higher because the replacement policy would be based on the insured's new age," he said. "Most costs are charged against the cash values in the early years of the policy. The incontestable and suicide clauses begin anew. The old policy may have better provisions in areas such as settlement of disability benefits. The cash values in an existing policy may have reserve value."
Policyholders whose needs have changed should explore whether the present carrier is able to change a policy to fit current needs on favorable terms, he said.
Mr. Isaacson said that for some people who decide to switch policies, variable life insurance, in which cash balances can be invested in a diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds and other holdings, might be more attractive than whole or universal life. Or, he said, they may agree with the classic argument: buy term and invest the difference. The disadvantage is that the premium will rise each year.

HEADLINE: GUIDEPOST;
Checking on C.D. Lures

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The sharp decline in personal savings rates has prompted many banks to create accounts designed to attract or keep customers. Often these accounts bear such names as "bump-up" certificates of deposit or "rising-rate" C.D.'s. They require the customer do some basic math to figure the real bottom-line return so they can make comparisons to find out what they could earn elsewhere. Bump-ups allow the depositor to change to a higher rate once during the life of the C.D. A rising-rate certificate pays progressively higher predetermined rates every three to six months over the life of the certificate. 
 Using a $10,000 investment as an example, here is what you might earn with the two types of C.D.'s over 12 months compared to a regular no-frills C.D., assuming that interest rates rise by a full percentage point in the next year.

HEADLINE: The Tides of Crime

 BODY:
Crime is going down, the New York City police report. Can it be true, after all these years of pain, cost and fear? The police and criminal justice experts respond with proper caution. History teaches that crime waves arise from profound forces not easily subject to Government control. Officials can't honestly do more than try to contain crime and minimize its damage.
But to the extent they exceed the trends elsewhere, the New York figures also suggest that government can achieve such containment, to visible and reassuring effect. There's good reason, in short, to persevere in efforts like the current expansion and redeployment of police in New York. 
 Scholars trace three crime waves in American history. The first began sometime in the 1840's and lasted until the Civil War. Homicide figures document a second surge in the early 1900's. The third wave has been going on since the mid-1960's. One reason is the baby boom, which increased the proportion of crime-prone young men.
Other reasons include immigration, domestic population transfers and economic changes that produce structural unemployment. Wars also disrupt labor markets and legitimize violence. The Vietnam War did both.
But those factors faded out in the 1980's, while crime leveled off at an elevated rate and then began a decline, so slight that it offers little reassurance. Some analysts attribute this decline mostly to "target hardening" -- more locks and alarms -- and the fear that keeps people home at night.
Why hasn't crime declined more? In part, surely because of ongoing structural unemployment and social alienation as more of the middle class abandons cities, leaving behind ever-harsher concentrations of poverty. But there is also a much more dramatic explanation: the crack epidemic.
Crack began to spread widely in the mid-80's and soon introduced millions to lives of drug abuse and crime. It produced a new generation of dealers, and a new profusion of firearms. They escalated street violence to appalling levels, much as Prohibition generated the violent gang mayhem of the 1920's and Samuel Colt's new handguns increased bloodshed in the 1840's and 50's.
The brutal surge in drug weaponry fed on itself as more youngsters felt the need to arm for self-defense. Manufacturers tooled up to supply the expanding new market, while smugglers reaped enormous profits running guns from states with lax gun laws to cities with strict ones.
In short, crime hasn't fallen back with changes in the population because of crack and guns. And while Government can't do much about the big historic tides of crime, it can do a great deal about these two specific scourges.
The Federal Government could, for example, pay for a big expansion of drug treatment, authorizing it as the first sanction for criminals found to be drug-involved. Public and private funds now support about 600,000 drug treatment slots nationwide; at least 300,000 more are needed.
There's even more the Bush Administration could do by way of urban arms control. It could restrict access to guns with uniform national purchase waiting periods. It could insist on licensing, training and other measures now blocked by Congressional capitulation to the gun lobby. And it could help localities expand and better deploy police against drugs and guns.
Americans have become resigned to crime as part of their daily routine. A serious Federal commitment to drug treatment, gun control and help for local police would not necessarily turn the tide. But it certainly could reduce crime, bloodshed and fear.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: For Many, Paying for College Only Gets Harder

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Creative Tuition Increase" (editorial, April 17) urges support for the innovative City University of New York proposal to offer a tuition-free pregraduation semester, while minimizing the impact of a tuition increase on students now enrolled. 
 With the availability of state and Federal financial aid for entering freshmen, we should be particularly concerned about economic assistance to students after they progress academically in college and exhaust their aid. The Tuition Assistance Program, for example, provides support for only eight semesters, even though most students take longer to graduate in today's difficult economy.
This reality, however, has existed since the original Free Academy (the forerunner of City College). In "City College and the Jewish Poor" (New York, 1982), Sherry Gorelick writes: "between 1848 and 1902, 30,000 students had been admitted but only 2,730 graduated" According to her, "most of the students dropped out because their parents could no longer afford to keep them in school."
The same economic pressures apply today, except for the added burden of tuition, which is especially onerous for students as they approach graduation.
We should be doing everything possible to help our students to graduate, and the CUNY idea is a step in the right direction.
 
HADASSAH GOLD
Chairman, Committee for Public Higher Education
New York, April 20, 1992

HEADLINE: Beware of Cost Parers Playing Doctor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Prof. Jesse Lemisch tells a poignant story in "Do They Want My Wife to Die?" (Op-Ed, April 15), describing how the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has informed him it will cut back nursing care for his wife, a professor of psychology struck down by acute chronic fatigue syndrome, from the 24 hours a day her doctor says she needs to stay alive to 4 hours a day. 
 This case may only hint at what medical treatment will be like under "managed care." Masquerading as the panacea for skyrocketing health expenditures, managed care is a euphemism for managed cost, which disregards patient care, as Professor Lemisch so eloquently describes.
While no one can deny that we must find some way to make fiscally sound decisions about the cost and practice of health care, managed care companies have encroached on medical decision making, forcing physicians to struggle with endless numbers of "reviewers" (most of whom have not gone to medical school) to justify what more than 20 years of education has taught them is necessary in order to provide quality treatment for their patients.
In addition, an unsuspecting public often learns that health insurance coverage is being switched abruptly to a managed-care format with only the very minimum of notification, explanation or opportunity to choose an alternative.
This happened to New York State employees when the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company subcontracted all mental-health services to a managed-care company called American Psych Management on Feb. 1.
To have non-M.D.'s determining "medical necessity" makes a mockery of a physician's training. Worse, it jeopardizes the seriously ill, who often lack the resources and stamina to fight back. Surely, the medical profession, insurers and government officials can find more creative economic solutions to spiraling health-care costs that will not expend patient lives.
 
CAROL A. BERNSTEIN, M.D.
Asst. Clinical Professor of Psychiatry, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University
New York, April 16, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
In the Huxtable World, Parents Knew Best

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
This week, after eight years of speCtacular ratings and spectacular profits, Bill Cosby will finish up what he had to say on "The Cosby Show."
The series was the most-watched show of the last decade, the comedy seen by more people than any other in television history, the show that resurrected the sitcom as television's most popular genre and the first to portray mainstream black middle-class life. NBC will broadcast its 198th and final episode Thursday night at 8. Like the other 197, the hourlong special will emphasize family values, family togetherness and family pride.
"Truthfully, I don't have anything left to say," Mr. Cosby said. "That may be why it's not a sad, sad moment. I'm satisfied." 
 In large measure, his satisfaction comes from knowing that the series, beyond making Mr. Cosby one of the best-liked and wealthiest entertainers in America, did what he set out to do: it restored the television image of the parent as loving authority figure, and it gave viewers, black and white, an unwaveringly positive look at family life, as lived in a home headed by two professional parents who happened to be black.
"It was a breakthrough in presenting a family with two parents working," said Ellen Galinsky, co-president of the Families and Work Institute, a Manhattan-based research organization. "It was a very moving testament to family life."
The series capitalized on Mr. Cosby's comedic talent, especially his winning way with children. But "Cosby" also emerged at an opportune moment. When it first appeared, in 1984, television was barren of its traditional staple: great situation comedy. Viewers streamed to "Cosby" because they could find laughs there every week. But the series also benefited from speaking to an audience suddenly eager to embrace the joys of parenthood. The baby-boom generation, having moved through "Leave It to Beaver," "My Three Sons," "Mary Tyler Moore," "M*A*S*H" and "Saturday Night Live," began changing diapers, and its focus. As the country's most populous generation began raising its own children, "The Cosby Show" captured them by illustrating nothing more than the day-to-day events of family life.
Earlier this spring, on the day before the taping of the final episode of "The Cosby Show," Mr. Cosby relaxed on the plush couch in his comfortable dressing room at the Kaufman-Astoria Studios in Queens, where the show was produced for the last five years. Soft piano jazz riffled from hidden speakers.
Mr. Cosby, who is 54 years old, is now among the most powerful figures in show business; he earns a portion of the show's syndication revenues -- so far more than $600 million. He is also involved in the production of the NBC spinoff comedy, "A Different World," which has been a top series for the last five years.
"Cosby" finished the official television season in 17th place in the Nielsen ratings. That's a long fall from being the unchallenged No. 1 show, which "Cosby" was from 1985 through 1989.
But the descent is not so disturbing that Mr. Cosby can't joke about it. During the last season, a sign on his dressing-room door read: "This show is no longer No. 1, so don't come knockin' on this door for nothin'."
He is even unruffled by "The Simpsons," which exacerbated his show's slide from the top when the Fox network put it up against "Cosby." For one thing, he said, the attention surrounding the battle between the two series focused attention on "Cosby" again. And then there was the contrast between his show and "The Simpsons," with its oafish father Homer and problem child Bart.
"When Bart first came out," he recalled, "USA Today had a story with somebody who said, 'I don't want to watch Cosby because I get a headache because I learn too much.' And I said, 'Bravo.' I know that I've lost that person, but by the same token obviously that person has gotten the message."
 
Message in a Sitcom
Parenthood Is No Joke
 "Cosby," Mr. Cosby said, was unashamedly about presenting messages as much as it was about comedy. His emphasis on education and achievement is apparent from his own decision to pursue a doctorate in education, which he earned from the University of Massachusetts in 1976. (He listed himself as William H. Cosby Jr., Ed.D., in the show's credits.) He conferred regularly about story lines and themes with his friend Alvin Poussaint, a Harvard psychiatrist who is listed in the credits as production consultant.
At the show's height, even a rival network's research department reported that millions of viewers watched "The Cosby Show" to get advice about how to be good parents. That was precisely Mr. Cosby's intention when he decided to do the series. "I was watching television back then," he said, "and I noticed the children were brighter than the parents. And the laughs were coming because the parents really weren't parenting. They had misconstrued any self-help book they'd read."
Mr. Cosby took his own assignment of presenting a different image of parenthood so seriously, he said, that he sometimes deliberately cut out lines and situations that he was sure would have made the show funnier. "Dr. Poussaint and I would get together and talk about the alternatives we wanted people to consider. What is your life about once you become a parent? It's about that kid. And what's it about as you grow older? It's about the education you gave or you didn't give."
From the beginning, what "Cosby" was really about was Bill Cosby's own family, and his own commitment to the values of education and respect among family members.
Mr. Cosby acknowledged that every element of the series reflected his personal vision. Everything was shaped by his input and his taste, down to the set, which he designed himself, covering the walls with copies of paintings by black artists in his own collection.
Like the Huxtables, Mr. Cosby and his wife, Camille, have four daughters and a son, now ranging in age from 16 to 27. The Cosbys have a home in Massachusetts and a town house in Manhattan. The show's fictional family, the Huxtables, live in a town house in Brooklyn Heights. When the show first began, the Huxtables had only four children, but within a few weeks Mr. Cosby had introduced an eldest daughter so the structure of the family would conform exactly to his own.
Sometimes the reference points were not exact between the real family and the television version. But in at least one case, what happened to the Huxtables was a virtual mirror image of events in the Cosby house. The final show, which centers on Theo Huxtable's graduation from New York University, recalls -- in a flashback featuring a boyish Malcolm-Jamal Warner as Theo and a far thinner and younger-looking Cosby -- a scene from the show's opening episode. In that show, Theo, the middle child and only son, tells his father, the successful obstetrician, about his lackluster grades and declares that the pressure to succeed is too much. He tells his father he would much prefer just to be like "regular people."
It was a defining moment for the series. Rather than respond in the then-popular fashion of the all-accepting, cowed parent, Cliff Huxtable tells his son how ridiculous he sounds.
In real life, the incident happened late one night. Mr. Cosby's son, Ennis, was then about 13. "It bothered me that Ennis was not doing his schoolwork," Mr. Cosby said. "I sat him down and said we're going to talk, and I want you to say whatever is on your mind. We talked until 4:30 in the morning. And he said he wanted to be regular people. He didn't want the pressure of studying."
Ennis's struggles with learning took the same course viewers saw Theo's take. "We go ahead, four years later, and find out, after great frustration -- no physical violence, but great frustration -- that after being tested, he is, in fact, dyslexic."
In both life and the series, the parents regarded the revelation as cause for celebration. Ennis/Theo went to a special school, learned the skills needed to cope with his learning difference and effectively transformed his life.
In the final episode, the proud father can't get enough seats for Theo's graduation. In real life, the proud father relates the story of Ennis's academic triumph: "He goes to college, moves from a 2.3 average to a 2.7. He goes back to the learning school for the summer. Now he's in his major, psychology, and he moves it up to a 3.6. And this semester, 3.8 -- for sure!"
 
 
The Idealization Issue
Were the Huxtables Too Perfect?
 Perhaps because the series was so close to home for Mr. Cosby, revisionist comments from some newspaper and magazine critics, after initial praise, cut especially deep. Beyond the complaints about heavy-handed message-mongering, the show was attacked for presenting an unrealistically idealized portrait of family life, particularly black family life, because the parents were too well off, too smart, too "perfect."
Mr. Cosby said the point was to present a family whose behavior offered a positive alternative to other, harsher contemporary images available on television and elsewhere. "It would have been wonderful if I had been able to bring on children in the family who had drug problems and make that funny," he said, "or had a daughter get pregnant out of wedlock and make that funny, or have had Dr. Huxtable having two or three nurses on the side and make adultery funny. But I just could not deal with the humor in those situations."
The enormous popularity of the series, and its impact on television, more than compensated for any criticism.
"Absolutely, the family was put in a better light," he said. "I think 'Family Ties' watched us and made some changes. 'Growing Pains' and other shows came right off us. The other important thing was it helped take off the .357 magnum people and brought us 'L.A. Law' instead. It took off black actors who were forced to play pimps and thugs and black females who were forced to play hookers and rape victims."
Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of African-American Studies at Harvard, said that "The Cosby Show" profoundly changed the television image of black Americans. "If you watched television before 'Cosby,' " he said, "you'd think that we talk about being black and poor all day long. What he did was simply present people as black; he didn't have to claim it for them."
The show made it possible, Mr. Cosby suggested, for black performers to play professionals like the Huxtables on other television shows, though he said it was hard at first to turn around some of the expectations of producers, who still wanted black actors to "roll their eyes and sound jive." The actors, he said, kept saying, "No, my mother and father went to college.' "
 
A Way With Children
The Proof Is In the Jell-O
 Mr. Cosby's own father, William Sr., attended college, in pharmacology, but dropped out because he could not afford it. He became a merchant seaman and he and his wife, Anna, raised their three boys in Philadelphia amid a cast of colorful street characters. One, recreated by Mr. Cosby as Fat Albert, became the center of many of his monologues. Beginning in 1972, he was also the main character in one of Saturday morning's biggest successes for more than a decade, "Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids" on CBS. Mr. Cosby's most successful work, in fact, has always been based on his personal life. He remains one of the leading stand-up comedians in America; his 24 comedy albums have sold more copies than any other comedian's.
In his monologues, Mr. Cosby started out reminiscing about his childhood and his days as an athlete at Temple University. Later he shifted his attention to the idiosyncrasies of his family life, developing comic takes on everything from a trip to the dentist to family vacations. More recently, he has expanded his range, taking seriocomic looks at the aging process and the sometimes unhappy consequences of raising children of wealth.
Along the way he developed a career in television. In the 1960's, with the NBC series "I Spy," Mr. Cosby became the first black actor to star in a television drama, and won three Emmy Awards for his role as Alexander Scott. But his television career hit several valleys before peaking in "The Cosby Show." A 1970 situation comedy for NBC, "The Bill Cosby Show," in which he played a high school gym teacher, was gone after two seasons. Two attempts at variety series, the first for CBS in 1972 and the second for ABC in 1976, disappeared quickly.
He has starred in a few films, with only occasional success. "Uptown Saturday Night" (1974) was his biggest box-office draw; his latest efforts, "Leonard Part 6" (1987) and "Ghost Dad" (1990), were undisputed and undistinguished duds.
Mr. Cosby's appeal to children never waned, however. As part of his commitment to fostering education, he appeared regularly on the PBS reading series "The Electric Company," in the 1970's.
But nothing captured his irresistibility to children better than his series of commercials for Jell-O and Jell-O Pudding, which feature Mr. Cosby at play with utterly enchanted toddlers.
 
So Long, Cliff
Life After 'Cosby'
 "The Cosby Show" has made it possible for Bill Cosby to do almost anything he wants with the rest of his life. He has turned some of his millions back into causes he believes in, primarily education. In 1988, he and Camille donated $20 million to Spelman College in Atlanta, the biggest single contribution ever made to a black college.
In the fall, he will star in a syndicated version of the old Groucho Marx game show "You Bet Your Life." He will also be producing what looks like the continuation of the Ennis story: a new series in which Malcolm-Jamal Warner plays a teacher in a special school. "Ennis," his father said, "is great with kids. He's even more of a Pied Piper than I am."
Still, nothing Bill Cosby does for the rest of his life is likely to approach the impact of "The Cosby Show" on television, or on the star himself.
"Because of that Thursday night every week for eight years," he said, "many people, not all, but many people love Bill Cosby. And there's a human being that I owe them every time I see them. And that is a human being that will not let them down.
"And it's not a bad challenge. I don't have to deliver any babies. I just have to live a good, clean life and make good sense."
 
 
 
OPENING THE DOOR TO A BLACK WORLD
 All television comedies with predominantly black casts can be categorized as "B.C. and A.C. -- Before 'Cosby' and After 'Cosby,' " says Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of African-American studies at Harvard.
Earlier black sitcoms, he says, were typified by the slapstick style of "Sanford and Son." But Mr. Cosby's series, he continues, "has a sense of black history and the continuity of the black family." Series that have been broadcast since "Cosby" began in 1984 have shown a wide range of black characters, from the nerdy Urkel of "Family Matters" to the owner and patrons of a New Orleans restaurant in "Frank's Place."
"The brilliant thing Cosby did," said Mr. Gates, "was to put race and economic issues on the back burner so we could see a black family dealing with all the things black people deal with the same as all other people. It was the first time most of us as black people have felt a sense of identity with and resemblance to the kind of values we have in common, our relationships with our parents and our siblings."
Here are some of the television images of black people before and after "The Cosby Show."

GRAPHIC: Photos:
BEFORE COSBY
"Sanford and Son" (1972-1977; NBC) -- featured Redd Foxx as a widowed, grizzled Los Angeles junk dealer and Demond Wilson as his restless son who dreamed of a better life. Mr. Foxx used the Norman Lear series as a showcase for broad slapstick humor.
 
"Good Times" (1974-1979; CBS) -- featured Jimmie Walker as the jive-talking son in a poor Chicago family, with Esther Rolle as the mother and John Amos as the often unemployed father. The series was a spinoff of "Maude," in which Ms. Rolle played the maid.
 
"The Jeffersons" (1975-1985; CBS), with Isabel Sanford as a long-suffering wife and Sherman Hemsley as a sputtering bigot, began as a spinoff of "All in the Family." The premise: cleaning-store owner makes good and moves to Upper East Side of Manhattan.
 
"The Cosby Show" (1984-1992; NBC), with Bill Cosby, right, and Malcolm-Jamal Warner (in a scene from the final episode), was the first series to feature an established middle-class family who just happened to be black.
 
AFTER COSBY
"Frank's Place" (1987-1988; CBS), with Tim Reid, left, and Tony Burton, lasted just one season but was a favorite among critics. It starred Mr. Reid as a Boston professor who inherited a New Orleans restaurant and, through it, discovered his cultural heritage.
 
"Family Matters" (1989-present; ABC), starring Reginald VelJohnson and JoMarie Payton-France, is about a solid working-class family in Chicago. Jaleel White plays the neighbor Steve Urkel, a bespectacled smarty-pants -- an unusual role for a black actor.
 
"Roc" (1991-present; Fox), starring Charles Dutton as a sanitation worker, is, like "The Cosby Show," about several generations in a black family. The critically acclaimed series features a cast largely drawn from productions of August Wilson's Broadway plays. (pg. 33)
 
Bill Cosby on the set of "The Cosby Show," whose final episode will be broadcast on Thursday. (Howard L. Bingham)(pg. 1)
