HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
On the Road With Your Children's Children

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
TRAVEL with your children's children, the best fun in the world, involves a lot of learning by doing, but novices can use some rules to keep the project on the rails.
Some guidelines derive from folklore: Where to find a toilet on Fifth Avenue, for example. Others appear in books and leaflets as grandparent-grandchild travel increases, and it is booming. Helena T. Koenig, a travel agent in Chevy Chase, Md., is offering 15 high-end tours in her sixth season of Grandtravel, and she says business has doubled every year since she began, although she expects growth to plateau in the recession. 
 Part of the growth stems from divorce patterns. Mrs. Koenig said that most of the children on her trips traveled with only one grandparent, typically a grandmother, but that most of them had eight grandparents rather than four. The growth is also driven by the increase in two-job families where parents have difficulty getting vacations at the same time, not to mention meeting the cost. In this situation, grandparents step in.
 
Trial Runs at Home
 When the child is ready to spend an overnight away from home, greenhorn grandparents might start with a whole day and night visit at their house. "Don't forget, the day does not end at 4," Bubbles Fisher, grandmother of 10 and author of "New York City With Kids" counsels. The visit will prepare both of you for life in another city: What to eat when, how many stories at bedtime, what television shows are acceptable.
When the relationship is ready for a trip, preparation should involve the child. Many grandparents promise a trip to each child at a particular age or occasion, and let the child select from a list: only two choices for a young child, more for an older one. Ms. Fisher's oldest grandchild, now at Amherst, selected Disney World at the age of 3, but this year's grandchild, from California, shunned such familiar fare and chose Washington. One grandparent, one grandchild on a trip is a good rule of thumb for safety.
Grandtravel publishes a free leaflet, "Travel Hints," covering its trips, but the principles are broader. Books, videos and magazines about the destination may be available at school or the library. Teachers may suggest projects for the children to share with the class later -- collecting coins or stamps. A notebook, sketchbook or scrapbook should be begun before the trip. I carry snubnosed scissors, sticky tape and lots of pencils. A travel agent will provide an itinerary and brochures and these can start the diary.
Learning what's going on in another city involves some effort close to departure time: phone calls to convention or visitor bureaus, and reading the city's newspapers to check for good hotel prices and coming events.
A hotel with a pool is a plus, but most hotels do not provide lifeguards, one reason that one grandparent for each child is a rational rule. When she makes a reservation, Ms. Fisher also asks the hotel to send a copy of the room service menu.
It is a great help if a museum you visit has a cafeteria. If the guidebooks do not say, call ahead. And be specific about the busiest times. Sarabeth's restaurant at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York, for example, is so popular on Sunday that there may be a half-hour wait, which rules it out for children.
Preparing for a museum trip does not mean a vague announcement, "We're going to a museum," but telling the child about the goal of the trip: to see Calder's Circus at the Whitney, for example, or the Pacific locomotive at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History in Washington or the helicopter at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. Children's museums are easier to visit because almost everything can be touched, but the age needs to be gauged carefully; 10-year-olds roll their eyes at tiny tables with thick crayons. A museum visit should not be scheduled for longer than an hour and opening time often avoids crowds, the nemesis of children.
Selecting souvenirs tests grandparents. Mrs. Koenig, who limits each of her trips to 25 participants and transports them in 48-passenger buses, thinks she ought to get a second bus for all the stuff that is bought. Children are encouraged to buy for children left behind, she said. Presents and souvenirs have to be packed, so I limit purchases to postcards and small books, but in any case, set the ground rules before you go into a museum or gift shop.
 
Tour Companies
 Grandtravel accepts children aged 7 to 17 for trips, often dividing them into one trip for 7 to 11's and another for 12 to 17's. The most popular age range is 10 to 15, Mrs. Koenig says, and this is probably the age when the range of interests best matches the grandparents.' The land arrangements for her trips range upward from $2,290 a person.
In her first year, she offered Washington, a safari in Kenya and a tour of the Southwest, and about six people signed up for each trip. This year, she listed 16 tours, but is reluctantly dropping the Kenya trip, the second time she has had to do this, because the State Department has issued an advisory urging caution in traveling to that country. The other international trips include castles of England and Scotland, barging in the Netherlands and Belgium, and Australia. Domestically, Washington, Maine, New York, New England, the Southwest, the West, Hawaii and Alaska are offered.
Grandtravel will send its 60-page catalogue or its tips leaflet free: Grandtravel, 6900 Wisconsin Avenue, Suite 706, Chevy Chase, Md. 20815, (800) 247-7651 or (301) 986-0790.
Adventure Express, 650 Fifth Avenue, San Francisco, Calif. 94107, (800) 872-7225, is in its sixth year of offering adult-child programs called Rascals in Paradise, with 30 trips suitable for adults and children. Such choices as the Canadian Rockies bicycle trip are probably better suited to parents than grandparents, but the "exotic classroom" offerings, including Australia and the Galapagos Islands, fit the grandparent category. The company offers a number of Caribbean all-inclusive resort packages, modified with early meals for children and sitter services. As a sample of prices, a New Zealand trip for four people, two adults and two children, without air fare, would be $8,524 with meals and sightseeing; seven nights in Belize, meals not included, $1,505.
Vista Tours of Frontier Travel & Tours, 1923 North Carson Street, Carson City, Nev. 89701, (800) 648-0912, is offering three modest grandparent tours this summer, with a number of departure dates: South Dakota, New England and Reno, Nev. According to Sylvia Ruh, the grandparent tours have increased in popularity since they started in the mid-80's. Four nights in Reno, with a trip to Lake Tahoe and the Ponderosa Ranch in Virginia City, Nev., costs $485 for an adult in double occupancy and $412 for a child as the third in the room. If the adult uses the room with a child only, there is a $20 supplement.
The American Association of Retired Persons, (800) 927-0111, offers two Disney packages for grandparents: Disney World in Orlando, and Euro Disney outside Paris. A four-night Disney World stay at the Disney Inn or Disney's Village Resort, with a pass to all attractions, is $581 a person, with two in a room. If there are two adults and a child in the room, the child's cost is $250.
Ms. Fisher's "Frommer's Family Travel Guide, New York City With Kids" (Prentice Hall, $18), which began life as "The Candy Apple" in 1987, is really a grandparent's book, done from the standpoint of a resident who is welcoming young people to New York rather than as a parent arriving in a strange city. The author provides only a small list of hotels. But her chapters on preparing and finding out what's going on apply for any city.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1468 words

HEADLINE: Talking: Bankruptcy;
Problems With Unit Owners

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
AN explosion in personal bankruptcies is undermining the financial safeguards built into the basic documents that govern co-ops and condominums.
The normal expectation is that anyone who falls behind in paying monthly maintenance fees or common charges can be speedily forced out. Also, that these fees can eventually be collected through legal action against the delinquent resident. 
 In a co-op, for example, the corporation normally has the right to seek a speedy eviction when shareholders default on their lease by failing to pay their share of the building's upkeep. Those unpaid fees then become a priority lien on the apartment, payable out of the proceeds of the subsequent forced sale -- or by the incoming buyers before they are permitted to take title.
A delinquent unit owner in a condominum will similarly forfeit the right to remain. The association can thus commence foreclosure proceedings. However, any unpaid charges may not carry the same priority standing as in a co-op and might never be fully recouped.
Nevertheless, in both instances, the governing body can normally pry some money loose from the recalcitrant residents. In addition, it can force the residents out and get the apartment occupied by somebody who will pay in a timely fashion.
Personal bankruptcy interferes with all of this by protecting the occupants' right to remain in the apartment until the disposition of all debts is sorted out by the courts. "And this can sometimes take six months or more," said Richard Liebman, a lawyer in Rockville Centre, L.I., who specializes in bankruptcies.
No wonder personal bankruptcy strikes all the other residents as such an outrage. "You can imagine how we feel," said a unit owner in the Bronx, "when we see this individual driving out of the building in a brand-new car and carrying shopping bags from some of the more stylish shops in Manhattan."
The reason it occurs, say lawyers, is that bankruptcy laws override virtually all established collection remedies. The problem is compounded because the unit is normally the debtor's primary residence. And in many states a person's home carries even stronger protection against seizure. In New York, for instance, the court must decide.
Yet this doesn't mean the association or corporation has been left totally defenseless, although "too many boards still think their hands are completely tied," said Mr. Liebman.
Individuals who file for bankruptcy have the option of doing so under one of three sections of the code -- Chapter 7, 11 or 13. Under Chapter 7, the most common, every asset is supposed to be liquidated as soon as possible to pay creditors.
But bitterness soon arises because some debts, such as the monthly arrears, may never be paid or only paid at a few cents on the dollar. Moreover, the condominium or co-op loses the right to sue the debtor for the remainder.
Chapter 11 and Chapter 13 assume the debtor will be able to pay at least some bills if allowed more time. Thus payments schedules are set up. This means that some money should start to trickle in. If it doesn't, questions should be raised with the court.
Lawyers warn, however, that in no instance can any financial obligation incurred after the bankruptcy filing, such as current and future monthly charges, be included in the restructuring. These debts remain due and payable in full, noted Michael D. Brofman, a lawyer in East Meadow, L.I., who also specializes in bankruptcies.
Thus, if a co-op or condominium doesn't begin receiving current charges on a regular basis the association or corporation should swiftly petition the court to compel payment. This must be done because as soon as the debtor falls behind in current obligations the court can dismiss the bankruptcy. If it does, the debtor immediately loses protection and relief from all prior debts -- a frightening prospect. "It works every time," said Michael L. Konig, a lawyer in Woodbridge, N.J, who has handled these workouts.
A CO-OP is in a stronger position than a condominium. If current payments are not made, the court may hold that the shareholders have lost their occupancy rights even during the bankruptcy workout. This allows the co-op to proceed with an eviction because the shareholders have only a tenant's rights, not the real property rights of a condo owner. "It's a form of relief very few co-ops realize they have," Mr. Konig.
Nevertheless, the primary concern should still center on the collection of the arrears and the debtor's ability to pay current and future charges.
Thus these lawyers recommend that as soon as any resident files for bankruptcy under any chapter of the code the association or the corporation petition the court to "lift the stay." This means allowing the disposition of the unit to be separated from all other debts being sorted out in the bankruptcy.
THIS would permit any pending foreclosure action frozen by the filing to proceed. In a co-op the same concession would apply to an eviction. The privilege is most often granted when outstanding debts against the unit -- such as mortgage and liens -- are so large that there would be nothing left to parcel out to other creditors.
Mr. Liebman said that the bank holding the mortgage on the unit can normally be counted on to join the association in seeking to liff the stay, since it also has much to gain from the speedy removal of the occupant and a quick foreclosure sale of the unit.
Far more aggravating delays and arrears tend to pile up when the debtor has substantial equity in the unit. In those instances, said Mr. Brofman, the court rarely lifts the stay because the trustee can normally get a better price at a private sale than can be realized at a foreclosure auction. And as he has a fiduciary duty to help satisfy the outstanding claims of all other creditors, he must squeeze the last penny out of a sale.
If this happens, the lawyers say, the condo or co-op should keep the pressure on the court's trustee to sell the unit quickly, anyhow. But as a practical matter this is rarely done, they say, because arrangements get bogged down with many other issues.
Thus at times it may even be necessary to sue the trustee, said Mr. Liebman. "You must keep making a lot of noise," he said.
But what about those arrears? In a condo the arrears cannot be passed along to the new buyer. Nor can the bankrupt debtor still be held personally responsible (except in a Chapter 13 filing).
By contrast, a co-op can usually recoup its losses because it can refuse to issue new shares until the arrears are paid by someone -- a technique that normally compels any incoming buyer (or the bank taking title after a foreclosure) to pay for the sale to be completed. This option is not available to a condominium because stricter rules govern the disposition of real property.
Finally, there are two regional experiences worth noting. Consider first the approach of Marilyn Mieszkuc, a lawyer in Houston who handled a number of bankruptcies on behalf condominiums caught in the Texas recession of the mid-80's. It became popular in that state, she said, for a condominium association to file aggressively to lift the stay and proceed with its own foreclosure because the banks holding the mortgages on the unit were refusing to intervene or join in the process.
The banks, she said, didn't want to risk being left owning these units in a bad market as they would be responsible for common charges until a buyer could be found.
So the condominiums themselves initiated the foreclosures, buying back the units at nominal sums since no other buyers were coming forward. They would then rent them out pending a revival of the market. The rent was used to cover current charges and pay off arrears. "We did very well," recalled Ms. Mieszkuc.
BOARDS should be aware of two recent court decisions that affect their rights. In Cohen v. North Park Parkside Condominium Association, the Federal Bankruptcy Court in San Dieg ruled in January, 1991, that Steven and Sheri Cohen, who had filed under Chapter 7, could not be held responsible for common charges while they remained in residence because such charges constituted a financial obligation entered into prior to the bankruptcy.
The ruling followed a similar decision by the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago in 1990 -- a case that pitted William and Joyce Rosteck against the Old Willow Falls Condominum Association.
"The rulings mean that, in future, boards must be even more vigilant about collecting arrears before a bankruptcy is filed," said James P. Lingl, a lawyer in Camarillo, Calif.
He had argued against such a ruling in the Cohen case on behalf of the Community Associations Institute, the national network of leaders in the community ownership field based in Alexandria, Va.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1266 words

HEADLINE: Home Businesses Run Afoul of Zoning

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
THE rising use of computers and facsimile machines is giving a new impetus to challenges to restrictive zoning rules that seek homeowners from conducting business from their residences.
In the metropolitan area, some communities are responding by re-evaluating their zoning regulations. But in others they are holding firm, taking the position that an in-home business may generate too much traffic or otherwise disturb the residential character that the zoning bylaws were designed to protect. 
 "We now have archaic businesses that were applicable in the 1920's, such as milliners, still on the books," said Louis Goodman, who supervises the building inspectors and administers the building code in New Rochelle, N.Y.
"Obviously, it needs to be updated to better reflect the times."
His city is the setting for a legal dispute that highlights the evolving nature of home employment and its impact on zoning issues. In drawing the ever-finer line, New Rochelle has not been willing to include "management consultants" as a legitimate occupation in a residential district.
Last February, the city refused to allow Evelyne Simon to run her management consulting business from her home, saying that it was not one of the customary professions allowed in the home-occupation ordinance. Under 1921 zoning, which was revised in 1955, the only businesses allowed include the offices of architects, artists and teachers, among others, or a "similar professional person."
Ms. Simon's lawyer, Alan H. Rothschild, contended before the city's zoning board of appeals that a management consultant should qualify as a "similar professional person" under the law, and that many other professions also not listed in the code were being practiced all over the city.
In most cases, such businesses can operate in quiet rebellion against the zoning laws because nobody knows the businesses are there. In Mrs. Simon's case, 16 neighbors petitioned against the business use. They objected to what they said was increased traffic and excessive parking.
"ONCE we find out about a business, my job is to adhere to the literal words of the ordinance," said Mr. Goodman. "I can't see a connection between a management consultant and the other businesses that are listed."
Late last month, the Zoning Board of Appeals upheld Mr. Goodman's position. Mr. Rothschild said he would appeal the decision to the New York State Supreme Court in White Plains.
Even with the court victory, Mr. Goodman concedes that the city's home-occupation code needs some updating, and a comprehensive rezoning package, which includes a revised home-occupation ordinance, is now before the City Council.
The nearby Village of Scarsdale is also considering revising its home-occupation ordinance, which was adopted in 1976. The impetus for the change came from a case brought before the village last May. A psychiatrist, who had been operating a home practice for 20 years, was informed he was in violation of the zoning law when a new neighbor complained about parking on the street by his patients.
The zoning board ruled that a home business could operate only on a part-time basis. The zoning rules also stipulate that a business may take up no more than 250 square feet in a house and that there must be designated parking for visiting clients.
THE city ordered the doctor to stop using his waiting room, since that enlarged the work space beyond allowable limits. He was also required to take up a sidewalk that ran from his office to the street and replace it with one that went from his office to a designated parking area at the side of the house.
The village did not insist on the requirement that home businesses be part-time, pending a review of the ordinance.
"It's a tradition that a home office be only a part-time business, but we're well aware that a whole lot of people are operating full time in the village," said Peter Van de Water, village planner. "Technology has gotten to the point with computers, faxes and modems that a shift to the home occupation is inevitable. It's time to draft some new rules."
Downturns in the economy are said to contribute to the growth in home-based businesses, estimated by the American Home Business Association to number 14 million across the country.
SEVERAL communities in the metropolitan region have already revised their home-occupation ordinances, including Bridgewater Township, N.J., in 1987 and Woodstock, N.Y., in 1989. And many others are considering doing so.
When Woodstock changed its ordinance, it was primarily in response to an outcry from its art community. "A lot of artists were complaining that they couldn't afford to remain in the community if they weren't allowed to have a work space," said John Ludwig, chairman of the planning board. Woodstock now allows artists to conduct their work in an accessory building, previously prohibited under the old code.
Dennis M. Doyle, senior planner for Ulster County's Department of Planning, hopes that Woodstock will serve as an example for changing ordinances throughout the county. Of particular concern to Mr. Doyle is removal of the "professional bias now found in many laws," he said.
"Blue-collar businesses could have just as small an impact on their neighbors and be equally as important to the economic viability of the homeowner," he said.
One particularly contentious area of home-business law is in the area of child care. In many places, if a mother takes in a few extra children to watch during the day, she is in violation of the law. Local officials are often reluctant to crack down in such cases, since child care serves such a vital need in the community.
The chief reason for limiting the types of businesses allowed in the home is to insure the preservation of a neighborhood's residential character and thereby maintain property values. As extra insurance, most ordinances also have strict rules about the location and size of outside signs, the number of employees, outside storage, and the amount of acceptable traffic and noise.
Many planning consultants believe that it is unnecessary and unfair to limit home occupations to certain professions. "Instead of listing so-called customary uses, like doctors and lawyers, why not just establish standards for noise and traffic and other nuisances," said Daniel Shuster, president of Shuster Associate Planning and Zoning Consultants, in Stone Ridge in Ulster County. "If a home business isn't bothering anybody, who cares if it's customary?"
Taking a different approach to the problem is New York City, the municipality with the largest number of home businesses in the country, according to the American Home Business Association. Technically the only types of businesses allowed include such professions as doctors, lawyers and other "professional offices."
Specifically, prohibited are offices in the home for public relations and advertising agencies, interior decorators and stockbrokers, although city officials acknowledge that many such businesses probably operate all over the city. At the moment, there are no plans to adjust the zoning to reflect that reality.
"Sometimes if you start getting into definitions, you create more problems," said Michael Parley, president of Development Consulting Services Inc., who specializes in consultation on New York City zoning regulations. "The best approach is often a case-by-case basis, and if nobody brings a case, there's no problem. These laws are designed to resolve problems. It's often not in the best interest of the city to make everybody adhere to them."

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 24; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1215 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Paintings of America And Photos of Mexico

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

 BODY:
WITH paintings, as with individuals, the face can be familiar but not the name. This is very much the situation now in the Benton Museum, at the University of Connecticut in Storrs.
The current show, which was organized by Hildy Cummings, the museum's curator of education, and Helen Fusscas, a former art dealer, includes 48 painters. None of them are superstars, although some enjoyed fame in their own time and have made a comeback, while others have remained in limbo. But still, the revisionist spirit behind the show is not the kind that revives reputations better left for dead. The curators have chosen artists who, in Mrs. Cummings's words, "did not change the course of American art but whose talent and vision greatly enriched it." 
 In confining themselves to painters of quality (dread word), the curators have come up with work that often seems more recognizable than it is. Thus, for a split second, it is possible to see an Asher B. Durand in Nelson Augustus Moore's "The Path Home" (1892); from across the room, Gilbert Munger's "Scene in the Wasatch Mountains" could be a Bierstadt study. Whether it's a matter of influence or Zeitgeist, the effect can be quite disconcerting.
To make matters more complicated, the curators have included works by artists who really are familiar. Ammi Phillips's portrait of a boy is an example: those brown eyes could be no one else's. (Did the artist ever paint a subject with blue eyes?)
The show's labels are excellent, their details always germane and sometimes gossipy. That for the Phillips notes that the boy, Frederick Gale, wears a "skeleton suit," a "new fashion for boys in 1815," and that the portrait probably celebrated the "breeching" rite, whereby 7-year-old boys were promoted from baby clothes. It also points out that the colossal hat carried by the child denotes his high social status.
Other noteworthy figures include John Haberle, of New Haven, with a circa 1890 trompe l'oeil, and John Ferguson Weir, brother to J. Alden and founder of the Yale Art School, with a small scene of a blacksmith preparing to shoe an ox. Samuel F. B. Morse is represented by a lovely little head of a fashionable Federal lady that is set in a spectacular rococo frame. Two still lifes -- of peonies and strawberries, respectively -- epitomize Charles Ethan Porter, a black painter working in Hartford who was returned to circulation several years ago. The prodigious portraitist Daniel Huntington is no stranger either, although he is represented here by a small sickbed scene, while David Johnson, celebrated for his landscape drawings, is here with a painting of Greenwich rocks beside a glassy sea.
Nevertheless, many of the figures are new -- to me at least. They include Samuel Broadbent, Robert Brandegee, Thomas Henry Hope, Frederick Stiles Jewett and Mary Bidwell. Broadbent arrived in Rocky Hill from England, in 1861, at the age of 38, to practice both medicine and portraiture. His medical performance remains obscure, but his "Mrs. Riley Whitney" is a beauty who looks sideways at the viewer, her piercing eyes the exact same brown as the bangs escaping from her white gophered bonnet. Normally, the canvas hangs at the Winchester Historical Society, along with a companion portrait of Mr. Whitney, together with likenesses of the same couple painted years later by Erastus Salisbury Field. Broadbent's great talent was to produce a credible -- if too well drawn -- imitation of Colonial painting.
Hope, another Englishman, settled at Bridgeport in 1861, at the age of 29, and in short order took a wife, started a family and signed on with the Union Army as a musician. He returned to study art in Philadelphia, where he met the trompe l'oeil specialist Frederick Peto. His own trompe l'oeil is as black and white as it is in the illustration. Brandegee left Berlin, Conn., to study in France with a pupil of Ingres and, upon returning, settled in at Miss Porter's School, in Farmington, as an art teacher, painting several portraits of the founder. The version in the show is a sensitive impressionistic study of a middle-aged woman in a dress with leg-of-mutton sleeves. Brandegee, the label says, "rarely exhibited, enjoyed marriage," did some writing and "relished his local reputation as an eccentric."
The marine by Jewett is a beautiful little scene of square riggers at sixes and sevens on choppy seas. Born in Simsbury, Jewett painted only for the last 7 of his 46 years. He was a specialist in marines, with a studio in Hartford, and he had Bidwell for a student. This artist's aerial view of East Haddam, where nothing stirs on the water but a tall yacht seemingly in tow to a microscopic tug, is no less perfect for being touched with naivete. This show is the first of three at the museum, and all are integral to its grand plan for publishing a biographical dictionary. The formidable project, scheduled for 1994, will be masterminded by Mrs. Cummings. And a good thing, too, for she clearly has a gift for educating an audience without enervating it.
A note about the Reginald Marsh show that occupies the upstairs gallery and that unfortunately closes today. A display organized jointly by the Benton and the Fort Wayne Museum of Art, it includes not only prints, watercolors and paintings but also photographs taken by the artist. This could be all you will ever need of Coney Island or, for that matter, Reginald Marsh.
On the same campus not far from the Benton is the School of Fine Arts, which contains the Atrium Gallery. The current attraction is Graciela Iturbide, a Mexican photographer. All the prints are black and whites, and all focus on Juchitan, a fishing village on the Pacific Coast, in Oaxaca, where, it seems, the women are strong, Zapotec and uninhibited. They also organize the local economy, doling out money for cigarettes and drinks to their peasant husbands, one of whom may have had more than his share. In the shot of a woman standing on a street corner beside a primitive cross, he lies supine on the sidewalk behind her.
Whether it is the female administration or the photographer's view of it, Juchitan is strange in ways that are hard to define. One of the women poses in a hat made entirely of iguanas; another sits beside a man holding a small alligator in her lap. Either the reptiles are extraordinarily tame, or the town has a very gifted taxidermist on hand. A mother lounges in a hammock, suckling a child and leering at the viewer as if in derision. And, of course, there are the inevitable images of death, like that of the bleeding roosters illustrated.
Though these spectacles seem calculated to make jaded gringos feel close to reality, the turning point doesn't come until a man named Magnolia appears in drag under a ridiculous sombrero, and an old woman poses dead center in front of a Yves Klein-style scribble on a wall. What seemed reasonably spontaneous before, or at least open to negotiation, now looks downright knowing. I left the show imprinted by Ms. Iturbide's visions -- they are stark and good -- but unable to trust them.
The show of American painters continues through May 17 at the Benton Museum and the photographs of Graciela Iturbide through May 8 at the Atrium Gallery, both at UConn in Storrs.
